HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
In Every Color, Finding the Blues

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:
Looking for a sure cure for the blues?
Just head for the New Victory Theater in the new Times Square and latch on to a ticket for "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues." 
 Now, that title bears some parsing, because this rich, evocative, rousing show, with some 50 musical numbers ranging from African chants and spirituals to Delta and Chicago blues, with plenty of stops along the dusty roads, river banks, broken country hearts and juke joints in between, is more than a musical feast.
Besides its cornucopia of splendidly interpreted song, "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues," through April 11, is a potent blend of visual eloquence and historical sweep that engages the eye and touches the heart while its songs soothe the ear, occasionally work mischief on the funny bone and always raise the spirits.
As the splendid cast assembled by the much-praised Crossroads Theater Company of New Brunswick, N.J., applies its individual and collective vocal, musical and actorly talents to songs like "I've Been Living With the Blues," "Blues Man," "My Man Rocks Me" and "St. Louis Blues," photographs projected onto screens behind the performers brim with history.
Here are sketches of slave auctions and pictures of thirsty women working the fields with their little children nearby, a black man dangling from a lyncher's noose, rural poverty, a riverside baptism, country churches, the great blues man Robert Johnson, and changing fashions in clothes and entertainment, as well as the economic, social and cultural upheaval surrounding the great black migration from the South to Chicago.
Presented in association with the San Diego Repertory Theater and the Alabama Shakespeare Festival, "It Ain't Nothin' but the Blues" is based on an idea by Ron Taylor, who wrote it with Randal Myler, its director, and Lita Gaithers, Charles Bevel and Dan Wheetman.
Mr. Taylor, Mr. Bevel and Mr. Wheetman, with Gretha Boston, Carter Calvert, Eloise Laws and Gregory Porter constitute the powerhouse lineup of singers who step up, step out and put over one number after another. Depending on the song, they can be heartbreakers, heartbroken, sexpots or absolute rapscallions. And after intermission, when they trade their simple attire, rustic airs and simple instruments for shapely gowns and stylish suits, each seems good-naturedly determined to outdo another, as they make their way with the backing of an enhanced band through pieces like "I'm Your Hoochie-Coochie Man," the sly, slinky, humorous "Crawlin' King Snake," "Walkin' After Midnight," the bitter "Strange Fruit" and "Let the Good Times Roll."
By this time the band is making the floor vibrate, and the cast and audience are raising the roof.
 
IT AIN'T NOTHIN' BUT THE BLUES
By Charles Bevel, Lita Gaithers, Randal Myler, Ron Taylor and Dan Wheetman, based on an original idea by Mr. Taylor; directed by Mr. Myler; musical direction by Mr. Wheetman; musical staging by Donald McKayle; vocal direction by Ms. Gaithers; sets by Robin Sanford Roberts; lighting by Don Darnutzer; costumes by Dione H. Lebhar; sound by Edward Cosla; production stage manager, Linda Harris; producing coordinator, Jeff Rowlings; dramaturgue, Lenora Inez Brown; associate producer, Mr. Taylor; co-founder, artistic director and chief executive, Ricardo Kahn; managing director, Keryl E. McCord. The New 42d Street Inc. presents the Crossroads Theater Company in association with San Diego Repertory Theater and Alabama Shakespeare Festival. SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 2; House & Home/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1911 words

HEADLINE: Relying on the Competence Of Strangers

BYLINE: By JENNY LYN BADER 

 BODY:
A MANHATTAN jury was startled when a woman carrying a garment bag interrupted a murder trial. She turned out to be the justice's personal shopper. "She took out three or four outfits, and the judge chose from among them," said Kevin Scott, one of the jurors. Then the trial resumed.
A Sun Microsystems engineer in Silicon Valley, his wife and their 3-year-old son had not slept for two nights after the boy misplaced his favorite teddy bear. Les Concierges, a San Francisco-based company that runs bothersome errands internationally, found a replica 2,000 miles away. 
 And Linda Rothschild, the president of Cross It Off Your List, a personal services company in Manhattan, bubble-wrapped homemade matzohs and sent them to Hawaii by Federal Express in time for a Passover dinner.
From the specialists who locate objects of desire to those who locate other specialists, there are now alluring experts for every household quest. With people spending more hours at work than a decade ago, the do-it-yourself movement, as an approach to home decoration and an outlook on life, has declined, giving way to a wide-ranging "let others do it" trend. Its credo is simple: to save time, just delegate tasks to pick up the dry cleaning, pamper the pets, coddle the offspring. Emerson, advocate of individualism, would be alarmed to learn that these others include professional organizers, new mentors called "life coaches" and household managers -- updated butlers who will supervise any other others you may hire.
Some see the boom in personal services as a sign of rising polarization and specialization: the rich get richer, and the poor get to run their errands. But some of the runners aren't poor, and many of their clients aren't rich. What they are is overworked, insecure and increasingly dependent on the competence of strangers.
"We want to give that custodian, that administrative assistant, that salesperson, the feeling that he can get the same thing that the C.E.O. gets," said Phil Wexler, an executive vice president of Les Concierges, which has 600,000 corporate and private customers. One client had Les Concierges orchestrate his marriage proposal. And last Thanksgiving, 27 million Americans ordered in.
Whatever happened to self-reliance? During the last two decades, employment in private-sector day-care centers increased by more than 250 percent, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And that's not counting the many au pairs and sitters operating without licenses.
Pets now have sitters, too -- not only cats and dogs but also ferrets, snakes and birds. "Ferrets are getting popular," said Marianne McDermott, the executive director of the National Association of Professional Pet Sitters, which is based in Washington and whose members visit an estimated 169,000 households a year. For $45, the Puddles pet service, in Manhattan, offers pet sleep overs, in which an employee has a slumber party with your pet when you leave town. And it has a 24-hour beeper service for last-minute business travelers who suddenly need to page a pet sidekick.
Things were not always this way.
In the summer of 1976, with the do-it-yourself movement flourishing, John Spadola, a private-school math teacher, decided to transplant his family from the Upper West Side to a mountain in rural Maine. He planned to build a house by himself from scratch, no contractors or decorators allowed. His 6-year-old daughter, Meema, learned to build a fire and immersed herself in the "Little House on the Prairie" books.
Like most postmodern pioneers, they found that doing it yourself is harder than it looks. Mr. Spadola's family ended up living in a tent from June until October. Today, his house is still not finished.
By the 1990's, customers had become so overwhelmed that the Home Depot, the dream mall for the truly motivated, and Ikea, the home-assembly furniture empire, added decorating departments with design consultants. So did ABC Carpet and Home, Pottery Barn, Ethan Allen and Hechinger's.
A continuing nationwide study begun in 1995 by the Joint Center for Housing Studies at Harvard University shows that many projects historically done on a do-it-yourself basis are now being hired out to professional contractors. "During the 70's and 80's, there was an awful lot of do-it-youself home remodeling," said Kermit Baker, the director of the study and a senior research fellow at the center. "And there is less of that done now than there was 10 years ago, and we project there will be less of it in 10 years from now."
The number of hours a woman spent on housework in America dropped from 27 hours a week in 1965 to 15.6 hours in 1995, said John Robinson, the director of the Americans' Use of Time Project, a national survey conducted through the University of Maryland.
The drop in drudgery chores reflects many social shifts -- more women in the workforce, more men agreeing to vacuum -- but it also portends the privatization of housework, which now extends beyond drilling and dusting to the mere act of being at home.
Les Concierges will wait around for the cable guy or the plumber, take your dog to the vet, pick up a guest from the airport. Les Concierges procured a live Siberian tiger for one client and a World War II military tank for a private event. "It had to be fully operational," said Valerie Raszka, the company's director of marketing relationships.
Once available only to corporate clients, Les Concierges now offers a full range of services to private members for a monthly fee of $500.
Ms. Rothschild, of Cross It Off Your List, once obtained a British telephone booth for a party. More typically she helps customers move households or overhaul closets. "Paper is a big problem for a lot of people," said Ms. Rothschild, whose rates start at $65 an hour.
But many personal services, often part time or once in a lifetime, are no longer just for the rich. Starting at rates of $15 an hour, errand-service providers will do your holiday gift-shopping. For $12 to 15, a pet sitter will visit a lonely tarantula. For $8 to $16 a person per meal, a personal chef will get fresh groceries, visit your home and make your favorite food for your family. David MacKay, a co-founder and the executive director of the United States Personal Chef Association, which started in 1991 with five members and now has nearly 2,500 members nationwide, estimates that 60,000 clients use personal chefs. He said that he and his wife, Susan Titcomb, the other co-founder, wanted to take having a personal chef "out of the realm of the wealthy," as housekeeping services had done regarding private maids. The average combined family income of surveyed customers is $80,000. Mr. MacKay believes the service is so popular because it caters to individual whims. "When you go out to your favorite restaurant, you can't say to the chef, 'I really like your beef stroganoff, but can you make it a little extra spicy and leave out the onions?' " he said. Chefs are trained to create anything from creme brulee to chitlins.
The idea behind subcontracting the personal is to simplify one's life. But it doesn't always work that way. "Finding the right people to delegate these things to is not easy," said Pepper Schwartz, a sociology professor at the University of Washington in Seattle. "You may be spending more to delegate things than you should. You may also lose the pride in creation of the actual experience. You may also lose some experience of your own creativity."
All this delegating does create jobs. Eileen Appelbaum, the research director of the Economic Policy Institute, a Washington research group, said that countries that have experienced the most rapid employment growth, like the United States, Britain and Sweden, are those in which household services and personal services have increased. "The real problem confronting the industrialized economies is how to provide these personal services without impoverishing the workers who provide them or having a tax burden that burdens the middle class excessively," she said. "We haven't solved that problem."
But are these the jobs we really want to be creating? Prof. Juliet Schor, a Harvard economist, said the rise of personal services reflects "an increasing polarization of good jobs and bad jobs." Professor Schor, an author, whose books include "The Overspent American" (1998), published by Basic Books, said: "It's a sort of new servant economy in a slightly different form, because people are not specialized in one employer. You don't have all-purpose servants -- you hire five different servants, and the servant has five different masters."
With so many others just a cell-phone call away, it is hard to remember to look for the answers within. Meema Spadola, who is now 29 and a filmmaker living in Manhattan, believes the hands-on ethic of her childhood taught her crucial lessons. She admits that she wouldn't try to build a house herself now. "But I made a film," she said. And she still feels nostalgic in hardware stores.
Carolyn Goldstein, the author of "Do It Yourself: Home Improvement in 20th-Century America" (Princeton Architectural Press, 1998), said that there is a "small niche of people who really take this stuff seriously and have a lot of skill comparable to a professional level of skill." She admires friends who do their own sanding. But she doesn't have time to do it herself, at home in Boston. "I don't really have that many hobbies," she said. "Nor am I going to go around slapping up aluminum everywhere."
Other than Martha Stewart, few are willing to slap up aluminum everywhere. "We don't make our own candles anymore," Professor Schwartz said. "Should we spin our own linen? Imagine women's lives in the 18th century. We don't want to get so nostalgic that we forget how little of our time was left when we really had to be self-sufficient."
Delegating one's personal life to others has obvious drawbacks: the loss of family time, of self-expression, of basic abilities. And with design consultants and personal shoppers in every other store, there is no need to develop personal taste. Mr. Scott, the Manhattan juror, not only was surprised that the State Supreme Court justice allowed her personal shopper in the courtroom, but also marveled at the justice's other decision. "If you ask me, I think she chose the wrong outfit," he said.
(This reporter has never consulted a personal shopper but did once hire an organization consultant. The "organizer" completed two hours of filing and went home, forgetting her sweater. The irony was too delicious to ignore: I was relying on the organizational techniques of an individual who had the same drive toward entropy that I had.)
And a message left one morning with the National Association of Professional Organizers, a group based in Austin, Tex., with an answering service stating that calls are retrieved daily, went unreturned until the next day.
Then there is the potential for pure disaster, from the infamous au pair convicted of shaking a Boston baby to death, to the more obscure Upper West Side dog walker fired for losing the dog. It was the walker's first day on the job. Which begs the question of all who would subcontract important tasks: How do you distinguish between the truly qualified and the cooing impostor? Worse, how do you tell if your life coach knows a thing about life?
At least with chitlins, you can tell whether they're chitlins.

SECTION: Section C; Page 20; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 256 words

HEADLINE: Pepsi Spinoff in Lackluster Stock Offering

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
An initial public offering yesterday by Pepsi Bottling Group Inc. provided a stark contrast to the pyrotechnics of recent Internet offerings.
In a spinoff from its parent company, Pepsico Inc., Pepsi Bottling sold 100 million shares at $23 each, for a total of $2.3 billion, which will be used to pay off debt. 
 The initial offering price was settled at the low end of the estimated range of $23 to $26, an indication that prepricing demand was less than the company had anticipated.
The stock closed at $21.6875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts were quick to distinguish Pepsi Bottling Group's offering from the string of highly successful recent Internet deals, whose phenomenal openings have conditioned investors into expecting huge first-day gains.
"This is an old-fashioned business that has prospered internationally," said Robert Mescal, an analyst with the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield Beach, Fla. "It has assets and a well-grounded financial background. There's nothing to get too excited about; it's just another soda company. But on the other hand, a very valuable asset to your portfolio."
Mr. Mescal said investors were expected to view Pepsi Bottling as a long-term investment.
With 155 million shares outstanding after the sale, the offering created a market capitalization for Pepsi Bottling of about $3.5 billion.
Pepsi Bottling's offering was the largest so far this year, and one of the five largest initial offerings ever, according to Securities Data/Thomson Financial.

SECTION: Section A; Page 27; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 734 words

HEADLINE: Essay;
Who's Losing NATO?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NATO's military objective was clear: to "degrade" Serbia's ability to drive the ethnic Albanians out of its province of Kosovo.
Some degradation. After a week of Milosevic's ethnic cleanskrieg, a third of the unwanted population has been driven out, many civilians murdered, the Kosovo Liberation Army decimated. Slow-moving NATO's bluff was called and fast-moving Serbia is winning the war. 
 Why? One reason is that Clinton's poll-following and wholly unnecessary promise of no use of ground troops emboldened the Serbian dictator. Another is that our cautiously phased air campaign concentrated on Serbian air defenses, thereby protecting our pilots, rather than combining that with an attack on Serbian field forces as they swiftly carried out their savage sweep.
In the face of seven days of defeat, NATO will now punish Serbia by bombing government buildings in Belgrade. That may salve our pride, but an equivalent discomfort -- an evacuation of the Pentagon -- would not stop America's ability to wage war. Pinpoint bombing of Belgrade headquarters will only solidify Serbian patriotic support for Milosevic.
We will also take more risks flying lower over Kosovo. That may take out 400 tanks and heavy artillery pieces now shelling towns, but will not stop the panicked exodus driven by men with rifles.
That leaves the West on a classic Vietnam spot: Serbia, the subpower, is fighting to win, while NATO, the superpower, is painfully escalating as it yearns to settle. To end brutal internal aggression against innocents, we have to break that pattern.
On the military front, beyond tactical air attacks on the cleanskrieg, NATO bombers should darken Belgrade. The removal of electricity would disrupt military communications and remind triumphant Serb leaders of the greater human hardship being inflicted by their orders on Kosovars. Then we should target industrial plants around Belgrade and Nis, and sink all Serbian naval vessels.
Ground troops? The prospect of body bags is anathema to Bill Clinton despite his bluster about genocide. Without his willingness to ask Congress to put our troops where his mouth is, Europeans and even Turks will not take on the nation that bloodily battled Hitler and stood off Stalin.
What can be done is to mass a NATO ground force near Albania and Macedonia borders, protecting and training a K.L.A. guerrilla force. The very presence of five armored divisions nearby, prepared for action under air supremacy, would radically change the local power equation.
Economic pain can be inflicted by the seizure of Serbian assets around the world to subsidize the upkeep of refugees. Psychological war can be waged by shortwave, leaflet and even the Internet, to Serbs now getting only Milosevic propaganda. Just as fissures will develop within the NATO alliance, political splits in the initial Serbian solidarity should be exploited.
On the diplomatic front, forget the Russians. To them, keeping Kosovo under Serbian rule means keeping Chechnya under Russian rule. Primakov's Foreign Minister, Igor Ivanov, said this week that NATO officials, not Serbian killers, should be tried as war criminals for their "undisguised genocide." The long-term Russian interest is to diminish NATO; Primakov cannot be its intermediary.
Our former political goal of an autonomous Kosovo under Serbian sovereignty has been overtaken by atrocity. Take the mushy offer we made at Rambouillet off the table. The allies should now stand for a separated Kosovo and be willing to consider a partition plan that lets Serbia keep revered historic sites but joins most of the area long populated by Albanians to Albania.
After his victorious first week, Milosevic will not hear of it. He sees what has not happened to Saddam Hussein's Iraq and logically assumes nothing serious will happen to his Serbia. We have not yet reached the end of the beginning.
But after sustained strategic and tactical bombing; after an economic blockade and asset seizure that squeezes his political supporters; after the buildup of troops on his borders that protects the seekers of vengeance, and might just roll tanks forward to establish fortified havens for innocents -- after all that, as crowds now cheering in Belgrade start to grumble about shortages and isolation, the conqueror of unarmed Kosovo might be more inclined to trade a little land for peace with Europe.

SECTION: Section C; Page 6; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 843 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. and Europe at Impasse On New World Trade Chief

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 31

 BODY:
A month before the head of the World Trade Organization is to leave his post, the search for a successor reached a stalemate today over the inability of the 134 members to decide between the two finalists.
After a yearlong search, the European Union and the United States appeared to be deadlocked over the choice between Suphachai Panichpakdi, the Thai Commerce Minister, and Michael Moore, a former Prime Minister of New Zealand. 
 Ali Mchumo, the Tanzanian representative, who leads the search committee, said the difficulties faced by the two candidates "are so serious that neither of them can enjoy consensus from the membership to enable them to be elected as the next Director General." He made the statement to a gathering of trade negotiators tonight, the deadline the organization had imposed for itself to choose a new director.
The leader of the trade organization runs its day-to-day affairs and helps settle contentious disputes among members. It is unclear what the group will do if it has not selected a Director General by April 30, when the term of Renato Ruggiero of Italy, the current chief, expires.
The deadlock comes as the United States and the European Union are fighting over a number of contentious trade disputes -- notably banana imports and resulting American sanctions, hormone-treated beef and aircraft noise.
Mr. Mchumo, describing the trade group's failure to meet its deadline as "unfortunate and disappointing," also alluded to complaints that certain nations, including the United States, were impeding the selection process. "It is clearly very unhealthy for this process to drag on because such delay breeds rumors, suspicions and even puts personal friendships at stake," he told negotiators.
The European Union's caretaker Trade Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, expressed his grievances in a letter to Mr. Mchumo, which was later faxed to journalists, accusing "unnamed countries" of threatening to veto a candidate.
"Anonymous vetoes are plainly inconsistent with the kind of transparency within the W.T.O. that we have been seeking," Sir Leon wrote.
Under its rules, the trade organization chooses a Director General by consensus, which has generally been accepted to mean there is no vote and no veto allowed. The idea is that every nation, regardless of size, gets an equal say and the trading giants cannot tip the balance.
However, the only time the process has been used before -- in selecting Mr. Ruggiero four years ago -- it took nine months and was plagued with delays, accusations and recriminations. The United States was accused of delaying the selection of Mr. Ruggiero, a former Italian trade minister, because of concerns that his background and approach were too bureaucratic.
European officials have asserted that once again, the Americans are holding up the selection and have been working behind the scenes to insure that Mr. Moore wins. The United States has never publicly stated a preference.
More than half the European Union's 15 countries back Mr. Suphachai. However, several countries, including France, appear to have shifted allegiances back and forth between the two candidates.
Rita Hayes, the United States delegate to the trade organization, called Sir Leon's letter "very difficult," but refused to comment further on its contents.
Although Mr. Moore insisted in a radio interview earlier this week that the contest for the post did not reflect a split between industrial and developing nations, interviews with trade diplomats say that is an element. The United States and other industrial nations support labor standards that require developing countries to insure minimum levels for wages and working conditions. Developing countries generally oppose such standards, arguing that they would raise the cost of their exports and make them less competitive.
Some trade envoys say the United States does not think its best interests would be served by Mr. Suphachai, 52, who is an economist.
"He's an academic, he's intellectual," said a European trade official, who insisted on anonymity, adding that the Americans "don't see having a cozy relationship with him."
Mr. Moore, this official said, "talks the language labor likes to hear."
"The Americans say he can also talk to Congress, which is suspicious of the W.T.O," the official noted.
Pakistan's envoy, Munir Akram, said Mr. Moore, 50, a former union activist, "is more likely to push for labor standards."
Pakistan has led an effort by developing countries to insure that one of their leaders becomes the next Director General.
Both Mr. Moore and Mr. Suphachai visited the trade organization's headquarters here for last-minute lobbying. Thai officials have won support not only from Asian and many European nations, but from Latin American and Caribbean countries as well.
Delegates are to meet again next week to try to choose between the two men. Countries backing Mr. Suphachai, envoys said, have threatened to block Mr. Moore if Mr. Suphachai's candidacy is derailed.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall, Bringing Worst Quarter in 3 Years to a Close

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bonds fell yesterday, finishing their worst quarter in three years, as a report on manufacturing activity in the Midwest raised concern that brisk economic growth will quicken inflation later this year.
The 30-year Treasury bond fell 17/32 , to 94 21/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.62 percent, the highest since March 4. The benchmark bond lost 7.59 percent in the quarter, its worst decline since the first quarter of 1996, when it fell 8.38 percent, according to Ryan Labs Inc. in New York.
"Inflation is an issue for the first time this year," said John Breazeale, who oversees $250 million at Weiss Money Management Inc. in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The trigger was the release of a report yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago, which showed an unexpected improvement in manufacturing and a jump in the group's inflation gauge.
So far, inflation, which erodes a bond's value, has been under control, increasing at just a 1.6 percent rate over the last year. The Federal Reserve signaled it was not concerned about inflation by holding interest rates steady at a meeting this week.
Even so, the Chicago purchasing managers' report jolted investors. The manufacturing index rose to 57 from 52.9, while the index of prices paid, an inflation measure, surged to 52.5 from 41.6 -- the largest monthly increase since 1980 and an indication that more companies reported price increases during the month.
"The economic numbers are still strong," and that's a reason to steer away from Treasuries, said Bill Stevens, who oversees $1.8 billion of bonds at Montgomery Asset Management in San Francisco. He favors corporate bonds and mortgage-backed securities.
Some traders worry that yesterday's report presages a strong reading in the National Association of Purchasing Management's national manufacturing report today, which carries more weight because of its broader scope, analysts say.
Bond yields have risen about a half percentage point over the last two months as reports on jobs, consumption and housing showed the economy was not about to slow.

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: NEWS ANALYSIS;
It's the 21st Century Arriving Early

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: BUDAPEST, March 31

 BODY:
Kosovo could be a template for the century to come.
The crisis there, which has produced a stern test for NATO and a catastrophe for the ethnic Albanians who form the province's overwhelming majority, bears little resemblance to the cold war that shaped the last half of this century. It is not about ideology. It does not directly involve the vital political or economic interests of the great powers. It carries with it no threat of nuclear annihilation. 
 Yet it presents precisely the kind of problem that the Western democracies, for all their wealth and military might, find it most difficult to cope with. And it is likely to be repeated elsewhere.
Unlike World War II, or even Korea or Vietnam, crises like this take place in a twilight zone, full of uncertainty, where rules are formulated (and broken) as the participants choose. It is hard to measure who is winning, sometimes harder to know who has won.
One catalyst for the Kosovo "war," if that is the correct term, is the mounting belief in much of Europe and North America that human rights matter more than national sovereignty -- that no leaders, whether democratically chosen or self-appointed, have the right to slaughter their citizens. Another is modern television.
NATO's bombing in Kosovo, a clear sign that the West puts a higher priority on human rights than on sovereignty, began a week ago. On that same day, England's highest court ruled that Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean president, could be extradited to Spain, even though under Chilean law he is exempt from prosecution for the offenses alleged, which occurred in his own country.
Both events dramatized the weakening of sovereignty, a development that disturbs both China and Russia.
If slaughter and television come together, as they did in Kosovo, "right-minded" people in Europe and America demand that their own governments do something about it. (If television is absent, as it largely was from the genocide in Rwanda, the demand is much less insistent, however great the loss of innocent life may prove to be.)
The United Nations is often in no position to act. Such is the case this time, with Moscow and Beijing ready to cast vetoes.
So the burden falls upon the Western democracies, which usually means the United States, acting in concert with NATO, as in Kosovo, through an ad hoc alliance, as in the Persian Gulf war, or sometimes alone.
But the new ardor for human rights, even when fanned by violence and misery on the television screen, stops well short of heedless passion. Few American or French or Belgian families are willing to risk the lives of large numbers of their sons and daughters in ground combat; because of the Vietnam quagmire, which still registers powerfully on the American political consciousness, the reluctance to commit ground troops is especially marked in the United States, particularly when the underlying strategic goals are ill-defined.
The answer to this paradox, so far at least, is air power: bombs and cruise missiles, launched from as far away and as high an altitude as possible to minimize the chances of a pilot's being captured. For television can cut two ways: pictures of human calamity can arouse the Western world to act, but pictures of Western soldiers or airmen dying or suffering humiliation, as in Somalia, can quickly discourage action.
By itself, air power may not prove adequate. In the case of Kosovo, it has given the Serbs time to intensify their campaign against the ethnic Albanians. Like the air strikes against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, these may have caused a stiffening rather than a weakening of resolve. And even if the bombs eventually cripple the military forces of President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, it may be too late; most of the "ethnic cleansing" may already have been completed.
One possibility for additional action is sending arms to the Kosovo Liberation Army. Another is to try to foment a military coup against Mr. Milosevic. Still another is to begin laying a political predicate for sending in NATO ground troops. Clearly, some of the NATO allies would resist such a move, and President Clinton has said he has no intention of committing Americans in an offensive role.
Yet Mr. Clinton has compared Mr. Milosevic to Hitler, just as President George Bush compared Mr. Hussein to Hitler. Either Mr. Clinton's words were hyperbole, or his present means are inconsistent with the problem at hand. It took Mr. Bush a long time, but he sold the American people and several key allies on the idea that sweeping Mr. Hussein from Kuwait was worth the loss of many Western lives.
He managed to do so in part because he was able to convince people that Mr. Hussein's aggressiveness constituted a strategic threat to Western oil supplies. But NATO's strategic goal this time is unclear. Mr. Clinton has spoken of degrading the Serbians' ability to wage war against the Kosovo Albanians. President Jacques Chirac of France said on Tuesday that Europe could no longer tolerate either Mr. Milosevic or his regime.
The prospect of a diplomatic deal remains dim as long as NATO insists, as it did after the attempted Russian mediation this week, that its troops be allowed to monitor any peace in Kosovo -- an idea that profoundly offends the Serbs. More likely is an indecisive, lingering conflict, not unlike the one in Iraq, with the dictator still in power and the West repeatedly frustrated.
"Make no mistake," said a Balkan diplomat who knows Mr. Milosevic and talks with him often. "The man pays attention, and he has watched Saddam Hussein gain strength as the bombs have fallen."
The two situations are different, of course. Mr. Hussein is not currently engaged in ethnic cleansing, for one thing.
But Kosovo and Iraq closely resemble each other in one crucial respect: neither problem seems susceptible to a short, sharp solution. Wars like the one in the Falkland Islands look like a thing of the past.

LENGTH: 931 words

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
I.B.M. vows to pull ads from Web sites that lack clear policies on protecting consumer privacy.

BYLINE: By Jeri Clausing 

 BODY:
SAYING it hoped to ward off Government regulation and increase consumer confidence in electronic commerce, the International Business Machines Corporation, the second-biggest advertiser on the Internet, said yesterday that it would pull its ads from Web sites that lacked clear privacy policies.
In a letter sent to 350 Web sites it advertises with in the United States and Canada, I.B.M. said that as of June 1 it would advertise only on sites that posted such policies. 
 The announcement, thought to be the first by a United States company, comes as the Federal Trade Commission, Congress and the European Union are closely monitoring the effectiveness of efforts by on-line businesses to police themselves on the issue of buying and selling personal data they gather.
I.B.M. said its own recent survey had found that only 30 percent of the 800 sites worldwide from which it buys ads had privacy policies posted.
"It was a little to our surprise, frankly, that so many sites didn't have privacy policies," said Abby Kohnstamm, I.B.M.'s senior vice president for marketing.
Ms. Kohnstamm and Chris Caine, vice president for governmental programs, cited three factors behind the decision announced yesterday: I.B.M.'s own history of protecting consumer privacy, research showing that consumer concerns about privacy are inhibiting the growth of electronic commerce, and the need for the industry to prove that it can regulate itself.
"Market-led policies need market leaders," Mr. Caine said.
Robert Pitofsky, the trade commission chairman, who last year told Internet companies to make fundamental improvements in protecting consumer privacy or face tough new regulations, said he was encouraged by the announcement.
"I think it is a good move," Mr. Pitofsky said. "I'm not sure whether it will catch on or not, but I think it is important that a company with the stature and prestige of I.B.M. take the first step. Time will tell if others see it in their best interest."
Even privacy advocates who view industry self-regulation as ineffective and unenforceable called the I.B.M. move a positive step in pushing companies to tell consumers what type of personal information they collect and how it is used.
"It is exquisitely timed," said Jason Catlett, president of the Junkbusters Corporation, which promotes consumer protection on line. "I don't think it's going to have an enormous effect," he added, but "I still feel I have to applaud I.B.M. because their heart is in the right place."
Mr. Catlett, saying that I.B.M. had a good history of protecting privacy, also pointed out that the company had avoided negative publicity like that recently faced by the Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation for embedding in their products identifying numbers that could allow marketers and others to track computer users' movements through cyberspace.
All three companies are members of the Online Privacy Alliance, which was formed last year to push companies to address privacy concerns after a survey by the F.T.C. found only 14 percent of Web sites had clear privacy policies posted.
Microsoft, the No. 1 advertiser on the Internet, applauded the move by I.B.M. and said it would watch its effects closely. "Because privacy is very important to us, we are always considering all ways in which we can encourage privacy protections," said Tom Pilla, a Microsoft spokesman. "We don't have any immediate plans to follow suit."
Although I.B.M. will not dictate standards for what privacy policies on Web sites should be, it does refer Web publishers to the Online Privacy Alliance, which has a list of recommended practices that are based on principles recommended by the F.T.C. last year.
The debate over the issue has reached a critical point as the F.T.C. nears a decision on whether a report to Congress due this spring will recommend the passage of new laws to protect on-line privacy.
A group of business interests, in conjunction with the F.T.C. and Georgetown University, recently completed a follow-up to the F.T.C. survey last year of on-line privacy practices. The results of that study, which have not been released, are expected to be a determining factor in the agency's decision.
Mr. Pitofsky told Congress last year that he would push for regulation if significant improvement was not found. He said yesterday that progress was being made, but he acknowledged, "I just don't know how much, and I hear radically different versions from differing groups."
He also emphasized that the report to Congress would look at more than just the numbers. "You want to know what kind of policy" that Web sites "are putting up there," he said. Some key points, he said, are whether the policies are clear and whether they explain that consumers have a choice in how the information they supply is used.
Indeed, I.B.M. cited the new survey in the letter that its on-line advertising agency, Ogilvy One Worldwide, a New York unit of WPP Group P.L.C., sent out yesterday morning.
"We believe that this presents a very timely opportunity for the private sector to continue to take the initiative in posting and following privacy policies," the letter said in reference to the survey. "While the appropriate privacy statement will vary from site to site, we strongly encourage Web site owners to employ industry best privacy practices."
I.B.M. said it spent about $45 million on on-line advertising last year, or 7 percent of its worldwide media budget. That is expected to increase to $60 million, or 10 percent of its budget, this year.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge in Microsoft Trial Sets a Long Timetable
The presiding judge in the Microsoft antitrust trial, Thomas Penfield Jackson, tentatively set a May 10 date for the trial to resume and laid out a timetable that virtually insures that what was to have been a speedy trial will not end much before 2000. 
 The long trial means that the Government will not achieve its main goal of stopping the bundling of a Web browser with Microsoft's Windows 98 operating system. Page C2.
 
Philip Morris Leads Stocks Lower
Stocks fell as investors sold shares of Philip Morris after a jury found the company liable for $81 million in damages for the death of a smoker and hopes faded for a quick settlement of Microsoft's antitrust trial. The Dow Jones industrials fell 127.10 points, to 9,786.16, and the Nasdaq composite index lost 18.53 points, to 2,461.76. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 14.38 points, to 1,300.75. C9.
 
Bonds prices fell, finishing their worst quarter in three years on fears of inflation. C8.
 
The Dow industrials rose 6.6 percent for the quarter, compared with 4.6 percent for the S.& P. 500, as investors intensified their preference for big companies' shares. C9.
 
Merrill Lynch Tops Underwriters List
Merrill Lynch underwrote more securities than any other Wall Street firm in the first quarter of 1999, while Goldman, Sachs led in mergers and acquisitions. Market Place. C8.
 
I.B.M. Stresses Web-Site Privacy
I.B.M., the second-biggest advertiser on the Internet, said that it would pull its advertisements from Web sites that lacked clear privacy policies. Advertising. C4.
 
CBS in Exclusive Clinton Interview
President Clinton gave his first exclusive interview in nearly 15 months to Dan Rather of CBS News, answering questions about Yugoslavia and the impeachment scandal. C4.
 
Conde Nast Names GQ Publisher
Thomas A. Florio, the publisher of Conde Nast Traveler, was named publisher of the Conde Nast men's title GQ. Jack Laschever is resigning for medical reasons. C4.
 
A Deadlock Over a New Trade Chief
After a yearlong search for a new head of the World Trade Organization, the European Union and the United States appear to be deadlocked between Suphachai Panichpakdi, the Thai Commerce Minister, and Michael Moore, left, a former Prime Minister of New Zealand. The term of Renato Ruggiero of Italy expires April 30. C6.
 
An Angry Denial by DaimlerChrysler
The co-chairmen of DaimlerChrysler responded angrily to recent reports of managerial troubles, insisting that the defection of a half-dozen former Chrysler executives, some to Ford and G.M., did not pose a problem. C6.
 
BMW Shares Fall on Rover Worries
BMW shares tumbled more than 4 percent after the company's top executives gave analysts a vague and unconvincing description of their strategy for repairing Rover, the troubled British subsidiary. C6.
 
Mitsubishi Will Cut 14,500 Jobs
Mitsubishi Electric, the big Japanese electronics company, announced a broad overhaul that will reduce its global work force by 14,500, or 10 percent, over three years. More than half the job cuts will be in Japan. C20.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazilian Central Bank Plans A Currency Insider Inquiry

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 31

 BODY:
The nation's central bank said today that it is conducting an investigation into accusations that several domestic and foreign financial institutions used inside information about an impending shift in exchange-rate policy in January to profit from the devaluation of the currency.
The assertions -- first made public in February by Aloizio Mercadante, a member of Congress from the opposition Workers Party -- include charges that nine banks used access to Government officials in the days leading up to the Jan. 13 policy shift to make trading decisions resulting in a combined profit of roughly $1 billion. The list of banks includes Citigroup, J. P. Morgan and BankBoston. 
 Many banks in recent weeks have reported preliminary results to the central bank showing they made substantial profits after the devaluation of the currency, the real, largely through a combination of successful bets in futures markets and purchases of dollar-linked Government bonds. The enormous size of these profits comes as the economy is struggling with recession, and has resulted in calls by several members of Congress to look into the legality of such financial results.
This week, Senator Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, the president of the Senate and a man widely considered Brazil's most powerful legislator, said he would support a Congressional inquiry into the accusations that some banks used inside information to profit from the devaluation. That move is separate from the central bank's investigation.
Georges Lamaziere, a spokesman for President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, said on Tuesday that the Government sees no problem with the Congressional inquiry going forward. The central bank's investigation should be finished by next week and the results will be announced then, a spokeswoman said in Brasilia, the capital.
Most of the banks have said they broke no laws by accumulating profits in the aftermath of the devaluation, which pushed the real down by 40 percent against the dollar.
There had been widespread expectations for months that Brazil might have to abandon its artificial support for the currency and let market forces of supply and demand determine its value. Currency traders at banks and other financial institutions who had bet on that possibility, based on publicly available information, did nothing illegal.
"When you have a devaluation, you tend to make money," said Richard Howe, a spokesman for Citigroup in New York. J. P. Morgan and BankBoston also denied any wrongdoing.
At the time of the devaluation, the central bank was led by an interim president, Francisco Lopes, who has since resigned. It is now headed by Arminio Fraga, a former fund manager, who ordered the insider-trading investigation last week. He has also ordered an inquiry into accusations that the central bank may have acted illegally in helping two small Rio de Janeiro investment banks, Banco Marka and Banco Fonte Cindam, after the devaluation. The banks lost millions of dollars after betting against the likelihood of a devaluation. Marka has since been taken over by the central bank, while Fonte Cindam has been sold to Banque Nationale de Paris.

HEADLINE: Short-Lived Dose of Shirt-Sleeve Temperatures

BYLINE: By MONTE WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
It was decidedly shirt-sleeve weather, and all across the region yesterday, people doffed their jackets and overcoats to take a walk, appreciate spring's blooms and otherwise enjoy a day that reached 73 degrees in Central Park.
"What is notable is the air is dry," said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at Pennsylvania State University. "It's like the climate of Arizona has come to New York City." Although warm, the temperature did not set a record. Last March 31, temperatures reached 86 degrees in Central Park. 
 Les Martin spent part of yesterday in his yard in West Hartford, Conn., after returning from the winter in Florida. He was uncovering purple crocuses as he raked out leaves and branches. "It's nice to come back to temperatures that are almost the same as they were in Florida," he said. "It's just the ideal day to be out."
Brunella Ibarrola, an adjunct professor at the University of Connecticut in West Hartford, sipped a soda before her evening nutrition class. "It's a glorious day," she said, wondering aloud how many of her students might "succumb to the temptation to go elsewhere."
On Broadway at 112th Street on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, Dave Shargani, 33, a baseball card vendor, said business was booming. "When the weather's like this sales go up about 40 percent," he said.
Nearby in Riverside Park, Phong Bui, an engineering student at City College, drew the buildings along Riverside Drive on a large sketch pad. "When I looked out my window this morning I said springtime is finally here," said Mr. Bui, 27, who is from Vietnam. "It's beautiful and it's definitely helping inspire my drawings. The only problem is I have allergies and I'm going to have to go inside soon."
Two women admiring a planter of bright yellow daffodils in Bryant Park in midtown Manhattan said that the warm weather promoted cordiality.
"We don't know each other," said one of the women, Bebe Carlson, an unemployed medical secretary from Long Beach, N.Y. "We just sat here and started talking."
Not everyone in Bryant Park was dressed for the day. Two visitors from England compared their spring day in the park with what they had left behind. "This is a lot better than the weather back home," said Robin Trotman, 30, a Londoner who said he works with the disabled. "When we left home, it was raining a bit, about 50 degrees and gray."
While Mr. Trotman was sporting a T-shirt, his friend, Richard Thomas, 36, a social worker from Bristol, was wearing a black leather jacket. Mr. Thomas said he was warm, but explained that the jacket wouldn't fit in his knapsack. "Plus I didn't want to crease it," he added.
Mr. Thomas's jacket may be of more use today and tomorrow. Mr. Gadomski, the meteorologist, said the gentle temperatures and the dryness were fleeting. Thickening clouds last night meant that it was expected to be about 10 degrees lower today, he said. "There will be some showers here and there," he added. Temperatures will drop even more by Friday, with highs in the mid-50's and lows in the high 30's, he said.
The cooler temperatures are sure to please those people who were not quite ready for the heat yesterday. Greg Zuccolo, 31, of Manhattan, a performance artist, was in Bryant Park putting his resume together with 8-by-10 glossies of himself. "I'm not a fan of this weather," he said. "I'm from Canada, and I prefer it to be cold for a lot longer -- at least mid-April."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Investors Stick to Big Names in Quarter

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
In its final sprint to the 10,000 mark, a peak once scarcely imagined, the Dow Jones industrial average showed that stock market investors intensified what had already seemed an inexhaustible preference for the biggest and best.
"It was all the big names -- the big caps," said Alfred E. Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis, in reviewing the first three months of 1999 yesterday, as managers finished dressing their portfolios for client inspection. "We're in a very selective market, so the deal is, you've got to buy the big-name stocks." 
 Yesterday's action, however, was not entirely a matter of professionals adding recent winners and shedding losers, since the market suffered a late sinking spell that pushed the Dow 127.1 points lower to pare its gain for the quarter to 6.6 percent.
The Standard & Poor's 500, also dominated by large companies, lost a proportionally similar amount to finish the quarter ahead by 4.6 percent.
It was the first time since the final quarter of 1996 that the Dow beat the S.& P., and it did so despite a 35 percent skid by Philip Morris Companies. Much of that slide came this week after an Oregon jury ordered the company to pay $81 million in damages to the family of a Marlboro smoker who died of cancer.
By contrast, Standard & Poor's indexes of medium-sized and small companies slumped 7 percent and 9 percent, respectively.
"You still have the large-capitalization, global growth companies leading the market and still have the narrowness that prevailed last year," said Timothy E. O'Grady, senior portfolio manager for First Capital Group in Morristown, N.J.
Software, computer and many other high-technology companies also sparkled, with Microsoft rising 29 percent, to finish at $89.625, where its total value surpassed $450 billion, 25 percent more than the No. 2 General Electric.
The Nasdaq market, which is heavily weighted with technology, spurted 12 percent over the winter, with CMGI, which develops and operates Internet and direct marketing companies, soaring 244 percent to finish at $183.0625. Amazon.com, the Internet bookseller, jumped 61 percent, to $172.1875, to surpass the price of Yahoo, the leading Internet search directory, at $168.375, up 42 percent for the quarter.
Joining the high-technology winners were brokerage houses, airlines and various retailers, beneficiaries of continued avid consumer spending that itself is partly fueled by rising stock prices.
Citigroup posted the biggest gain among Dow stocks -- although it was not the biggest contributor to the average's 605-point gain -- as it climbed 29 percent, to $63.875, more than double its low of last October when foreign economic turmoil was its most intense.
Charles Schwab & Company and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette paced a giant run-up in brokerage firm stocks, which were badly battered last year. Each of them rebounded 70 percent during the latest quarter. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter climbed 41 percent, Lehman Brothers and Merrill Lynch & Company by about one-third and Bear, Stearns & Company by 25 percent.
Airlines, aided by low fuel prices, as well as free-spending travelers, were led by Delta and Southwest, each up 33 percent, and UAL, which rose 30 percent. AMR, which experienced a 10-day sickout by its pilots, and U S Airways, however, edged lower.
Among retailers, Consolidated Stores, up 50 percent, and Dollar General, up 44 percent, posted some of the biggest gains. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the No. 1 retailer, gained 13 percent to push its market capitalization -- what it would theoretically cost to buy every share -- above the $200 billion level.
Drug stocks were mixed, with American Home Products 16 percent higher, Pfizer up 11 percent and Merck up 9 percent. Abbott, Bristol-Myers and Eli Lilly all lost between 4 and 5 percent, while Warner-Lambert, maker of the controversial diabetes drug Rezulin, lost 12 percent.
Utilities weakened as interest rates crept higher, with the S. & P. utility index falling 10 percent. Nonetheless, there was little sign of faster inflation, and precious metals turned in another poor performance, with the Philadelphia gold and silver index slipping 8 percent.
Looking ahead, the Dow after millenary milestones has advanced in the following quarter on two of every three occasions, and has also done better than other market indexes. Its biggest rise was 12.5 percent after the average hit 6,000 in late 1996, according to LIM Research.com. The biggest loss was 1.2 percent in the quarter following the Dow's July 1997 surge to 8,000.
The research company also noted that the Russell 2000 underperformed the general market in the quarter following seven of the last eight 1,000-point milestones.

HEADLINE: The Man Behind the Exams;
New York's Education Chief Pushes Agenda of Change

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
When Richard P. Mills came to New York as its Education Commissioner three and a half years ago, the state had just drafted a detailed set of blueprints, contained in thick bound volumes, for how to teach nine subjects from English to science in every grade from pre-kindergarten through high school.
But as he visited schools from the South Bronx to Buffalo, Mr. Mills was dismayed to find that the plans, called "curriculum frameworks," had made almost no impact in the trenches. 
 Few teachers even knew they existed, let alone used them. Finally, he pulled a teacher aside and asked why. "You don't get it," the teacher said, with what Mr. Mills remembers as almost a sneer. "If the standards are not on the test, they're not real."
Fortified by that insight, Mr. Mills, who came to New York from Vermont with a reputation as a progressive educator, has emerged as a leader of the national movement to promote standards through old-fashioned testing. He has made testing at all levels the centerpiece of state policy, using scores to judge districts, schools and students. And he has imposed stark consequences -- like withholding high school diplomas -- for failing to meet those standards.
"It's not fair to graduate children without the knowledge and skills to make it in the world," Mr. Mills said. "We are setting them up for failure."
Mr. Mills's testing agenda struck fear into fourth graders and their parents in January, when he introduced a new three-day reading test, which required 9-year-olds to write essays with correct spelling, grammar and punctuation, rather than fill in the simple multiple choice bubbles of the past. In New York City next year, the tests may be used as a factor in promotion to fifth grade. His tough new high school graduation standards have forced school administrators from affluent suburbs to impoverished inner-city schools to scramble to prepare struggling students for what was until now considered an honors curriculum.
Mr. Mills says he is challenging a state-sanctioned system of low expectations that for decades has consigned many poor and disadvantaged children to a second-class education. But to his critics, including many academics, teachers and administrators, he has become the Darth Vader of educational reform, whose focus on testing could deny diplomas to thousands of children and brand scores of schools as failures.
"There will be casualties," said Jay Heubert, co-editor of a study on high-stakes testing for the National Academy of Sciences.
Whoever is right, the policies adopted by the State Board of Regents have set the stage for years of bruising political and educational confrontation. Mr. Mills and the Regents have decided that next year, all high school seniors -- including most immigrants who do not speak English fluently -- will be denied diplomas unless they pass a three-day, six-hour English Regents examination that in the past was reserved for honors students. By 2003, students will have to take exams in five subjects to graduate.
State officials are urging students with learning disabilities to at least attempt the Regents exams. And Mr. Mills is negotiating with private schools to set similar standards. One academic describes him as pursuing a shock therapy approach to education reform. If the new standards had been in place last year, 27 percent of all high school seniors in the state -- 37 percent in New York City -- would have failed to receive diplomas, and the percentages would have been much higher in some schools.
Despite his aggressive policies, Mr. Mills, who goes by Rick, cultivates the outward demeanor of a colorless corporate manager, declining, for instance, to be called "Dr.," even though he has a doctorate in educational leadership. One legislator once compared him to Clark Kent.
Though mild-mannered, he has had a testy relationship with Rudy Crew, the New York City Schools Chancellor, almost from the moment they were appointed to their jobs, Mr. Mills in September 1995 and Dr. Crew a month later. Four days after Dr. Crew arrived in New York from Tacoma, Wash., Mr. Mills threatened to close down 16 failing public schools in New York City unless they improved by the end of the school year.
Dr. Crew called Mr. Mills "a strategic ally," but bridled at the notion that the State Commissioner was setting the agenda for New York City.
"The monkey is on our back to produce here, but that's not a function of Rick Mills," Dr. Crew said. "That's a function of what we believe to be true."
Mr. Mills seemed an unlikely warrior for testing when he arrived in New York. As Commissioner of Education in Vermont for seven and a half years, he introduced a method of evaluating students that is almost the antithesis of standardized tests -- portfolios. A favorite tool of progressive educators, portfolios are collections of student work that are evaluated by committees of teachers or outsiders. The Rand Institute on Education and Training found that the portfolio system in Vermont had improved teaching, but was too subjective to be fair or reliable as a testing tool.
In his dark-paneled office in Albany, where the only personal touch is a set of oversized red and green cardboard blocks that spell STANDARDS, Mr. Mills said that his testing program in New York was not a repudiation of his experience in Vermont.
He said he still thought that portfolios, although in need of fine-tuning, were the right testing system for the town-hall, populist environment of Vermont, where there was no history of statewide testing. But he insists that conventional standardized tests fit the educational culture of New York State, which has a history of giving Regents examinations that goes back to the Civil War.
"People just assume that you pack a suitcase full of ideas that you bring over the border and impose," Mr. Mills said. "You have to use the tools at hand."
Mr. Mills had his first brush with old-fashioned standards when he was 10. He was born in Paris, Ill., the son of a peripatetic insurance executive, who moved on to Ohio and then Winnipeg, Manitoba. Going from a progressive to a traditional school, he discovered that he was no longer the smartest kid in class. "It was a very useful experience when I was young to have to really scramble," he said.
Planning to become a historian, he entered a master's program at Columbia University. But academic life felt suffocating, he said, and he answered a posting to teach history to junior high and high school students at Dalton, the exclusive Manhattan private school.
At Dalton, he became part of a group of teachers who wanted to try new ideas. With four older teachers, Mr. Mills, then 26, ended up resigning and creating a challenge to the system -- the 35-student Elizabeth Seeger School in Greenwich Village, with a progressive faculty that believed in hands-on learning, like visiting the Federal Reserve Bank to study economics and a farm in New Jersey to read King Lear.
After two years, he decided that he did not know enough to run a school, and he returned to Columbia to earn a business degree, and later a doctorate in education.
As Mr. Mills applies a bottom-line mentality to education, his biggest challenge may come not from his direct opponents, but from those who say he is trying to do too much too fast.
Until now, New York has had a two-tier diploma system -- Regents diplomas for the best students and local diplomas for the rest. But research shows that two-tier diploma systems lead to a dumbed-down curriculum for students in the lesser track.
Still, Dr. Heubert, who studied the issue for the National Academy of Sciences, says that asking children to meet higher standards before schools have demonstrated that they are teaching the material is unfair, and likely to be challenged in court.
Randi Weingarten, president of the city teachers' union, said the standards could not be met without more money to lower class sizes, train teachers and improve facilities like laboratories.
And teachers and children may fail because the standards are not clear enough, said Diane Ravitch, an Assistant Secretary of Education in the Bush Administration, and an advocate of national testing and curriculum. She wants the Regents to be more prescriptive about curriculum, down to the literature children should read, the historical events they should study and the methods they should use to learn math.
"I think you have an obligation to say that if you learn these things, you will pass this exam," Dr. Ravitch said.
To Mr. Mills, such arguments are a Catch-22: without a test, there is no way to tell how well schools are teaching.
Carl T. Hayden, Chancellor of the Regents, said that the pressure to meet graduation standards would drive stronger curriculum, more money and better teacher training. "It will make politicians more accountable," he said.
Already, the specter of failure has driven some changes. To help students pass Regents tests, New York City is spending $12 million this year to reduce the size of high school English and math classes. West Lake High School in Westchester County is giving students at risk of failing the Regents exams an extra period of instruction every day, said Louis Cuglietto, the principal. Even so, Mr. Cuglietto said, he is nervous.
Just how far he has veered from his original educational course dawned on Mr. Mills one day soon after he became Commissioner. He was signing routine paperwork when a document from the Elizabeth Seeger school crossed his desk. The school had closed in 1981, but the other teachers had maintained its operating permit, apparently in hopes of someday reviving its unconventional program.
But in that winter of 1996, as Mr. Mills embarked on the biggest testing program in New York history, his onetime fellow rebels were giving up, and his signature was needed to confirm the end of their experiment.
"They were surrendering their charter," he said, a hint of regret in his voice.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Says Deal Is Near On Obstacle at Stadium Site

BYLINE: By MIKE ALLEN 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 31

 BODY:
Just two days before a deadline requiring them to show progress on a plan to build a stadium for the New England Patriots, Connecticut officials said today that they were close to a deal to remove the biggest obstacle to the plan: a steam plant on the site.
Officials of the company that owns the plant, C.T.G. Resources, were more cautious in describing negotiations on moving the plant. But they said that the talks, which had broken down in public finger-pointing between Gov. John G. Rowland and the company, were now progressing. 
 "The change in tone suggests the possibility for a successful completion of negotiations," said Lynn C. Blackwell, a spokeswoman for the company. But, she added, "There are an awful lot of open issues."
State officials, who saw the stadium plans bog down over one unexpected issue after another, spoke more optimistically about the outlook for the stadium than they have in weeks.
"All the points of disagreement that were on the table were either removed or substantially modified," said Richard D. Gray, the Governor's chief negotiator. "We believe there can be an agreement between the parties soon."
C.T.G. also has renewed talks with the Connecticut Resources Recovery Authority about the agency's offer to replace the steam plant, and both sides reported progress.
On Friday, the state is scheduled to present the Patriots with the first of several reports showing progress on preparation of the site, intending to have the stadium ready for play in the 2002 season. Under the contract signed by Governor Rowland, the team could walk away from the deal within 30 days of receiving Friday's report if it concluded that adequate headway had not been made.
C.T.G.'s headquarters and steam plant occupy the riverfront site in downtown Hartford where the state hopes to build a stadium for the Patriots. Ten days ago, the company was demanding $49 million to move its headquarters, double the amount that had been raised by the private backers of the stadium complex, which is to include a hotel and convention center.
Officials involved in the talks say that C.T.G. is now considering leasing a new building instead of buying it. C.T.G. has withdrawn its demand for indemnification against environmental cleanup costs, and instead the state and the company will buy an insurance policy covering the site, state officials said today.
The state has prepared a draft of its 30-page report to the Patriots. Governor Rowland said he was confident the report would show sufficient progress, adding that the "degree of specifics we'll get to will be hammered out in the next couple days."
"Failure is not an option," he said. "The Patriots will be playing in Hartford."
Governor Rowland also met this morning with a group of Hartford's corporate leaders to enlist them in building enthusiasm for the stadium plan, which has suffered a decline in public support, a poll has found.
Last week, the Governor had said he planned to ask the group of about 20 executives to help finance C.T.G.'s demands. "They've been asked to show up with their checkbooks," he said.
Instead, over coffee and bagels at the Capitol today, he asked the executives to join his "pro-stadium effort," including such gestures as "writing letters to the editor and talking amongst their friends."
"We're going to start to get out and publicize the benefits of having the stadium here and the benefits, economically and otherwise, of having the Patriots in Hartford," he said.
The Governor said the executives said they might be willing to help with loan guarantees, and by supplying legal, architectural and other services to the stadium development complex, to be called Adriaen's Landing.
The poll, taken for The Hartford Courant by the University of Connecticut, found that the stadium's support had declined to 45 percent this week from 58 percent in December. The poll of 500 state residents was conducted from Thursday to Sunday and has a margin of error of plus or minus five percentage points.
Governor Rowland said he was not alarmed by the decline. "This has been a huge vacuum over the last two months," he said.
"We had a lot of excitement when we had the press conference and the announcement and the development agreement and the legislative activity. Now it's the lull, as you go through the minutiae of hammering out the plan."

HEADLINE: New Nigerian Leader Says Democracy Can Thrive

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 31

 BODY:
The President-elect of Nigeria, Olesegun Obasanjo, says he is paying no heed to skeptics who argue that a legacy of corruption has rendered Nigeria, Africa's most populous nation, incapable of sustaining democratic rule.
Mr. Obasanjo met Tuesday with President Clinton to reaffirm his commitment to democracy, saying his nation needs a stable civilian government in order to prosper. 
 "I understand and sympathize with the skeptics, but I don't go by the views and the thinking of the skeptics," he told reporters. "The success of democracy in Nigeria will signal success and be a catalyst to success of democracy elsewhere in West Africa, and indeed in Africa."
Mr. Obasanjo said Mr. Clinton had expressed "not just understanding, but also sympathy" for Nigeria's political and economic situation. Nigeria has $30 billion in foreign debt. The peacekeeping force it leads, Ecomog, has seen its share of assistance from the United States fall from $3.9 million in 1998 to $1.3 million this year.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Obasanjo talked for half an hour about establishing democratic rule in Nigeria, which the Administration regards as a potential force for political stability on the continent.
Mr. Clinton emphasized that democracy was essential if Nigeria hoped for economic reform and increased investment, the White House national security spokesman, Mike Hammer, said.
Mr. Obasanjo said he assured Mr. Clinton that Nigeria would continue to lead a West African peacekeeping force now in Sierra Leone, which has been racked by civil war. He also promised to insure that Nigeria's military would become more professional and would remain under civilian control.
Mr. Obasanjo was Nigeria's military leader from 1976 until 1979, when he yielded power to a civilian government. The military took over again four years later.
Mr. Obasanjo had been jailed by the dictator Gen. Sani Abacha, who died last June. His successor, Gen. Abdulsalami Abubakar, steered Nigeria toward civilian rule. Mr. Obasanjo was elected in February.
The visit to Washington is part of a tour of several countries before his May 29 inauguration. Mr. Clinton has been invited but has not yet said whether he will attend.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
No Comfort in New Solvency Figures

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Administration boisterously pointed this week to new actuary studies showing that Medicare and Social Security will remain solvent for a few more years than previously estimated. Social Security would not go bankrupt until 2034, rather than 2032, and the Medicare trust fund would last until 2015 rather than 2008.
But the revised estimates should bring little comfort to anyone who looks seriously at the numbers. Solvency is an accounting measure that can be achieved merely by shifting costs from the trust funds to general taxpayers. The fundamental problem posed by Government retiree programs has not gone away. 
 Longer life expectancies, rising medical costs and falling birth rates combine to drive up the working Americans' burden of supporting the elderly. Add up the cost of Social Security, Medicare and the part of Medicaid that pays for nursing homes for the elderly. These three retiree programs alone will account for more than a third of Federal spending next year.
By 2030, retirement benefits will account for more than two-thirds of the budget. That means the fraction of the Federal spending devoted to other parts of Government, from law enforcement to housing subsidies, will shrivel unless Congress substantially cuts the growth rate of retiree benefits or raises taxes.
Eugene Steuerle of the Urban Institute points out that the baby-boom generation can look forward to generous retiree benefits even as birth rates fall, leaving fewer workers to support a growing number of the elderly. By locking in layers of retiree benefits for rich and poor alike, Mr. Steuerle observes, the baby boomers are leaving themselves a Government "almost the sole purpose of which will be to care for their consumption needs in retirement, a Government by, of and only for the baby boomers."
The footprints of Mr. Steuerle's stern warning lie all over the White House and Congressional budgets. Sam Elkin of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities tracks domestic discretionary spending, which encompasses nearly all the programs except military and entitlement programs like Social Security and welfare. Mr. Elkin points out that under the recently passed Republican budget, such spending will fall by 18 percent by 2002 and almost 30 percent by 2009, after taking account of inflation.
That would take domestic discretionary spending from almost 3.5 percent of the national economic output today -- which is as low as this figure has been since the early 1960's -- to about 2 percent by 2009. As Medicare and Social Security costs rise thereafter, this figure would fall further still. By comparison, domestic discretionary programs accounted for more than 5 percent of the economy in 1980.
The proposed evisceration of discretionary spending comes as no surprise from the party that has all but declared war on big government, but the fact is that President Clinton's budget would not restore the proposed cuts.
In his winning Presidential campaign in 1992, Mr. Clinton pledged to raise Government spending by $50 billion a year on public programs, for example high-speed trains and improved training for the work force. His current plan would use about 10 percent of the expected surpluses over the next 15 years to preserve some descretionary spending. That would avoid more than half of the Republicans' proposed cuts.
But the added money would not come close to honoring his 1992 pledge, even though the current and projected economies are flush compared with the economy that Mr. Clinton inherited from President George Bush. Indeed, Mr. Elkin said that after taking account of inflation, Mr. Clinton's latest budget would probably cut domestic discretionary spending by 7 percent by 2002 and 13 percent by 2009. There goes part of the President's investment bridge to the 21st century.
To do more, Mr. Clinton would have had to propose trimming retiree benefits, perhaps by proposing to raise the eligibility age for Medicare. Or Mr. Clinton would have had to propose cutting Social Security and Medicare benefits for upper-income families, measures neither he nor the Republicans would touch.
Instead, he proposed to use most of the expected surpluses to give Medicare and Social Security first call on general tax revenues in the future when the trust funds run dry. Therein lies the fate of future discretionary programs.
There are important differences between the Clinton and Republican plans. His plan buys back far more of the Government's $3.7 trillion debt from the public, a sound economic step that would pump trillions of dollars into private capital markets for use by companies to invest in plants and equipment. The Republicans would return about $800 billion of the future surplus to taxpayers in the form of a tax cut over 10 years. They would not use the surplus to bolster domestic discretionary spending, unlike the President.
But the similarities overwhelm the differences. Both budgets call for a future wherein the Government takes in tax dollars from a diminishing number of workers in order to support the consumption of an increasing number of elderly.
Few take seriously the prospect that Congress, even if it stays in Republican hands, will gut discretionary spending anytime soon. It would seem ludicrous to believe a Congress that needed decades to summon the political courage to strip wartime subsidies from the producers of mohair would immediately whack nearly a third out of the budget for border patrols, medical research and highway construction.
But budget logic will eventually have to overcome cowardice. Over time, Congress will have only grim choices: trim retiree benefits, eviscerate discretionary spending or raise taxes. "Never before," says Mr. Steuerle of entitlement spending for the elderly, "have so many commitments and so much growth been scheduled in our laws -- literally for an eternity."
Many economists make the point that in about 30 years a third of the adult population will be retired and that these people will spend about a third of their lives in retirement. Congress can promote private savings in a number of ways. It can generate Federal surpluses far into the future.
But, Mr. Steuerle points out, there is no way that Congress can spur savings enough "to support close to one-third of the entire adult population on Social Security for one-third of their adult lives," adding, "Doesn't the blessing of longer life involve some obligation to share in its cost?"
