HEADLINE: THINK TANK;
All the King's Horses and All the King's Men Were Still Optimistic

 BODY:
Wall Street cheered this week as the Dow Jones industrial average finally closed above 10,000. Many analysts are counting on a continuing bull market. Who knows? They may be right. And then again, they may not. Stock market predictions are a tricky business, as you can see from a look back at what was said 70 years ago, before and right after the Oct. 29 crash. Joyce Jensen compiled these quotations from "The Great Crash, 1929," by John Kenneth Galbraith (Houghton Mifflin, 1997); "The Stock Market Crash of 1929," by James Crane Kellogg 3d and William E. Downey (J. C. Kellogg Foundation, 1954); "The Experts Speak," by Christopher Cerf and Victor Navasky (Villard Books, 1998); "The Day the Market Crashed," by Donald I. Rogers (Arlington House, 1971), and "The Big Board: A History of the New York Stock Market," by Robert Sobel (The Free Press, 1965).
"The poorhouse is vanishing from among us. We have not yet reached the goal, but given a chance to go forward with the policies of the last eight years, we shall soon . . . be in sight of the day when poverty will be banished from this nation." Herbert Hoover, the Republican candidate for President, June 1928. 
 "The market is following natural laws of economics and there is no reason why both prosperity and the market should not continue for years at this high level or even higher." Thomas C. Shotwell, "Wall Street Analysis," The World Almanac for 1929.
"We seem only to have touched the fringe of our potentialities. . . . As long as the appetite for goods and services is practically insatiable, as it appears to be, and as long as productivity can be consistently increased, it would seem that we can go on with increasing activity. But we can do this only if we develop a technique of balance." From a report by a Presidential committee, "Recent Economic Changes in the United States," early 1929.
"The economic condition of the world seems on the verge of a great forward movement." Bernard Baruch, financier and Presidential adviser, June 1929.
"The outlook for the fall months seems brighter than at any time." The Wall Street Journal, Aug. 23, 1929.
"The consensus of judgment of the millions whose valuations function on that admirable market, the Stock Exchange, is that stocks are not at present overvalued." Joseph Lawrence, professor at Princeton University, 1929.
"I see no reason for the end-of-the-year slump which some people are predicting." Charles Mitchell, head of the National City Bank and director of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, Oct. 15, 1929.
The market should go "a good deal higher than it is today within a few months," Irving Fisher, professor of economics at Yale University, Oct. 15, 1929.
"This crash is not going to have much effect on business," Arthur Reynolds, chairman of Continental Illinois Bank of Chicago, Oct. 24, 1929.
"The worst has passed," Joint Statement by representatives of 35 of the largest retail brokerage houses on Wall Street at the close of trading, Oct. 24, 1929.
"This is the time to buy stocks. This is the time to recall the words of the late J. P. Morgan that any man who is bearish on the United States will go broke. Within a few days there is likely to be a bear panic rather than a bull panic. Many of the low prices as a result of this hysterical selling are not likely to be reached again in many years." R. W. McNeel, director of McNeel Financial Service, quoted in The New York Herald Tribune, Oct. 30, 1929.
"A severe depression like that of 1920-21 is outside the range of probability. We are not facing protracted liquidation." The Harvard Economic Society, November 1929.
"Financial storm definitely passed." Bernard Baruch, cablegram to Winston Churchill, Nov. 15, 1929.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Food Near End, Aid Workers Say

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 2

 BODY:
The food scarcity engulfing North Korea will worsen in the next two months because Government rations, on which a majority of the population depends, are running out and will not be restocked until the summer harvest, a senior aid official said today.
"We're now entering the most difficult months of the year," said David Morton, the United Nations aid coordinator for North Korea, at a briefing in Beijing. 
 For the next two months, Mr. Morton said, much of the population will have to depend on so-called substitute foods -- cakes or noodles made from corn stalks, cabbage stalks or grass ground with grain -- or on wild roots and grasses they scrounge themselves.
The most acute scarcity will ease in June and July when potato and vegetable crops are harvested, officials say, although the country will remain chronically short of food.
People in North Korea's cities and towns have tended to be the worst off, aid workers have found, especially if they rely for income on industries that are now nearly idle for lack of fuel or raw materials. Fewer than one-third of North Korea's people work on farms, where there is often access to more food.
Food aid from abroad, supplied mostly by the United States and channeled through the United Nations World Food Program, is mainly directed to young children in nursery schools and kindergartens, with some going to hospitals. In a new push, aid agencies are trying to feed more pregnant and nursing mothers and the elderly.
But the aid can help only a fraction of the population and offers no long-term answer, Mr. Morton said.
"We're keeping alive a generation of children," he said. "But this is only a holding action."
As other foreign visitors to North Korea have, Mr. Morton described a country where malnutrition has stunted most children and weakened many adults, where hospitals and schools have no heat and little food and where water supplies are unsanitary because there is no chlorine for treatment. "Famine, defined as an extreme scarcity of food, remains a reality for much of the population," a United Nations strategy paper concluded last month.
An unknown number of people, by some evidence in the millions, have died as a result.
Mr. Morton took issue with charges that have made by some refugees that much of the aid is being diverted to the army and political elites. Those groups vastly prefer rice to the corn and wheat in the aid program, he said, and national supplies meet their needs.
While United Nations monitors must travel with escorts and usually must declare their destinations in advance, they visit all regions where aid is given to see if schools and hospitals have received their allotments. "We believe, from what we see, that they are getting the food," Mr. Morton said.
Though the country's agricultural production has been hurt by floods and droughts, the famine's roots lie in the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, most experts now believe, when North Korea lost its major supplier of fuel, fertilizer, industrial inputs and farm equipment. It has been unable to replace those supplies through foreign exchange.
Per capita income fell to less than $500 by 1996 from more than $1,000 in 1992, according to international estimates. Fertilizer plants went idle, tractors had little fuel, irrigation pumps lacked electricity and food production plummeted.
Last fall, fuel was so scarce that 90 percent of the country's rice fields were not plowed after the harvest, the usual practice to suppress weeds and pests. That factor alone will reduce the next harvest by 12 percent, a North Korean official has said.
Simply rebuilding agriculture will not solve the problem, Mr. Morton said, because North Korea has limited arable land.
"This is an industrial country," he said. "What it needs is an economic revival."
But for both political and economic reasons, other countries are reluctant to provide large-scale economic aid. So long as North Korea refuses to make major reforms in its closed, Communist economy, many experts say, such aid may only prop up the system that helped cause the current famine.

HEADLINE: BRIDGE;
Deceptive Leads on the Way To a Cavendish Teams Title

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott 

 BODY:
One of America's finest players, Edward Manfield of Philadelphia, died of a heart attack at 55 on Monday, shortly after returning from the Spring National Championships in Vancouver, British Columbia.
Eddie Manfield was born in the Bronx, graduated from Harvard University and received a master's degree in economics. He worked for the Federal Trade Commission and then was successful as an options trader, heading his own company. 
 He won one world bridge title and 11 national ones, including the Vanderbilt Teams. In 1979 he captured the Cavendish Invitational Teams with his regular partner, Kit Woolsey.
They were aided by the diagramed deal, on which Woolsey as West opened with a weak two-bid in spades. This suggested six spades, but the modern tendency is to take this action with a strong five-card suit.
Against three no-trump, he led the spade four, an imaginative choice to provide for the possibility that his partner held a doubleton or singleton honor. The right play for South was the ten from dummy, but that was not obvious, and he played low, winning in his hand with the king.
Preparing for the end position, he led a diamond to the ten. Manfield as East won with the jack and returned the suit. South won with the ace in dummy, cashed four club winners and reached this ending:
The declarer gave himself the best chance by leading the diamond two. Manfield took his three diamond winners and had to break the hearts. If he had led low, South would have played low and finessed the ten successfully. But he led the queen, and South fell into the trap. After winning with the ace he finessed the ten, going down two. Perhaps he should have reasoned that Manfield would have led low with queen-jack-six.

HEADLINE: Way Paved for Philadelphia To Develop Naval Shipyard

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
Agreements signed this week by the United States Navy and the City of Philadelphia have cleared the way for the city to develop the huge shipyard that was shut down four years ago in a round of military base closings.
The city can now begin to market the former Philadelphia Naval Shipyard as a commercial site, an endeavor that is expected to result in up to 3,000 new jobs. 
 The first major business interested in the shipyard, Kvaener ASA of Norway, the largest shipbuilding company in Europe, agreed more than a year ago to build there but needed title to its site by April 2000 to proceed. The agreements, in effect, pass ownership of the shipyard to the city, allowing it to sign contracts with individual buyers and tenants.
Kvaener, which is planning to lease 115 acres for about $345,000 a year for 99 years, could create 1,000 jobs or more.
"This is a very important milestone in a difficult process," said Julie K. Van Nostern, director of Philadelphia's Office of Defense Conversion, an arm of the city's industrial development agency. "For economic development, it's very significant."
Opened in 1801, the Philadelphia Naval Shipyard operated as one of the country's largest shipbuilding sites until it was included among 26 military bases in 1991 recommended to be closed in the aftermath of the cold war. Over the years, more than 100 ships were built there, and thousands were repaired.
In the peak years, from World War II through the mid-1980's, as many as 12,000 people worked at the shipyard, but when it closed, in September 1995, the work force was down to 1,600. The aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy was the last naval craft to be overhauled there.
Once the shipyard closed, city and state officials began planning a development strategy, leading to a $429 million commitment by the city, state and Federal governments to upgrade the site and offer job training programs.
City officials negotiated with the Navy to obtain the rights to the property, and on Wednesday officials signed three contracts that passed control of 1,100 acres to the city for $2 million. The Navy is retaining 130 acres for its own use.
The agreements allow the city to sign long-term deals with tenants, some of whom will require major construction projects to accommodate their businesses. Ms. Van Nostern said that before the city's deal with the Navy was completed, some prospective tenants had been reluctant to sign leases with no guarantees that the Navy would allow them to remain beyond a few years.
The site has two major components, the former shipbuilding yard, which Kvaener will occupy, and a former naval station, which officials hope to market as a gated, mixed-use site for commercial and light industrial businesses.
Major selling points, they said, are the property's location, a suburban setting about halfway between downtown and Philadelphia International Airport, and a light-rail line that runs onto the site.
Dee Kaplan, director of Mayor Edward G. Rendell's Business Action Team, said the city's agreement with the Navy "gives us more freedom and flexibility to deal with companies who want to buy or lease" at the former naval yard.
"A lot of companies have expressed interest," Ms. Kaplan said. "We also have a lot of existing companies in the area who love the ambiance of the place."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japanese Stock Prices Mixed; Export Companies Fare the Best

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 2

 BODY:
Japanese stock prices closed mixed today, with the shares of export-dependent companies benefiting from the dollar's gains against the yen.
Major financial markets elsewhere in the world were closed for Good Friday. 
 In Tokyo, investors were encouraged by indications on Thursday that Japanese pension funds had begun the new fiscal year by buying stocks. That raised expectations that domestic investors would join global fund managers, who already had been buying shares on the Tokyo market, one of the world's best-performing markets so far this year.
The Nikkei average of 225 stocks, which jumped 3.1 percent Thursday, fell 37.37 points today, to 16,290.19. The index rose 1.7 percent in the week and is up almost 18 percent this year.
The broader Topix index, which comprises all the companies listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's first section, rose 3.73 points today, to 1,304.17.
The Sony Corporation, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and other exporters rose again today. The dollar, which increased more than 1 percent against the yen on Thursday, rose slightly in Tokyo today, to 120.52 yen from 120.43 yen in New York Thursday afternoon. A stronger dollar increases the amount of yen produced by sales overseas.
In the economic background, the central bank's quarterly survey of Japanese business confidence, to be released Monday morning, is expected to show the first increase in seven quarters, thanks in part to the Government's efforts to support the construction and banking industries.
Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi said on March 23 that the economy had bottomed out. Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa said a week before that he expected an economic recovery to have taken hold by early May.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1519 words

HEADLINE: International Business: Retooling Fortress Wallenberg;
Swedish Empire, Under Siege, Scrambles to Adapt

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM

 BODY:
What's in a name? If the country is Sweden, and the name is Wallenberg, then the answer is just about everything.
Since the mid-19th century, Swedish industry has been largely synonymous with the Wallenberg family. The dynasty's tentacles reach everywhere, from heavy trucks and mobile phones at home to construction sites in Asia and board rooms in the United States. As one measure of the Wallenbergs' power in Sweden, their holding company, Investor A.B., controls companies that account for an estimated 40 percent of shares traded on the Stockholm stock exchange. 
 But like Sweden itself, the Wallenberg business empire is under siege these days by the forces of the global economy.
"We were suddenly subject to all the competitive powers in the world," said Jacob Wallenberg, 43, the chairman of Investor's SEB bank, who, along with his cousin Marcus Wallenberg, also 43, represents the family's newest generation of top managers.
In an unyielding global economy of free-flowing money, international megamergers and an intense focus on "core competencies" and shareholder value, the Wallenberg family conglomerate, with its disparate and far-flung interests, has been looking increasingly like an anachronism.
"Investor's traditional strategy -- as a long-term dominant and active owner across a range of sectors based on a slowly changing or unchanging portfolio -- is untenable," wrote Sweden's leading weekly business magazine, Affarsvarlden.
But the Wallenbergs are hardly sitting idle while the economic ground shifts under their feet. Rather, they are reorganizing crucial parts of their empire, particularly in forestry and pharmaceuticals, to make it more international, all in an effort to improve returns. And in a change from tradition, the family business is being run by a nonfamily member, Percy N. Barnevik.
In 1997, the family patriarch, Peter Wallenberg, stepped down as chairman of Investor A.B., though not as head of a Wallenberg family foundation that controls 35.6 percent of Investor's voting rights. The top jobs of chairman and chief executive of Investor went to Mr. Barnevik, 58, and Claes Dahlback, 52. In February, the company said that Mr. Dahlback, who has been the Wallenberg family's top nonfamily manager for years, would retire in April and be replaced by Marcus Wallenberg as chief executive.
Peter Wallenberg's departure opened the way for the beginnings of a rapid transformation under Mr. Barnevik, who had made a name for himself with the success of the 1987 Swedish-Swiss merger that created ABB Asea Brown Boveri. Mr. Barnevik, who remains chairman of ABB but is no longer chief executive there, seemed perfect for the job of running Investor. Indeed, ABB, the engineering behemoth based in Zurich, was acclaimed as one of the world's first truly borderless companies.
In his short period at the helm of Investor, Mr. Barnevik has instilled tighter corporate governance in clubby Sweden and loosened the Wallenbergs' grip on Swedish industry.
For years, the Wallenbergs had solidified their power at many Swedish companies not so much by acquiring majority equity stakes but by creating special voting rights for themselves that in some cases were as much as 1,000 times their actual holdings.
"More and more players in the capital market would say that peculiar capital structures make for peculiar decisions," Jacob Wallenberg said in an interview here.
At some companies, Investor reduced its voting-power advantage to tenfold, a more defensible level that nonetheless left the Wallenbergs in effective control even with a minority interest. The balance between stock and voting rights is a tricky one. Without the voting power to dominate management teams, the holding company finds its ability to run the companies in its portfolio greatly diminished. Investor's low equity stakes mean, though, that the company does not necessarily benefit as much from successful investments.
Meantime, with dizzying speed over the last two years, Investor has made deals in forestry, pharmaceuticals and aerospace that produced waves far beyond Sweden.
In December, Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain announced a $34.6 billion stock-only agreement to acquire the Astra A.B. unit of Investor to create a pharmaceutical powerhouse with its corporate headquarters in London, its research and development unit in Sweden and Mr. Barnevik as its chairman.
Investor's Saab Aircraft sold a 35 percent stake in its aerospace division to British Aerospace P.L.C. for $454 million. Saab also announced plans to close a civilian regional aircraft unit at the end of this year. Late last year, Stora A.B., Investor's forest products group, announced a $6.9 billion merger with its Finnish rival, Enso Oy, to produce a giant based in Helsinki, not Stockholm.
Those deals were intended to give the company a competitive edge in increasingly global businesses. And Investor insiders say the wave of revamping is far from over. At the same time, Investor's ramparts no longer seem as immune to assault as they once did.
In January, Volvo A.B. -- which is not a Wallenberg company but is run by a former Wallenberg manager, Leif Johansson -- bought a 12.85 percent chunk of stock in Scania A.B., the Wallenberg-controlled truck company. Such a challenge to the Wallenbergs, once unthinkable, could only have been undertaken with the help of leading institutional investors.
But the once improbable has become commonplace all across the corporate landscape as the barriers that once kept Swedish businesses in Swedish hands crumble. For most of the century, entrepreneurs have ventured out from Stockholm in search of profitable opportunities to enhance their sheltered home base. That business energy enabled Sweden to become one of the world's richest countries and to afford a costly cradle-to-grave social safety net.
Now, the trend has been reversed. Sweden's per capita income has plummeted to No. 17 in the world from No. 3 over the last two decades, and its welfare state cocoon has slowly unraveled under assault from outside forces and internal stresses. Corporate executives and college graduates have been seeking jobs in Britain and the United States, fleeing in record numbers from Sweden's punishing personal tax rates, which go up to 60 percent.
Ericsson, the Swedish mobile-phone maker that is under severe competitive pressure from Nokia of Finland, has joined the exodus. A big element in the Investor portfolio, Ericsson will move its European headquarters and corporate finance department to London in August. There, the argument runs, executives prefer to pay lower taxes and live in closer proximity to Europe's biggest capital markets.
As Ericsson departs, corporate giants from elsewhere are moving in, underscoring Sweden's grudging absorption into the nearly universal capitalist world order. The Ford Motor Company bought the car division of Volvo, the quintessential emblem of Swedishness, for $6.5 billion in January. The General Motors Corporation, which acquired a 50 percent stake in Saab Automobile A.B. from Investor in 1990, is widely expected to acquire the other half soon.
In the past, the very breadth of Investor's holdings underpinned the Wallenberg dominance in Swedish business. But as it confronts pressure for revamping, its stakes in the companies in its stable, and thus its control of them, stand to be reduced.
Moreover, the structure of the family fortune, which is held in a tax-exempt trust, leaves Investor few options but to shed its equity stake in some companies to concentrate on those it regards as essential businesses, Swedish analysts say. Its further challenge will be to catch the wave of new, high-technology businesses that younger Swedes see as the future.
Mr. Barnevik, once viewed as a corporate magician, now faces unaccustomed criticism from Swedish commentators questioning his touch ever since Investor took a big hit from the economic tailspin in Asia and Russia last year. Investor shares closed on Thursday in Stockholm at 362 kroner, or $43.93, down from a high of 479.5 kroner, or $58.19, last July 2.
The erosion of the Wallenberg empire has led to speculation that other Investor interests -- including parts of its original 19th-century base, SEB bank -- may be on the block. "It is increasingly difficult to play the part of an active owner once control of commercial enterprises is diluted," Mr. Dahlback, Investor's outgoing chief executive, told Affarsvarlden earlier this year. "And if we cannot perform as active owners, we would prefer to get out."
Others argue that the future of the Wallenberg dynasty depends on a broader alchemy that permits Investor to exercise control through the appointment of key managers and directors and draws on the readiness of institutional investors to follow the holding company's lead.
"It's not just a numbers game," Mr. Barnevik, the company chairman, said. "It's a game of confidence from the institutions that you are a good owner whether you own X percent or two times X percent. It's a question of how well you do the job."

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 1592 words

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Browns Rushing Into Existence

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

DATELINE: BEREA, Ohio

 BODY:
Al Lerner recently watched his first indoor practice and nearly got trampled. Lerner, the billionaire owner of the expansion Cleveland Browns, lingered on a sideline, his hands in his pants pockets, when halfback Malcolm Thomas raced full speed toward him.
Carmen Policy, the team's president and part owner, pushed Lerner to safety. "Al was reluctant to go," Policy said later, "and I dragged him there. I said it would be fun. All I could think of was visiting him at the Cleveland Clinic, his leg up in traction, and he says, 'For this, I paid $530 million?' " 
 What Lerner saw of his huge investment were 73 men -- expansion draftees, free agents and trade acquisitions -- in brown, white and orange, scrimmaging with unusual ardor as cameras above one end zone and at midfield recorded every movement of the team-in-progress.
In his first National Football League head coaching job, Chris Palmer prowled the artificial turf, windmilling his right arm, urging the players to move faster, then faster. Running back Terry Kirby wondered about the raw intensity of this first practice, in shorts and no pads.
"It was shocking," said Kirby, a free-agent acquisition. "This is March. Isn't March Madness supposed to be about basketball? No, obviously this March Madness is football madness."
That is what Lerner, a 65-year-old banker, got for his $530 million on the first day of minicamp. "Being involved in football, sitting at the edge of my seat waiting for the first game, is all good stuff," he said. Lerner is poker-faced; Policy, garrulous. Lerner needed Policy's football acumen. Policy is enamored of Lerner's desire to spend lavishly. They frequently set up each other's sentences and thoughts.
"People are learning very quickly," Policy said, "that you have to know what you're talking about with him, and there's no shame in saying, 'I don't know.' "
Once Lerner entered the Browns sweepstakes, he became the prohibitive favorite. The wealthiest of the bidders, Lerner is a friend of Commissioner Paul Tagliabue of the N.F.L. As a limited partner in the old Browns, he counseled Art Modell to take them to Baltimore as the Ravens in 1996. After a period of public reproval for aiding Modell, he is adapting to the type of public role he has never led as the chairman of the MBNA Corporation, the nation's third-largest credit card lender.
"It's hard to walk in and out of restaurants or go to public places," he said at a conference room table in Policy's office. "Would I like to go back to my life of quiet desperation? I'd like to, but it's O.K."
"He isn't comfortable with it," Policy said.
"But I do the drill," Lerner said.
For a city that mourned and raged when Modell fled to Baltimore, this team-in-formation will do quite fine. And Lou Groza likes what he sees. Groza, the legendary kicker for the original Browns who is now 75, watched the practice from a chair far from the sideline.
"This is like a relative coming home," Groza said.
Coincidentally, the new Browns and the Browns-turned-Ravens are division rivals and will play each other twice a year. Their first meeting is Sept. 26 in Baltimore.
The return of the Browns is an N.F.L. success story in the modern era of stadium-driven sports economics.
It began with Modell's secret talks with Maryland officials, escalated into angry protests that forced Modell's permanent exile from Cleveland and provoked Capitol Hill hearings about franchise relocation and concern that the N.F.L. could do nothing to prevent carpetbagging by teams.
The saga ended with an agreement to reseed the Browns as an expansion team, build a publicly financed stadium for $283 million (with nearly all revenue going to the team) and orchestrate a high-profile auction, which led to Lerner's buying the team for what was then a record sum. (The $800 million sale of the Washington Redskins to a group led by the New York real estate magnate Howard Milstein is pending.)
"If you gave me a team for free in any other city, I wouldn't take it," Lerner said. "This is the only team I have any intention to own."
Without a game played, every seat, luxury box and club seat in the stadium is sold out. Combine the stadium cash with $58.1 million in network television money this year (and steadily more in each year thereafter), and profitability looks imminent.
"We'll make a profit," Lerner said. "But do you produce a return as good as a Government bond? Not for a long time. But you can't watch your T-bills play. This is a business, but it's not a business. You have to win. It wouldn't be a success if it only made money."
The rebirth of the Browns introduces high expectations, which Lerner is underwriting with his desire to spend what is necessary for talent; to rebuild five outdoor practice fields and redo the Berea headquarters for $2 million, and to restock a weight room left empty when Modell left.
But the hopes are fueled by the near-instant prosperity of the previous expansion teams, the Jacksonville Jaguars and the Carolina Panthers. After coming to life in 1994, they played in their conferences' championship games the next season. Never mind that Jacksonville and Carolina had nearly two years to prepare for their first college draft and the Browns barely six months. Never mind that the Browns are not guaranteed top draft picks in their second season, as their expansion predecessors did. And never mind that Lerner, Policy and Dwight Clark, the vice president for football operations, have never built an expansion team.
"This is more difficult than I thought," said Policy, the former San Francisco 49ers president, who has a 10 percent stake in the team. "Managing the 49ers during the 90's is entirely different from what we're experiencing now. We had a structure in place. We had to maintain, fine-tune and improve it. But it's daunting to start from nothing."
For the Browns, the future is virtually now.
"We need to be competitive in Year 2 or 3," said Clark, whom Policy brought from San Francisco and who has imported 12 former 49ers. "We have higher expectations than the people outside this building."
"The 1999 win-loss record is of low priority, at least to the architects," Policy said. "We want to compete for the A.F.C. Central championship in 2000."
Said Lerner: "They have to be realistic. I don't. I want to win every game."
Palmer, 49, who was hired for his teaching skills, started his quest to become a head coach a year ago. He was a head coach at Boston University and the University of New Haven, but an assistant since then with the Houston Oilers, the New England Patriots and Jacksonville.
"When you're close to 50, your options start to dry up," he said, sitting in a rented black chair in his office. His work with the Patriots and Jaguars, especially with young quarterbacks, was known to other teams, but he was not on the top rung of Cleveland's coaching candidates. Still, his "token" interview with Policy and Lerner went unexpectedly well, and he was hired for five years.
Jacksonville Coach Tom Coughlin, Palmer's boss from 1997 to 1998, advised him, "Get going, you're already behind."
Palmer knows about high expectations. He is reminded of them when he sees how little time he has to invest the team with chemistry and discipline and satisfy fans who have waited three years to see their Browns. He knows it from the task of dealing with his assistant coaches, most of whom he has never worked with. He knows it from the bus driver who shouted at him, "Take the quarterback, it's what you know," regarding the April 17 college draft.
"This is not the real world," Palmer said. "I go to lunch in a place near here and you see a sign that says, '154 days until Browns football,' and I can't enjoy lunch very much. We have two years to win."
How quickly the Browns win may depend on whom they choose with the expected No. 1 pick in the draft. It could be a quarterback, like Tim Couch of Kentucky or Akili Smith of Oregon, or it could be the Heisman Trophy-winning running back Ricky Williams of Texas.
That top choice -- and others -- would add to to the core built through the expansion draft (with onetime Browns cornerback Antonio Langham the main pickup), free agency (Kirby, free safety Marquez Pope, offensive tackle Lomas Brown and defensive tackle John Jurkovic) and trades (quarterback Ty Detmer, defensive lineman Roy Barker and tight end Irv Smith, all from the 49ers, who were clearing salary-cap room, center Dave Wohlabaugh and linebacker Chris Spielman).
"If one of those quarterbacks can take us all the way, we have to take him," said Clark, "even if he goes through what Peyton Manning did." But Clark remembers how Joe Montana broke in with the 49ers under Coach Bill Walsh: "Bill had Joe watch until he started for the first time in the middle of the second season."
Couch seemed like the Browns' certain choice until Smith's workout with the team raised his profile. The Browns could deal their top pick; New Orleans Saints Coach Mike Ditka has offered all his draft picks to leap into the first or second slot and take Williams.
"The decision on the first pick will affect me more than anyone else," Palmer said. "If it's a good pick, I get to stay a while. If it's not, I don't. I just want to be the first Browns coach to get a contract extension."
All he need do is mold Couch (or Smith) into a Lake Erie version of Montana, take the Browns to the American Football Conference championship game in 2001, and turn Al Lerner's $530 million gamble into a sure thing.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1240 words

HEADLINE: Low Prices Have Sapped Little Oil Producers

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Even after a 30 percent jump in crude oil prices last month, Terry Smith, the general manager of the Tidelands Oil Production Company, is not sure it is time to begin reopening oil wells.
Tidelands has 834 wells off the coast of Long Beach, Calif., but it has shut 327 of them in the last year as oil prices plunged. 
 Prices had been so low for so long that Mr. Smith is reluctant to spend the $30,000 it takes to bring a well back and rehire workers, even though he says he makes a profit when prices are $10 a barrel. West Texas intermediate crude oil traded at above $17 a barrel this week for the first time in more than a year, largely on the strength of cutbacks announced by big oil producers last month.
But Mr. Smith's cash has been depleted, he has laid off a third of his workers and, as with thousands of other small independent producers, he is worried that prices might collapse again. "I want to see if this thing is going to stabilize," he said in a telephone interview.
Independent oil companies like Tidelands account for 40 percent of the oil produced in the United States. Many are facing the same kinds of hard choices that Mr. Smith confronts. While they have seen many downturns, the last year has hit them particularly hard, with crude prices at a low of $10.35 a barrel in December. Their problems make it unlikely that domestic production, which hit a 50-year low of about six million barrels a day last month, will recover soon.
Those that have suffered most and will have the hardest time recovering are the very small producers. They typically own about 10 so-called stripper wells. Many motorists glimpse wells of this type from the highways in states like California, Texas, Oklahoma, and Kansas, the pumps slowly bobbing up and down, extracting about 2.2 barrels a day at each unit from old and often declining fields.
Even though they produce very small amounts individually, together they account for 1.3 million barrels a day. That is about 20 percent of domestic output and roughly the amount the United States imports daily from Saudi Arabia.
While lower crude oil prices have enabled consumers to enjoy some of the lowest gasoline prices in decades, and cheap oil has contributed to low inflation, those working in the domestic oil industry have paid a heavy price for these benefits.
About 52,000 jobs have been lost since October 1997 in oil and natural gas production, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Many of these will not be replaced.
There are 574,000 oil wells in the nation capable of producing an average total of 6.4 million barrels a day, but about 136,000 of them have been shut temporarily. Of those wells, which are capable of producing about 550,000 barrels a day, some oil economists and industry experts predict that up to half could be abandoned.
The loss of production could turn out to be as high as 400,000 barrels a day. Some experts say many wells that will be restarted are likely to produce at lower rates because of equipment and technical problems.
Such a large loss of output means that domestic oil production is expected to continue to decline even if prices maintain their current levels. Last month, imported oil made up more than 55 percent of the United States supply, one of the highest levels ever, and increasing dependence on imported oil is likely to continue.
"It not just like turning the tap back on and we recover the production that has been lost," said Scott Espenshade, the senior economist at the Independent Petroleum Association of America.
Of particular concern is the loss of the skills and knowledge of experienced workers who have been laid off and moved on to other fields. The losses range from crews that can handle the tough job of drilling and keeping wells producing to the extensive web of thousands of small and large companies that provide services and equipment that enable many small producers to operate.
Mr. Smith of Tidelands, for example, said most of the 65 workers he had laid off had found other jobs in the strong California economy and would not return to the volatile oil industry. Thus, he will face the expense and strain of training new people. And once he decides to bring the wells back he will have problems finding contractors to help with the work because some have gone out of business or cut back severely themselves.
And many among those who have been laid off have been struggling, especially in places where the local economy is not strong, like the area around Great Bend, Kan., a city of about 15,500 in the central part of the state some 90 miles northwest of Wichita.
After spending 32 years in the oil industry, Dan Murta, who lives in Great Bend, lost his job as vice president with Tomkat Ltd. a small independent oil company based in Wichita. From a salary of $45,000 a year, he said, he was now reduced to earning little more than minimum wage as a telemarketer.
In past downturns, Mr. Murta recalled, he was able to fall back on being a consultant to the industry for $200 to $300 a day. But so many producers have shut down that even that has dried up.
"There's no opportunity out here," he said. "I just couldn't find anything."
At 56, he says he should be at the height of his career, with skills and knowledge that the industry has increasingly found difficult to replace once a recovery is under way.
Mr. Murta recalled that the Halliburton Company, the Dallas-based company that is one of the world's biggest providers of oilfield services, once had seven centers in Kansas where those in the business could get equipment and workers to maintain and drill wells. But because of cutbacks by the company, which merged with Dresser Industries, the only office left is in Liberty, Kan.
When he began working for Texaco in 1973, Mr. Murta recalled, eight big oil companies had operations in Great Bend. "They've all gone," he added, and some of their buildings stand empty.
Danny Biggs is the general field superintendent of the Pickrell Drilling Company of Great Bend, which has about 300 wells in the area, of which 50 are shut. He is worried that even if prices are high, he may have trouble gearing up again. As wells sit idle, all kinds of problems can develop, including water seeping into fields and cracking in pipes.
"It's like letting a car sit around for six months," Mr. Biggs said. "You don't know what might go wrong." His company, however, has the financial strength to recover because the wells that have kept pumping have provided enough cash flow.
Others are not as fortunate.
Virginia Banks Lazenby, the chairwoman of the Bretagne Corporation, a 600-well independent based in Nashville, said that while her company was able to conserve enough cash to rebuild, many people did not have the capital. "It's going to be an extended time before they can begin reinvesting," she said.
Even the smaller producers might have to invest $10,000 to $15,000 to get a well pumping again. That is a substantial sum when, in a good year, with crude oil prices in the range of $17 to $18 a barrel, a producer with 10 wells might net about $10,000.
"It's going to be harder for the small producer to find the capital," Ms. Lazenby said. "That's why not everyone is going to get back in."
She was also pessimistic about the long-term future for small operators. "There are few young people coming in," she said. "They're just tired of fighting it."

HEADLINE: Statehouse Journal;
School Crisis Chips Away at New Hampshire's Anti-Tax Stance

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Does this sound like the New Hampshire known for its ferocious aversion to taxes?
Polls have found that when New Hampshire residents are asked how the state should respond to a court decision requiring it to end its heavy reliance on local property taxes to pay for schools, hefty proportions favor an income tax. 
 The school financial crisis is now in overtime. Despite marathon sessions, lawmakers missed their court-imposed April 1 deadline to come up with a new system, and no one here is predicting confidently when or how it will end.
The Republican-controlled state House of Representatives passed a bill three weeks ago that would have established a 3.5 percent income tax. The state Senate, which turned majority-Democrat last November for the first time since 1912, passed its own version late last month, but the House backtracked last Tuesday and rejected the Senate version.
The Democratic Governor, Jeanne Shaheen, true to her pledge to resist sweeping new taxes, has vowed to veto any income tax -- a veto that is not likely to be overridden. And teachers are beginning to receive warning slips that their jobs may be in question next fall.
But one fact has emerged clearly from the muddle: New Hampshire no longer seems such a granite monolith of anti-tax sentiment.
It is one of only two states without an income or sales tax. (The other is Alaska, which is considering an income tax proposal of its own.) But the school-financing issue has brought out signs that the "Live Free or Die" sentiment that is emblazoned on New Hampshire's license plates, and that has long influenced the state's first-in-the-nation Presidential primary, may be mellowing.
"I don't want to exaggerate the changes," said John Camobreco, an assistant professor of political science at the University of New Hampshire who specializes in state politics. "But there are significantly more people, I think, who sort of see that whole 'pledge' and the whole anti-income tax thing as sort of antiquated."
The "pledge" embodies the essence of New Hampshire's anti-tax sentiment. For state politicians, it is the pledge to oppose any sales or income tax, and most candidates have taken the pledge since the state's largest newspaper, the conservative Manchester Union Leader, began insisting on it in 1972.
Presidential contenders here are prodded to make a parallel Federal commitment to low taxes, and New Hampshire's tax phobia thus translates into a national advantage for anti-tax candidates.
But the pledge has come under such a heavy attack as the Statehouse strives to solve its school-financing conundrum that even a Republican State Senator, James Squires, was quoted in The Union Leader today as saying that the pledge "stifles our thinking and diminishes our capacity for logic."
A Democratic State Senator, Katherine Wells Wheeler, said New Hampshire's tax structure "for a long time was set by one newspaper," referring to The Union Leader. "All evidence indicates that newspaper is losing its influence," she added, and that "is helping to allow people to think more independently."
The tax question has also brought to the fore the voices of income tax supporters who normally kept quiet, said Fran Chapman, chairman of the Granite State Taxpayers Inc., a taxpayers' organization.
"What's happened is some people were scared to talk about it, and now they're saying, 'Let's get out there and do it,' " Mr. Chapman said.
What happened to spur this debate is a decision by the state Supreme Court in 1997 that the system of paying for public schools almost entirely local, with spending-per-pupil varying significantly from town to town, was unconstitutional.
The decision threw this state of 1.2 million people into the kind of dilemma that about 30 other states have faced. New Hampshire is very much like the rest of the country, said Clark Hubbard, a political science professor at the University of New Hampshire, in that "everybody wants good services and nobody wants to pay for them."
But in a way, everything matters a bit more here, because this is the staging ground for future Presidents.
Professor Hubbard said that in next year's primaries, "I wouldn't predict a major backing away from the tax pledge just because it's almost a cultural part of the primary now and so it has kind of a traditional ring to it." But he added, "It may be, over the next couple of election cycles, that New Hampshire will no longer be able to claim that special tax-exempt status, and will begin to put less emphasis on taxes as a Presidential issue."
The national candidates who are now starting to campaign here will be stepping into the school-financing crisis at their own risk.
Bill Shaheen, the state chairman for Vice President Al Gore's campaign, said that Mr. Gore "basically asked me what he should say, and I said, 'What do you think you should say?' And his response was absolutely correct, that this was a local issue and should be decided by the local people of New Hampshire."
A yet unanswered question is whether the candidates will conclude that New Hampshire is not as libertarian-leaning as they had thought, and tailor their campaigns accordingly.
The basis for such a conclusion is the idea that the income tax sentiment is a sign of demographic change. For a generation, New Hampshire has been the fastest-growing state in New England; its population nearly doubled in the last 30 years as it transformed itself from a farm-and-mill backwater to a high-tech powerhouse.
Well over half the state's residents came from elsewhere, many from places where they had become used to much heavier and broader-based taxes. So the prospect of an income tax, the theory goes, holds little terror for them.
But a countertheory holds that the newer residents sought to escape high taxes elsewhere, and so they are more likely to oppose an income tax. State Senator Beverly A. Hollingworth, a Democrat, said, "When you talk to the native New Hampshire people, they are the ones in general who support making change and providing for education."
Senator Wells Wheeler puts it this way: "We're maturing. We're realizing our social obligations. We're realizing we can't live independently with just a barn-raising to help our neighbors."
Also influencing the discussion, some say, is the growing emphasis on education, as demonstrated in polls showing it is the No. 1 issue.
The Legislature has been examining dozens of plans for raising the $1 billion or so to pay for public schools. Some have included a statewide property tax; others have involved gambling taxes, business taxes and entertainment taxes. New Hampshire already has one of the highest property tax burdens in the nation, and much of the discussion has focused on how best to shift that load.
Political analysts expect the Legislature to find some solution in the next few weeks, even if it is only a provisional plan for the year.
Though the court decision carried no explicit penalty for missing the deadline, as of Thursday, the start of the new financial year, it became illegal for towns to collect local property taxes for schools. That means all kinds of possible complications for the next school year, from hiring teachers to sending out tax bills. School administrators look with dread toward July 1, when money will run out unless the Legislature comes up with a workable plan.
The state's consideration of tax plans has frazzled lawmakers but has provided a fabulous civics lesson at meetings and debates throughout New Hampshire, said Mr. Chapman of the Granite State Taxpayers. One forum was so lively it reminded him of a revival meeting, he said.
Mr. Camobreco, at the University of New Hampshire, said that in the end new light may be cast on the nature of New Hampshire, but it is important to be wary of ascribing major change to the state's politics.
"Yes, there are people who voted for an income tax," he said. "But they never would've gotten a chance to cast that vote without the Supreme Court -- never in a million years."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Bond Market Rises Sharply On Jobs Data

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
A smaller-than-expected increase in nonfarm payroll jobs last month, in part a result of a decline in manufacturing jobs, set off the bond market's best rally in four weeks yesterday.
The bond market is normally closed on Good Friday, but trading yesterday occurred until noon. But in a special shortened session, held to allow trading after the 8:30 A.M. release of the March employment data, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond jumped 1 2/32, to 95 1/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.59 percent from 5.67 percent on Thursday. 
 The rally came after a two-day selloff that started with the report of data from National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago and continued with the report of the National Association of Purchasing Management. Both reports indicated that manufacturing was rebounding strongly.
The signs of an additional lift to economic growth, given the already strong consumer spending, raised concerns among many traders about a possible interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve later this year.
But the employment data showed that manufacturing payrolls fell by 35,000 jobs last month and were down by 374,000 since March 1998. "The employment report does tend to alleviate some of the anxieties from the purchasing managers reports," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the March jobs data showed that "at best, manufacturing has just flattened out."
In addition to calming fears about a surge in manufacturing, the jobs report showed once again that the economy seems to be able to grow strongly without generating inflationary pressures. One of the key measures of wage inflation, hourly earnings, rose just two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same pace as in February.
"Here we get another report saying the economy is strong and labor is tight," said James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "But there is no inflationary imbalance." The reason, he said, is that with the rest of the world's economy growing sluggishly or worse, competition is preventing American companies from making price increases stick.
But analysts agreed that the low March job growth, which was clearly held back by bad weather and was well below Wall Street forecasts of 140,000, did not confirm that the economy was slowing significantly from the torrid 6 percent pace of growth in the fourth quarter of last year.
Because of this uncertainty, interest rates are likely to remain in their recent trading range, with long-term rates centered around 5.5 percent. Interest rates first jumped to this level in February after it became clear that the economy had entered 1999 at a much stronger pace than expected and would not slow down quickly, as many Wall street economists had forecast at the end of last year.
"There are elements of moderation coming through, but it is not very compelling yet," said Mr. Glassman, whose forecast for the year is one of the slower on Wall Street.
Mr. Fine said that consumer spending was still so strong that barring a sudden collapse in the stock market, it would take some time for the economy to slow significantly. He is forecasting 3 percent to 3.5 percent growth for the first quarter.
He said such a pace would normally be "a little too rapid for the Fed." But given that inflation remains in check and that the pace of growth would be slowing, he said the Fed should be happy. "If the Fed was on hold before, this would give them more breathing room," he said.
Mr. Fine said that the Fed could not cut interest rates because the economy was still too strong. But it cannot raise rates either, he argued, because inflation is not a threat now and because of the fragility of the global economy, with both Latin America and Asia struggling to turn themselves around.
Based on the performance of the futures contracts on the Federal funds rate, the Federal Reserve's target short-term interest rate, some investors still think that the next move by the central bank will be up. The yield on the contract for October has risen in the last two days to 4.93 percent, which is almost a quarter-percentage-point above the Fed's current 4.75 percent target, which it left unchanged at its policy-making meeting Tuesday.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Halcyon Days for Airlines, If Not for Many Passengers

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
These are truly boom times for the nation's airlines: their earnings are stronger than ever and they flew a record 611 million passengers last year without a single fatality. And they did so while maintaining their on-time performance and without a significant increase in officially registered complaints.
So successful, and yet, by many accounts, they have never been so unloved. 
 "The more you fly, the more aware you are that there's a pattern of indifferent service," said Carl Hughes, the president of Fahey Bank in Marion, Ohio. Although he has experienced exemplary service on flights, the bad has lately outnumbered the good, he said. For example, it took him 23 hours to fly from Columbus, Ohio, to Belfast, Northern Ireland, last spring, rather than the usual nine hours, because of a series of delays, cancellations and what he said was a lack of concern from most of the six airlines he dealt with on the trip.
Many other travelers have tales of woe. The complaints, of course, are not new: poor service, scant leg room, lost or mishandled baggage, incomplete or misleading information about delayed flights, overbooking and frustration with frequent-flier miles that are easy to accumulate but next to impossible to use. But recent air-travel fiascos -- the January snowstorm in Detroit that trapped people on Northwest Airlines planes for hours and the sickout by pilots in February that at times caused more than half of AMR's American Airlines' flights to be canceled -- have swung a spotlight on passenger complaints.
Now, Congress and Vice President Al Gore have seized on the issue. They have proposed doubling the maximum compensation for being bumped from a flight, requiring that all tickets be refundable within 48 hours of purchase and that airlines disclose their cancellation and flight delay policies and tell how many seats on flights are available for frequent fliers.
They are pushing for changes even though few want a return to full-blown airline regulation, abolished in 1978, and even though Transportation Department statistics show that the number of consumer complaints filed has remained steady in recent years and was just 9,606 last year. (Critics, especially travel agents, say few travelers bother to file complaints with the agency, which does little more than categorize the complaints.)
"When I look at all the numbers, I have to conclude the system is working pretty well, considering its complexity," said Dean Headley, an assistant professor of marketing at Wichita State University in Kansas, who has analyzed the complaints filed last year with the Transportation Department. "The airlines do what they promised, getting people from A to B. But passengers seem to be saying, 'We like what you do, we just don't like the way you're doing it.' "
In a University of Michigan nationwide survey of 2,000 adults released in February, airlines were ranked 31st (tied with network broadcasters) among 34 industries in terms of customer satisfaction.
In many ways, airlines are victims of their own success. More people flying more places has taxed the air traffic control system and jammed airports, causing bad tempers and frayed nerves.
Carol Hallet, president of the Air Transport Association, the trade group for 23 United States airlines, contends that about two-thirds of all delays are the fault of weather and inefficiencies in the Government's air traffic control system, which handles, on average, 21,000 flights a day. The system, she said, is inadequate to handle the existing traffic, much less the air traffic in the next decade, when the number of passengers is expected to rise to a billion from 611 million.
Still, the industry's image continues to take a battering. At Congressional hearings last month, passengers caught by the snowstorm in Detroit told of being forced to endure more than seven hours trapped in a plane without food, water or usable lavatories. Travel agents at the hearings criticized airlines for selling tickets for flights that were already overbooked.
Some influential lawmakers are sympathetic. Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is chairman of the Commerce Committee, has sponsored, along with Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, the Airline Passenger Fairness Act, which would enable air travelers to find out whether the flights they are booked on have been oversold.
"Every American traveler has the right to the same kinds of basic protections when they buy an airline ticket that they do at the corner grocery store," Mr. McCain said.
The airline industry contends that overbooking is a response to no-show passengers. The number of extra seats sold is not determined arbitrarily, industry officials say, but by tracking historical data to determine how many passengers are expected to show up for the flight. And the number of passengers bumped from flights has declined over the last five years, according to the Transportation Department -- to 44,797 passengers last year (or 0.87 for every 10,000 passengers) from 60,636 in 1994 (1.27 per 10,000).
There is similar legislation being pushed in the House by Representative Bud Shuster, a Pennsylvania Republican and chairman of the House Transportation Committee. Mr. Gore has also proposed "passenger rights" legislation. Among other things, the proposals would require airlines to tell passengers when and why flights are delayed, canceled or diverted to another airport and to provide information about all fares, including fares offered through E-mail and on Web sites.
The Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington-based research group, estimated that the proposed measure could cost airlines $6 billion in lost revenues and would result in higher fares, lower industry efficiency and customer service. The industry earned $5.1 billion last year.
Privately, airlines executives contend that the measures are in large part a product of political posturing, as officials seek to gain exposure and win votes from disgruntled air travelers.
Nonetheless, the airlines' trade group, the Air Transport Association, acknowledges that the industry needs to burnish its image. It recently pledged to make efforts to see that passengers get timely and accurate information about flight delays and cancellations, and that travelers be quoted the lowest fare available for which they qualify.
"We're definitely responding," said David Fuscus, a spokesman for the trade group, "as you tend to do when you have the Vice President and the head of the Senate and House committees that oversee your industry making suggestions."
Pledges and statistics, however, may not be enough to assuage some passengers.
"Regardless of what airlines or what time I fly between New York and Los Angeles," said Leslie Goldman, a book editor in Manhattan who flies regularly, "there's always a long, long wait to get to the terminal after we land."
Ihor Chyzowycg, a soccer coach in Cincinnati, was with other coaches on a plane set to fly to Florida when the flight was canceled. "People at the gate told us the weather there was too bad to land, but didn't say why we were boarded and taxied out to the runway in the first place," he said. "And after we sat in the airport an hour, they reboarded us on another plane, and off we went without any more talk about the weather."
Those kinds of experiences have fueled suspicion that the weather and mechanical trouble are often excuses to cancel lightly filled flights, or to double up on later flights. Airlines vehemently deny they do that, saying even a single cancellation ripples throughout the system and is therefore more costly than flying a nearly empty plane.
Such suspicions are likely to linger, as long as airports are crowded and airplanes are cramped, some experts say. "There seems to be a new level of expectations," noted Professor Headley of Wichita State, "and it isn't sinking in to the airline industry."
"For as good as air service is, the airlines have to understand that perception is reality."

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate In U.S. Hits 29-Year Low

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
The nation's jobless rate dropped in March to its lowest level in 29 years, the Labor Department reported yesterday, falling from 4.4 percent in February to 4.2 percent in the latest of many signs that the labor market in the United States remains remarkably robust.
But in a break from the feverish hiring of the last three years, American companies added far fewer new workers to their payrolls last month than had been typical lately. 
 After creating nearly 300,000 additional jobs in February, employers expanded payrolls by a mere 46,000 in March when a burst of cold weather held down the usual seasonal upswing in hiring in industries from construction and landscaping to fast food. Still, hiring was nearly as strong as ever in most of the vast service economy.
Indeed, for workers, particularly those at the bottom of the economic ladder, the recent experience with sustained low unemployment -- the jobless rate has been at or below 4.5 percent for nearly a year -- has clearly started to deliver some solid benefits. The 30-year trend that has depressed pay and job opportunities the most for the least educated and the least skilled seems to have been stopped dead in its tracks, at least for now.
"What's really exciting about this report is that our policies are working well for the people who need it the most," said Labor Secretary Alexis Herman. "We haven't just touched them, we've literally propelled them into the new economy."
In a striking turnaround, the jobless rate among high school dropouts fell to 6.1 percent in March, from 7.5 percent in February. A one-month change is not necessarily reliable, but that is now half the jobless rate that dropouts faced in 1992.
The unemployment rate for those with only a high school degree -- 3.4 percent -- now resembles what used to be typical for college graduates.
"A lot of people who used to be hiring college grads are setting their sights lower," said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass. "Or if they were hiring high school grads, they're saying, 'I can get by with a high school dropout.' "
Minorities are benefiting enormously from the heavy demand for workers. Last month, for example, joblessness among Hispanic workers fell to 5.8 percent, the lowest level since the Labor Department began compiling statistics separately on the group in the early 1970's. "The fastest-growing population is taking real advantage of this fast-growing economy," Ms. Herman said.
The rate for blacks was 8.1 percent, close to the historic lows reached a couple of months ago. By comparison, the jobless rate for whites was 3.6 percent.
To be sure, the unemployment rate fell in March largely because of a sharp contraction in the labor force. (The unemployment rate is calculated from data gathered from a survey of households, different from the payroll statistics collected from employers.) But the labor force had been growing about 50 percent faster than its long-term trend of about 1 percent a year and seemed simply to have fallen back in line with the long-term pattern in March.
For investors, the pause in job creation came as a reassuring hint that economic growth was cooling from the superhot 6 percent rate at the end of last year to a more sustainable pace. That makes it less likely that inflation might speed up or that the Federal Reserve would be tempted to raise interest rates.
The stock market was closed yesterday for Good Friday, but the bond market, in abbreviated trading, registered its relief by pushing the rate on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond down to 5.59 percent from 5.67 percent on Thursday.
Still, signs abound that the labor market continues to be extraordinarily tight. New jobless claims are at unusually low levels, help-wanted advertising remains near its highs and a record proportion of consumers are reporting that jobs are plentiful.
One telling detail in yesterday's jobs report: the number of people who quit their jobs voluntarily jumped to 13.5 percent, the highest rate in a year and a half and evidence that American workers are feeling confident about their prospects of finding good jobs.
Job opportunities varied widely from industry to industry. A spring cold snap following unusually mild weather this winter accounted for a drop of 47,000 jobs in the booming construction business.
The weather may also have been responsible for the failure of fast-food chains to hire as many workers as they usually do at this time of the year; that trimmed 48,000 jobs from the eating and drinking industry. Landscaping and other agricultural services were down 8,000 jobs.
But Tom Nardone, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said that the seasonal quirks should not be allowed to obscure the broader picture. "Outside the sectors that were affected by the weather," he said, "you had the same pattern of hiring that you've been seeing for months."
As hundreds of layoff announcements over the last few months foreshadowed, manufacturers are still tightening their belts. In March, they trimmed another 35,000 workers from their payrolls, bringing the total number of jobs lost to 391,000 over the last year. That weakness seems, on the face of it, to contradict recent reports from purchasing managers suggesting a broad recovery in manufacturing.
More likely, however, the dichotomy reflects ferocious price competition, which is forcing manufacturers to clamp down on costs to sustain reasonable production.
Service companies, on the other hand, added 95,000 new positions, close to the average of 112,000 a month over the last year. Management consultants and engineers were in as much demand as ever. Banks, brokerage firms, insurers and other companies involved in financial services added workers by the thousands.
Health care companies, schools and universities, and movie chains, amusement parks and other entertainment businesses did lots of hiring, too.
For those wondering whether the good times can continue, one of the most reassuring bits of news in the report was the absence of any speed- up in wage gains. "The wage gains are surprisingly tame," said Paul Kasriel, chief United States economist at Northern Trust Bank in Chicago. "If anything we've seen a slight deceleration."
The hourly pay of nonsupervisory workers -- admittedly a smaller and smaller slice of the work force -- rose by 3 cents, to $13.09, in March, 3.6 percent higher than a year earlier. In April 1998, hourly pay had risen 4.4 percent over the previous 12 months.
Still, with the change in the Consumer Price Index running at around 1.6 percent a year and other gauges showing even lower levels of inflation, that represents a solid gain in the standard of living of average workers.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: OVERVIEW;
NATO HITS BELGRADE CENTER FOR FIRST TIME, RAZING COMMAND SITES FOR KOSOVO FIGHTING

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
After nine days of hesitation, NATO attacked the center of Yugoslavia's capital, destroying the headquarters of the security forces carrying out President Slobodan Milosevic's offensive against the ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.
A barrage of seven cruise missiles -- fired from American warships in the Adriatic -- struck just before 1 A.M. Saturday in Belgrade, the officials said. A British submarine, the Splendid, fired an eighth cruise missile at another target outside Belgrade, they said, declining to specify where. 
 The Pentagon refused tonight to disclose the targets hit, but flames raged from two buildings near the Sava River in Belgrade's core, the Federal Ministry for Internal Affairs and the Serbian Ministry of the Interior. The buildings house the headquarters of the paramilitary police forces that have carried out Mr. Milosevic's yearlong crackdown against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.
It was the first time in 10 days of attacks that NATO had struck the center of Belgrade, a once-thriving capital that has slowly withered under years of economic sanctions and diplomatic isolation caused by Mr. Milosevic's policies.
Although previous attacks battered military targets on Belgrade's edges, the missiles tonight struck with a thunderous clap that shook the entire capital. Within minutes of the first explosion, an enormous arc of flames soared hundreds of feet into the air.
The extent of casualties from the strikes was not immediately clear, but the attack occurred in the middle of the night, at a time when the buildings would presumably have few people in them.
The two buildings are close to other government buildings, including a hospital. But it appeared that the cruise missiles -- each with a 1,000-pound warhead -- struck their targets with pinpoint precision, leaving other buildings nearby still standing.
But Yugoslavia's Deputy Prime Minister, Vuk Draskovic, said there were "many, many victims."
Militarily and psychologically, the strikes were the first firm evidence that NATO was carrying out the warning by its commander, Gen. Wesley K. Clark, that there would be "no sanctuary" for Yugoslavia's political and military leaders.
Earlier this week NATO gave General Clark the authority to expand the raids beyond strictly military targets in or near Kosovo. On Thursday American F-15's destroyed a bridge over the Danube River in the city of Novi Sad, and Pentagon and NATO officials have vowed that more bridges and other targets in cities would be pounded as long as Mr. Milosevic continued his repression in Kosovo.
The targets of this phase of NATO's campaign -- first the bridge, then the two Ministry buildings -- are being deliberately chosen and timed to maximize their psychological impact and to leave the Yugoslav authorities uncertain of when and where the next strike will be, a senior Administration official said. The official said other buildings, like the Ministry of Defense, were on the target list.
Tonight's strikes came after nine days of bombing had made little progress in slowing Mr. Milosevic's onslaught against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. Refugees continued to pour into Albania and Macedonia, telling of killings and forced expulsions from villages, towns and cities throughout the province.
The mushrooming refugee crisis along Kosovo's border -- where hundreds of thousands of refugees have gathered, short of food and shelter -- has put new pressure on the United States and NATO to step up the campaign, even if that means considering the use of ground troops. While NATO officials have discussed the possibility of NATO troops' escorting ethnic Albanians back to Kosovo and protecting a self-governing enclave there, those plans are preliminary, and senior officials here in Washington said the Administration continued to adamantly oppose any proposal to use ground troops in combat in the Balkans.
President Clinton, facing sharp questions at a White House news briefing, appealed for patience and expressed confidence that an air campaign alone would be able to achieve NATO's military and political objectives in Yugoslavia.
"We must be determined," Mr. Clinton said. "We must be persistent. We must be patient if we expect to see this mission through. And I am absolutely determined to do that. We have to make sure that Mr. Milosevic pays a heavy price for this policy of repression. We have to seriously diminish his capacity to maintain that policy."
The NATO air campaign has been severely hampered by the Balkan weather, with rain, low clouds and fog forcing many warplanes to abandon their targets. Through the first nine nights, alliance aircraft flew about 2,700 missions over or near Yugoslavia, 405 of them combat strikes. The Pentagon estimated that 20 percent of the missions had been scrubbed because of foul weather, but other officials have said the number was much higher.
Earlier today, a number of NATO warplanes -- including F-16's and F-15's -- took advantage of a brief break in the rainy weather to launch the first daylight air raids against Yugoslav forces. The jets attacked ground forces operating near the center of Kosovo, NATO and Pentagon officials said, declining to identify what was struck.
By nightfall, however, clouds and rain once again blanketed the region, forcing frustrated NATO commanders to limit their attacks to weapons unaffected by weather, including the Tomahawk cruise missiles that struck Belgrade tonight. Forecasts predict that the weather will clear over the weekend, and when it does, officials at NATO and the Pentagon said, the raids will increase in scope and intensity.
At NATO's headquarters in Brussels, officials said the brunt of the raids is now falling on ground forces directly involved in the campaign against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. A military spokesman, Air Commodore David Wilby of Britain, described a series of strikes against military targets on Thursday night.
One strike hit what he described as a support base for Yugoslavia's 243d Mechanized Brigade, which is now operating in the Pagarusa Valley, where thousands of Albanians have reportedly been surrounded by Yugoslav forces and repeatedly shelled. The Pentagon's spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon, said American B-1 bombers, joining the attacks for the first time, had also bombed a staging area for armored forces in Yugoslavia.
Despite those attacks, the Yugoslav forces have continued to press their offensive in the Pagarusa Valley and near Malisevo, a city west of Kosovo's capital, Pristina, that is the last stronghold of the Kosovo Liberation Army.
Intelligence reports collected here suggest that Mr. Milosevic's forces have largely routed the rebels of the Kosovo Liberation Army, but Commodore Wilby said today that the rebels remained a viable force.
He and other officials also said the Yugoslav forces were being slowed, if not stopped, by the cumulative effects of NATO's raids, particularly the destruction of fuel and ammunition depots. Commodore Wilby said one Yugoslav unit, the 549th Motorized Brigade, had been "immobilized" near Djakovica while waiting for more fuel.
He said that "therefore, NATO air-to-ground operations against fielded forces in Kosovo are already degrading and disrupting" the Yugoslav military's ability to use tanks.
Cruise missile strikes against fuel storage sites in Prokuplje on Wednesday and at Leskovac and Pristina on Thursday destroyed an estimated 35 percent of Yugoslavia's entire supply of fuel, a senior Pentagon official said today.
At the Pentagon, Mr. Bacon said the attacks were taking a toll on Yugoslav morale, too, though he offered little evidence to back that up.
"We clearly are having some impact on command and control," he said. "We're seeing some morale problems in the army. The forces are clearly more wary of being hit. They've had to disperse more and are having a harder time operating in large, coherent units."
But he also acknowledged the limits of the success. "We have not seen tanks stopped in their tracks, if that's what you mean," he said.
Despite signs of some progress, officials have pressed for new weapons that would allow NATO to intensify the attacks on the ground forces. General Clark has asked Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen to approve the use of Apache helicopter gunships -- used to attack tanks -- and long-range rocket batteries to support them.
Mr. Bacon said Mr. Cohen had not yet made a decision on the request. The helicopters would require large numbers of Army troops to move into the region --300 soldiers for a battalion of 18 helicopters -- and that has raised fears that it would amount to an introduction of American ground forces into the Balkans.
The sensitivity of bombing Belgrade was so great that Mr. Clinton himself approved the target list earlier this week and authorized the attack itself within the last 24 hours, an aide said. General Clark and other NATO planners chose the targets each day, but because of the possibility of substantial civilian loss of life, aides sought Mr. Clinton's specific approval for the attack on the two Ministries tonight.
