HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE PRESIDENT;
Attack Has 'Barely Begun,' Clinton Warns Milosevic

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2

 BODY:
As allied forces prepared their attack on downtown Belgrade today, the White House warned President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia that he had "barely begun" to feel NATO's bombers and cruise missiles attack.
Trying to halt any public doubts after 10 days of on-again, off-again bombing of Yugoslavia, President Clinton sought to assure Americans that the campaign against Mr. Milosevic would succeed. The bombing has so far done nothing to halt the Serbian advance through Kosovo province and the flood of refugees into neighboring countries. 
 And the White House sent a clear signal that it was turning the attack more directly on the Yugoslav leader and his high command.
"Milosevic has barely begun to incur the damage he will feel to his military and police and the security apparatus by which he keeps his dictatorship in power," Vice President Al Gore told reporters.
Earlier in the day, President Clinton, too, warned that Mr. Milosevic would pay a heavy price for continuing his policy of "ethnic cleansing."
The President said that despite the exodus of refugees from Kosovo, the military and political objectives of the Western allies were still attainable with an air campaign.
"I believe we have quite a good chance of achieving our objectives of the return of the Kosovars to live in security with a measure of self-government," Mr. Clinton told reporters today as he made a hastily announced appearance in the White House briefing room.
Mr. Gore described Mr. Milosevic's activity as so "morally unacceptable," and suggested that the bombing would be so extensive that a political settlement might be moot. "Whether or not a negotiation with Milosevic is ever again possible," he said, "that's an open question, frankly, because he has perpetrated these horrible crimes against humanity."
Expressing confidence that the bombing would succeed, Mr. Gore added of Mr. Milosevic: "He has forced many of those people from their homes before, and they have returned. These, too, will return."
The President spoke before the announcement tonight that NATO missiles had hit downtown Belgrade. Earlier this week he had approved a target list for the NATO strikes that included ministerial buildings and headquarters in Belgrade.
But this afternoon Mr. Clinton suggested that the framework of the failed peace talks in France would still serve as the basis for any settlement, and that NATO -- and the United States -- would help the refugees return to Kosovo and provide for their protection. For the Kosovars to live with some degree of autonomy, he said, "will require, clearly, for some period of time, some sort of international force that will be able to protect their security."
He added: "I think there will have to be some sort of security arrangement in order for them to live safely. And then there will have to be some sort of agreement that entails the autonomy to which they are entitled."
In Washington, the Administration has been considering a plan under which NATO troops would escort Albanians back into Kosovo after Serbian forces there had been routed by bombing, and would set up a self-governing enclave under allied protection, NATO officials have said.
But today Mr. Clinton still seemed frustrated by the difficulty in explaining the mission, its objectives and its ramifications. "Everyone is trying to get their hands around a very complex problem," he said.
Clinton aides said the President showed up in the briefing room today partly in response to television networks' requests for fresh footage of the President.
The President is measuring his responses to the Balkan war and also publicly engaging in other matters. He talked at the briefing today about the new unemployment figures, the lowest since 1970. He is planning a trip to Philadelphia next week to discuss health care. And he will be welcoming the Chinese Prime Minister to Washington next week as critical talks continue on China's entry into the World Trade Organization.
Mr. Clinton insisted today that Kosovo was not lost, but he also focused on the aid efforts that have been under way there for a year. With television images of Kosovo refugees streaming into Albania and Macedonia, Mr. Clinton continued to try to dispel the notion that the NATO bombing had aggravated Mr. Milosevic's violence and prompted the exodus.
Julia Taft, Assistant Secretary of State for Population, Refugees and Migration, said the Government had been working with relief agencies for more than a year to respond to the refugee problem. The United States has sent $91 million to the region since last year, and Mr. Clinton authorized $50 million more on Wednesday, officials said.

HEADLINE: An Environmentalist on a Different Path;
A Fresh View of the Supposed 'Wilderness' and Even the Indians' Place in It

DATELINE: MADISON, Wis.

 BODY:
On the short flight from Chicago on a clear cold day, the descent into Madison is not a bad way to begin to understand William Cronon and the ideas that have made him a pivotal and provocative figure in the growing field of environmental history.
Spread out below is the landscape of Mr. Cronon's childhood, where he hiked and camped and spent summers at his grandparents' lake-front cottage -- the fields and farms, woodlands and subdivisions, the city intertwined with its lakes, where he sees humans inextricably entangled with nature. 
 "I like a landscape that reminds one of those connections," he said in an interview. "Much as I love wilderness and much as I love Manhattan, I'm conscious when I'm in those places that it's hard to see how Manhattan is implicated in Yosemite or how Yosemite is implicated in Manhattan."
Which, he said, they very much are.
At 44, Mr. Cronon is one of the most influential figures in environmental history, the study of what Americans have done to and thought about the natural world, a field founded on the belief that human history cannot be understood without its natural context.
A Rhodes scholar and former MacArthur fellow who gave up tenure at Yale to return home in 1992 and teach at the University of Wisconsin, he is a generator of ideas that have repeatedly shaken up the ways people think about nature.
In a field that grew out of the environmental movement, he defies easy political labeling. He is on the board of governors of the Wilderness Society, but several years back he alienated many environmentalists by publishing an essay critiquing the very idea of wilderness.
He is also a slightly unorthodox member of the group of new Western historians who have rewritten the history of the American West, a mentor to many younger scholars and the author of several prize-winning and strikingly literary books that have become staples of history reading lists.
"Bill's real influence is that his work often gets translated into a larger American history," said Richard White, a Western and environmental historian at Stanford. "He has taken what is a subfield of American history and made it part of the basic literature of American history itself."
Mr. Cronon's first book, "Changes in the Land: Indians, Colonists and the Ecology of New England" (Hill & Wang, 1983), looked at the way plant and animal communities in colonial New England changed in the shift from Indian to European dominance. It revealed not only that people's ideas about property shape their environment but also that even the Indians had not lived passively on a pristine landscape.
His second book, "Nature's Metropolis: Chicago and the Great West" (W. W. Norton, 1991), a history of the relationship between 19th-century Chicago and its hinterland, is credited with having radically widened many environmental historians' gaze beyond such things as forests and public lands to include cities and what Mr. Cronon calls the "elaborate and intimate linkages" between city and country.
Then in 1995, he published the essay called "The Trouble With Wilderness," which appeared in The New York Times Magazine and the next year in a book he edited. In it he challenged the environmental movement's focus on wilderness as an ideal. He called the dream of an untouched landscape a fantasy of people who had never had to work the land for a living and suggested it posed "a serious threat to responsible environmentalism at the end of the century."
He wrote, "The flight from history that is very nearly the core of wilderness represents the false hope of an escape from responsibility, the illusion that if we can somehow wipe clean the slate of our past and return to the tabula rasa that supposedly existed before we began to leave our marks on the world." That leaves little room, he continued, for figuring out "what an ethical, sustainable, honorable human place in nature might actually look like."
Many environmentalists remain infuriated by the essay. They accuse Mr. Cronon of misunderstanding the conservation movement, ignoring biology and caring too little about the political consequences of his critique. They accuse him of such sins as relativism and anthropocentrism, ceding to human beings too prominent a place in the hierarchy of life.
"I must confess I'm getting a bit grumpy about the dumb arguments being put forth by high-paid intellectual types in which they are trying to knock Nature, knock the people who value Nature and still come out smelling smart and progressive," Gary Snyder, the poet and environmentalist, wrote in Wild Earth in an issue of the wilderness-protection quarterly that was devoted to answering Mr. Cronon.
Yet after Mr. Cronon's essay appeared, he was invited to join the Wilderness Society's governing council, in part because its chairman at the time, Christopher Elliman, thought Mr. Cronon could carry on the society's tradition of fostering original thinking about wilderness while also nudging the environmental movement forward.
"The point is, we're so implicated in nature that you can't just stop now," said Michael Pollan, an author who writes frequently on environmental topics and who admires Mr. Cronon's work. "Once you've changed the world, you have a responsibility to stay involved. Then the issues get much harder: How do you weed a wilderness? Do you encourage fire? Do you set fire?
"You get into all these gray areas where Bill is happy to go and that I find very exciting to think about. But most environmentalists, who may be shrewder politically than we are, know that it's a very hard place to go, and you're going to get into all sorts of trouble. It's so much easier to say, 'Lock it up and throw away the key' with a piece of land."
"We're very invested in a stark opposition between nature and culture," he added. "And Bill is interested in breaking that down. That breaks a lot of china, too; it goes to the heart of Americans' ideas about nature."
Environmental history first took shape in American universities in the late 1960's and early 70's as younger historians interested in environmentalism began emerging from graduate school dissatisfied with what their elders were calling history.
Donald Worster, a 57-year-old historian at the University of Kansas whom many see as the dean of the field, recalled in an interview that when he was a graduate student at Yale, every American historian in the department seemed to be working on one of two topics, Puritanism or slavery. He picked Puritanism, then got sick of it.
"I had grown up on the Great Plains," said Mr. Worster, the author of books on the Dust Bowl and water supply in the American West, among others. "For me, things like climate and grasses and the memory of bison didn't seem to have much to do with the imaginations of my mentors. They didn't seem to be aware that those things had any significance."
But the field's relationship with the movement has grown strained, some historians say, as scientists have realized that natural systems are not as predictable as popular notions about the "balance of nature" once implied, and as historians have shown that human beings were manipulating ecosystems as far back as any record or evidence extends.
"Virtually all early environmental historians considered themselves environmentalists," Mr. White said. "Most still do. But precisely because so much environmental history is pointing out the problems with naive ideas about nature and untouched pristine lands, there has come to be a sense that we're not fully to be trusted. And I guess in some sense we aren't."
A tall man with a youthful lope, angular face and preference for well-worn flannel shirts, William Cronon grew up mostly in Madison. From his father, E. David Cronon, a political historian and former dean at the university, he inherited his historian's predilection for asking, upon encountering almost anything, how it got to be the way it is.
From his mother, Jean Cronon, he says he acquired a passion for nature. He remembers an endless series of nature activities, like rock collecting, instigated by her, and a fifth-grade vacation in the family station wagon, circumnavigating the West from the Grand Canyon to the Black Hills, that was one of the formative experiences of his life.
"My father's library is full of biographical books, which is typical of scholars of his generation," Mr. Cronon said one afternoon, his legs dangling over the arm of a chair in a campus office. "Whereas the dominant thing that operates in my mind is landscape. I think in maps, actually. I tend to ask how these places came to be the way they are."
One of his earliest research projects occurred in his junior year in high school. Using original land records from the 1830's, he reconstructed the presettlement vegetation of a Wisconsin county. "I was just endlessly fascinated by the notion that a landscape is a palimpsest, these layers that can be peeled off," he said.
He entered the University of Wisconsin as an undergraduate thinking he might be a quantitative plant ecologist or a novelist; drifted toward geology; alighted in medieval studies; won a Rhodes scholarship to study Old English and Old Norse, and then, in his senior year at Wisconsin, walked into a course on the history of the American West, taught with an environmental focus, that convinced him that would be his field.
He spent his two years at Oxford doing a research project on Coventry and how shifts in energy consumption affected this English town's social life and political economy. His paper earned him a Ph.D. Then he headed off to Yale to study with Howard Lamar, at that time the best-known graduate teacher of Western history.
For his dissertation topic, he chose Chicago. Feeling he had failed in Coventry to look at the coal fields that had given the town its economic life, he decided to study the interaction between Chicago and its hinterland over a long sweep of time, and the environmental and economic links that arose.
Then Mr. Lamar became the dean of Yale College, creating an opening on the faculty for a Western historian. Though only a graduate student, Mr. Cronon got the job. He was 27. He received tenure in 1988 before completing his dissertation, having already published "Changes in the Land," which had begun as a paper for a seminar during his first year at Yale.
In 1992, a year after the publication of the ground-breaking "Nature's Metropolis," Mr. Cronon accepted his current job as a professor of history, geography and environmental studies. He and his wife, Nancy Fey, returned home to raise their two children near their grandparents and to settle in the part of the world that has so profoundly shaped Mr. Cronon's thinking.
Passing through O'Hare Airport around the same time, Richard White, the Stanford historian, recalls having noticed a businessman beside a baggage-claim carousel reading "Nature's Metropolis." He remembers thinking, "What I would give to have a guy like that reading one of my books."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
How World Stock Markets Fared in the First Quarter

BYLINE: By Dylan Loeb McClain

 BODY:
The first quarter was not a period of substantial turmoil in world markets, with one notable exception. Brazil's devaluation of its currency touched off a panic in emerging markets. Unlike the 1998 Russian debt crisis and the 1997 Asian currency crisis, Brazil's crisis was shorter lived. It quickly bounced back, spurred largely by the naming of Arminio Fraga as its new central banker and the Government's adoption of a credible economic restructuring program.
 Mexico, after an initial dip caused by Brazil's problems, ended up strongly as investors increasingly tied its long-term prospects to those of the United States economy. 
 In Europe, many markets had good, if unspectacular results, but Germany suffered the lingering effects of Finance Minister Oskar Lafontaine's tax-reform program, which was passed by the German legislature after the embattled minister resigned in mid-March.
 In Asia, markets continued their slow recoveries from the problems of 1997, with Japan posting some of the best results. Analysts said that announcements of several high-profile corporate revampings, and the greatest willingness of the Government to take active steps to fix some of the country's economic problems, convinced foreign investors that Japan may be on the verge of a turnaround. DYLAN LOEB MCCLAIN

HEADLINE: Commercial Property /New Jersey;
In Piscataway, a Central Laundry for Region Hiltons

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: PISCATAWAY

 BODY:
THE squat, yellowish green building looks much the same as any of its neighbors at the Rutgers Industrial Park in this Middlesex County township. But the 100,000-square-foot building's interior is distinct from all others.
The 25-foot-high ceiling is covered with a maze of tracks from which big blue canvas bags filled with laundry hang. And lining the floor are seven washing machines -- three of them giant stainless steel tubes called tunnel washers -- dryers, conveyor belts and an army of gadgets that sort, pick, iron and fold 90,000 pounds of towels, sheets and pillow cases during the plant's 10-hour day. 
 Meritex L.L.C., a Piscataway-based commercial laundry operator, in partnership with Hilton Hotels, transformed 73,000 square feet of the building into a computerized central laundry. It runs its operation exclusively for Hilton, servicing eight of its lodgings totaling 6,400 rooms in New York and New Jersey.
The plant, which opened last September and is a first for Hilton, will handle 30 million pounds of laundry this year. Eventually, it could be expanded to fill the entire building and handle 50 million pounds of laundry a year, servicing 3,000 additional rooms for four to eight more Hilton hotels in Pennsylvania and Connecticut, as well as some hotels in all four states that have franchise agreements with Hilton.
"It's a simple concept," said Dan Oberlander, a partner at Meritex with Don Pertl, a laundry consultant. "Take a cluster of hotels in a concentrated geographical area, determine their needs and meet them through a centralized laundry that on a collective basis could significantly lower costs."
Equipped with $10 million in the latest technology and machinery -- including the giant washers, each of which does 110 pounds of laundry every 2.5 minutes, the laundry is believed to be one of the most automated in the nation. The plant's general manager, Peter J. Botbyl, sits at a computer in his glass-walled office high above the laundry, controlling the entire operation and its staff of 135.
George Nesson, Hilton's vice president of engineering and housekeeping, said the central laundry would save his company about $1 million a year. The space left behind by the on-site laundries has been or will be converted to alternative uses to generate additional revenue, he said.
For example, Mr. Nesson said, at the 2,041-room New York Hilton, on the Avenue of Americas between 53d and 54th Streets in Manhattan, the company, as part of renovating the hotel, is relocating its administrative offices to the former laundry space in the basement. In turn, he said, it is reconfiguring its current administrative offices to create more meeting rooms and converting existing meeting rooms to additional guest rooms. Mr. Nesson added that Hilton was considering replicating the concept elsewhere in the country where it has a large number of rooms in one location.
Capturing space to create "additional rooms at a reasonable cost is an advantage in today's hotel market," especially in areas where construction and real estate costs are high, said John A. Fox, senior vice president at PKF, a Manhattan-based hotel and real estate consulting firm. In Manhattan, for example, renovating existing space costs $25,000 to $50,000 a room, compared with $250,000 to $300,000 for building a room in a new hotel, he said.
Off-site laundries have gained in appeal in recent years as hotels search for ways to maximize space and minimize costs.
Arthur B. Adler, managing director of the lodging and leisure group at Sonnenblick-Goldman, a real estate investment bank in Manhattan, said in-house laundries could be inefficient and costly to many hotels. "Most hotels are outsourcing their laundry to commercial operators because of the economy of scale that provides," he said. "But creating an off-site laundry is another step in the evolution."
Also stoking the trend are technological advances that have made such laundries more efficient. Moreover, large hotel chains, buoyed by the strong lodging market in the nation in general -- and in New York City in particular -- are on a growth spree.
AT the end of 1998 the occupancy rate for hotels in the nation was 64 percent, virtually unchanged from the year before, while the rate for New York City rose by 1.5 percent to 81.3 percent, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn., which tracks the market for hotel companies nationwide. At the same time, average daily room rates increased by 4.4 percent to $78.62 in the nation, and by 9.1 percent to $180.01 in New York City.
Against that backdrop large hotel chains must find "creative ways" to enhance their profits, said Daniel H. Lesser, senior director of the hospitality group at the Manhattan office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage. Consolidating laundry operations to reduce redundancy in employment and services is one way to do that, he said
Next year Hilton, as part of its overall expansion, plans to open or have in construction 200 of its "mid-market," 90- to 250-room Garden Inns nationwide, including some in the New York region.
And Marriott plans to open nine hotels this year with a total of 1,500 rooms in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. In anticipation of its growth the company is doubling to 100,000 square feet the space in the laundry it has operated since 1985 in an industrial building in Edison, N.J.
When the expansion is completed in July the Edison plant -- which now does 35 million pounds of laundry a year, servicing 9,000 guest rooms in 17 of the Washington-based chain's hotels in those three states -- will handle 50 million pounds of laundry annually from a total of 14,000 guest rooms. Marriott also operates two central laundries on the West Coast.
Steven J. Samson, director of operating supplies and standards at Marriott, said his company was considering opening other off-site laundries in major markets where it has a substantial presence. "We get increased productivity and quality at less cost," he said, adding that those benefits were enhanced in markets where "the cost of real estate is an issue."
Starwood Hotels and Resorts in White Plains, which last year acquired the Sheraton and Westin chains, among others, is exploring ways to either centralize its laundry operations in one hotel or create an off-site laundry. The acquisitions pushed the number of hotels Starwood owns and manages nationally to 430 from 100.
"It's absolutely clear that in areas where we have six or seven hotels it pays to centralize our laundry because with the higher volume we can reduce costs," said James Gallagher, a company spokesman. "In this business scale matters."
Mr. Oberlander of Meritex said the Piscataway laundry would not work as effectively with fewer than 5,000 rooms. He added that the "plant is more efficient than the sum total of the previous laundry operations" at the eight Hilton hotels, which either sent out laundry or did it in house.
Off-site laundries are not without problems, warned Andrienne Grizzell, chief executive officer of the National Association of Institutional Linen Management, a nonprofit trade group in Richmond, Ky. "Late deliveries can be costly and quality control problems are more difficult to monitor and control," she said, adding that "we see the beginning of a trend back to in-house laundries for these very reasons."
Mr. Nesson of Hilton feels differently. He said his company had explored several options, including rebuilding in-house laundries and contracting with outside vendors. But joining with Meritex was the best option, he said, because Meritex provides the technical and laundry expertise while Hilton retains control and gets to recycle the former in-house laundry space.
Meritex has a 10-year agreement to run the Piscataway laundry solely for Hilton and not to build a plant for another chain for three years, said Mr. Oberlander. "We also have a unique business deal with Hilton in that profits are shared between the user hotels and ourselves," he said. At a cost of 29 cents per pound of laundry, including expenses such as the $427,000 in annual rent for the plant, "we expect to break even" the first year, Mr. Oberlander said.
The laundry, which now turns out 9,000 pounds of laundry an hour, expects to increase its production to 10,000 pounds an hour by September, he said. "The more efficient we can make the process," Mr. Oberlander said, "the less we charge and the more profit we make."

HEADLINE: L.I. Team to Orioles: In Cuba, We're No. 1

BYLINE: By RICK MURPHY 

DATELINE: EAST HAMPTON

 BODY:
WHEN the Baltimore Orioles played the Cuban national baseball team in Havana last Sunday, broadcasters and headlines across the country noted that it was the first such visit by a Major League Baseball team in 40 years.
Well, yes. But you could forgive the Maidstoners, a motley band of East Hampton beer league softball players, for feeling as though they had beaten the major leaguers to the punch by several weeks. 
 The team managed to sneak past the American embargo in early March, played an eight-game schedule on the Communist island and hoisted Old Glory -- and quite a few glasses -- along the way.
The seeds of the story were planted last summer, when Peter Honerkamp, the proprietor of the Stephen Talkhouse in Amagansett, assembled a modified slow-pitch team to raise money for the Child Development Center of the Hamptons. He issued a challenge -- the team would play any opponent who would match a $300 donation to the cause.
The Maidstoners were a little surprised at the response. For 25 of 26 consecutive nights (with one rainout), the team was in action at Maidstone Park in Springs, their home field. Even more surprising was that this makeshift band of carpenters, landscapers, artists and bartenders, ranging in age from the early 20's to the late 50's, won 21 of the 25 games.
To celebrate, the team held a party at the end of the season. "Everyone wrote jokes about each other," recalled Steve Day, the team's center fielder. "I was always the guy who said, 'let's play another," so the joke on me was I was going to go down to Cuba to play winter baseball."
Everyone laughed, but the joke set Mr. Honerkamp to thinking. The Federal Government forbids trade with Cuba, but recently has begun encouraging cultural exchanges.
"We were more of a cultural exchange program, the way I figured it," he said of a good will softball tour.
Besides, Mr. Honerkamp said, he did some research and found that thousands of Americans visit Cuba each year. About 400 or so get in trouble with the Federal Government, but usually only those who try to set up business deals there.
"I called the State Department, but I quickly became convinced I'd never get anywhere" seeking official endorsement, Mr. Honerkamp said. Instead, he called a friend at CNN, asked for the name of a Cuban who could serve as a guide, flew to Jamaica in November and from there to Cuba. He held discussions with several softball teams in the Havana area, then flew down again a couple of months later, in January, to firm up some dates.
The Cubans were reluctant to make any commitments, but Mr. Honerkamp convinced them it was to be a fun affair with no political overtones.
When he returned to East Hampton, Mr. Honerkamp told his team of his plan. "We had to worry about our families, money and the repercussions," he said. Nevertheless, most of the players enthusiastically endorsed the idea.
A fund-raiser at the Talkhouse raised some seed money. Players who could afford their own way paid, and others chipped in for those who couldn't. "It was a socialistic approach to financing," Mr. Honerkamp said.
On March 1, 28 ballplayers flew from Kennedy Airport to Kingston to Havana. The Cuban customs officials agreed not to stamp their passports.
Booked into the Ambos Mundos Hotel, where Hemingway wrote most of "For Whom the Bell Tolls," the Maidstoners comported themselves in a way to make Papa proud.
"It was pretty wild," said Randall Rosenthal, who pitches, catches, sculpts and plays second base. "The other tourists would go up to the rooftop cafe for breakfast and some of our guys would still be up there partying from the night before."
The Maidstoners, who hadn't played a game since October, spent a day practicing at the ramshackle field at Havana University before their first game, on a different dilapidated field bordering a railroad station and army barracks against a team of perfume factory workers. Both teams were nervous at first, and the language barrier was a further obstacle, but things loosened up after three innings or so, Mr. Rosenthal said. The keg of beer the Americans took along didn't hurt.
"They understood we were just like them," Mr. Rosenthal said. "We love to play and take it seriously, but we have fun, too."
The Americans played poorly and lost, but the beer flowed freely and the two teams intermingled players for another game. It became a tradition to play doubleheaders at each stop, with the second game a mixed-team event. At the end of the day players from both sides embraced.
When some of the Americans took pictures after the games, military police intervened and would not allow photos with the barracks or railroad station in the background. Otherwise the Americans were pretty much ignored by the authorities.
The next day the team played a group of electronics technicians, many from the local Casio plant. The oceanside field had been spruced up by the "computer guys," with base lines neatly chalked, the grass cut and manicured, even a "USA" stenciled onto the field. The Americans sang their national anthem, and the Cubans sang theirs. Flags of both countries were raised. The Maidstoners lost again.
"We were out of shape," said Eric Peterson, a landscaper and left fielder. "If we had practiced for a week we would have been fine. My legs were hurting. We were all pretty rusty."
The Americans brought baseball caps and T-shirts for the fans and opposing players. Some of the locals slipped them mail to deliver to their relatives in the United States.
The Americans said they found Havana a mix of police state and Wild West cow town. Though there were military police on every corner, prostitutes and even drug dealers went about their business.
The American dollar was the currency of choice. Mr. Rosenthal ordered a pastry at a Cuban national baseball game they attended and gave the hawker $3. The hawker gave him the entire tray. Some players paid $5 -- the ticket price at the official exchange rate -- to get into the game, and found out later that at the black market rate it would have cost them one American quarter. None of them minded.
"We went down there with the intent of spending all our money and that's what we did," said Neil Hosey, an electrician and catcher.
The Americans said the Cuban people, though poor, were highly literate, well fed and friendly. "Growing up, we heard all the stories about this evil country, and like the witch who lives at the end of your block, you find out it's just an old woman eating cat food," Mr. Day said.
Perhaps the least likely ambassador for detente on the trip was Reginald Cornelia, a 55-year-old real estate broker and first baseman. His conservative views are well known in East Hampton. "The only way I ever saw myself coming to Cuba was carrying an M-16," he said. But Mr. Cornelia said he enjoyed the visit as much as any of the players.
"He made a couple anti-Castro remarks," Mr. Honerkamp said. "But then again, so did they."
The Maidstoners lost two more games, one to a group of barrio youths they had befriended. Finally, on March 7, the day before they left, the Maidstoners won. Mr. Cornelia delivered the winning hit. "I'll never forget the look on his face when he turned to face us and saw everyone chanting 'Reggie! Reggie!' " Mr. Honerkamp said.
The players exchanged jerseys, and the Americans gave their gloves and bats to their opponents. Some of the Cubans even ventured back to the hotel bar with the team for some after-game carousing.
The Americans flew back via Montego Bay. "It's like the Long Island Rail Road," Mr. Rosenthal said. "Change at Jamaica."

HEADLINE: Counting Homeless In Fairfield County

BYLINE: By JARRET LIOTTA 

 BODY:
BRYAN MCFADDEN knows the streets of Norwalk better than anyone. This was where he grew up, dealt drugs, lived in the shelters, earned jail time, eventually got sober, and finally found his way back to his life.
Mr. McFadden, now 39 years old and an outreach worker with Keystone House, a social service agency, goes back to the streets regularly to offer homeless people information. He tries to encourage people to take advantage of services including counseling and housing support, and he continues to spread the word that change is possible for everyone. 
 "Since I've changed my life, a lot of people when they see me, they say, 'Bryan, can you pray for me?' or 'Can you get me a job?'," he said. "A lot of it is a game. A lot of them don't want the help. They want to see if they can get the coffee and donuts. They want to see if they can get money from me."
But the needs are varied and not fully known, which is why Advocates to End Homelessness, a Norwalk coalition of social service agencies, recently began a second survey of homeless people, hoping to get a more accurate count of those in need. And the Norwalk coalition is sharing its expertise with Bridgeport, Danbury and Stamford agencies, who are doing their own surveys, in order to get a county-wide picture. All the municipalities will use the data in support of requests for Federal funding.
Melissa M. Leigh, housing and community development coordinator with the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, said a 1997 survey in the Norwalk area, which she helped design, found 173 homeless people. "I'm guessing that the number will probably be in that same ballpark," she said of the latest survey (its results are still being compiled).
This year, the Federal Housing and Urban Development's grant, called Continuum of Care, will be $750 million, to be distributed throughout the United States to agencies serving the homeless.
While the state directly gives some money, Ms. Leigh said, most of that is earmarked for emergency shelters, making the H.U.D. funds highly sought after, and the application process very competitive.
"By having this information with the level of detail we collect," Ms. Leigh said, "it really helps us support our cases, support our needs, and make a good argument for why we need resources."
The short survey, which requires participants to use their initials only, their birth date and several identifying characteristics, asks questions about previous housing, current housing and needs including those for drug and alcohol abuse, mental health and domestic violence. Conducted the week of March 15, volunteers from various agencies did the legwork for the survey, seeking out homeless people not only at shelters but also on the streets.
Few people could have been better qualified to conduct the survey than Mr. McFadden, a small, stocky man with glasses and a Kansas City Chiefs baseball cap.
"I know everybody," he said. "The people that I don't know, I know of them, or they know of me."
As he rounded a corner, he rolled down his window and yelled out a greeting to a man walking by. Then he turned to a visitor and said, "Norwalk is a nice place to live if you've got your head on straight and know what's going on." For the purposes of the survey, people who are staying temporarily with friends or family are considered homeless, even though such a designation is not formally recognized by H.U.D. Still, the agencies hope such information will help in defining needs.
Alex Berardi, executive director of Keystone House, said that with welfare reform and the cost of housing increasing, the number of homeless men, women and children is likely to increase as well.
"A lot of folks, especially people with mental illness and substance abuse, don't live in a shelter," he said. "My folks tend to be prey in the shelter, and they tend to avoid those places."
Part of the problem, he said, is the inability to keep housing, even if it can be found. Many do not qualify for Social Security benefits (which are for disabled people and surviving children as well as for elderly men and women), yet aren't necessarily able to maintain an apartment.
Some people that Mr. McFadden encountered on a recent day while conducting the survey demonstrate the dilemmas of coping with mental illness. One man at a downtown mall, who has been homeless for many months, talked incoherently about terrorist groups in the neighborhood that are planning diabolical acts against him. He smelled of alcohol and his clothes and person are ragged and dirty. Still he refused Mr. McFadden's counsel.
At another stop at a small parking lot adjacent to the emergency shelter, the problems of substance abuse hit home. A sign on a chainlink fence identifying the area as a "drug-free zone" was being mocked by several crack dealers nearby who mixed catcalls and cursing with an occasional deal done through a car window. Several people passed by, some homeless, all of whom Mr. McFadden knew by name. He told one man about the survey. "He said he didn't have time for it; he's going to get something to eat," Mr. McFadden reported afterward.
Many Spanish-speaking people think he might be an immigration officer, he said. Some flee when they see him coming.
Another man was more cooperative. He is 73 years old, African American, with a beard, gray hair and a weather-worn face. He moved slowly, his hands shoved in the pockets of his black sweatpants. He is a veteran and a grandfather who lost his home because he couldn't afford the rent. "I've been living with my daughter," he told Mr. McFadden, asking him why he wanted the information. "I'm doing it so we can get money," Mr. McFadden responded, "so we can get houses, so you don't have to be out in the streets."
Stephanie Ross, assistant director for the Human Services Council of Mid-Fairfield, also supervised training and planning for the survey.
"What's beneficial for the community is that we can actually quantify and qualify homeless demographics and service needs for the community, and it gives us a basis for planning for these needs," she said. "It also makes our plans realistic because they're based on actual facts and not supposition."
For example, she said that the last survey showed many homeless people had some source of income, yet did not have enough money to afford housing. "That was a real eye-opener," she said. "That showed that there was a real gap."
Ms. Ross said that 44 social service and government agencies were involved with this year's survey in Norwalk, which will have taken almost 100 volunteers 800 hours to complete. She said those doing the survey were trained for several hours last month, given tips on questioning, and taught the technicalities and language of the form. "I think that the volunteers have shown incredible enthusiasm and accuracy in what they're doing," she said.
As Mr. McFadden continued his search for homeless people, he talked about his results so far. He said that mostly he had found African-American men, although the homeless population in Norwalk covers all ages, both sexes and a mixture of ethnic background.
"This guy's 40 years old who just waved at me," he said. "He's been in and out of jail just as much as I have. He's given the state of Connecticut 20 years of his life; he's a nice guy but he just keeps doing the same thing."
In Norwalk's 1997 survey of homeless people 91 were African-American, 66 white and 16 Latin American. The small number of Latin Americans counted, Ms. Leigh said, reflected not only the fears felt by illegal immigrants but also a tighter network among families and friends in the immigrant groups.
Rick Starbuck, of Access, a Bridgeport agency, said he believed the survey would net good results for his city, which last year counted 1,300 homeless. "We had done our past work in this area by getting information from agencies rather than individual clients," he said. "We thought that this was an improvement." Ben Gross, director of research and development at Hall-Brooke Foundation, a psychiatric hospital in Westport, who has been assisting Danbury in this year's survey efforts, said problems involving the movement of the population can be changed through the survey.
He said that homeless people who had lived in suburban towns often end up in cities, where more resources are available. Consequently, many towns, including Danbury and the surrounding area, have not sought H.U.D. money in the past, instead forcing the urban areas to carry more of the responsibility.
"I don't mean to say they're doing that intentially," he said, "but if you have no services in your community, homeless people are forced to migrate to where there are services."
This year, Danbury, which had 146 homeless adults in 1993 when the last count was done in that community, is working with six surrounding towns to complete the survey, including Bethel, Brookfield, New Fairfield, Newtown, Redding, and Ridgefield.
He said that money was lost last year simply because some towns didn't bother to apply to H.U.D. "That's a terrible thing," he said. "We should never give money back to Washington."
During a recent day of searching, Mr. McFadden also took the opportunity to drive past his old apartment in Norwalk, where he lived with his family for most of his first 30 years.
"Building 20, right here on the third floor," he said. "All eight of us, and it was a three-bedroom apartment." His parents both died when he was 12. By the age of 16 he had been sentenced to serve six years in Somers Correctional Institute for a robbery.
"They believed in me when I didn't believe in myself," he says of Keystone. "They tried to give me an outreach job and I laughed at them. And I tried to do the job high, and it didn't work."
The offer of the responsibility helped lead him into recovery. Since then he has remarried and lives in Norwalk with his wife and daughter.
"I thank God for it, because without God we're lost," he said. "If a person don't have some spirituality in their life, they're lost. They can have all the money in the world."
Asked why there are still many homeless people in Norwalk, Mr. McFadden emphasized that he had his own opinion.
"People need exposure," he said. "People need to be educated on job skills, on how to deal with their problems, on how to get apartments, on how to get jobs.
"People need to be educated, because if they don't know how, they're going to be homeless."

HEADLINE: Litchfield Landmark Yields to the Future

BYLINE: By SUSAN PEARSALL 

 BODY:
SINCE 1751, Litchfield has been the seat of one of Connecticut's largest judicial districts covering most of the region from Hartland to Bridgewater. For more than two centuries there has been a courthouse on the green, and the country's first law school was founded in 1775 by Tapping Reeve, just south of the green.
But for the last 20 years, there has been debate about whether to build a new courthouse in Litchfield or in nearby Torrington, the judicial district's largest city (its population is 35,000). Until last year, Litchfield's 8,700 residents felt strongly that historical precedent was on their side. The current granite courthouse, built in 1889 with a tall clock tower, is the town's fourth courthouse. 
 Then representatives of the state's Department of Public Works arrived in Litchfield with plans for a $43.5 million courthouse. It was quite a shock. The new courthouse would be a 160,000-square-foot building and require parking space for 300 cars, said a department spokesman. All court business now conducted in the 18,000-square-foot Superior Court and five leased locations would be housed under one roof.
The new building would relieve overcrowding, provide for 20-year growth projections, and meet current standards that require courthouses to have three separate traffic patterns for judicial staff members, court visitors and prisoners, officials explained. Most historic courthouses have a single internal traffic pattern for everyone.
A new courthouse for Litchfield is part of a major expansion for the state judiciary to replace old, sometimes historic courthouses and to build new ones to meet growing caseloads. Sixteen new court complexes have opened in the last 14 years. Three more are opening this year, one next year and 18 more are to be built by 2004. For Litchfield, the project took some unusual turns.
In January, public works officials chose a site from 11 offerings -- a 47-acre property less than two miles northeast of the Litchfield green on Route 202. It is zoned for residential use. Downtown Torrington is about four miles away.
On March 11, the Commissioner of the Department of Public Works, Theodore R. Anson, who lives in Bridgewater, attended a public hearing in Litchfield. More than 200 residents turned out to voice concerns about potential increased traffic and commercial development along Route 202, demands on town services, and security issues.
In an unusual action, Mr. Anson said he and Gov. John G. Rowland would abide by the results of a March 25 townwide referendum on whether a new courthouse should be built in Litchfield. Technically, state officials do not need local approval to build new centers.
There were questions, too, about the $120,000 annual payment the state would make to the town in lieu of taxes on the new building and the state's plans to renovate the old courthouse if the new building was approved.
Many residents argued such a large building belonged in an urban center like Torrington, not on wooded land in Litchfield. The only people to speak in favor of the new courthouse were two lawyers and the town's tax collector.
After the public hearing, the Board of Selectmen voted 4-0 to endorse building the new courthouse on Route 202. The Litchfield Economic Development Commission and the Litchfield County Bar Association also supported the plan, although the bar did not specify a site.
The First Selectman, Craig Miner, said in a telephone interview that building a new courthouse would substantially increase the town's income, while developing the 47-acre property for 18 houses would cost the town about $234,000 a year above the property taxes generated to educate two children in each household.
In a separate conversation, an opponent, Kent Gilyard, said he worried that residents would not understand "this is no longer the nice, little, historic courthouse in the center of Litchfield, but a processing center for all of the criminal element of Litchfield County."
Over the next two weeks, opponents and supporters alike waged spirited campaigns in radio advertisements and letters to the editors of local newspapers. Opponents mailed fliers to 4,500 homes and businesses. Yard signs appeared with slogans like "Save Our Courthouse" and "Courthouse Too Big for Litchfield."
In the end, Litchfield residents approved building a new courthouse by 213 votes, 1,399 to 1,186. More than 40 percent of the town's registered voters cast ballots, said the Town Clerk, Evelyn Goodwin. The new courthouse is expected to open in July 2002, according to judicial department documents.
While Litchfield is the only town to vote on a courthouse proposal, many towns in the state's 13 judicial districts have faced similar problems finding sites for larger courthouses and preserving historic ones in need of expensive renovations. The state's Chief Court Administrator Robert C. Leuba said 16 new courthouses had been built in the last 14 years. New court complexes opened last year in Waterbury and last month in New Britain with openings scheduled in Danielson in July and in Stamford in October, 2000.
The judicial branch's capital plan for the fiscal years 2000 to 2004 includes 18 more projects expected to cost $415.8 million. The top priority items are building new criminal courthouses in Bridgeport ($71.5 million) and New Haven ($71.5 million) and a new juvenile court in New London ($13.3 million). Building a new Litchfield courthouse is fourth on that priority list; renovating the old courthouse, estimated to cost $4 million, is the 14th priority. The list also includes renovating historic courthouses in Waterbury, Bridgeport, Hartford and New Haven.
"We have an ongoing program of repairing and upgrading buildings," said Karen Berris, manager of communications for the judicial branch. The state's oldest operating courthouse is the New London Superior Court, built in 1784, Ms. Berris said. The two-story clapboard building has a modern addition.
A tour of the Litchfield courthouse offers a look at how judicial employees function in outdated buildings.
Just inside the front door, a metal detector, monitored by a sheriff's deputy, takes up half the narrow hallway. People waiting to pass through the metal detector block access to two public offices and the steep staircase that leads to the largest of the building's three courtrooms. (The juror assembly room doubles as a courtroom on Mondays.) On the first floor, five clerks share one small office where lawyers enter pleas. There is no room for visitors to sit down.
Without an elevator, the second floor is not handicapped accessible, said Scott Hartley, a trial court administrator, who conducted the tour. In the upstairs courtroom, there are large cracks running along one wall. Hanging chandeliers provide light.
The law library is down the hall in a narrow room crammed from floor to the 13-foot-high ceilings with law books. Two ladders on tracks offer access to books on the top shelves. According to a judicial department fact sheet, the library is less than 15 percent of the recommended size. Books that cannot fit are stacked on shelves in a nearby hallway and in the basement near holding cells for prisoners.
The basement cellblock area contains three holding cells. "Sometimes, we have 12 to 14 people here," said Sheriff Richard L. Zaharek. Prisoners are transported to the Litchfield courthouse in leg irons, he said, and brought in through a basement door. A secure entrance means clearing the hallways before prisoners enter, he said.
"To bring people into a building like that to conduct some of the most important business of their lives is a travesty," said Judge Leuba. People coping with divorce proceedings, or with child custody battles, for example, "have to confer with their lawyers in a cramped corridor with other people doing the same or different activities," he said.
Michael Rybak, a Litchfield lawyer and advocate for a new courthouse in town, called the old building "a disaster waiting to happen." He has attended controversial trials when the upstairs courtroom was packed with observers. "It would be difficult to evacuate that building, particularly if a fire was started in the back stairwell," he said.
At the same time the district's criminal court docket has been growing. Records show the number of pending criminal cases increased 66 percent, to 174 cases from 105 between July 1, 1996, and June 30, 1998. At the public hearing, William Conti, a Torrington lawyer who practices criminal law, said the district's caseload had quadrupled in the last 25 years.
Now that Litchfield voters have approved the courthouse, Mr. Anson said his department would purchase the $395,000 property, complete an environmental impact study and design the building. The building could have three floors, with one underground, he said.
The town's selectmen will have an opportunity to comment on the design, although final approval rests with state officials.
Already, Mr. Anson has agreed to concessions raised by selectmen. The new courthouse will not have a cafeteria, only vending machines, to avoid hurting business at nearby restaurants, he said. To allay residents' fears about future building on the site, Mr. Anson said he would be willing to dedicate unused property to open space. And there is talk about a dedicated water line for the new courthouse, which would not encourage development around it.
Mr. Miner, the First Selectman, said the hard-won vote carried a responsibility. "It's going to be a real obligation for the Board of Selectmen and the people in the community who want to work on the project to see that it is as nice a complex as possible and meets the needs of the region," he said.
By the morning after the referendum, most of the yard signs had disappeared. Mr. Gilyard had removed the large "Vote No New Courthouse" sign displayed in front of his house on Route 202. In its place was a new sign which read: "Feed Hay $3."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Watercolor and Photography, Meshing in a Single Genre

BYLINE: By FRED B. ADELSON 

DATELINE: HADDONFIELD

 BODY:
LYNN MOWRER of Magnolia and Mike Sproch of Collingswood may initially seem to be artistic worlds apart. Although Ms. Mowrer is a watercolor painter who uses accents of rich color and Mr. Sproch is a photographer who produces black-and-white gelatin-silver prints, they nicely complement each other as they exhibit together at the Markeim Art Center. Because this show is presented as separate exhibitions with works by each artist displayed in adjoining spaces, the connection may seem less obvious. However, both artists deal primarily with still-life subject matter.
Each watercolor by Ms. Mowrer is a convincing illusion of reality. Her strongest works are images of ripe fruit, fresh-cut flowers and sundry household objects gathered from around her home-based studio. In addition to these 13 still-life paintings, she is showing three family scenes based on photographs; the accessories are what really capture the attention. In the large portrait "Eddy and Rita With Kevin," her mother's suit is exquisitely painted in pink washes. 
 With the horizontal arrangement of domestic objects, Ms. Mowrer creates a well-balanced order. Vibrantly colored hydrangeas, peonies and poppies, along with cobalt blue glassware, seem to jump off the lightly washed tabletops. Her still lifes suggest relatively shallow space within arm's reach of the viewer. The illusion of three-dimensionality is strongly enhanced by a carefully foreshortened object like the cantaloupe wedge in "Hydrangea on Turquoise II" or the clothespin in "Green Scoop," a subtle image of whites on white.
Ms. Mowrer, who studied at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, demonstrates her familiarity with the Philadelphia school of still life. In "Listening to Story," the curled apple peel and the perforated ceramic basket immediately bring to mind paintings by the Peale family. She also directly acknowledges the Old Masters with her reproduction of a Joshua Reynolds print of a young boy (supposedly painted while listening to a story) that serves as a backdrop for the fruit.
Like Ms. Mowrer's paintings, Mr. Sproch's compositions are carefully fabricated. He is not interested in capturing an observed moment of reality, but prefers to create a subject for the camera to document. Although he has been making photographs for nearly 20 years, this is his first public exhibition. Most of the prints date from the last two years; none are before 1994.
Mr. Sproch made two cut-paper collages that serve as his pictorial vocabulary, and he photographs these patterned designs from various angles and distances. In a series of high-contrast prints, figure and ground are virtually indistinguishable because of the deep, rich black and the pure, stark white. In "High Contrast Image No. 5," one of his largest works, the artist has taken the process even further by making a collage of negatives and then printing it on two contact sheets. The result is a kaleidoscopic effect that has a decorative quality reminiscent of an Islamic mosaic.
"Kitchen With Collage" is another intriguing example of how Mr. Sproch creates a fictive image. The photograph of the artist's kitchen presents an overabundance of traditional still-life elements carefully arranged on the counters, range and microwave. Everything has been meticulously cleaned; the stove and kettle sparkle. Despite the seeming hyper-reality of what is represented, Mr. Sproch has made a checkerboard pattern from photographs of his collage and squares of black paper to create the illusion of tilework. His work has the meticulous finish of commercial photography, which makes the artificial somehow seem more believable.
L ESS than four miles away is the seventh annual juried watercolor exhibition at the Hopkins House Gallery. Artists were invited to submit one or two works completed in the last two years; mixed materials were accepted as long as watercolor dominated. The juror was James Toogood of Cherry Hill, a celebrated watercolor painter who is a member of the prestigious American Watercolor Society and the Philadelphia Water Color Club. Mr. Toogood selected 49 works by 37 artists. Except for one from Philadelphia, all live in the surrounding South Jersey counties; many are familiar names on the regional art scene.
Sponsored by the Camden County Cultural and Heritage Commission, this group show reveals the variety of approaches in using aqueous media. Most works are traditional in both subject matter and technique. Alice Steer Wilson's "Our Home Town" is a classic example of watercolor painting; she has been awarded a solo exhibition next year at Hopkins House. With washes of color, Ms. Wilson, of Merchantville, is able to suggest a bright summer day in Cape May. The dappled sunlight and color-filled shadows make this an image of seductive charm.
By contrast, Linda Casario-Malek's "Tea and Sympathy" is a realistic still life with an unusual perspective. It may seem as if the china cups, mugs and saucers defy gravity, but the viewer is actually looking down on the covered tabletop. This jumble of objects is distinctly different from the ordered arrangement of Ms. Mowrer's still-life subjects.
"Pit Lane," by Mr. Toogood, is discreetly displayed near the staircase, but it takes center stage. The juror's craftsmanship puts many of the other artists at a visual disadvantage. His meticulous handling is a superb demonstration of controlled brushwork. This scene depicts Lime Rock Park, a race track in Lakeville, Conn. The illusion of deep space is enhanced by the recession of the guardrails, and the blue color scheme gives the image an Ektachrome-like tonality that reinforces its photo-realist quality.
To his credit, Mr. Toogood recognized technical approaches and esthetics markedly different from his own. Lois Lewis Schumm of Cherry Hill received an award of merit for "Dinner on the Serengeti," an image of geometric forms and stick figures that blends elements of abstract Surrealism with pictorial motifs recalling non-Western cultures. Her fanciful work, with its deeply saturated color, commands the room's attention. On the other hand, "Make a Joyous Sound," by Ben Cohen of Cinnaminson, is a small picture of flat colors arranged in a synthetic Cubist style. It is rather puzzling why this work was awarded the single purchase prize.
Deborah Gross-Zuchman, the only artist not from New Jersey, is represented by two wonderful constructions of cut and colored papers. "Still Life on Place Mat," which received a juror's award, is an image of vegetables and fruits with a bean pot set on a place mat that is made of actual woven strips of paper. Ms. Zuchman has successfully combined the still-life arrangement of Cezanne, the decorative patterning of Matisse and the whimsy of Red Grooms.
 
MIKE SPROCH
LYNN MOWRER

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Small Business Success

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The results of a State Tax Department report last month show that New York's one million small businesses account for half of the state's total employment and nearly half of all business receipts.
The Small Business Report, compiled by the Tax Department from a review of tax filings, also shows that 99 percent of New York businesses employ fewer than 100 people. 
 The report also showed that nearly 90 percent of small businesses employ fewer than 10 employees, and more than one-half employ 5 or fewer; 47 percent of small businesses -- including most farms -- are sole proprietors; the average receipts of small businesses totaled $677,565, but the actual amounts varied widely, based on the type of company and number of employees.

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
State Backs Debated Plan For Turnpike Link With Route 1

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
State environmental experts last week announced their approval of the proposed Route 92 in Middlesex County, a $350 million project to connect the turnpike with Route 1. The decision put them at odds with Federal environmentalists, who have said the road should not be built because of its adverse effect on wetlands.
The decision on the road, which has been under consideration for years, is now in the hands of the Army Corps of Engineers, which will study traffic patterns, economic impact and environmental questions, said Peter Shugert, a spokesman for the corps's New York and New Jersey regional office. 
 The Turnpike Authority, which is in charge of the project, has said building 5.7 miles of road for Route 92 and improving another mile of existing Route 32 would take 20,000 cars a day off local roads. The proposal has been modified several times, and the area of wetlands that would be lost has been reduced from 33 acres to 14.8 acres, while 57 acres of new wetlands would be created. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: Curtains Up: A Razzle-Dazzle Road Show Hits New York

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS

 BODY:
THE previews are over and the glittering cast has settled in for a nine-day run. It's not exactly the Great White Way, but it's just a few long blocks from Broadway. And where else in New York can one see so many cars that aren't yellow?
 Despite New Yorkers' reputed preference for subway cars over sports cars, the New York International Auto Show draws the biggest crowds of the nation's four leading car shows. And since it is the last of these, its displays include most of the future models and design studies, known as concept cars, that were previously unveiled in Detroit, Chicago and Los Angeles.
 The new-car news at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, where the last New York auto show of the century runs through next Sunday, has been about bread-and-butter cars like a restyled Ford Taurus and the first midsize Saturn. Still, there are plenty of sexier models that made their debuts earlier but have not been seen by New Yorkers, like the future Ford Thunderbird, the Bauhaus-inspired Audi TT, the 30's-style Chrysler PT Cruiser and the Cadillac Evoq, which heralds a new direction for General Motors' luxury division. Among the other vehicles new to New York are these: 

ASTON MARTIN DB7 VANTAGE -- This car's stats could have James Bond rethinking his defection to BMW: 420 horsepower from a 6-liter V12 derived from Formula One race cars, a top speed of 180 m.p.h. and 0-to-60 acceleration in less than 5 seconds. Both a coupe and Volante convertible go on sale next year; prices have not been announced.
 
BMW 3-SERIES COUPES -- Following the introduction last year of all-new 3-Series sedans, BMW has updated its 323Ci and 328Ci, which go on sale in July as 2000 models. Though the styling is similar, the two- and four-door models share virtually no parts. BMW is also displaying a new M5, which it calls the world's fastest production sedan, and modestly restyled Z3 roadsters.
 
CHEVROLET SUBURBAN/GMC YUKON -- Last fall, General Motors introduced completely redesigned full-size pickups. Now it is showing prototypes of full-size sport utilities based on that solid new truck platform. The Yukon and its Chevy counterpart, the Tahoe, get a third-row seat -- to compete better with the Ford Expedition -- and side air bags. Styling of the bigger Suburban, like that of the Tahoe/Yukon, is a bit more rounded.
 
INFINITI I30 -- Nissan's premium division has restyled its midsize luxury car, based on a redesigned Nissan Maxima, for 2000. The interior is more roomy and horsepower from the V6 is up by 37, to 227. The I30 now offers a navigation system connected to a 24-hour response center for emergency assistance. Other new options include Xenon headlamps and a rear sunshade.
 
KIA KMS-4 -- In a demonstration that economy cars need not be dull, the South Korean auto maker showed a sharp-edged design study in the vein of the Mercury Cougar. The KMS-4 features a glass roof and a solar cell to power accessories. The four-passenger concept coupe has a four-cylinder engine, transmission-shifting paddles behind the steering wheel and a sporty suspension.
 
MAZDA MPV -- This minivan gets some much-needed improvements: front-wheel drive, sharper styling, various family-friendly features. Sliding rear doors -- with power windows, an exclusive touch -- replace hinged doors. The second-row captain's chairs slide together to form a bench; they also fold and can be removed. The third-row seat, like that of the Honda Odyssey, flips into the floor. Mazda may later add all-wheel drive.
 
MERCEDES-BENZ CL -- Mercedes-Benz is showing its next high-end coupe for the first time. Arriving in showrooms early next year, it will be offered as the CL500, with a 5-liter V8; a V12 model will probably come later. Mercedes is also displaying its flagship S-Class sedan, which is about to go on sale. Lighter and less expensive than the previous S-Class, the car is a technological wonder: There is a standard navigation system, voice-recognition features and a "smart" cruise control that maintains a set distance behind another vehicle.
 
MITSUBISHI ECLIPSE -- A new version of this sporty coupe has a low-slung front end and prominent ribs along its sides. In keeping with the "geo-mechanical" design of Mitsubishi's concept cars, the Eclipse has a machined look; the fuel filler cap, for instance, has a riveted metallic appearance. The Eclipse goes on sale this summer.
 
NISSAN Z -- Though it made its worldwide debut in Detroit in January, the Z concept car got a big lift in New York, where Nissan announced that it would indeed produce a new version of the classic Z sports car within three years. Nissan insists that the next rear-drive Z will not be retro, but will have the "design DNA" and reasonable price of the original 1970 Datsun 240Z. The powertrain has not been selected; the show car has a 200-horsepower four-cylinder engine.
 
OLDSMOBILE AURORA -- For the first time since its 1994 introduction, the car that set a new import-fighting course for Olds is being revamped. The 2001 model is styled less dramatically, in line with the less expensive Intrigue. Smaller and 300 pounds lighter, the front-drive Aurora will offer a V6 along with its highly regarded 250-horsepower V8. It will go on sale in about a year.
 
SAAB 9-3 VIGGEN -- This new offshoot of the 9-3 series derives its name and badge from an aircraft, the Saab 37 Viggen jet fighter. Its 2.3-liter four-cylinder engine has been modified to produce 225 horsepower, and the car has a new sports suspension and performance wheels. The coupe goes on sale in limited numbers in May; convertible and five-door models arrive in the fall.
 
SATURN L-SERIES -- Having survived its first decade with a single set of small cars, Saturn at last adds some new models. Based on the Opel Vectra from Germany, the midsize L-Series (for large) is available as an LS sedan, which goes head-to-head with the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord, or a LW station wagon. Resembling the smaller S-Series and bearing plastic body panels like all Saturns, the L-Series offers four-cylinder or V6 engines. The new models go on sale this summer; prices were not announced.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
In the Stampede to Big Stocks, Some Managers Are Left Behind

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
DESPITE some sharp ups and downs, the bull market in large-capitalization stocks plowed forward through the first quarter, confounding some money managers and rewarding others.
The story was no different for the five managers who have built hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times: None of their portfolios lost money in the quarter, but only three beat the average return of 0.96 percent for diversified domestic equity funds, as tracked by Lipper Inc. In comparison, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index of large companies gained 4.65 percent in the period. 
 The winner for the quarter, with a return of 4.56 percent, was Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. Mr. Jacobs's portfolio was helped by hefty stakes in large-capitalization stocks, and he expects more strong market gains.
"I anticipate that the bull market will continue through the second quarter," Mr. Jacobs said, because the factors propelling it -- low inflation, low interest rates and a strong economy -- are still in place. "I don't think that we have seen the highs for the Dow this year," he added.
Half of Mr. Jacobs's portfolio is invested in two funds: the Vanguard 500 Index, which mimics the performance of the S.& P. 500, and Vanguard Total Stock Market Index, which has much broader holdings. The portfolio also includes Vanguard Windsor II, a large-cap value fund.
Mr. Jacobs plans no changes to the portfolio, despite relatively poor showings by some of his international stock funds. "It's a long-term commitment, so for a minor drawdown it's not worth doing anything," he said.
The market bias toward large-cap stocks continues to hold back managers with more diversified portfolios, including Harold R. Evensky, a financial adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. Mr. Evensky took fourth place in the quarter, with a portfolio gain of 0.50 percent.
He remains a firm believer in asset allocation, although he said that during the quarter, a sobering market adage from John Maynard Keynes came to mind: Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent.
Nonetheless, Mr. Evensky also plans no changes to his portfolio. "While value and small-cap stocks continue to buck history and significantly underperform the handful of lottery winners driving the S.& P. 500, I continue to believe in long-term investing," he said.
THE performance of the hypothetical portfolios is tracked each quarter by Lipper, which is based in Summit, N.J. It excludes sales charges, transaction costs and taxes, because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five managers can choose any funds open to new investors and can shift money quarterly. At the outset of the competition, in July 1993, they were asked to pick portfolios intended to grow for 20 years.
Mr. Jacobs remains the overall leader, with a gain of 140.15 percent since the contest began. In that time, the five portfolios have risen an average 111.99 percent, compared with a 227.71 percent return for the Vanguard 500 Index fund.
Eric M. Kobren, president of Kobren Insight Group and editor of Fidelity Insight in Wellesley, Mass., took second place in the quarter, with a gain of 3.11 percent. He was hurt by a 15 percent position in Fidelity Small Cap Stock as well as a 25 percent position in Fidelity Spartan Government Income, which fell as the stock market rose to record levels.
Mr. Kobren, whose portfolio is made up entirely of Fidelity funds, said that he felt uncomfortable investing only in equities with the market at such high valuations. But given the portfolio's long-term objective, combined with the economy's surprisingly strong showing, an all-stock portfolio seems in order, he said. So he is selling his bond position and buying a 20 percent stake in Fidelity Value, which he said could be a big winner if the market broadens, reflecting a modestly stronger-than-expected economy, better prospects among industrial companies and the recovery of beaten-down value stocks.
He is also adding 5 percent to his position in Fidelity Contrafund II; he said a quarter of that growth fund was invested in technology, a modest level compared with some of its most aggressive peers.
Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who advocates "socially responsible" investing, took third place for the first quarter, with a gain of 2.64 percent. The return was bolstered by big holdings in large-cap stock funds, including Domini Social Equity, an index fund that is considered a socially responsible proxy for the S.& P. 500.
This quarter, he is replacing Calvert Capital Accumulation, a mid-cap growth fund, with IPS Millennium, a growth-and-income fund. He described the IPS Millennium fund manager, Robert Loest, as a "New Age economist" who uses a model called "evolutionary ecosystems mechanics" to evaluate how changes in technology and society affect the stock market.
Mr. Brill said the fund was not as widely screened for socially responsible investments as others in his portfolio; its major focus is on animal rights. IPS does not invest in poultry or fertilizer companies, for example, because of environmental concerns, he said.
In last place for the quarter was Susan Dziubinski, who edits the Morningstar Fund Investor. Her portfolio gained just 0.35 percent, hurt by its very limited exposure to large-cap stocks. TIAA-CREF Growth and Income, her sole large-cap fund, which she added in the last quarter, beat the S.& P. 500 by gaining 6.18 percent. But that was more than offset by holdings in small-cap stock funds like Skyline Special Equities, which fell 11.83 percent.
Ms. Dziubinski, however, plans no changes to her portfolio, which remains mostly entrenched in funds that buy small- and mid-cap stocks. She expects the high valuation of the large caps to take its toll eventually. "I just can't justify putting money into big stocks when the S.& P. 500's trailing price-earnings ratio stands near 35," she said.
