HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
4Who Won With Technology

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MANY mutual fund managers eked out small gains in the quarter just ended, with the average domestic diversified equity fund returning just 1.26 percent, according to Morningstar Inc.
But funds in the technology sector broke out of the pack, averaging returns of 16.35 percent. And some diversified stock funds also leaped to the top rankings because of holdings in Internet, cable and telecommunications companies. 
 The managers of four of the highest-ranked funds talked about what drove their performance and looked ahead to the rest of the year.
 
Bargains and Branches
 "Our theme is how the Internet is changing our lives," said Garrett R. Van Wagoner, who runs the $286.8 million Van Wagoner Emerging Growth fund, the top American diversified stock fund for the quarter, up 55.84 percent. (He also runs the category's No. 2 and 3 funds, Van Wagoner Micro-Cap and Van Wagoner Mid-Cap, respectively.) "People are hooking up on line, causing a tremendous amount of data traffic growth across the country, and many different technology sectors are benefiting from the explosion."
His top ranking marks a sharp turnaround from his poor returns in 1997 and early 1998. Mr. Van Wagoner said he had concentrated the portfolio into just 45 stocks, but reversed course last March, bringing the fund up to 115 stocks.
After last year's stock market selloff, Mr. Van Wagoner bought some semiconductor and communications stocks at bargain prices, including RF Micro Devices and Transwitch. They proved to be big winners in the first quarter.
He also posted strong profits from telecommunications companies that are competing with the old-line telephone companies. Among these are Metromedia Fiber Network, which lays fiber strands in metropolitan areas and sells capacity to providers of telecommunications services, and Allegiance Telecom, which sells bundled telecommunications services.
Mr. Van Wagoner has also been attracted by the content side of the Internet. His biggest holding, a top performer last quarter, is Onhealth Network, which runs a Web site that provides health and fitness information. He is not taking profits on the stock, which he says "has a long way to go." But he is trimming some of those other first-quarter winners, "not because we think something is wrong, but to be prudent," he said. "Trees don't grow to the sky."
 
Buoyed by Biotechnology
Neal P. Miller, who runs the $1.87 billion Fidelity New Millennium fund, also went on a shopping spree after last year's market slump. The fund rose 24.54 percent for the quarter, earning eighth place among domestic diversified equity funds.
Part of the performance came from biotechnology stocks. "After the honeymoon period with biotech companies eight years ago, they have languished as a category," he said. "Now, selective companies are making great advances." One favorite is the Immunex Corporation, which makes an arthritis drug recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration.
He also made money in semiconductor capital equipment concerns, which are recovering from the Asian economic crisis. "Now, people need more storage and faster products at the same time that fewer people are producing them," he said. One favorite is Micron Technology, which he said had tripled its market share.
On the Internet front, Mr. Miller likes CMGI Inc., a technology investment company that helped develop Lycos and Geocities. Another favorite is Real Networks, the leading maker of software that lets computer users send and receive audio, video and other multimedia services on the Web. "Anything involving entertainment on the Internet will probably use their product," he said.
 
A Cable-Cellular Mix
Cable television stocks helped propel the $526.5 million WM Trust II Growth fund into 12th place among American diversified stock funds in the first quarter, with a return of 23.25 percent. "Cable companies will be able to dramatically improve their basic cable, video and TV offerings as they move from analog to digital networks," the fund's manager, Warren B. Lammert, said, adding that they would be able to enter new businesses like voice telephony and "always on," or continuously connected, Internet services.
Among his favorite stocks are Time Warner and United International Holdings, which owns cable systems in Europe, Latin America and Australia.
Mr. Lammert's biggest bet is in technology stocks, and his biggest such holding is Nokia, an industry leader in cellular phone and network equipment, which he said "is benefiting from the growth in cellular use."
His performance was also bolstered by Internet stocks (15 percent of the portfolio), particularly the bookseller Amazon.com, as well as At Home and Excite, which are planning to merge. At Home provides Internet services in partnership with cable companies; Excite is the No. 2 Internet portal, after Yahoo.
 
Looking Beyond the Net
Despite its name, the Munder Net Net fund, which ranked third in the first quarter among technology sector funds, with a gain of 54.10 percent, is not a pure Internet fund. "We buy companies that derive revenue or strategic significance from the Internet," said Paul T. Cook, manager of the fund, which has $1.45 billion in assets.
The fund invests, for example, in Ameritrade, which has a successful on-line trading operation as well as a profitable off-line brokerage business. On-line trading, Mr. Cook said, "has a lot of momentum because people are successful."
"But if the market reverses," he added, "they might look for investment help off line."
The portfolio also includes investments in electronic commerce, which he expects to increase to 10 to 15 percent of all retailing over the next 5 to 10 years; it now accounts for less than 1 percent. He particularly likes America Online, "because the relationships and deals it has struck with other E-commerce partners make it a diversified way to get at the E-commerce trends."
He also likes Verticalnet Inc., which creates Web sites that provide information and on-line communication for various industries.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Is the U.S. Income Gap Really a Big Problem?

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
IN economics, the facts alone don't usually tell the whole story.
Consider inequality, the trendy subject of dozens of books in the last few years. The facts are uncontroversial: By any hard measure -- wages, income, wealth -- the gap between rich and poor in America has been widening for decades. And while there are indications that the gap may have stopped growing in the mid-1990's, the disparities between Americans of different means are wider today than at any time since the end of World War II. 
 Sounds like a big problem, right? The conventional wisdom says so.
Oddly, though, none of the authors who spend hundreds of pages and thousands of statistics documenting the phenomenon devote even a few paragraphs to rigorously demonstrating that greater income disparities -- as opposed to, say, the persistence of an entrenched underclass -- is a serious problem for the nation. They simply assume that it is.
So when two distinguished empirical economists take the trouble to challenge what has become an article of faith, it's intriguing -- particularly because neither is a right-wing ideologue baldly denying the facts, nor a hoary elitist insisting that inequality is necessary for innovation, saving or support of "high" culture.
The main question they must tackle is how to decide whether rising inequality is good, bad or indifferent.
One approach, taken by Martin Feldstein, president of the National Bureau of Economic Research, is to ask whether the sources of increasing inequality meet a widely accepted ethical criterion first proposed by the Italian economist Vilfredo Pareto. It is the economic equivalent of the Hippocratic standard in medicine: Any change is good if it makes someone better off without making anyone else worse off.
Professor Feldstein examines some of the changes that have created an explosion of riches at the very apex of America's income distribution. The most important, economists agree, is the market's increased tendency to heap most of its rewards on those with lots of education and sophisticated skills.
In addition, opportunities for entrepreneurs have burgeoned wildly; as recently as 1980, 60 percent of the Forbes 400 had inherited the bulk of their wealth; by 1997 the old money had dropped to just 20 percent.
Then there's the well-publicized phenomenon of the 70-hour work week for investment bankers, lawyers, management consultants and other top professionals, a contrast to the past when those who worked the longest were those with the lowest wages. And, finally, there's the extraordinary bull market in securities, mostly owned by the haves.
All these changes, Mr. Feldstein says, are in themselves positive, and tend to benefit some individuals without making others any worse off. By the Pareto criterion, that's a change for the better.
Finis Welch, a labor economist at Texas A & M University who gave this year's prestigious Ely Lecture at the American Economics Association annual meeting, takes a different approach, focusing on inequality's consequences rather than its causes. Mr. Welch argues that rising inequality has had important positive effects along with at least one negative.
He points out that, while the market's uneven rewards for skills have caused the wage gap between high-paid and low-paid individuals in general to widen dramatically, they have also sharply narrowed the far more disturbing wage gaps between blacks and whites and between women and men.
Under these circumstances, it is hard to believe that most Americans would prefer the more homogenous income distribution of the late 1940's, when racism and sexism severely limited occupational choice and pay.
Growing inequality could have devastating effects if it convinced those at the bottom that efforts to move up are doomed to failure. But largely the opposite has happened. Young Americans are finishing high school and going on to college in record numbers, an obvious plus.
 STILL, one clear response to increased wage inequality that Mr. Welch identifies is unambiguously troublesome. Low-skill, low-education men react to their falling earnings potential by giving up on work and relying instead on welfare and other social programs for income, an option that did not exist before the mid-1960's.
Policy makers are more conscious of the pitfalls and are more inclined than ever before to tie benefits to work. That, together with the tightest labor market in memory and a recent surge in pay among the less skilled, may be drawing some drop-outs back into the work force.
"Everybody was just wringing their hands" about income inequality, Mr. Welch said, "but I just kept thinking that people have more of a sense of control over their destinies than when I was a kid."
Mr. Welch, who overcame a devastating accident that left him a paraplegic at 18, seems in step with the mood of most ordinary Americans, who seem to feel that, whatever has happened to the income distribution, opportunities abound -- and not just for the rich.

HEADLINE: THE CULTURE OF MONEY;
Having Our Colors Done

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST 

 BODY:
WERE we filled with envy? Tinted by our obsession with money? Consumed with longing for a more natural life? Who knows why everyone seemed to like the color green so much in the 90's?
The point is, green is over. If gray is the new black, then blue is the new green. And at the turn of the century, orange will be the rage. 
 So say America's color gurus, who preside over one of the grandest intersections of money and culture. You may think that your favorite color is yours alone, an expression of your bodily humors or your inner paint chip. But when it comes to hues, no consumer is an island.
It matters who you are, where you live, and of course, what you see. We influence one another's tastes, naturally. But we're probably influenced most by the marketing messages, overt and subtle, that bombard us every waking hour like gamma rays from Planet Commerce.
In this sense, the wonderful world of color (remember Disney's TV program?) is a mysterious one, where it is never quite clear how or why a particular hue suddenly becomes popular and just as quickly disappears. Why, for instance, were harvest gold, persimmon and that scary avocado so widely embraced for so long? Was it part of a larger movement in the 1960's toward reconnecting with the natural world? Or were people just tired of the colors of the 50's?
These questions are crucial in business, because the right color can sell a product that the wrong color will kill. Much time and treasure is spent trying to identify and promulgate the next hot color. And such machinations lead naturally to questions on a higher plane: Do the color gods really permit free will, or is orange predestined somehow? The next time you buy a car, who really decides what color you end up with? What do we mean by "you?"
THE Mount Olympus of the world of color is an organization called the Color Marketing Group, in which people from various industries get together either to divine or dictate, depending on your level of cynicism, the colors that people will like and want. C.M.G. says it's blue for 1999.
"Of course you have free will," said Harold Linton, a color forecasting specialist at Bradley University in Peoria, Ill., who projects orange as the blue for the new millennium. "Yet at the same time, you're tied to this massive industrial complex."
It's a complex that's hard to shake. Japan and Europe each have a big organization analogous to the Color Marketing Group, which also has a smaller competitor in America, the Color Association.
 But where is the person so fatalistic as to suggest that color choices reflect nothing beyond orchestrated indoctrination? Wasn't Picasso on to something when he said, "Colors, like features, follow the changes of the emotions?"
The colors of the moment change in part because times change. Kenneth Charbonneau, a color consultant to Benjamin Moore & Company and former president of the Color Marketing Group, says it's the economy: During hard times, people stick to conservative colors like navy, burgundy and hunter green, but in more ebullient times, people go for brighter hues. The yellow or red power ties of the 80's were classic chromatic symptoms of a boom.
Color specialists like Mr. Charbonneau look at economic as well as other factors. Social trends like immigration and the growth of the Sun Belt and Pacific Northwest all play a role.
"The climate alone tells you you don't want green in Seattle," Mr. Charbonneau said.
Trends in business count, too. When fashion designers like Ralph Lauren and Calvin Klein cross over into home furnishings, they amplify the influence of fashion on color selection throughout the consumer economy. America's car culture does the same thing for the auto industry.
And don't forget technology. On top of color television and color presses at newspapers, there are new construction materials and paint formulations that create more kinds and combinations of colors in home design and decoration. Look for more special effects, like iridescence.
YET it's hard to avoid suspecting that, at base, it's really about planned obsolescence.
Last year, The Trend Curve, a newsletter for the home furnishings industry, suggested that millions of aging baby boomers might soon be holding yard sales to get rid of stuff they are inheriting from their parents. But what if consumers conclude that yard-sale treasures are a fine way to furnish a home on a budget, and decide to buy secondhand instead of new?
"The only way to guard against it," The Trend Curve warned, "is to insure that home furnishings 10 years from now look different than they do today."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Can Americans Give More, and Not Hurt?

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
FIVE years ago, Claude Rosenberg, a retired San Francisco investment manager, began touring the country, telling Americans that they could easily double their annual giving to churches and charities without lowering their standard of living, or their wealth, one iota.
It was a controversial message, embraced by people like Ted Turner, who pledged a billion dollars to the United Nations, and ridiculed by others, who took comfort in the oft-repeated observation by professional fund-raisers that Americans are the most generous people in the world. 
 After all, living Americans gave away either $109 billion or $115 billion in 1997, depending on whose estimate is used, or about $1 of every $40 of adjusted gross income.
Now Mr. Rosenberg has updated his figures. Because of the booming stock market, he says, Americans over all could nearly triple their annual giving without reducing the quality of their life styles.
Americans will give about $132 billion to churches and charities this year, several studies indicate. But Mr. Rosenberg said Americans have the capacity to give an additional $242 billion, for a potential total of $374 billion in gifts, money that he said would provide enormous societal gain with no individual pain.
Mr. Rosenberg's proposition: Change how you look at your capacity to give, focusing on what you have instead of what you make.
"Our main point," Mr. Rosenberg said, "is that generosity has been based too much on income. With capital for many people being so much larger than income, there is enormous untapped capacity to give."
He advises people to first figure out how much they need to maintain their life styles, get them through any imaginable turmoil and provide for their families.
But after that, he said, many Americans -- even at the $50,000 income level -- have stashed away more wealth than they need. He recommends that those people increase their giving now so that they learn to give in ways that accomplish clear goals, whether more opera in their cities or more after-school recreation for poor children. And as they learn how to make a difference with their gifts, he said, they should step up their giving.
"I am trying to convince people, especially wealthy people, that it is very much in their interest to give away much more and to create a society where they can live safer, happier, better lives," Mr. Rosenberg said. "They just need to change how they think about how much they can afford to give."
Using income tax data for 1996, the latest year for which information is available, Mr. Rosenberg calculated that a couple with $50,000 to $74,999 of income, and investment assets of $118,000 -- the average for that group -- could afford to increase donations by 21 percent. That would raise their giving to $1,600, from the $1,322 average shown in Internal Revenue Service data.
Families with earnings of $100,000 and $1 million of invested assets could give away $16,000 without changing their way of life, his economic model showed. That is about six times actual average giving.
And the roughly 111,000 families with annual incomes of more than $1 million could increase their yearly giving more than tenfold, Mr. Rosenberg said.
That group had average adjusted gross income of $2.8 million and financial assets of $21.2 million, Mr. Rosenberg estimated. Based on those figures, he said, they could give an average of $1.2 million a year, versus their actual average of $119,830. (In his calculations for that group, Mr. Rosenberg used I.R.S. data for 1996 on dividend and interest income to estimate average financial assets.)
YET financial advisers indirectly discourage people from giving as much as they could, Mr. Rosenberg said. They urge the wealthy, in particular, to hold down taxable income. Then, because their giving is based on their income, not their assets, their contributions are diminished.
Many charitable endowments operate on the theory that they can give away roughly 5 percent of assets each year, forever, and keep pace with inflation. Mr. Rosenberg's estimates for individuals are slightly higher. But, of course, individuals don't live forever.
He said that even the relatively few people who tithe, following the biblical injunction to give away 10 percent of income, are out of step with modern finance because they, too, ignore investment assets.
Mr. Rosenberg's organization has trademarked the word "newtithing" for his concept of charitable giving based on assets and surplus income. The idea was first outlined in his book "Wealthy and Wise: How You and America Can Get the Most Out of Your Giving" (Little Brown, 1994); it is also explained in detail at www.newtithing.org, his organization's Web site, which soon will include a calculator to help people determine their giving capacity.
Newtithing grew out of "my own experience soliciting donations," said Mr. Rosenberg, whose family foundation has $32 million. "I was disappointed, even angry, that people I knew were giving little compared to their estimated wealth." He came to believe that some individuals he regarded as stingy were simply listening to standard tax advice and then measuring their capacity to give largely in terms of income.
Paul G. Schervish, a Boston College social work professor who has studied the wealthy for 15 years, says assets are increasingly being counted in calculations of the capacity to give, a dramatic change that Mr. Rosenberg is helping to spur.
"He is attempting to mobilize the consciousness and the consciences of wealth holders to appreciate how much wealth they have and what good they can do with their wealth," Mr. Schervish said. "And he is right that advisers focus on income, not wealth."
Peter Lynch, the famed money manager, and former President Jimmy Carter are among those who endorse Mr. Rosenberg's approach.
"A lot of people have been waiting for some validation that it is all right to give a lot more," Mr. Rosenberg said. "I am giving it to them based on research."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
On Social Security, The Good News Is Bad

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AT first blush, the news last week from the Medicare and Social Security trustees was good. The economy over the last year has been so strong, actuaries found, that even with no changes in the law, the Medicare system should be solvent until 2015, seven years longer than expected, and Social Security reserves should be sufficient to pay full retirement benefits until 2034, two years more than anticipated.
Publicly, President Clinton and Republican leaders were quick to say that the wise course would still be to resolve their differences and act this year to put Medicare and Social Security on sound footing. But the truth is that for Congress, now on recess for Passover and Easter, the news was political manna. It made the problem of the insolvency of the two largest and most popular Federal programs seem less urgent. And it provided an excuse for postponing tough decisions until after the next election. But data buried in the trustees' report illustrated why the matter cannot be put off indefinitely. The figures showed how the ratio of people of retirement age (who receive Medicare and Social Security benefits) to those of working age (who pay the taxes that finance the benefits) will rise after the baby boomers begin to retire. This almost certainly means that sooner or later taxes will have to be increased or retirement benefits reduced. 
 Next year, for example, there will be 210 people age 65 and over for every 1,000 people ages 20 through 64. By 2030, the number of Americans of retirement age will rise by 69 percent to 354 for every 1,000 people of working age. And by 2075, it is projected that the figure will nearly double. DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

HEADLINE: NATO, In A Corner

BYLINE: By Lawrence S. Eagleburger; Lawrence S. Eagleburger was Secretary of State from 1992-93 and Ambassador to Yugoslavia from 1977-81.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If the current bombing campaign in Yugoslavia fails to end the bloodshed in Kosovo soon, the United States and NATO will have suffered a very serious defeat and will face a very unpleasant choice: Do we tuck our tail between our legs or do we mount a land campaign involving several hundred thousand troops and the certainty of substantial casualties?
The chances of the bombing succeeding alone are probably no better than 50-50. The Serbs are tough and highly nationalistic, Kosovo occupies an almost holy place in their hearts, and they are led by a power-hungry opportunist who thrives in crises. 
 I first met Slobodan Milosevic when I was the United States Ambassador to Yugoslavia; he was the head of the largest bank in Belgrade. My impression was that he was one of the more promising economic reformers the country had to offer. I had no inkling of his ambition to power, nor perhaps did he, until he stumbled upon the use of Kosovo as a political tool during a trip there in 1987.
During that visit (he was by then a senior Communist bureaucrat) he gave a speech, mild by today's standards, reassuring the Serb minority that Belgrade would forever protect them from the Albanian majority. But it was the first-ever challenge to Tito's holy of holies: thou shalt not encourage nationalism in any of the republics of the Yugoslav Federation. The response to the speech in Serbia was spontaneous and overwhelming, and Mr. Milosevic was on his way to power.
Although Mr. Milosevic is the prime mover behind the murder and agony that have filled our television screens for the better part of a decade, he has not acted alone. He may plan the strategy, but the Serbian people are the willing instruments of his terror. There are, of course, many decent Serbs who decry the violence, just as there were decent Germans under Hitler, but that does not excuse the Serb nation for its part in making a killing field of so much of the former Yugoslavia. (Not that Serbia bears all the guilt -- so does, for example, Franjo Tudjman's Croatia.)
Some argue that all would be well if we removed Mr. Milosevic from the scene. Too simple by a long shot! This is not a third-world dictator like Saddam Hussein who can keep power through terror and repression. Serb nationalism is the real ruler here. Whoever would follow Mr. Milosevic would certainly be just as bad. Or he might even be worse -- a true believer in the nationalist cause, rather than a political operator like Mr. Milosevic, who simply embraces patriotism for his own purposes.
None of the region's other recent wars can teach us much about what to expect in Kosovo -- a lesson that was lost on those who felt the Serbs would quickly back down after NATO started bombing. Belgrade's aggression in Croatia and Bosnia was in furtherance of a mythical "Greater Serbia" -- an effort to add territory and unite Serbs living in the neighborhood. The purpose now is to retain a piece of old Serbia -- and one that represents the best and worst of the Serbs' history. They lost their independence there to the Turks in 1389 and did not regain it for 500 years. To give up Kosovo would be to turn back the clock.
I do not believe that Mr. Milosevic has ever been ready to grant autonomy to Kosovo (a status the province held under Tito) because he sees that so long as Albanians constitute the vast majority of the population, their desire for independence will one day bear fruit. Whether that judgment was correct in the past is an open question; it is surely the case now after the recent killings and forced departures.
Thus President Clinton's warning that, because of Serb ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, the alliance may support Kosovar autonomy rather than independence must fall on deaf ears. Mr. Milosevic already believes that any compromise on his part would inevitably lead to Kosovo's independence, and thus he would never have considered abiding by the peace agreement reached in Rambouillet, France, last month even if he had signed it.
So can he continue to withstand our air attacks? If NATO is prepared to continue its air campaign indefinitely, perhaps not. But will our allies (and the American people and world opinion) support such an effort indefinitely? Probably not. It may, therefore, be a question of who gives up first. Since our bombing has rallied the Serb nation behind Mr. Milosevic, he is playing with a strong hand.
Even if Mr. Milosevic does cave in, we would face a monumental task. The return of refugees, repair of housing and public works, and the certain Kosovar demand for independence at some early point all insure instability and suggest that NATO "peacekeepers" would not be enough to assure a tranquil atmosphere.
When the Yugoslav Federation began to break up in the late 1980's and the first signs of ethnic strife became apparent, the Bush Administration took a relatively hard look at what to do. We had no illusions about the fact that to have an effect would mean involving several hundred thousand ground troops, and for better or worse we decided that it was a swamp into which we did not want to walk. NATO may no longer feel it has that choice; if so, it is vital that those who make the decisions take just as realistic a view as we did as to what intervention would entail.
Some have suggested that we should arm the Kosovars. This would insure increased Albanian intransigence both now and in the future. The Kosovo Liberation Army earned its reputation as a terrorist group and would under the best of circumstances be a factor for instability.
In short, while we could not trust the Serbs to keep their part of any bargain, neither should we put much trust in Kosovar commitments. Serbian suspicions in recent years that the Kosovars have never had their sights on anything but independence were well justified.
And if Mr. Milosevic does not give up? Then the alliance either ends its attempts to force him to meet our demands, putting as good a face on our failure as we can, or we send in ground forces in sufficient numbers and strength to defeat almost certain resistance from the Serbs. Given the terrain and the toughness of the Serbs, it would not be an easy or cost-free enterprise.
The real question is, Can NATO and the United States afford to fail? Now that we've gone this far, probably not. If anything stands in the way of an unstable 21st century it is that very alliance. Our credibility must be preserved or all the would-be Milosevics around the world will believe that they, too, can kill and maim with impunity.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report;
What's Killing the Value Managers?

 BODY:
Think value investors have it tough these days? Just ask William J. Nasgovitz, portfolio manager of the Heartland Value fund, whose own mother recently tried to pull her money out of the fund.
 "My mom wanted to buy Walgreen at 50 times earnings and sell out of the value fund after making six times her money," Mr. Nasgovitz said. "It's a great company, but it isn't worth 50 times earnings." 
 He eventually persuaded his mother to stay put. Recently, however, his son Will admitted to buying an index fund. "Another little dagger," Mr. Nasgovitz said.
 And there are many more. "Clients, consultants and advisers are all tired of talking value," he said. "They want action."
 "Action" in this case really means one thing: big growth companies and the funds that invest in them.
 Value managers like Mr. Nasgovitz have long shunned what they view as overvalued growth stocks like Coca-Cola or Wal-Mart, trading at 40 times earnings or more. Instead, they favor stocks with lower price-to-earnings or other valuation ratios.
 But that has lately brought grief for their shareholders, as stocks relatively cheap by traditional measures continue to be clobbered by the big growth companies that have paced the enormous run-up in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
 In fact, according to Morningstar Inc., the Chicago researcher, large-cap growth funds beat large-cap value funds by an average of nearly 25 percentage points over the last 12 months, the widest margin this generation. The trend held in the first quarter of 1999, with large-cap growth funds turning in an average return of 6.9 percent, versus 0.9 percent for comparable value funds. Mid-caps and small caps, which have trailed the large caps over all, have shown similar disjunction, with growth funds wildly outperforming their value siblings.
 As for Mr. Nasgovitz's small-cap value fund, it lost 8.3 percent in the last quarter, slightly less than the average for its peer group.
The desperate straits of value managers have begun to alter the investing landscape. While investors in the funds are the most obvious sufferers, entire fund organizations are being disrupted.
Some experts are questioning the accepted wisdom that investors should hew closely to a specific investment style. And the plight of the value manager is not helped by the fact that no one seems sure why value stocks have underperformed so much in the last four years.
After being stalwart in their loyalty, longtime value fund shareholders have begun to bolt: So far in 1999, three-quarters of the funds with the largest investor withdrawals have been value funds, according to AMG Data Services, a company in Arcata, Calif., that tracks mutual fund sales. Investors have pulled $10.3 billion from those 15 funds this year, with the biggest net withdrawal -- $1.2 billion -- coming from the once-storied Vanguard Windsor.
Meanwhile, so far this year, a total of $9.6 billion has poured into the two most popular growth funds, the Janus 20 and the Vanguard Growth Index, together with the Vanguard 500 Index.
The role of value funds -- especially those of the large-cap variety -- as a mainstay of the individual investor's portfolio has been diminishing. Just over a year ago, investors had $2 invested in large-cap value funds for every $1 in large growth funds, according to the Financial Research Corporation, a data gatherer in Boston. But that ratio has narrowed, to $2 in the value funds for every $1.40 in the growth funds -- a result of market gains, sales of value fund shares and purchases of growth fund shares.
And the trend is accelerating. About 98 percent of new money flowing into equity mutual funds this year has gone to growth funds, according to J. P. Morgan Securities.
Fund companies with a value bent are feeling investors' pain. Shares of Franklin Resources, a big value and international mutual fund manager, dropped 47.1 percent in the last year as some of its best-known funds, including the Mutual Series funds, lagged substantially behind the market. (By comparison, shares of Kansas City Southern Industries, which owns the red-hot Janus funds, have jumped almost one-third over the last 12 months to near an all-time high, as its assets have soared 60 percent.)
BUT as Mr. Nasgovitz can attest, it is the value managers themselves who have borne the brunt of the storm.
Poor performance recently led the Vanguard Group's chief executive, John J. Brennan, to hire stock-pickers from Sanford C. Bernstein to take over part of the Windsor fund portfolio run by the value manager Charles Freeman, a longtime protege of the legendary Windsor manager John Neff.
And last month Jean-Marie Eveillard, the value manager at Societe Generale, saw the demise of a deal to sell the company's asset management unit to Liberty Financial after $2 billion in losses and investor withdrawals from his company's mutual funds. "It has been four years of basically crossing the desert," said Mr. Eveillard, who owns 20 percent of the money management unit. "If one was not in big growth stocks, one was pretty much left with the crumbs."
For all the disruption, there is no consensus on what has caused the gap between value and growth to be so wide, or on when it will close.
Some managers think that with the advent of a new, technology-driven economy -- where economic cycles are far longer than they have been in the past -- it could be many years before value stocks return to favor for an appreciable period.
But more managers cite a combination of temporary issues. Among the big factors over the last two years, many say, were the economic crises in Asia, Russia and Brazil that moved money managers to buy the big technology and stable multinational consumer-goods companies that proved, quarter after quarter, that they could sustain profit growth even in rocky times.
Growth stocks were driven up further, they say, by what is sometimes called "closet indexing" -- the purchase of the largest-capitalization stocks in, say, the S.& P. by active fund managers. Some managers moved into these big growth stocks simply because they grew tired of missing out on the market's momentum.
The rush to Internet stocks also played a role in helping growth funds, some said, while day traders -- the ultimate momentum players -- became market movers in their own right.
Low interest rates, meanwhile, allowed bullish analysts and investors to justify ever-increasing P/E multiples. Plummeting commodity prices, driven lower by waning Asian demand, socked energy and natural resources companies, core holdings of many value portfolios.
Avoiding commodity companies was the biggest reason that the $31 billion Vanguard Windsor II fund beat so many other value funds last year, said the fund's manager, James P. Barrow. "The metals and heavy chemicals and things like that, those stocks were just terrible last year," said Mr. Barrow, whose fund rose 16.4 percent in 1998 but still trailed the average large-cap growth fund by nearly 20 percentage points. Last quarter, it rose 2.1 percent.
Managers have been feeling increased pressure from fund companies and 401(k) clients to stick with an investing style, be it large-cap growth, small-cap value or whatever, no matter what the market might do. Now, some value managers have rethought the way they appraise the value-growth distinction.
Of course, some have long been flexible. "It boxes you in," said Charles M. Royce, who manages $2.3 billion in value-oriented portfolios at Royce Funds, referring to the tendency to pigeonhole managers into narrow classifications. "It's defining what kind of stocks you buy, as opposed to what you think is the most interesting opportunity."
"We buy growth stocks when they're depressed, but we're a value manager," Mr. Royce added. "If the style police were looking over our shoulder, they would probably raise that issue."
Investors are less likely to do so: His funds have generally lost less money in the last year than the average small-cap value fund.
Mr. Barrow, the Vanguard manager, does not criticize value managers who are riding high on some high-valuation stocks, like William H. Miller 3d of Legg Mason Value Trust, a large-cap fund that rose 49.9 percent in the last year on the back of high P/E stocks like Dell Computer and America Online. "I'd rather have his numbers, and try to explain away his idea of value, than have mine," Mr. Barrow said.
FEW people, of course, predict the death of value equities, which have outperformed growth stocks for long periods in the past.
Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, has noted that from 1962 to 1989, stocks with the lowest P/E ratios performed far better as a group than stocks with the highest. And studies by Eugene F. Fama, a University of Chicago finance professor, have shown that over long periods, stocks with lower price-to-book ratios outperform those with higher ratios.
But this does not mean that value investors will feel better anytime soon.
The divergence between growth and value could continue, said George U. Sauter, manager of the $78 billion Vanguard 500 Index fund. "Just because valuations would point more to value stocks and small-cap stocks doesn't necessarily mean performance has to shift there," he added.
Mr. Sauter predicted that value stocks would eventually make a comeback but warned that investors should not base their decisions on when that will happen. Stock-picking "is child's play next to trying to call value and growth cycles," he said.
Value fund investors may have to swallow one last bitter pill anyway. While many investors think that the relatively low price-earnings and price-book ratios of value stocks provide a cushion during market corrections, that has not been true lately. Large-cap value and growth stocks fell about the same amount during the October 1997 selloff, while value stocks actually declined slightly more than growth stocks during the correction last summer.
Few value managers dare to predict when their turnaround might come, but they say that higher inflation or a strengthening economy would be strong catalysts. Some of them say, optimistically perhaps, that the recent 37 percent jump in oil-service stocks could be a harbinger. And others say growth stocks could underperform value stocks if the Internet bubble popped or if technology companies' growth abated after worries over the Year 2000 computer bug passed.
A turn could come soon, Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan, has argued. His research indicates that the last time stocks had such high valuations -- measured by comparing bond yields with the average P/E ratio of the S.& P. 500 -- was about seven years ago, when value stocks began a two-year period of sharp outperformance over growth stocks. Moreover, he thinks value stocks will be spurred by an upturn in global economic growth in the coming year.
And Mr. Eveillard of Societe Generale said things were so out of whack that companies might take matters into their own hands. He predicted that a wave of corporate arbitrage -- in which large growth companies buy smaller value companies by trading their own richly valued stock for the lower-valued shares -- might soon wash through the markets. The big companies could add to their per-share earnings even while paying huge premiums.
"As always, when a strong trend has been in place for a few years, there is no lack of people who rationalize why what has been true will continue to be true -- in other words, that value, and particularly small value, will never come back," Mr. Eveillard said. "If I thought so, I would retire."

HEADLINE: Volatile Issues Await China's Premeir in U.S.

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, April 3

 BODY:
Zhu Rongji, China's charismatic Prime Minister and the driving force behind its current ambitious economic reforms, arrives in the United States next week determined to fight the downward spiral in Chinese-American relations.
But he cannot depart from the Communist line and, in the apparent absence of any major new agreements to announce, he may have to rely on the sheer force of his personality to sway American opinion. 
 The 70-year-old Mr. Zhu, widely admired in China for his frank talk and impatience with incompetent officials, will have to confront head-on the many political disputes that have come to a boil since his trip was conceived in the afterglow of President Clinton's visit to China last year. Human rights, accusations of Chinese nuclear spying, the military balance with Taiwan and a widening trade gap are all factors that have soured a skeptical Congress on Washington's and Beijing's strategy of mutual engagement.
The Chinese, meanwhile, are outraged by the American-led bombing of Yugoslavia, which they regard as an illegal intervention in a sovereign country -- a threatening precedent as they confront possible ethnic rebellions in Tibet and the Muslim province of Xinjiang and a possible independence movement in Taiwan.
Top Chinese leaders seriously considered postponing the trip until the bombing stops. But they decided to proceed, a sign of how much China still values good relations with the United States, considered vital to its own modernization.
Mr. Zhu departs Beijing on Tuesday for a day in Los Angeles before continuing to Washington and then Denver, Chicago and New York, finishing in Boston on April 14.
Although his agenda is weightier than he had expected, Mr. Zhu still plans to spend a day discussing the environment with Vice President Al Gore -- part of his original agenda of bolstering economic ties with the United States and developing projects to fight China's severe environmental pollution.
But negotiations for entry to the World Trade Organization have stalled because China could not agree to open its markets as broadly as the United States demanded -- meaning there will be no high profile agreement to sign..
Mr. Zhu is bound to run into heavy criticism of China's human rights record, including the stiff sentences given last fall to democracy campaigners and the repression of the Dalai Lama's supporters in Tibet. Chinese and Western political analysts in Beijing say he simply cannot waver in defense of China's record, in particular now that the United States has announced it will sponsor a resolution condemning China's rights record at a United Nations meeting this month in Geneva.
Any departure from the Communist Party line would undermine the Prime Minister's power, political analysts say. Still, if any Chinese leader can carry off such a prickly trip, it is Mr. Zhu. A former Mayor of Shanghai, where he courted foreign investors, Mr. Zhu knows the West and talks with a absence of Marxist cant. His spectacular rise to power, after years as a political outcast, seemed based on competence alone and he is respected in China for his intellect.
"He's a smart leader with great personal charisma, and is very adept at using it to sell his messages," said Zhang Xiaojin, a professor of international politics at People's University in Beijing. "This trip comes at a critical time, and what he does could have an important impact on the long-term development of the Chinese-American relationship."
In his only public statements on the American visit, at a rare news conference on March 15, Mr. Zhu said, "The goal of my visit is to tell you the truth and also to let you vent your anger and voice your complaints. It is also to resume the good momentum toward building a constructive strategic partnership."
Rightly or wrongly, the Chinese feel terribly misunderstood in the United States. In the view of many Chinese, Mr. Zhu and President Jiang Zemin are bravely steering the country through a painful transition toward a market-oriented economy. Those Chinese, unlike the dissidents whose cause is important to many in the West, see China as a country where the rule of law is expanding and people have unprecedented freedom in their personal lives, if not in politics. And Taiwan, people here note, is internationally recognized as an inalienable part of China.
So why are Americans so stringent about China's entry to the World Trade Organization? Why so much fuss about the arrest of some disruptive radicals, and why the threat to create an open military alliance with Taiwan? "Zhu Rongji will try to get the American people to understand the real situation in China," said Xiong Zhiyong, dean of the Foreign Affairs College in Beijing.
However, Mr. Zhu and other Chinese leaders tend to underestimate the depth of American concerns over rights, trade and foreign policy, said David Shambaugh, a China expert at George Washington University and the Brookings Institution in Washington. Instead, they tend to attribute criticism to a small cabal of enemies.
"They don't understand that the broad masses see China through suspicious eyes," Mr. Shambaugh said, adding that a host of American interest groups, from the religious right to labor to supporters of the Dalai Lama, may all voice complaints.
Mr. Zhu is likely to be at his persuasive best when he discusses economics, an area where he has broad knowledge and unusually sweeping powers. Earlier in this decade, Mr. Zhu guided China out of rampant inflation without stifling economic growth, an achievement praised worldwide.
Still, while China is gradually opening to foreign companies and forcing its state firms to adapt to the market, Mr. Zhu is no Adam Smith. He has been a Communist since 1949, his career largely in central planning. His strategy of wringing out bloated state enterprises is intended to save the state sector, not liquidate it.
On human rights, Mr. Zhu can -- if he chooses -- assert a certain authority to debating the issue because he was a victim of persecution himself.
In 1957, as a rising official of the state planning commission, Mr. Zhu was branded a "rightist," pushed out of his job and allowed only to work as a math teacher. Then, as Mao's Great Cultural Revolution began in 1966, he was sent to the countryside in Hubei province, where he worked on a farm and taught math. Mr. Zhu was able to return to government work only in 1973, as the late Deng Xiaoping, an economic reformer, regained power.
But current leaders here make a distinction between the "excesses" of the Maoist past and their present demand for social stability as they pursue economic changes whose consequences are unpredictable. Their notion of stability means stamping out any threats to the rule of the Communist Party, which leads them to imprison advocates of democracy despite international criticism.

HEADLINE: As It Opens to Outsiders, Cuba Is Infected by Crime

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: HAVANA, April 2

 BODY:
Never mind that one robber had second thoughts and was replaced at the last minute or that another did not shoot as planned. Or that the bounty was only $6,000 instead of the expected $30,000, or that the whole gang of seven men was arrested in less than three weeks.
In the annals of crime in revolutionary Cuba, the assault on a Government armored van in daylight last December during which five people were wounded was a botched but spectacular act of boldness. 
 "I first heard the shots, then I saw the wounded people go by," said Marta Acosta, 59, who lives across the street from La Arcada, the cluster of dollar stores in the municipality of Guanabacoa here that was the scene of a shootout between one of the thieves and two armored van workers picking up the shopping center's receipts. "It was shocking."
Indeed, the high-profile caper was the kind that Government officials used to associate more with the ills of American society than with their highly policed island. But today Cuba, which for decades was immune to the high crime rates of more open societies, is itself grappling with a rising tide of common crime that has swelled in the last year.
The rise is taking place as Cubans struggle with hardship piled up by the collapse of their Soviet patron 10 years ago, Communist Party policies and more than three decades of economic embargo by the United States. Necessity now leads scores of people to steal from work places, to earn dollars as illegal drivers or prostitutes and to join a thriving black market. In rural areas, livestock theft is such a problem, Government officials said, that some people take their cows into their homes at night.
But the problem has also been fueled by the opportunity that has arrived here along with increasing numbers of foreign tourists as the Government has slowly tried to open the island to outsiders.
President Fidel Castro himself sounded the alarm about crime in a speech three months ago to the Revolutionary National Police, associating it with a creeping moral laxity and Cuba's opening to dollars, tourists and foreign investment in the mid-1990's, but noting that those were the very sectors crime now endangered. Two Italian tourists were fatally shot last September during a robbery, even though handguns are not prevalent and legal access to them is tightly restricted.
"In the fight against crime we're also defending the prestige of the country and its economy," Mr. Castro said. "The rise in crime discourages tourism, aside from the damage it causes to 11 million citizens and the uneasiness it produces."
In response to the crime wave, the Government has stationed police officers on almost every corner in Havana's tourist areas and in February stiffened penalties for crimes ranging from drug trafficking and pimping to armed robbery and the illegal trade in beef.
The deployment of special police officers distinctive for their black berets has given parts of Havana, where officials say 80 percent of the island's crime take place, the feel of a city under siege. In some areas the young officers are often seen checking the identification cards of Cubans, writing tickets for some infraction or giving instructions to drivers, cyclists and passers-by through loudspeakers.
The crackdown, which Government officials say is already working, has been welcomed by many Cubans and foreigners who have been victims of pickpockets and burglaries. But the heightened vigilance is also stifling what some Cubans say is their only way to make ends meet.
What is most notable has been the virtual disappearance of prostitutes from the streets after they have either being sent back home to the countryside or interned in "rehabilitation centers," work camps where repeat offenders receive counseling while putting in up to four years of agricultural and other labor. While not illegal here or penalized as a criminal offense, prostitution is regarded as "antisocial" and a magnet for related crime such a drug use.
In his speech, Mr. Castro, disclosing rarely published crime information, said the use of Cuba as a transshipment point for Colombian cocaine destined for the United States and Europe "persists." And he announced new, stricter penalties for drug trafficking, which this year were made to range from 15 years in prison to death. As an offshoot of the trafficking, there has also been increased drug use in Cuba, Mr. Castro said.
The Cuban leader also noted a loosening of morals. He excoriated Cubans who drive tourists around and rent out rooms illegally, police officers who accept bribes, parents and pimps who induce young women to sell their bodies and those who steal merchandise from their jobs.
"We have to fight through every legal means, including public shame," he said. "We have to inspect the inspectors, and also control the controllers."
But American and other Western officials say more controls only invite more lawbreaking because illegal activity is the only way many Cubans who do not get dollar remittances from family members in the United States can complement their meager state salaries, most of which are paid in a local currency that is no longer accepted for many transactions that now take place in dollars.
A 31-year-old driver with a wife and two young sons who said he earned 260 pesos a month, or $13, making bricks, said he could make $40 or more driving a foreigner around for the day.
Some Western officials said that the anticrime measures and policing went beyond what was warranted, serving to complement the increased anti-American statements and a law, also passed in February, to rein in the small but growing number of dissidents and independent journalists.
"There was an impetus for more opening within Cuba and from foreign countries that Castro feels went too far," a Western diplomat here said. "He's now aiming at telling us, 'No, we stay where we are.' That's rather unrealistic. The train is already moving."
Some Cubans say one reason for the rampant underground activity is that legal alternatives, like the private restaurants and other enterprises allowed since the mid-1990's as a way to deal with the economic crisis, are too strictly regulated to make them worth the effort.
A retiree who rents rooms in his house to tourists here said he had to pay 80 percent of his rental income to the Government. "You can't stand out" financially, said the man, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
At a dimly lit nightclub here near El Malecon, the capital's seaside boulevard, some 40 young women in tight outfits and platform shoes milled around the bar shortly before midnight on Thursday, waiting for the "extranjeros," or foreigners, to pick them up. Despite the crackdown, many prostitutes have merely gone underground, meeting men indoors, dressing more demurely or working through pimps.
"The situation is horrible," said a 32-year-old woman and mother of two young sons, who said she is stopped almost every day by police officers but is let go after showing her identification card
"They're squeezing us too much," she said, asking a reporter three times during a short conversation whether she was a police officer. "They don't let us breathe," she said. "Look at all these youths. Do you think we'd be here if not for the need?"
But Jose Luis Toledo, president of the judicial affairs commission of Cuba's National Assembly of People's Power, which passed the tougher anticrime measures, argued in a recent interview that while economic need was "undoubtedly" a factor in illegal activity, most lawbreakers in Cuba are "individualists wanting to satisfy personal preferences."
"Those who engage in such activity are a minority," he said. "Here we have a majority identified with the revolution and willing to make sacrifices. We are trying to guarantee the safety of that majority."

HEADLINE: India Offers Rights to Attract Its Offspring's Cash

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 3

 BODY:
The Indian Government this week initiated a program that will make it easier for people of Indian descent sprinkled around the globe to travel to their familial homeland and to invest in it, but stopped short of giving them the right to vote, as many of them have sought.
The hope is that doctors, lawyers and bankers, as well as executives in multinational corporations and others among the millions of people of Indian descent living around the world will invest in India, or convince others with deep corporate pockets to do so, contributing to the country's economic growth, officials said. 
 "There will be a broader mass base who may be willing to invest in India," said Anin Trigunayat, an officer in the passport and visa division of the Ministry of External Affairs.
The new program came in the same week that Indian officials announced loosened import restrictions on almost 900 consumer and agricultural goods, a step aimed at encouraging foreign trade.
Indian embassies and consular offices this week began accepting applications for the so-called Persons of Indian Origin card, which will be issued for a fee of $1,000 and be good for 20 years. It will entitle people of Indian descent who are citizens of other countries to travel to India without a visa, buy and sell real estate here (except for farmland), invest in Government bonds that only Indian citizens living abroad could buy before, and apply for admission to Indian colleges.
The steps are part of a broader recognition by a growing number of countries that people who move abroad remain potentially valuable contributors in an economically interdependent world.
For the large and prosperous settlements of Indians in the United States, Canada and the Caribbean, the new card will make it easier to sustain close ties to India. Cheaper air fares and telephone rates, as well as communication by E-mail and fax, have already tightened the connections between India and its diaspora of about 15 million people.
"I have seen the hunger of Indians abroad to have their children linked to their country of origin," said Home Minister L. K. Advani, who said introduction of the card was motivated by a desire for closer ties between india and its disaspora, not for their investment dollars.
A number of nations have gone even further than India, allowing dual citizenship for emigrants. For example, Mexico, Costa Rica, Italy and the Dominican Republic permit their nationals to retain native citizenship, with full political rights, even after they become citizens of other countries.
Mr. Advani said his political party, the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, supports dual citizenship, but does not now have the political support to win approval for a constitutional amendment.
However, the new card is a step toward welcoming back people of Indian descent, he said. All Indians who have become citizens of other countries, as well as their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren, will be eligible for the card. People from neighboring Pakistan and Bangladesh, however, will not be eligible because officials say they worry that the card could become a vehicle for illegal immigration.
Since India began opening its economy in 1991 to greater foreign investment, Indian citizens living abroad and people of Indian descent have accounted for almost a quarter of the direct foreign investment, officials said.
"I hope the new card will encourage more investment," said A. R. Nanda, the chief commissioner for Investments and Non-Resident Indians at the Government's Indian Investment Center. "The main advantage is that they don't have to bother about a visa. They can come and go whenever they want. It's hassle-free."

HEADLINE: 1999 BASEBALL PREVIEW;
The Haves Have It and the Nots Don't

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Baseball people have probably spent more time this winter talking about the growing disparity in team payrolls than they have about this year's top rookies or even Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa.
Officials, owners, general managers and other club executives all lament the disparity and predict doom and gloom for those teams -- more than half the clubs in the majors -- whose payrolls will be under $50 million this year. The first ball has not been thrown out for tonight's season-opening game in Monterrey, Mexico, and already 16 of the 30 teams, if not more, they say, have no chance to contend for the playoffs six months from now. 
 Payroll disparity is No. 1 on management's list of problems. Commissioner Bud Selig, in fact, has named a blue-ribbon panel to try to find a solution to the problem that has the Yankees opening the season with an $85 million payroll and the Montreal Expos paying about one-fifth of that.
Players are not represented on the panel; officials have not asked them what they think. On a recent HBO "Real Sports" segment dealing with the disparity, Tom Hicks, owner of the Texas Rangers, had this to say of the union's opposition to a salary cap: "If 85 or 90 percent of their constituents are unhappy because they don't have a chance to win on the day the season opens, the union's going to change."
Nowhere near that percentage of players, however, is unhappy with their contending status. Some are, to be sure. But a growing number has reason to like the disparity because it has created jobs for them. That view became evident this spring during interviews with dozens of players and managers on teams that are the have-nots or the haves.
"If you're going to have a team in that predicament, they're going to have a lot of young guys who are glad to have a chance of playing," said Kevin Brown, whose $105 million contract with the Los Angeles Dodgers magnified the disparity. "They're getting a chance to get their foot in the door and start their big league careers. It's hard to damn that situation. It's produced a lot of good players."
Furthermore, players even on low-paid teams refuse to begin a season feeling beaten. "If you're a major leaguer, you shouldn't be coming into a clubhouse at the beginning of the season saying you don't have a chance," said Dustin Hermanson of Montreal. "If you do, you shouldn't be in the major leagues. I believe in Cinderella stories."
Other players do see the problem that management officials and fans see. "The disparity is definitely ridiculous," said Ed Sprague, Pittsburgh's veteran third baseman. "The number of teams with a legitimate shot every year is shrinking. Something needs to be done. I think players are starting to realize that. I don't think the playing field should be totally equal. But I think the disparity needs to shrink a little bit. I don't think you can have a team with a $90 million payroll and one with a $10 million payroll. That's not a healthy industry."
The players who expressed Sprague's view, though, generally also said they felt the owners were the ones who should devise a solution. And while they were at it, they said the owners shouldn't bother proposing any kind of a payroll cap. The last such suggestion led to a labor dispute that nearly killed the game.
In the winterlong anguish over disparity, though, no one had considered the benefits some of the players and managers discussed.
Mike Maddux, a veteran relief pitcher with the Expos, who have the major leagues' lowest payroll, has seen first-hand the point Brown made. His teammates, Maddux said, don't feel deprived of a chance to win.
"I don't think that's a factor for anyone here," he said one day in Jupiter, Fla. "You have young guys trying to establish themselves. They get their time in. In the past, Montreal has been a feeder for other clubs. A lot of guys see that here and use it as an apprenticeship."
Tom Kelly and Tony Muser, managers of two economically challenged teams, use the system as motivation for their young players.
"I told the players what an avenue that has opened up for you," said Kelly, who has 10 rookies among his 25 Minnesota players. "It's a wonderful avenue to drive down. They're not stupid. They see a chance here to play in the big leagues."
Todd Walker, the Twins' second baseman, is good enough that he would have won a job in the majors under any system, but he acknowledged the break young players get with teams like the Twins.
"We as players consider it a blessing just to be in the big leagues and have an opportunity to play," the third-year player said. "You'd like to make the playoffs and win some championship games, but we don't count ourselves out based on economics."
Muser, the Kansas City manager, said he has told his players, young and older, to take advantage of the system.
"We've got guys in here who have a chance to be major league players who wouldn't have a chance somewhere else," he said. "We have guys like Rey Sanchez and Joe Randa who have a chance to be everyday players that were said to be platoon-type players, and maybe they are. But here they're not."
Jeff King has experienced downsizing in Pittsburgh and Kansas City, making him an expert on the topic.
"We've got some young guys on this team who are going to turn out to be very good players," King, the Royals' first baseman, said. But he added a caveat that has been demonstrated vividly in Montreal.
"It's just going to be a matter of time before they won't be able to keep those guys," he said. "That's why nothing is going to change. When I was just coming up, teams were holding on to these guys until they were free agents. Now after three or four years guys are making so much money that they probably won't be able to hold onto them. That's something somebody's going to have to think about and maybe try to fix."
Although opening-day payrolls won't be set until teams name their 25-man rosters and players who open on the disabled list, it is a given that half a dozen teams will have payrolls beyond or just under $70 million. They and another six or eight with payrolls exceeding $50 million are considered the only teams with a chance for the playoffs. The other, lower-paid teams are fodder for the wealthy.
"I feel that the disparity in the payrolls is obviously creating a bad situation for a lot of teams," Mike Mordecai of Montreal said. "Looking at it from the fans' standpoint, why would they want to waste their money and go see a team that isn't going to finish in the top four in the division?"
For the most part, players said that owners have to create a more level playing field by sharing more of their revenue and requiring that clubs that receive money under the revenue-sharing plan use it for their payrolls. The Expos received $13 million under baseball's partially implemented welfare plan last year but had only an $8.3 million payroll. They acknowledge that they made money.
Players also said that if particular owners can't afford to compete, they should sell their teams, and if particular cities can't support teams, the teams should move. Tim Belcher, a veteran starter now with Anaheim after having spent the past three seasons in Kansas City, suggested that baseball created a problem by overexpanding.
Asked if the Players Association should do anything to deal with the problem, Mordecai said, "Listen to what the owners have to offer at the next bargaining session."
Jeff Montgomery of Kansas City, who has been active in union affairs, said the union should "take the pulse of the players to see how guys feel over all."
"It's the responsibility of our association," the veteran closer added, "to decide what's best, not just for the players but for baseball. Players are only going to prosper if baseball prospers and that's what worries me about baseball. I don't know how much longer it's going to go on like this before there's a problem that's beyond repair."
David Cone of the Yankees, the union's most articulate spokesman among its members, acknowledged some frustration among players on have-not teams. But he cautioned both sides to await further results of the plans in place and the opening of the half-dozen stadiums under construction.
"Let's get all the data in and re-evaluate," Cone said. "Everybody says we need a more level playing field. Everybody seems to agree, but how do you get that? How much does the luxury tax help? How much revenue-sharing is really needed? How much will all these new stadiums help solve some of these problems? They aren't the end-all answer to the problems, but you have to start there."
Does he talk to players on other teams about the situation? "Sure I do," Cone said. "A lot of them want to get traded to contenders."

HEADLINE: Board of Trade Staying Put But Gets Smaller City Deal

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Board of Trade plans to modernize its current trading complex at the World Trade Center, but it will do so with $31 million in government incentives instead of a $98.5 million deal it had won three years ago after threatening to move to New Jersey.
The Board of Trade, a combination of the Cotton Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, plans to spend about $50 million on computerized trading equipment for its longtime home at 4 World Trade Center in lower Manhattan. 
 The plans are far less ambitious today than in 1996, when the two exchanges persuaded city and state officials to grant them the $98.5 million incentive package for a new headquarters by threatening to jump to Jersey City. But then nothing happened, either because the exchanges' officials could not afford to move at all, or because they changed their plans.
The city and state's 1996 offer expired in September. The commodity traders then scrambled to salvage some public subsidies. The new deal is expected to be formally announced this week.
"We're delighted to keep the New York Board of Trade and all their jobs in the city, especially at this reduced price," said Randy Levine, the Deputy Mayor for economic development. "The Board of Trade tells us they expect to grow in the future."
James Bowe, president of the Board of Trade, declined comment.
Under the new deal, the Board of Trade would get a rent subsidy at the World Trade Center worth about $17.5 million, a $3.5 million reduction in sales taxes on new equipment and a $5 million capital contribution from the Empire State Development Corporation. The Board of Trade would also get a low-interest loan from the state that would save the exchanges nearly $5 million.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said the deal would allow New York to retain 2,800 jobs and create an additional 3,600 jobs over 15 years. The deal would also allow the city to use a publicly owned site on Greenwich Street, between Murray and Warren Streets, for other economic development projects. It had been set aside for the Board of Trade's proposed $120 million headquarters.
"Admittedly, it's an open question whether the exchanges would have really moved to Jersey," Mr. Gargano said. "But the important thing is that they are committing to adding 3,600, fairly high-paying jobs. We have in our agreement particular penalties if they don't reach those job levels."
The Board of Trade may find it hard to meet those goals. The number of commodity brokers and dealers in New York City rose to 3,425 last year, from 3,085 in 1997. But that is still well below the peak of 4,224 in 1989.
The deal with the Board of Trade is only the latest in a long line of subsidy packages the city has provided the financial industry when companies threatened to move to New Jersey or Connecticut. Criticism of the deals has mounted in recent years as both conservative and liberal analysts have said they doubted that the companies actually intended to move. The critics regard the deals as corporate welfare that deprive the city of resources for public transportation, bridges, schools and libraries.
"It looks like there's no end to this," said James Parrott, chief economist for the Fiscal Policy Institute, a nonprofit research organization supported by unions, foundations and other groups. "They're content to declare victory in the battle to retain the city's status as a financial center. As a consequence, they're unable to shift their attention to other pressing economic needs."
In the last six years, the Giuliani administration has granted more than $1.6 billion in tax breaks, electricity subsidies and cash to 19 financial corporations and 4 stock or commodity exchanges.
It is often difficult to gauge the full value of the incentives. The city's Economic Development Corporation has stopped publishing a detailed list of past deals and more recently stopped announcing new ones. But even when the deals were announced, some subsidies were never mentioned in speeches or written descriptions.
In the case of the New York Mercantile Exchange, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said in August 1994 that they would provide $184 million in incentives that would enable the exchange to build a new $220 million, 500,000-square-foot trading complex at Battery Park City instead of moving to New Jersey. The package included a $125 million cash grant. Exchange officials said the cash grant later grew to $129 million.
The announcement did not say that the state-controlled Battery Park City Authority would charge the Mercantile Exchange a rent of only $1 million a year, or about $16.5 million less than the market rate, real estate brokers said.
That deal became the model for the other financial exchanges. In 1996, city officials said they would provide only $34 million for the Cotton Exchange and the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, but the two exchanges held out until the city and state put a $98.5 million package on the table.
"They put so much pressure on us, saying they would leave the city because they were so crowded at the World Trade Center," Mr. Gargano said. "They got the deal and we never heard from them again. Now the story has changed and we provided new incentives for them."
