HEADLINE: Streetscapes /The Grand Concourse in the Bronx;
Will It Be City's Thinnest, Longest Historic District?

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
A LECTURE, an exhibition -- and landmark designation? Supporters of the Bronx's four-mile-plus Grand Concourse are hoping to make it the city's thinnest, longest historic district.
The Concourse has a dual fame: as a destination address for successful residents of the Lower East Side and other immigrant neighborhoods from the 1920's through the 1940's, and as a collection of unusual Art Deco buildings. But is it enough for landmark designation? 
 The Grand Concourse was planned in the early 1890's for carriage access to new parkland in the northern Bronx. The planner was Louis S. Risse, an engineer and surveyor, who aligned the Concourse with what he later described as "a magnificent ridge" just east of Jerome Avenue, with fewer intersections than usual. "It would be a sacrilege against nature to disturb" this feature by designing in the usual rectangular block system, he wrote in an undated history of the street.
A few early private houses survive, but most of the Grand Concourse's extant early buildings are five- or six-story apartment houses, just under the height limit that triggered more expensive fireproofing requirements. Except for height, until 1930 the typical Grand Concourse facade was not too different from those on Park or West End Avenues in Manhattan.
In his "A History of Housing in New York City" (Columbia University Press, 1990) Richard Plunz describes the typical Grand Concourse building as a "people's palazzo."
The Depression pretty much stopped construction in Manhattan, but by the mid-1930's the new IND subway line prompted renewed development on the Grand Concourse -- with a big difference. The new Art Deco style prevailed, in part because the newest apartment marketing gimmick, corner windows, broke apart the traditional model of a building as a big box outlined by a solid frame.
A typical Art Deco building is at 1947 Grand Concourse, at the southwest corner of 178th Street, designed by H. Herbert Lilien and finished in 1939. The facade is a restless collision of horizontal, colored banding and vertical brick piers. The lobby is a neat 1930's time capsule: original embossed elevator doors, domed recessed ceiling illumination and Mondrian-style terrazzo floors.
A 1939 article promoting the building in "Buildings and Building Management" listed shower stalls, sunken living rooms, incinerators, Venetian blinds, electric refrigerators and aluminum main entrance doors as special attractions.
Perhaps the most spectacular Art Deco apartment house on the avenue is Horace Ginsbern's 1150 Grand Concourse, built in 1937 at McClellan Place, a few blocks up from the Bronx County Courthouse. The Art Moderne-style facade is a complicated pattern of curved corners and sloping balcony walls, without the zigzag decoration of other Art Deco buildings.
But what makes people stop and stare is the astounding color-mosaic fantasy of undersea life -- tendrils, fish, jellyfish and bubbles -- flanking the main doors. The parts of the main doors that remain are remarkable constructions of stainless steel and brass. The entry area is surrounded by a field of dark cast stone with inset green glass forms.
AS along most of the Grand Concourse, people have become used to astonished passers-by; the lobby attendant at 1150 recently waved a visitor inside casually -- "In the summer this happens almost every day," she said. The lobby has two large murals of fantastic nature scenes, by C. P. Graves and Rene Graves, and a terrazzo floor that inventively mixes small and large stone chips in contrasting colors. A wall of thick frosted glass screens the mail room.
Except for occasional damage, the lobby looks more like an imported period room on loan to the Museum of Modern Art than a hall in a middle-class building.
The Grand Concourse took a nose dive in the 1960's, as residents left for Co-op City and the suburbs. But if new windows are any guideline, housing economics are better -- almost every building has ripped out its original windows for aluminum replacements in the standard brown that has spread over New York.
On April 29 at 5 P.M., the photographer Carl Rosenstein will present a slide lecture, "A Bronx Tale," covering the Art Deco of the Grand Concourse and adjacent areas, at the Flom Auditorium of the Walsh Family Library at Fordham University in Bronx, near the corner of Webster Avenue and Fordham Road. (Information: (718) 817-3570).
Mr. Rosenstein's lecture is related to an exhibition of his photographs, "Bronx Art Deco and the Grand Concourse," through June 30 at the library. (Hours vary; information: (718) 817-3595).
At the same time a long-percolating plan to ask for a Grand Concourse Historic District is nearing a conclusion. Clint Roswell, press secretary for Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, says that the Bronx Landmarks Task Force is a few months away from recommending that the entire Concourse be designated.
One possible problem with such a designation is that the Art Deco buildings on the Grand Concourse are few and far between -- perhaps one in 20. In the "A.I.A. Guide to New York City" (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, 1988), Norval White and Elliot Willensky describe the Art Deco buildings as "sprinkled between the older dour apartment blocks of the 1920's."
Regardless of the outcome of a historic-district request, Mr. Ferrer is planning a $30 million redesign of the Concourse roadway. "We want less traffic, particularly less truck traffic," Mr. Roswell said. The proposal includes more trees, streetscape improvements and roadway realignment.
Mr. Roswell says that changes in the last few years have made the Concourse much safer, in terms of traffic accidents. "But it's still a very heavily used traffic artery," he says, "and we want to make it more of a greenlink."

HEADLINE: A Broker Whose Line Is Specialty Food

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
SIX kinds of olive oil and a dozen or more different types of tea compete for shelf space in specialty markets, put there by Ron Maiorino, a food broker in Chappaqua.
Six years ago, Mr. Maiorino, who was 42 at the time, left a top job with a large food distributor to form his own company, R. J. M. Trading. "Looking back, it probably wasn't the best time to go into business for myself," he recalled. "My wife was pregnant. We had just put a new addition on our house, but I didn't need a lot of capital to get started. A phone, stationery, a fax -- that was it. And I knew sales of specialty food were growing bigger every year." 
 The robust economy, the quest for a healthier life style and more sophisticated tastes in food were reasons Mr. Maiorino cited for the growth.
"For instance, take tea," he said. "Seventeen years ago when I started in the food business, black tea in bags dominated the market. Now there are all kinds of loose teas and high-quality teas, including herbal teas, readily available. And the same is true for olive oil. Producers from Italy, Spain, Greece and most recently California are supplying a market that gets bigger and bigger."
Mr. Maiorino, who describes himself as "a manufacturer's rep whose line happens to be food," started in business with a couple of olive oil lines. "I had a good customer base in Connecticut, and they bought what I had," he said.
Although some food brokers carry 100 or more lines, Mr. Maiorino decided to limit himself to about 20. "After all, how many lines can a broker carry, give personal service and still understand each client's special market niche?" he said. "I sought out quality products, and at the Fancy Food Show in California I found several being made by small up-and-coming companies. One was making terrific biscotti. They were looking for representation in the East. I still represent the biscotti company along with a hand-picked line of quality products that I can be enthusiastic about."
Products, he said, like Tabard Farm's Route 11 Potato Chips. ("They're handmade in small batches in six flavors.") Or the Tazo line of teas and specialty coffees. ("The winner of the 1995 Specialty Coffee Association of America's Best Product Line.") And Moonstruck Chocolatier, which offers handmade truffles and seasonal delicacies in unusual packaging.
Mr. Maiorino knows a lot about food. "At one point, I wanted to be a chef," he said. "I was always interested in food, and during summers of sharing houses in the Hamptons I was the one who did the cooking with my friends encouraging me."
When he was in his mid-20's, he made his first career change. "I went back to school for a totally different career," he said. "I had a degree in psychology and was working at a diagnostic center for kids on Staten Island, but after five years I felt the world was going on while I was in a backwater. So I got a job at Brooklyn College at night and went to the New York Restaurant school, planning to become a chef."
Yet that world was too much for him when he was exposed to the noise and heat of a restaurant kitchen for the first time. "It was pretty intense," he said. "Not an environment I was comfortable in. So when -- through a friend -- I was offered a job as an assistant restaurant manager at Macy's, I took it and liked it. I learned a lot."
Mr. Maiorino was eventually transferred to the Macy's marketplace division. "The marketplace was sensational," he said. "A store within a store that carried some of the best gourmet foods around, including smoked fish, cheeses, coffees and teas. I liked the job immediately, It was so diversified. Salesmen were calling on me, and that's how I learned how the specialty food business worked. I also developed an expertise in merchandising, which has been invaluable to me."
He switched to the wholesale side, joining Belcanto Foods, a distributor of imported olive oil, pasta and Italian cheeses in Manhattan. Given only a few established accounts, he developed a following in the New York City area within six months.
His aggressiveness paid off, and he moved on to a larger specialty food distributing company, serving as its sales representative in Connecticut.
"I called on all the top-of-the-line specialty food shops, and in two years' time I doubled existing sales," he said. "Promotions followed, and I eventually became district manager of New England."
When he decided to go into business for himself, he said, his contacts made all the difference. "Initially, I was able to draw on a customer base in Connecticut that bought the lines I had," he said. "I did $200,000 the first year and doubled that amount by the end of the second year."
Mr. Maiorino estimates that he drives at least 600 miles a week, calling on customers in New York, Connecticut and New Jersey. "My customers are almost every major specialty retailer in the New York tristate area," he said. "Accounts include Dean & DeLuca, Grace's Marketplace, Macy's, Balducci's, Zabar's, Bloomingdale's and the Hay Day markets in Westchester and Connecticut. The newest is ABC Carpets. They opened a sensational food hall. I also place a lot of lines with distributors who have 10 sales people selling my customers' products."
Because brokers depend entirely on commissions, Mr. Maiorino observed: "You rely on quality accounts. I don't get paid until the customer pays the vendor, so deadbeats are a problem. I shy away from taking on start-up companies that are not well financed. Early on I took on a terrific product, but the company was short on capital, so they used my commission. I lost about $2,000 but learned a lesson."
Although the demand for specialty foods is high, Mr. Maiorino said: "It's very hard to launch a new food product. You need a lot of money, great packaging and merchandising know-how. In the food business, the fight for shelf space is an eternal battle."

HEADLINE: TELEVISION/RADIO;
Giving a Guerrilla Journalist the Freedom of Cable

BYLINE: By WARREN BERGER; Warren Berger is the founding editor of One, a magazine about advertising.

 BODY:
IN the debut episode of "The Awful Truth," the new series created by the guerrilla-style documentary filmmaker Michael Moore, viewers meet Christopher Donahue, a Florida man with a life-threatening pancreatic illness. Mr. Donahue desperately needs a transplant, but his health care provider, Humana, refuses to pay for the operation.
On a conventional newsmagazine program, Mr. Donahue's plight might have inspired grave tones and earnest pleas from a well-coiffed correspondent. For Mr. Moore, it is not just a call to action but an opportunity to create mischief. With cameras rolling, he accompanies the ailing Mr. Donahue on a stroll through the corporate offices of Humana, where Mr. Moore asks a sweating, stonewalling public relations official to help him choose in advance a nice coffin for Mr. Donahue. Subsequently, Mr. Moore stages a mock funeral for Mr. Donahue on the lawn of Humana's headquarters in Louisville, Ky. Mr. Moore himself delivers a eulogy for the man standing beside him: "I remember Chris always used to say," Mr. Moore begins, then leans toward Mr. Donahue and asks, "What did you always say?" Mr. Donahue replies, "I just want a pancreas." Before long, Mr. Moore has so thoroughly embarrassed Humana that the company responds by reconsidering in Mr. Donahue's favor. 
 Those familiar with Mr. Moore's work, particularly his breakthrough documentary film in 1989, "Roger and Me," and his Emmy-winning series "'TV Nation," will recognize that the basic ingredients remain the same in "'The Awful Truth," which has its premiere next Sunday at 9 P.M. on Bravo. As in the past, Mr. Moore can be counted on to defend downtrodden "ordinary people" like Mr. Donahue while taking aim at rigid (and some might say easy) targets like bureaucratic corporations and double-talking politicians. As ever, his chief weapons are his unblinking movie camera and his wicked, offbeat sense of humor, which usually manages to keep him from seeming sanctimonious as he plays a kind of shlumpy Robin Hood.
Mr. Moore's arrival on Bravo could be viewed as a step down for someone who once occupied a prime-time slot on NBC, then one on Fox, with "TV Nation," which ran sporadically during the 1994 and 1995 television seasons. But Mr. Moore insists that he is pleased to be returning to television on cable, where, he said, he is granted more freedom to take on subjects that might be taboo on broadcast networks.
"This show is going to be everything 'TV Nation' would have been if we didn't have the heavy hand of network standards and practices on us," Mr. Moore declared on a recent evening at a Manhattan editing suite, where he was putting the finishing touches on a scene from "The Awful Truth." The segment shows Mr. Moore bringing a group of Christmas carolers to the headquarters of a tobacco company, where he leads them in song in the lobby. The catch: The carolers, all lung cancer victims, sing with croaky artificial voice boxes, as mortified tobacco executives stand by helplessly and watch. "That's something you've never seen on TV before," Mr. Moore said.
Certainly not on Bravo, whose viewers are accustomed to the more mellifluous singing of, say, Luciano Pavarotti. Some viewers of the arts network are likely to be surprised by "The Awful Truth," whose rambunctious segments include one in which Mr. Moore travels with a group of homosexual men in a recreational vehicle he calls "the sodomobile" into states where sodomy is outlawed and interviews shocked local residents.
"If the show creates a little controversy, we're comfortable with that," said Ed Carroll, the general manager at Bravo, which is producing the series with the British network Channel 4. Mr. Carroll said he believed "The Awful Truth" might help Bravo connect with "viewers who haven't sampled the network before." Although "TV Nation" was never highly rated (Mr. Moore blamed poor time slots for the ratings and the show's ultimate demise), it did attract a following of younger viewers, who responded to Mr. Moore's outrageous pranks and his willingness to challenge authority.
In "The Awful Truth," Mr. Moore's fans are with him not only in spirit but in person. Mr. Moore closes and opens the show and introduces each segment standing before and interacting with a live studio audience, filled with mostly young devotees. During the taped segments, the crowd can be heard tittering and cheering whenever Mr. Moore, camera in tow, begins to advance on the bastions where he is most unwelcome (corporate America, Capitol Hill, the Deep South).
But Mr. Moore is not just a prankster playing to the youth audience, a la Tom Green of MTV, whose idea of humor is to cover himself with food. Most of Mr. Moore's segments touch on serious issues like race, class, free trade, environmentalism or health care. Mr. Carroll of Bravo believes that the channel's sophisticated viewers will respond to that aspect of the show as well as to Mr. Moore's arch humor and cinema verite style. Meanwhile, as he is wont to do, Mr. Moore sees his presence on Bravo in terms of class struggle: an arts channel "should not be the purview of only people from the upper class," he said. He promises to bring not just college students but also working-class viewers into the Bravo fold.
"They're part of my core audience, too," he said.
Mr. Moore, who invariably wears jeans and a baseball cap, and whose slumped posture and bowed knees make it seem as if he is supporting the weight of the world, remains proud of his modest background, often bringing it up with no prompting. "I didn't go to film school, and I didn't start out at Sundance," he said during a break in his editing session. Sitting like a child -- slumped, sideways, with one leg draped over the arm of a plush chair -- Mr. Moore veered between animated political discourse (true, the murder rate in New York is down, he acknowledged, but only because "they don't count people killed by the police") and personal data.
When he began filming "Roger and Me," Mr. Moore recalled, he was collecting unemployment in Flint, Mich., where he "shopped at K Mart and lived in a $27,000 house." He made the film -- in which he doggedly pursues Roger Smith, then chairman of General Motors, to confront him about the closing of G.M. plants in Flint -- "because I was angry at what General Motors had done to my town, and I was going to do something about it," he said.
"Roger and Me," one of the most successful documentaries ever made, turned Mr. Moore into an unlikely celebrity. But he resisted changing his regular-guy image or his guerrilla-film ways. On "TV Nation," he continued to stage pranks and conduct ambush interviews, often intended to make a political or social point and to make his targets look foolish. He often succeeded, with help from willing victims. (On one "TV Nation" segment, Mr. Moore showed that with a bit of lobbying, he could coax Congressmen to propose legislation designating a national holiday in honor of his series.)
Mr. Moore has drawn criticism for his ambush tactics. The television critic Tom Shales once derided him for "dragging people in front of a camera lens and humiliating them." However, Mr. Moore contends that he doesn't trick his subjects and always allows them to speak freely. "I try to present myself in as nonthreatening a way as possible," he said. "Some people end up saying things they shouldn't say because they look at me and think, 'Well, this isn't going to end up anywhere; look at him, he hasn't even shaved in a week.' "
Mr. Moore doesn't hide his political agenda, which leans heavily toward labor and usually favors liberal positions over conservative ones (though he considers himself politically independent). In the opening episode, he ridicules Kenneth Starr by staging his own more cost-effective Capitol Hill witch hunt, complete with overwrought, finger-pointing actors in Puritan garb. But Mr. Moore makes no apologies for presenting a politically biased show. Citing Comedy Central's "Daily Show," which he considers derivative of "TV Nation" but "without the politics," Mr. Moore said that because that show lacked an underlying serious message or point of view "it ends up just making fun of stupid people."
Ten years after "Roger and Me," the real issue for Mr. Moore may not be one of politics or occasional harsh treatment of subjects but of staying power. Though he has added a few new wrinkles, he remains the same basic character who burst on the scene in his debut film: the labor-loving Everyman, shambling into corporate lobbies and asking rude questions. His schtick, if it's fair to call it that, given his obvious passion, does not seem to have evolved much. Mr. Moore is aware of this and understands the need to reinvent oneself in the fickle media landscape. He insisted that he planned to limit the number of "scenes of Mike going into the lobby and jousting with public relations people," and that he would try some new creative approaches on his show. But no one should expect a kinder, gentler or apolitical Mr. Moore anytime soon. And industry moguls who see someone with a baseball cap and a movie camera coming through the revolving doors would be well advised to hide.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
In the Stampede to Big Stocks, Some Managers Are Left Behind

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
DESPITE some sharp ups and downs, the bull market in large-capitalization stocks plowed forward through the first quarter, confounding some money managers and rewarding others.
The story was no different for the five managers who have built hypothetical retirement portfolios for The New York Times: None of their portfolios lost money in the quarter, but only three beat the average return of 0.96 percent for diversified domestic equity funds, as tracked by Lipper Inc. In comparison, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index of large companies gained 4.65 percent in the period. 
 The winner for the quarter, with a return of 4.56 percent, was Sheldon Jacobs, editor of the No-Load Fund Investor in Irvington, N.Y. Mr. Jacobs's portfolio was helped by hefty stakes in large-capitalization stocks, and he expects more strong market gains.
"I anticipate that the bull market will continue through the second quarter," Mr. Jacobs said, because the factors propelling it -- low inflation, low interest rates and a strong economy -- are still in place. "I don't think that we have seen the highs for the Dow this year," he added.
Half of Mr. Jacobs's portfolio is invested in two funds: the Vanguard 500 Index, which mimics the performance of the S.& P. 500, and Vanguard Total Stock Market Index, which has much broader holdings. The portfolio also includes Vanguard Windsor II, a large-cap value fund.
Mr. Jacobs plans no changes to the portfolio, despite relatively poor showings by some of his international stock funds. "It's a long-term commitment, so for a minor drawdown it's not worth doing anything," he said.
The market bias toward large-cap stocks continues to hold back managers with more diversified portfolios, including Harold R. Evensky, a financial adviser in Coral Gables, Fla. Mr. Evensky took fourth place in the quarter, with a portfolio gain of 0.50 percent.
He remains a firm believer in asset allocation, although he said that during the quarter, a sobering market adage from John Maynard Keynes came to mind: Markets can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent.
Nonetheless, Mr. Evensky also plans no changes to his portfolio. "While value and small-cap stocks continue to buck history and significantly underperform the handful of lottery winners driving the S.& P. 500, I continue to believe in long-term investing," he said.
THE performance of the hypothetical portfolios is tracked each quarter by Lipper, which is based in Summit, N.J. It excludes sales charges, transaction costs and taxes, because most retirement money is held in tax-deferred accounts. The five managers can choose any funds open to new investors and can shift money quarterly. At the outset of the competition, in July 1993, they were asked to pick portfolios intended to grow for 20 years.
Mr. Jacobs remains the overall leader, with a gain of 140.15 percent since the contest began. In that time, the five portfolios have risen an average 111.99 percent, compared with a 227.71 percent return for the Vanguard 500 Index fund.
Eric M. Kobren, president of Kobren Insight Group and editor of Fidelity Insight in Wellesley, Mass., took second place in the quarter, with a gain of 3.11 percent. He was hurt by a 15 percent position in Fidelity Small Cap Stock as well as a 25 percent position in Fidelity Spartan Government Income, which fell as the stock market rose to record levels.
Mr. Kobren, whose portfolio is made up entirely of Fidelity funds, said that he felt uncomfortable investing only in equities with the market at such high valuations. But given the portfolio's long-term objective, combined with the economy's surprisingly strong showing, an all-stock portfolio seems in order, he said. So he is selling his bond position and buying a 20 percent stake in Fidelity Value, which he said could be a big winner if the market broadens, reflecting a modestly stronger-than-expected economy, better prospects among industrial companies and the recovery of beaten-down value stocks.
He is also adding 5 percent to his position in Fidelity Contrafund II; he said a quarter of that growth fund was invested in technology, a modest level compared with some of its most aggressive peers.
Jack A. Brill, a San Diego investment adviser who advocates "socially responsible" investing, took third place for the first quarter, with a gain of 2.64 percent. The return was bolstered by big holdings in large-cap stock funds, including Domini Social Equity, an index fund that is considered a socially responsible proxy for the S.& P. 500.
This quarter, he is replacing Calvert Capital Accumulation, a mid-cap growth fund, with IPS Millennium, a growth-and-income fund. He described the IPS Millennium fund manager, Robert Loest, as a "New Age economist" who uses a model called "evolutionary ecosystems mechanics" to evaluate how changes in technology and society affect the stock market.
Mr. Brill said the fund was not as widely screened for socially responsible investments as others in his portfolio; its major focus is on animal rights. IPS does not invest in poultry or fertilizer companies, for example, because of environmental concerns, he said.
In last place for the quarter was Susan Dziubinski, who edits the Morningstar Fund Investor. Her portfolio gained just 0.35 percent, hurt by its very limited exposure to large-cap stocks. TIAA-CREF Growth and Income, her sole large-cap fund, which she added in the last quarter, beat the S.& P. 500 by gaining 6.18 percent. But that was more than offset by holdings in small-cap stock funds like Skyline Special Equities, which fell 11.83 percent.
Ms. Dziubinski, however, plans no changes to her portfolio, which remains mostly entrenched in funds that buy small- and mid-cap stocks. She expects the high valuation of the large caps to take its toll eventually. "I just can't justify putting money into big stocks when the S.& P. 500's trailing price-earnings ratio stands near 35," she said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley Aftershocks

BYLINE: By REED ABELSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Dan Scheinman joined Cisco Systems in 1992, he was a neophyte in the ways of Silicon Valley. Leaving a job as an associate at a law firm, he was offered his choice at Cisco of a signing bonus or stock options in the company.
Mr. Scheinman chose the sure thing -- the bonus. And as Cisco's stock price, yoked to the growth of the Internet, soared over the years, this "goof," as he calls it, cost him roughly $700,000. 
 So Mr. Scheinman, now the company's general counsel, has become a true believer in the power of the stock options to create wealth. "The bigger risk is not getting options," he said. "Here, nobody thinks about salary any more."
Little wonder, given the huge windfalls that many technology stocks are providing employees -- and especially certain top technology executives. Though their salaries tend to be modest by corporate standards, options are moving the leaders of companies like Cisco and Yahoo rapidly up the ranks of the country's most highly compensated chief executives, according to an analysis of executive pay conducted for Money & Business.
Big grants of options -- which give the holder the right to buy shares at a set price for a specified time -- have long allowed technology companies to lure and retain employees without diverting cash from their own growth or damaging their often tenuous profitability. And by doing so, they have done what shareholders have demanded for a generation: linked management's interests to investors'.
But Silicon Valley's obsession with options -- an obsession increasingly shared by the rest of corporate America -- is approaching an unhealthy extreme, according to some pay consultants, recruiters and even investors. Like Internet bubble babies, too many executives, these critics say, are focused on stock performance and stock performance alone.
"The thing that concerns me the most is the trend toward building market capitalization rather than building companies," said Roger McNamee, the founder of Integral Capital Partners, a Menlo Park, Calif., investment company that has backed such fast-growing companies as Rambus Inc. and the Inktomi Corporation.
The combination of option-rich pay packages and an overheated market -- one where the performance of certain Internet highfliers seems to have little to do with fundamental performance -- is creating an employment environment that resembles a lottery, according to pay experts.
Critics warn that these packages, many of which let executives quickly convert their options into stock, are not creating a loyal work force focused on the long term. Instead, they may be encouraging a short-term mindset among employees hoping to strike it rich by joining companies whose stocks seem ready to soar.
Companies have responded by offering even more options to keep key workers, ratcheting the stakes higher and higher. "It's upped the ante for both executive talent and key engineering talent," said Steve Patchel, a senior consultant for Watson Wyatt Worldwide, a pay and benefits consulting firm.
That route is being taken by many technology companies, according to Graef Crystal, the editor of the crystalreport.com, an Internet newsletter on executive pay, who conducted the study of last year's executive compensation for Money & Business. When he looked at amounts being ladled out at a sampling of technology companies with ties to the Internet, he found that the average executive made more than twice as much as his counterpart in the rest of corporate America -- entirely because many packages were stuffed with options.
But Mr. Crystal's calculations take into account only the size of the options grants themselves, not the rise in the companies' stocks. "Obviously, if you combine huge grant size with huge price performance, you get the fourth movement of Beethoven's Ninth, complete with a 350-voice chorus," Mr. Crystal said.
For example, the increase in the value of his options in just the last year put Timothy A. Koogle, chief executive of Yahoo, in nearly the same pay league as John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric, even though G.E.'s $100 billion in sales is 500 times more than Yahoo's $200 million. Mr. Koogle, with total compensation of $22.7 million, ranks among the 20 highest-paid executives in Mr. Crystal's study -- and that does not count the one-year jump of nearly a half-billion dollars in the value of his options. Not bad for someone who was brought in to run the company less than four years ago.
As Mr. Koogle's case shows, it is no longer just the Bill Gateses of the world who become enormously wealthy as technology booms. Executives who played no role in starting a company are being given stakes that provide them with wealth akin to that of founders who had to stake everything on their dreams.
"We are rewarding professional executives with entrepreneurial rewards," said Pearl Meyer, the president of Pearl Meyer & Partners, a New York consulting firm.
Yahoo says Mr. Koogle was brought in to the company very early and is largely responsible for its success. "He put the first business model in place," said Diane Hunt, a company spokeswoman.
The danger for businesses driven by high-spiraling stocks comes in a market reversal -- a development that, for all technology's power, many observers consider inevitable.
The technology sector, of course, has always had its ups and downs. But now many more people -- not just founders and top executives, but workers on the corporate front lines -- hold options and shares. That ties them for better or worse to the current cycle. And many have never experienced "worse."
BEYOND that, many of the fresher faces in Silicon Valley "have begun to believe that they are worth the number" they are now earning, said Barry Obrand, who heads Silicon Area activities for Russell Reynolds Associates, an executive search firm. If stocks drop, he worries that many employees and executives will vanish as quickly as the paper profits on their holdings. Companies could have a hard time rebounding if key people depart.
Closer to home, the issue is what will happen to employees who have changed their life styles based on visions of a future bonanza. Anyone buying an expensive house or car, and expecting to cash in options to make the payments, could be in for a rude awakening.
To be sure, stock options are viewed as an important way to motivate employees and management. "You work differently; you work smarter," said Matt Ward, chief executive of WestWard Pay Strategies, a consulting concern in San Francisco. "Everybody's there to get the mission accomplished" -- that is, to bolster shareholder returns.
This mind-set is increasingly prevalent as companies across the country embrace a similar philosophy. "Options have become a bigger and bigger part of the pay package," said Mr. Crystal; options accounted for about half the total compensation paid to executives in his survey of 428 large companies.
But as large investors have begun to complain about how the corporate printing presses "keep running," as Mr. Crystal put it, there are signs that the huge increases in pay may be moderating. While Mr. Crystal found that the median increase in compensation was nearly 25 percent in 1997 for chief executives of the biggest companies, it climbed only 10 percent last year.
The faithful in Silicon Valley are quick to assure cynics, especially those from the other coast, that the "money culture" is not pervasive. "We are building something that we want to be around in 10 years," said Mr. Scheinman of Cisco, which makes Internet networking equipment.
As long as the executives running these companies are representative of what some describe as Old Silicon Valley -- sharing an overarching belief in the ability of technology to change the world -- executives will still work 100 hours a week to try to get their latest products out on time, say defenders of the industry's ways. And programmers will still devote hours to perfecting a piece of code.
"The reason you don't have to worry about this is that the day-to-day environment is not about the stock price," said David Peterschmidt, chief executive of Inktomi, an Internet software company that has been among the hot upstarts of late. Since going public in June, the stock has more than quadrupled.
What's more, veterans say, it is well understood in Silicon Valley that many of even the most promising companies fail. "A lot of people have a lot of worthless options as wallpaper in their garage," said Mr. Ward of WestWard Pay. At Cisco, employees joke about former colleagues who sought their fortunes at some of these failures, Mr. Scheinman said, noting that "plenty of E-commerce companies have folded their tent."
BUT oh the rewards -- if only on paper -- for workers whose companies are embraced by investors. Given the recent success of Internet-related initial public offerings, companies that are planning to go public can use options to give employees the potential for vast riches. "Most of these Internet companies can get anyone they want by dangling stock options," said Rick Gostyla, the head of the North American high-technology practice of Spencer Stuart, an executive search firm.
A decade ago, an executive recruited by a start-up might get $20 million in options, according to David B. Kixmiller, a partner at Heidrick & Struggles, another search firm. Today, the package is likely to be worth $100 million. "All the valuations are pushed up higher in every stage of the deal," Mr. Kixmiller said.
Moreover, many pay packages no longer lock employees into long-term relationships in order to collect the jackpots. Many companies are granting options that can be converted into stock relatively quickly, said Judith Fischer, the managing director of Executive Compensation Advisory Services in Springfield, Va.
Steven Westly, a vice president at Ebay, the on-line auction company whose stock has shot up 778 percent since its public offering in September, was given options on roughly 2.4 million shares at just 7 cents each when he joined the company in August 1997, according to company filings. Mr. Westly, who was free to exercise the options immediately, has done so, according to the filings. If he still holds the shares, he has a paper profit of more than $330 million. Ebay had no comment.
Even when companies offer more traditional options, which vest over several years, many allow a substantial fraction to be exercised in short order. At Silicon Graphics and Inktomi, for example, additional shares vest monthly.
That is why few consultants still argue that options are a tool to retain executives in Silicon Valleys. Companies lose as much as a fifth of their work force each year, according to the Radford division of Aon Consulting, which conducts an annual survey of high-technology companies. If a competitor wants to hire someone badly enough, it will simply offer enough new options to make up for any money left behind, pay experts say.
"Using a long-term incentive for short-term gains creates a problem," said David M. Leach, a consultant with Compensation Resource Group in New York. "It certainly sends a message of short term."
The siren call of options also penalizes companies whose stock has already been very successful, like America Online or the two-year-old Amazon.com or even corporate toddlers like Ebay. While companies point to past stock performance in recruiting prospects, a stock that has been too hot can make recruiting difficult. In such cases, executives and other candidates turn pessimistic, because "their stock has only one way to go," explained Mr. Gostyla of Spencer Stuart.
And woe to any company whose stock starts to struggle.
Silicon Graphics, which makes computer systems, has experienced an exodus since its stock started performing poorly a few years ago. To attract its new chief executive, Richard E. Belluzzo, from Hewlett-Packard, the company offered him a yearly salary of just under $1 million and 3 million stock options -- a fifth of which vest after just 10 months on the job. So he could exercise his Hewlett-Packard options, Silicon Graphics also gave Mr. Belluzo a short-term loan, which he has repaid, according to the proxy statement.
"To attract the best talent, you have to be competitive with the market," said John Cristofano, a spokesman for Silicon Graphics.
Like other technology companies with tumbling shares, Silicon Graphics has reduced its options' prices twice in the last two years. While many investors frown upon the practice, compensation experts say such companies have little choice if they hope to keep or attract key people.
Companies "feel that they cannot wait a year" for the stock to recover, Ms. Meyer said. "If they wait more than a quarter, they will have an outflow" of essential workers.
But the act of repricing options is being threatened by a change in the rules governing how companies account for options. The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the nation's accounting rule maker, has proposed that repricing options result in a charge to earnings if the stock price moves up. Many experts say this would all but end the practice, because companies would be very reluctant to incur the charges.
WITHIN technology companies, few people seem to resent the enormous wealth being created in the Valley -- because that wealth is being at least partly shared. Many companies make a point of including all their employees in option plans. A survey of Internet service companies by WestWard Pay showed that half of workers making less than $30,000 were eligible for options.
While the proliferation of options is helping to keep the peace, it also means that a much larger group of people will suffer in any downturn.
When Hewlett-Packard lost significant market value more than a decade ago, employees did not head for the hills. "They didn't have stock options," said Mr. Kixmiller, the executive recruiter from Heidrick & Struggles. "Stock options were not as big a part of the landscape."
So what will happen when today's landscape is bombarded by what could be dozens of crashing stocks?
"We don't know the answer," said Mr. Kixmiller. "The valuation placed on the Internet I.P.O.'s is unprecedented."

SECTION: Section 4A; Page 32; Column 1; Education Life Supplement

HEADLINE: Total Recall

BYLINE: By Bruce Weber; Bruce Weber is a national correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
In a conference room in the library of Carleton College, a small liberal arts school about 40 miles south of Minneapolis, 20 or so students were sitting around a horseshoe of desks, their shoulders hunched, buzzers clenched in their fists. They were concentrating on the man in front of them, Eric Hilleman, their coach, who was flinging carefully phrased questions at them in disciplines from chemistry to history to pop culture and waiting for, encouraging even, the quickest response.
This was exercise, conditioning for the synapses between the brain and the buzzer finger. Practice for the Carleton quiz-bowl team, one of the best undergraduate groups in the country, isn't really athletic training, it's more like a tuneup for a human search engine. And on this night they were getting a workout: in two days, three four-person teams would travel to Iowa City, site of the regional championships for the National Academic Quiz Tournament circuit. 
 Mr. Hilleman began: "He noted in his inaugural address that even in ancient Rome, politicians did not keep their promises. Unlike them, he did keep his promise to serve only one term -- but not in the way he had in mind. For 10 points, name this President who got sick his first day on the job and died a month later."
A student buzzed. "William Henry Harrison."
"Yes," Mr. Hilleman said, continuing without a pause. "She is not Lara Croft, but according to a December 1998 poll she stars in 4 of the nation's 10 hottest computer games: one as a detective, another in a riding club, a third as a photo designer and a fourth as a nail designer. For 10 points, identify this blond bombshell made by Mattel."
A buzz from the far corner. "Barbie."
"Yes. Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, a bacterium often found in deer ticks -- "
Buzz. "Lyme disease."
"Yes. In 'Moby-Dick,' Queequeg celebrates it in his room, while Ishmael gets himself hired aboard the Pequod. Its 27th day -- "
Buzz. "Ramadan."
"Yes, that's 15 points," Mr. Hilleman said, awarding a bonus for an early correct answer.
"Nice buzz," a student offered.
Question, buzz, answer. Question, buzz, answer. The rhythm quickened; the room filled with arcana: Whitaker Chambers. "Bringing Up Baby." Halogens. Bert Blyleven. Calligraphy. Grub Street. William Cullen Bryant. "The Barber of Seville." Red Skelton.
"Nice buzz."
For a visitor with a reasonably good education but slack recall muscles, the scene was somewhat belittling. But for a visitor more then twice the age of these students, the scene was also a reminder of the days when academic quiz competition was Sunday-night television fare in the form of "G.E. College Bowl," with the hosts, first Allen Ludden and then Robert Earle, moderating contests between well-groomed teams representing universities and colleges nationwide.
Talk about retro! None of the Carleton students were alive when the show, first broadcast in 1959, went off the air in 1970. They are, nonetheless, part of a resurgence of the sport (game? activity? enterprise?) on American campuses, with thousands of students participating in hundreds of tournaments every year, both intramural and intercollegiate. High schools compete as well, as do adults who continue to crave the rush of a contest that tests wits and reflexes.
The revival has been led by the College Bowl Company, the very same organization that produced the television show, which now provides, for a fee, questions and game equipment to about 300 colleges and hundreds of high schools. It was College Bowl that established the structure of the game. A question, known as a tossup, is asked to both teams simultaneously; the first player to buzz gets to answer, and a correct answer earns the team a bonus question.
The revival has also been fueled by the emergence of competing organizations, like the National Tournament, which have modified the game with different kinds of questions, scoring and time elements to suit the varying preferences of its ardent devotees.
Three distinct national championship tournaments are scheduled this month, and many teams will play in more than one. The National Tournament, with 48 teams, will be held in Ann Arbor, Mich., April 9 and 10. The College Bowl championship, featuring 16 teams, will be held in Gainesville, Fla., April 16 to 18. And a third group, the Academic Competitions Federation, has scheduled a 27-team event in Chicago on April 23 and 24.
Like any subculture, the quiz-bowl world has its peculiarities, legends, heroes, habits, intense debates and internal feuds. The Carleton team, which will appear in both the National Tournament and Academic Federation championships, eschews all College Bowl events because, the players say, the questions are too easy, the entry fees too high, the tournament rules too regimented. Players make reputations as cautious or quick on the buzzer, anticipating a question almost before it is asked. And though penalties are assessed for wrong answers, it is thought that being too aggressive is better than being too careful.
The most famous buzz was that of Robert Hentzel, now the president of the National Tournament, who in a practice session as a player at Iowa State University buzzed after hearing "Its pretext was. ... " with the correct answer: "The Crimean War." And everyone acknowledges that Andrew Yaphe (pronounced YAH-fay), a literature grad student at the University of Chicago, is the nation's leading player, but is he the best ever? Mr. Hilleman said that honor belonged to Tom Waters, now a history teacher, who played for Emory University and Armstrong State College between 1979 and 1986 and was a champion on the television show "Jeopardy." Mr. Hilleman added that Mr. Waters never lost a game; Mr. Yaphe, however, said he beat him in one.
"He's deified more than he should be," Mr. Yaphe noted. "But I don't like to make pronouncements about where I stand in the history of the game."
Mr. Yaphe said he doesn't prepare for tournaments because the game itself teaches you how to play. Questions in certain subjects echo one another.
"It's a heuristic process, " he said. "It's mimetic to a certain extent. Peter the Great is more important, than, say, Ivan II, so there will be more questions about him." If you know the answer is a Russian czar, therefore you can make a reasonable wager that it's Peter the Great, he said.
Quiz bowl is, for whatever reason, largely a male domain populated by the kind of person who doesn't mind calling himself a geek. The boys are wont to complain that they spend so many weekends at quiz-bowl events that they don't have a chance to meet girls. Carleton is unusual in that two members of its A team, Emily Pike, a senior biochemistry major, and Cheryl Klein, a junior English major, are women. At tournaments, Ms. Pike said, "I get a lot of offers for dates." As far as anyone knows, Andrew Ulland, a 21-year-old economics senior who was captain of the Carleton football team and is the B team's quiz-bowl captain, is the only varsity athlete who also competes at quiz bowl.
"I've been playing football since I could walk," Mr. Ulland said. "It's what I do. Saturday afternoons in the fall, it's life and death for me. You have to be a little more restrained to play quiz bowl. It's a different kind of excitement, but I do tend to pound the table a lot." Asked if his football teammates tease him for playing quiz bowl, he laughed. "Actually, I get more comments from quiz-bowl players about my football playing than I do from football players about quiz bowl."
Each week, results of tournaments and collegiate rankings are sped around the country on the Internet; the quality of the tournament questions are discussed in fervid E-mail postings: "Too many hockey questions!" Serious competitors spend much of their free time "taking questions," as they say. They're kids who know the composer, the characters and the plot of every important opera written in the past three centuries but who have never been to see one. On the other hand, "When I came here, I didn't know anything about music and art," Andy Felton, a junior English major, said. "I started studying them because of quiz bowl and I'm grateful I did, because I like them. Now I study them because I want to." They're proud of their talents, their wide familiarity with factoids and their ability to recall them instantaneously, but they also see the humor in it.
"An obsession?" asked Ms. Klein, who was engaged in the memorization of all United States Senators. "Yeah. Sad but true." Like many other quiz-bowl teams, Carleton receives modest financial support from the college. (The team travels in its own van, for one.) Beyond that, it has the advantage of being coached by Mr. Hilleman, the college archivist by occupation and a fierce quiz bowler by predilection. Mr. Hilleman, who plays in masters tournaments and is known, by his gift for high-speed articulation, as perhaps the finest quiz-bowl moderator in the country, maintains in his office what he says is the largest library of quiz-bowl questions in the world --- thousands of them, gleaned from tournaments.
"What does skill in quiz bowl measure?" said Mr. Hilleman, who studied religion and history at Brown University and the University of Wisconsin. "Skill at quiz bowl." He laughed. "To some degree, it measures knowledge, memory, some elements of reflex. Intelligence apart from knowledge doesn't come into it much, except in terms of decoding the language of questions and anticipating where a question is going." Still, he pointed out that knowledge is not such a bad thing. True enough. In an age when intellectualism is often demonized and Forrest Gump is a hero, "formal knowledge tends to be undervalued," he said, "and it's not like it exists at the expense of thinking. You don't do one without the other."
For the uninitiated, a primer is probably necessary, because apprehending the quiz-bowl landscape is an arcane intelligence test all its own. The National Tournament and the Academic Federation are newcomers started by quiz-bowl players whose habits were not being sufficiently fed.
The Academic Federation was founded in 1990 by players from the Universities of Maryland and Tennessee who wanted to redefine the College Bowl format. The games are played without a time clock. Instead, they are based on a specific number of questions, which are longer than other formats', yielding their clues in tinier increments. The Federation shuns sports and popular culture, concentrating instead on academic subjects, with the questions considered more difficult than other formats. And though the original organization disbanded in 1997, it has since been revived. Tournaments are organized by a host team, which edits questions that are supplied, as part of an entry requirement, by competing teams.
The National Tournament, which has commercial aspirations and is seeking corporate sponsors, was founded in 1995 by a group of 10 players, including the legendary Mr. Waters, from a variety of schools. It is led by David Frazee, who was a University of Michigan law student and is now a lawyer in San Francisco. The core group is 13 players who write about 12,000 questions annually for tournament kits, which they peddle for $225. (In a standard kit, there are 20 packets, or one packet per game, each with 28 tossup questions and 28 bonuses.) All tournaments take different forms, but the most popular is a round-robin event with every team playing every other team, the top finishers playing off head-to-head.
The National Tournament is administered from a home office by Mr. Hentzel, a computer consultant in Kansas City, Mo., and former quiz-bowl player at Iowa State University who said he writes about 2,000 questions a year. The questions are distributed among academic subjects, sports, pop culture and current events and steer clear of the giveaways, even at the ends of questions, that the College Bowl often indulges in, infuriating purists.
"There was a famous one in 1988," said Michael Zarren, the captain of the University of Chicago team, which is considered the nation's strongest. "It began with some obscure description of a tropical plant, and then finished with, 'For 10 points, name this curved yellow fruit.' "
Still, there are disputes about questions that begin cleverly, trying to mislead competitors, like the one beginning with a reference to Hester Prynne in Hawthorne's "Scarlet Letter" but whose answer is an animal substance used in making buttons -- "mother of pearl." Disdainful players call that "a hose question."
Mr. Hentzel says he doesn't take the fee -- the National Tournament pays 75 cents a question. "In theory, we're for-profit, but we're not doing particularly well at that," he said. "Principally, we do this because we love it."
About 55 colleges and 200 high schools, he said, competed in National Tournament events last year. These are usually timed games divided into nine-minute halves -- which is why the moderator is so important. Someone who can read aloud and be understood at high speed gets through more questions -- why accomplished moderators like Mr. Hilleman and Mr. Hentzel are so valued. "Bob takes pride in finishing a packet before time expires," said Andy Felton, an English major on the Carleton team.
The granddaddy of the quiz-bowl groups is, of course, the College Bowl Company, a small, privately held business in Los Angeles managed by Richard Reid, a television producer whose father, Donald, invented the game in the 1940's. The company, which employs two full-time question-writers, does its own research, writing and editing of questions for its game packets; these are sold to colleges and high schools for $60.
College Bowl's questions are considered the easiest of three formats, with ample pop culture and current events to make it more marketable, a game more people can play. The company administers college tournaments, including the Honda Campus All-Star Challenge for historically black colleges, at one time televised on the Black Entertainment Television cable network. A version of the game is currently played on television in Britain, and the younger Mr. Reid -- his father died in 1996 -- has been trying to get it back on television in this country.
"This isn't sex, drugs and rock-and-roll, and that's what people really want to buy," Mr. Reid said. "So you look for ways to make it sexy, so the new design is different, you have the players competing for money, for themselves and their schools. The object for a new version of College Bowl is to make it a game of today rather than yesterday."
The animosity between College Bowl and the National Tournament boils down to the former believing the latter to be a usurper of intellectual property, and the latter snorting at the idea that questions and answers can be copyrighted.
"They're not threatening the franchise, so long as they're doing it as a hobby," said Mr. Reid, who said he has decided against suing for the time being. "But if I read in the paper that I.B.M. is doing a TV show with National, I'll sue them."
The College Bowl surfaced on the airwaves between 1953 and 1957, when it began a four-year run on the radio, sponsored by Good Housekeeping magazine. In 1959, the game was licensed to General Electric. With such a powerful sponsor, it became a staple of network television, broadcast live for most of its life at 5:30 Sundays on CBS.
When it went dark in 1970, a casualty of the expanded Sunday reach of pro football and G.E.'s consequent withdrawal as a sponsor, the company more or less became moribund.
"We were basically a TV company, and as with everybody else in the universe, when you do something you love, the notion that it has gone away dies hard," said Mr. Reid, who at that point was producing television shows in Canada. "My father still had offices, and in 1975, he got ill, and I came back to help him, though I didn't know what helping him really meant."
A fortuitous phone call from Michael Decker, who was running a quiz-bowl tournament for fun at Emory University in Atlanta, sparked the proverbial light bulb of an idea. Mr. Decker, who has since become College Bowl's head question-writer, invited Mr. Reid to the tournament and persuaded him that running tournaments on college campuses -- syndicating the game -- could revive the business. In 1976, Mr. Reid and his father struck a partnership with the Association of College Unions International, a nonprofit group that coordinates activities on college campuses. Within a year, College Bowl was on 250 American campuses.
The phenomenon has been growing ever since.
The National Tournament regional championships took place on seven campuses on Feb. 12 and 13. The Midwest regional, held at the University of Iowa, was typical: For two days, the teams shuttled from one classroom to another, gathering around tables, answering 18 minutes' worth of questions read by volunteer moderators, most of them students themselves, performing to otherwise empty rooms.
Much of it was mundane. Teams collected in lounges between rounds for post-mortems and practice sessions. The disqualified participants attended the semifinals and finals and supplied some drama with appreciative gasps at any courageously early buzz, but there was no surprise at the outcome. It was won by the University of Chicago, with Mr. Yaphe leading.
The Carleton A team finished third, behind the University of Illinois, but first among undergraduate teams, earning a place in the national championship tournament. It lost to Chicago in the semifinal match, 405 to 170, termed "a respectable loss" by Ms. Klein but leaving Ms. Pike lamenting Chicago's sweep of questions concerning Greek and Roman mythology and muttering, "I should reread my Edith Hamilton."
Indeed, what was striking was the competitive juices and the coming to grips with winning and losing, which are, after all, a part of any rounded education.
"I consider quiz bowl a sport, the same way bridge and chess are sports," said Steve Jenkins, a junior majoring in English on the Carleton A team. "We certainly practice as much as any athlete, and we have as much dedication." And, Ms. Pike said, "It does make you sweat."
Mr. Yaphe had the victor's perspective. At 22, speaking with the weary air of an accustomed champion, he said that he had known the answers to 90 percent of the tossup questions. "And I would say, very arrogantly, that I know more than anyone else at this tournament."
Asked if he considered quiz bowl a sport, he said no, "a hobby or a game, though there's a certain willpower inherent in all sports that to a certain extent finds its parallel here." He said college-level competitions were becoming less and less challenging for him. So why does he do it? Ego? "Almost entirely," he said. "I keep playing because I like to win."

Because of a transcription error, a sample question in the special Education Life section on Sunday, with an article about college quiz bowls, misstated Leonhard Euler's polyhedron formula and his birthplace. The formula is is V + F - E = 2 (not V + E - F = 2); the birthplace was Switzerland, not Sweden.

(Answer: Pinocchio)

From the National Academic Quiz Tournament (extra points given for an answer before the asterisk ):
 
Tossup: Though Archimedes and Descartes worked extensively in geometry, their work almost entirely dealt with measurement, and both missed the simple formula V plus E* minus F equals 2, which this man later discovered. Before this he began work in the field of topology in his solution to the Konigsberg Bridge Problem. For 10 points, identify this Swedish-born mathematician.
(Answer: Leonhard Euler)
 
Bonus: The element calcium is part of several of the first members of Mohs' hardness scale. For 10 points apiece, identify the anion in each of the following: gypsum (answer: sulfate); calcite (answer: carbonate); fluorite (answer: fluoride).

The name is from Guaran 1/4, meaning "a place to paddle," and it flows in a great arc from its source in the Guiana Highlands to its mouth on the Atlantic Ocean. For 10 points, identify this South American river, which forms part of the border between Colombia and Venezuela. (Answer: the Orinoco)
