HEADLINE: Once Burned, Now Shy About Florio;
Some Democratic Leaders Are Wary of Former Governor's Senate Bid

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: BELLMAWR, N.J., March 30

 BODY:
"Here he is," bellowed the local party chairman above the raucous crowd of nearly 400 Democratic Party regulars packed into the fire hall. "Here is New Jersey's pride -- New Jersey's next United States senator."
With that, Jim Florio and his wife, Lucinda, barreled through white frosted-glass doors, as the crowd erupted. The former Governor made his way to the stage, grabbing outstretched hands, blowing kisses to old friends and embracing supporters from 16 past campaigns. 
 Six years after voters threw him out of the New Jersey State House and elected Christine Todd Whitman, a Republican, Jim Florio is trying to make a political comeback. He is running for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate seat to be vacated next year by Frank R. Lautenberg.
But as popular as he is here in his base, the southern part of the state, Mr. Florio is having difficulty building support elsewhere for his candidacy. And the biggest threat comes not from Mrs. Whitman, who is also considering making a bid for the Senate seat, but from leaders within his own party.
Many party leaders from northern and central New Jersey shudder at the prospect of seeing his name on a ballot next year and a possible rematch with Mrs. Whitman. Some are even courting other potential candidates.
"The reality is that he has a certain amount of baggage," said Joseph C. Spicuzzo, Middlesex County's sheriff and Democratic Party chairman. "He is very popular down south, but the majority of Democratic leaders in the state have not come out and endorsed anyone yet."
The problem for Mr. Florio is that party leaders are worried that voters may have lingering memories of his tax increase. Almost a decade ago, Mr. Florio inspired a statewide tax revolt after ramming a $2.8 billion tax increase through the Legislature to meet a court order demanding more state money for urban schools.
Within two years, Democrats lost control of the Legislature, and in 1993 Mr. Florio became the first Governor in modern history to lose a second term in a general election. As a result, many Democrats worry that a Florio campaign could reignite voter anger over the tax increase and damage the chances of other Democrats, including the candidate for President on the ticket next year.
State Senator Raymond J. Lesniak, an Elizabeth Democrat, said that while he did not belong to the "stop-Jim-Florio-at-any-cost school," the party needed to consider other candidates.
"I think we have better candidates, and I am not ready to hand over the nomination to Jim Florio," said Mr. Lesniak, the Democratic leader in Union County. "The tax issue is a real concern."
Mr. Florio, who has been practicing law since he left office, insists that he is in the race to stay, whether or not he wins the backing of the party leaders elsewhere around the state. He has moved quickly to demonstrate his strength in recent weeks, lining up two major Democratic fund-raisers and endorsements from nine county chairmen, mostly from southern New Jersey, where he represented Camden County in the State Legislature and Congress for 16 years.
Although he says that the last few years have softened him a bit and made him more empathetic to voter concerns, Mr. Florio remains very much the former Navy boxer. Even his opponents acknowledge that he would be tough to beat in a primary.
"If I'm not troubled entering the contest, why should they be?" he asked as he sipped tea over breakfast. "Anybody who wants to run in the Democratic primary should be out there. Tell us what you think. Tell us what you stand for. And then let the people in the state -- north, south, central, by area codes, whatever -- decide. I don't have any problem with that."
Mr. Florio, 61, has spent all but the last five years of his working life in politics. He has run for governor four times, winning once, losing one primary battle and losing two of the closest general elections in the state's history, including his 1993 re-election campaign. Mrs. Whitman's last-minute pledge to cut taxes helped her come from behind and beat Mr. Florio by 26,000 votes out of 2.5 million cast.
Mr. Florio dismisses talk that his 1990 tax increase would hurt his prospects or the chances of any other Democratic candidates on the ballot. He defends the tax increase but acknowledges that he did not properly reach out to voters and explain why it was necessary at the time.
He also said that he did not view a possible matchup with Mrs. Whitman as a replay of the 1993 gubernatorial campaign, because Mrs. Whitman did not have a record then. Now, he said, she does.
"I don't have any difficulties with the idea that we had to fund our schools," he said. "You have to balance the budget. I think it is interesting that people are bragging now about a $700 million surplus. I came into office with a $600 million deficit, went through the worst recession since the Great Depression, and finished my administration with a $400 million surplus. And now, after these six or seven years of unprecedented prosperity, you're only talking about a $700 million surplus?"
"If it comes to pass," he said, "it will almost become an ideal opportunity for people in this state to contrast dramatically different individuals, styles, philosophies, backgrounds."
Asked if he is seeking vindication or redemption, as some of his critics have suggested, he replied: "Redemption is going to heaven. I'm talking about the Senate. I am very confident. Maybe too confident. I have a sufficient amount of self-esteem so that I don't have to prove anything to anybody."
When he learned in February that Mr. Lautenberg would not seek re-election, he said he jumped at the chance to get back into the arena because he believes he can address the public's concerns over health care, Social Security and education.
From his one term as Governor, he said that he learned the importance of engaging voters and reaching them more effectively. He said he now understands why his tax plan made him seem arrogant and indifferent. "It may have been presumptuous of me to think that everybody out there was listening to my profound rhetoric and policy explanations," he said.
Mr. Florio said he was not troubled by the efforts of some fellow Democrats to derail his candidacy or the possibility that he might face a serious challenge for the nomination.
"I will compete with anybody," he said. "I think the power of the ideas that I have and the ability to present them in a meaningful way is something that will stand me competitively with anybody."
Because Mr. Lautenberg's decision caught state Democratic leaders by surprise, there was not one candidate whom party leaders were prepared to unite behind. Representative Robert E. Menendez, a rising star in the party, was widely expected to receive the party's backing, but he decided against making a bid. It was then that Mr. Florio emerged in front of the pack.
Some Democratic leaders have been trying to persuade Jon S. Corzine, who is stepping down as co-chairman and chief executive of Goldman, Sachs & Company, to enter the race, knowing that he has the money to mount an expensive primary fight. Others are courting Michael Murphy, the former Morris County Prosecutor, who made a surprisingly strong showing in the 1997 Democratic gubernatorial primary.
So far, county leaders have not formally backed any of the people who have expressed interest in the race. The list includes B. Thomas Byrne Jr., the former chairman of the state party; Susan Bass Levin, the Mayor of Cherry Hill, and Representative Frank Pallone Jr., a Congressman from Long Branch.
Mr. Pallone has been trying to position himself as the "other" Democrat whom party leaders from the north and central parts of the state should get behind.
"Most of the party leaders do not want Florio to be the candidate," Mr. Pallone said. "They would rather have somebody new run who could take the party into the next century, and not have a replay of the old issues in a Whitman-Florio race. I think the Democrats have an agenda in Washington that works, and that people support. That is the agenda that we should be running on, not a replay of the sales tax and income tax issues."
Mrs. Whitman, who is expected to decide soon about the campaign, cannot count on an easy race against Mr. Florio, analysts say. They note that the state has been leaning more Democratic in the last two years, and voter turnout among Democrats is traditionally high in Presidential election years.
"I think it would be a very competitive election," said Cliff Zukin, director of Rutgers University's Eagleton Poll. "She has run three times, and she has gotten 49 percent. She has not run a strong statewide race in New Jersey. She has always been more popular out of the state than in it."
Thomas P. Giblin, the state Democratic Party chairman, said the party can ill afford an expensive and ugly primary fight, particularly if Mrs. Whitman enters the race and clears the Republican field.
Mr. Giblin also said that the party could not survive a rift between the north and south. To help heal any wounded feelings, he accompanied Mr. Florio to the rally here and assured the party regulars there that the entire party organization would rally around the best candidate. And he has urged his fellow party leaders to tone down their criticism of Mr. Florio.
"I don't want to make light of the tax increase that was enacted," said Mr. Giblin, who is also the leader in voter-rich Essex County. "Some Democrats are not happy with that, and they feel that it affected their political future. But that was then. This is now. We have to judge who is the best candidate for this race based on who is able to articulate the message and who can raise the money."

HEADLINE: A Project Aims to Unhitch Computing From Its PC Harness

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 31

 BODY:
For David Clark, an M.I.T. computer scientist, research is like "an expedition into the future."
With the faculty and students at the Laboratory of Computer Science here at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Mr. Clark, one of the lab's top managers, is about to embark on just such a journey -- one meant to liberate computing from the PC-centric world it has occupied for the last two decades. 
 On Monday, April 12, scientists here plan to introduce Oxygen, an ambitious $40 million, five-year research project that is being financed by the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, or Darpa, the Pentagon's research arm. The objective is as broad as it is audacious: to reinvent all facets of information technology, from chips and software to computers and networks. And in the Oxygenated future, a desktop computer would be largely beside the point.
In this digital new world, a person could know if a colleague working elsewhere was reachable at her desk because sensory-based computers in the wall would know. A hand-held point-and-click pointing device could be used to remotely command every household appliance to do its bidding. And instead of typing on keyboards or stabbing at a screen with a stylus, a person would simply tell any computer what to do.
Or at least such concepts are the vision. In reality, the Oxygen project, Mr. Clark said, must walk the exceedingly thin line between an unrealistically futuristic "Star Trek" notion of computing and an overly timid short-armed reach for the easily attainable.
"You have to quantum tunnel from 'It's too soon' to 'It's too late,' " he said. "You've got to have guts."
It might be easy to dismiss such talk, were it not for the Laboratory of Computer Science's track record over the last three and a half decades. True, it has simmered at a lower publicity temperature than its bubbly academic sister, the M.I.T. Media Laboratory. But since its creation in 1964, the L.C.S., as it is known, has been associated with many of the most important developments in computing.
The lab's many historic fruits include word-processing and spreadsheet software. And though it was invented elsewhere by Robert Metcalfe, Ethernet, the standard architecture of today's PC networks, was subsequently refined during the 1970's as Mr. Metcalfe wrote his Ph.D. dissertation at the lab.
It may be an M.I.T. effort that predates the lab by a year -- Project MAC, set in motion by a $2 million Darpa grant in 1963 -- that offers the best model for a project like Oxygen and the impact it could conceivably have on the next generation of computing.
It was Project MAC, after all, that redefined the computing world by making it possible for many users to simultaneously share a single computer. From Project MAC sprang innovations like an early E-mail system and the concept of shared information utilities, the forerunners of today's on-line communities and even the World Wide Web.
Project Oxygen, which will be formally kicked off at the laboratory's 35th anniversary next week, is the brainchild of the lab's director, Michael Dertouzous, a computer scientist whose own career traces to his days working on Project MAC as an M.I.T. student. Intent on putting people first, Mr. Dertouzous is determined to chart an information technology future in which computers recede into the background.
"We want to liberate ourselves from the tyranny of 'going to the computer,' " he said.
Oxygen, seen as a proof-of-concept testbed for technologies that others might turn into actual products, will be based on several components that the lab is already developing. The first will be called Handy 21, a portable device with a small screen, a video camera, a Global Positioning System receiver and a powerful computer. Combining the functions of a cellular telephone, two-way data radio, television set, beeper, handheld computer and an intelligent remote-control pointing device, the Handy 21 will rely heavily on advanced voice recognition technologies that have been developed at the lab.
Speech recognition -- the ability for machines to understand spoken instructions -- is a vital part of the Oxygen project. A group led by the M.I.T. speech researcher Victor Zue has developed an approach significantly different from that now being pursued by most others in the speech recognition field.
Mr. Zue's Spoken Language Systems group has developed systems with powerful speech-recognition capabilities -- in large part because they focus on relatively narrow subject areas, like the weather, airline reservations or local traffic.
"I have to confess that I don't know how to build HAL," Mr. Zue said, referring to the computer in "2001: A Space Odyssey" with the complete conversational repertory of an eerily dispassionate human being.
The aim of the Spoken Language Systems research group is to achieve a limited, though seemingly conversational, voice input system by stitching together many different recognition systems with vocabularies based on narrowly defined subjects.
Mr. Zue cites three factors making voice recognition more important as a computer interface: computers are becoming increasingly mobile; people love to talk, and the shrinking size of computers is making the conventional keyboard a large and ungainly component.
Much of the design effort will revolve around the idea of delegating tasks to machines. For example, Mr. Zue said that instead of merely inquiring of the Oxygen system when a plane is scheduled to arrive at the airport, the user, planning to meet the flight, might also give this command: "Call me half an hour before Flight 116 lands."
Besides the Handy 21, the Oxygen system will be based on another building-block computer that the researchers call Enviro 21. These devices, which would be powerful versions of the Handy 21 system, would be embedded in office walls, car trunks or basements at home. The systems would have extensive sensor networks meant to enable them to monitor the state of the environment -- knowing whether an office door is open, for example, or if the car trunk is unlocked or the basement sump pump is operating.
And besides merely sensing a situation, the Enviro 21 would have the intelligence to instruct mechanical systems to close the door, lock the trunk or reset the pump. Or by the same token, if an office door is open, a distant colleague might infer that the occupant would not mind being interrupted with a phone call.
Both the Handy 21 and the Enviro 21 will be based on a processor chip design developed by Anant Agarwal, a computer architect at the lab. Working with I.B.M., Mr. Agarwal's group is now designing a processor architecture known as Raw. Unlike earlier chip designs which are based on predetermined instruction sets, Raw processors subject even the most minute, or "raw," circuitry of the processor to customization by software designers.
Raw is a gamble, because it would be harder to program than conventional processors. But it may have a huge payoff if the design proves workable, by offering markedly faster data processing and the potential for large numbers of the chips to be custom programmed to work in powerful concert.
"A lot of our experiments will be high risk, and they will fail," Mr. Dertouzous conceded. "But there is also low-hanging fruit."
Project Oxygen is the clearest example yet in a new direction in Federal financing of information technology research patterned after previous research projects that upset the dominant computing assumptions of their day. A notable example from the past is Xerox's legendary Palo Alto Research Center during the 1970's.
"This is all about investing in long-term, high-risk research," Tom Kalil, President Clinton's special assistant on economic policy, said of Oxygen. "What's motivating this is our understanding of the impact of government investment in information technology research in the 1960's and 1970's. Innovations from that investment are driving the economy today.
"The Administration," he said, "really wants the research community to invest in the future and swing for the fences."
Besides speech recognition and Handy 21 and Enviro 21, the other basic technology component of Oxygen would be a computer network capable of linking the other systems together and also connecting to the Internet.
With these, as well the underlying software that supports the basic technologies, Mr. Dertouzous hopes that Project Oxygen can lead to computing systems that bring a meaningful increase in human productivity.
"Our overarching goal," he said, "is to enable people to do more by doing less."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about a new project at the computer science laboratory of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology misspelled the surname of the laboratory's director. He is Michael L. Dertouzos, not Dertouzous.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 1; Science Desk 

LENGTH: 2136 words

HEADLINE: When No One Read, Who Started to Write?

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
The Sumerians had a story to explain their invention of writing more than 5,000 years ago. It seems a messenger of the king of Uruk arrived at the court of a distant ruler so exhausted from the journey that he was unable to deliver the oral message. So the king, being clever, came up with a solution. He patted some clay and set down the words of his next messages on a tablet.
A Sumerian epic celebrates the achievement: 
 Before that time writing on clay had not yet existed,
But now, as the sun rose, so it was!
The king of Kullaba Uruk had set words on a tablet, so it was!
A charming just-so, or so-it-was, story, its retelling at a recent symposium on the origins or writing, held here at the University of Pennsylvania, both amused and frustrated scholars. It reminded them that they could expect little help -- only a myth -- from the Sumerians themselves, presumably the first writing people, in understanding how and why the invention responsible for the great divide in human culture between prehistory and history had come about.
The archeologists, historians and other scholars at the meeting smiled at the absurdity of a king's writing a letter that its recipient could not read. They also doubted that the earliest writing was a direct rendering of speech. Writing more than likely began as a separate and distinct symbolic system of communication, like painting, sculpture and oral storytelling, and only later merged with spoken language.
Yet in the story, the Sumerians, who lived in Mesopotamia, the lower valley of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers in what is now southern Iraq, seemed to understand writing's transforming function. As Dr. Holly Pittman, director of the university's Center for Ancient Studies and organizer of the symposium, observed, writing "arose out of the need to store information and transmit information outside of human memory and over time and over space."
In exchanging interpretations and new information, the scholars acknowledged that they still had no fully satisfying answers to the most important questions of exactly how and why writing was developed. Many of them favored a broad explanation of writing's origins in the visual arts, pictograms of things being transformed into increasingly abstract symbols for things, names and eventually words in speech. Their views clashed with a widely held theory among archeologists that writing grew out of the pieces of clay in assorted sizes and shapes that Sumerian accountants had used as tokens to keep track of livestock and stores of grain.
The scholars at the meeting also conceded that they had no definitive answer to the question of whether writing was invented only once and spread elsewhere or arose independently several times in several places, like Egypt, the Indus Valley, China and among the Olmecs and Maya of Mexico and Central America. But they criticized recent findings suggesting that writing might have developed earlier in Egypt than in Mesopotamia.
In December, Dr. Gunter Dreyer, director of the German Archeological Institute in Egypt, announced new radiocarbon dates for tombs at Abydos, on the Nile about 250 miles south of Cairo. The dates indicated that some hieroglyphic inscriptions on pots, bone and ivory in the tombs were made at least as early as 3200 B.C., possibly 3400. It was now an "open question," Dr. Dreyer said, whether writing appeared first in Egypt or Mesopotamia.
At the symposium, Dr. John Baines, an Oxford University Egyptologist who had just visited Dr. Dreyer, expressed skepticism in polite terms. "I'm suspicious of the dates," he said in an interview. "I think he's being very bold in his readings of these things."
The preponderance of archeological evidence has shown that the urbanizing Sumerians were the first to develop writing, in 3200 or 3300 B.C. These are the dates for many clay tablets with a proto-cuneiform script found at the site of the ancient city of Uruk. The tablets bore pictorial symbols for the names of people, places and things for governing and commerce. The Sumerian script gradually evolved from the pictorial to the abstract, but it was probably at least five centuries before the writing came to represent recorded spoken language.
Egyptian hieroglyphics are so different from Sumerian cuneiform, Dr. Baines said, that they were probably invented independently not long after Sumerian writing. If anything, the Egyptians may have gotten the idea of writing from the Sumerians, with whom they had contacts in Syria, but nothing more.
In any event, the writing idea became more widespread at the beginning of the third millennium B.C. The Elamites of southern Iran developed a proto-writing system then, perhaps influenced by the proto-cuneiform of their Sumerian neighbors, and before the millennium was out, writing appeared in the Indus River Valley of what is now Pakistan and western India, then in Syria and Crete and parts of Turkey. Writing in China dates back to the Shang period toward the end of the second millennium B.C., and it dates to the first millennium B.C. in Mesoamerica.
Archeologists have thought that the undeciphered Indus script, which seemed to appear first around 2500 B.C., may have been inspired in part from trade contacts with Mesopotamia. But new excavations in the ruins of the ancient city of Harappa suggest an earlier and presumably independent origin of Indus writing.
In a report from the field, distributed on the Internet, Dr. Jonathan Mark Kenoyer of the University of Wisconsin and Dr. Richard H. Meadow of Harvard University showed pictures of marks incised on potshards that they interpreted as evidence for the use of writing signs by Indus people as early as 3300 B.C. If these are indeed proto-writing examples, the discovery indicates an independent origin of Indus writing contemporary with the Sumerian and Egyptian inventions.
Dr. Meadow, using E-mail, the electronic age's version of the king of Uruk's clay tablet, confirmed that the inscribed marks were "similar in some respects to those later used in the Indus script." The current excavations, he added, were uncovering "very significant findings at Harappa with respect to the Indus script."
At the symposium, though, Dr. Gregory L. Possehl, a Pennsylvania archeologist who specializes in the Indus civilization and had examined the pictures, cautioned against jumping to such conclusions. One had to be careful, he said, not to confuse potter's marks, graffiti and fingernail marks with symbols of nascent writing.
Of the earliest writing systems, scholars said, only the Sumerian, Chinese and Mesoamerican ones seemed clearly to be independent inventions. Reviewing the relationship between early Chinese bronze art, "oracle bones" and writing, Dr. Louisa Huber, a researcher at Harvard's Fairbanks Center for East Asian Research, concluded, "Chinese writing looks to be pristine."
But few pronouncements about early writing go undisputed. Dr. Victor Mair, a professor of Chinese language at Penn, offered evidence indicating, he said, that "the Chinese writing system may well have received vital inputs from West Asian and European systems of writing and proto-writing."
Dr. Mair cited an intriguing correspondence between the Chinese script and 22 Phoenician letters and also Western-like symbols on pottery and the bodies of mummies found in the western desert of China. The recent discoveries of the mummies, wearing garments of Western weaves and having Caucasoid facial features, have prompted theories of foreign influences on Chinese culture in the first and second millennia B.C. It had already been established that the chariot and bronze metallurgy reached China from the West.
Though no one seemed ready to endorse his thesis, Dr. Mair said, "We simply do not know for certain whether the Chinese script was or was not independently created."
Dr. Peter Damerow, a specialist in Sumerian cuneiform at the Max Planck Institute for the History of Science in Berlin, said, "Whatever the mutual influences of writing systems of different cultures may be, their great variety shows, at least, that the development of writing, once it is initiated, attains a considerable degree of independence and flexibility to adapt a coding system to specific characteristics of the language to be represented."
Not that he accepted the conventional view that writing necessarily started as some kind of representation of words by pictures. New studies of Sumerian proto-cuneiform, he said, challenge this intepretation. The structures of this earliest writing, for example, did not match the syntax of a language. Proto-cuneiform seemed severely restricted, compared with spoken language, dealing mainly in lists and categories, not in sentences and narrative.
This presumably reflects writing's origins and first applications in economic administration in a growing, increasingly complex society, scholars said. Most of the Uruk tablets were documents about property, inventory and, even then, taxes. The only texts that do not concern administrative activities, Dr. Damerow said, were cuneiform lexicons that were apparently written as school exercises by scribes in training.
For at least two decades, in fact, Dr. Denise Schmandt-Besserat, a University of Texas archeologist, has argued that the first writing grew directly out of a counting system practiced by Sumerian accountants. They used molded clay "tokens," each one specially shaped to represent a jar of oil, a large or small container of grain, or a particular kind of livestock. When the tokens were placed inside hollow clay spheres, the number and type of tokens inside were recorded on the ball with impressions resembling the tokens. Finally, simplifying matters, the token impressions were replaced with inscribed signs, and writing was invented.
Though Dr. Schmandt-Besserat has won wide support, some linguists question her thesis and other scholars, like Dr. Pittman of Penn, think it too narrow an interpretation. They emphasized that pictorial representation and writing evolved together, part of the same cultural context that fostered experimentation in communication through symbols.
"There's no question that the token system is a forerunner of writing, and really important," Dr. Pittman said in an interview. "But I have an argument with her evidence for a link between tokens and signs, and she doesn't open up the process to include picture-making and all other kinds of information-storage practices that are as important as the tokens."
Dr. Schmandt-Besserat, who did not attend the symposium, vigorously defended herself in a telephone interview. "My colleagues say the signs on seals were a beginning of writing, but show me a single sign on a seal that becomes a sign in writing," she said. "They say that designs on pottery were a beginning of writing, but show me a single sign of writing you can trace back to a pot -- it doesn't exist."
In its first 500 years, she asserted, cuneiform writing was used almost solely for recording economic information. "The first information that writing gives you is only the same information the tokens were dealing with," she said. "When you start putting more on the tablets, products plus the name of who has delivered and received them, that is where art would enter the picture. Then writing is out of the box, in all directions."
Dr. Damerow agreed that cuneiform writing appeared to have developed in two stages, first as a new but limited means of recording economic information, later as a broader encoding of spoken language for stories, arguments, descriptions or messages from one ruler to another.
Even so, it was a long way from the origin of writing to truly literate societies. At the symposium, scholars noted that the early rulers could not write or read; they relied on scribes for their messages, record keeping and storytelling. In Egypt, most early hieroglyphics were inscribed in places beyond the public eye, high on monuments or deep in tombs.
In this case, said Dr. Pascal Vernus of the University of Paris, early writing was less administrative than sacred and ideological, "a way of creating and describing the world as a dominating elite wants it to be."
Dr. Piotr Michalowski, professor of Near East civilizations at the University of Michigan, said the Uruk proto-cuneiform writing, whatever its antecedents, was "so radically different as to be a complete break with the past, a system different from anything else." It no doubt served to store, preserve and communicate information, but also was a new instrument of power.
"Perhaps it's because I grew up in Stalinist Poland," Dr. Michalowski said, "but I say coercion and control were early writing's first important purpose, a new way to control how people live."

SECTION: Section F; Page 6; Column 1; Health & Fitness

HEADLINE: Of Life, Death and the Rules of Liver Transplants

BYLINE: By HOLCOMB B. NOBLE 

 BODY:
Ralph Benedetto is dying in his mobile home in Clearwater, Fla.
Swirling around him is a debate over whether he and patients like him should be denied liver transplants that might save their lives -- specifically, whether the nation's health care system denies transplants out of failure to keep abreast of medical and technical advances or out of eagerness to save money. 
 Mr. Benedetto, 44, a disabled Medicaid patient, contracted hepatitis B 10 years ago from a blood transfusion he received after he was struck by a drunken driver. Two years ago, his doctors said his disease had progressed to the point where he could die at any moment without a liver transplant. But his health maintenance organization refused to pay for the treatment.
The H.M.O., Staywell Health Care in Tampa, Fla., cited guidelines issued by the state of Florida recommending against liver transplants to hepatitis B patients on the ground that the virus would destroy a replacement liver just as it did the original, leaving the patient just as sick and wasting a scarce organ in a transplant doomed to fail. The Federal guidelines that apply to 39 million Medicare recipients say the same.
But medical researchers and liver transplant surgeons said advances in the treatment of hepatitis B had left the guidelines outdated. Since the early 1990's, drugs started to become available to better treat the disease and now, the researchers say, the drugs appear to have blocked liver damage in more than 80 percent of the thousands of hepatitis B patients who have received transplants in states that allow them.
Experts say there is now wide agreement that hepatitis B, in and of itself, is no longer a valid reason to deny someone a liver transplant.
A spokeswoman at the Florida Agency for Health-Care Administration said it was the agency's policy not to discuss guidelines in detail. Mr. Benedetto's condition changes from day to day, making it difficult for him to be interviewed. But his former wife, who is caring for him, said she was furious when the transplant doctors had recommended was denied.
"I could not believe Ralph would simply be allowed to die when everybody knew successful treatments were available," Theresa Benedetto said.
Both Dr. David R. Nelson, a professor of medicine and an expert in hepatology at the Shands Hospital of the University of Florida in Gainesville, and Dr. Scott E. Hallgren of the Florida Center for Gastroenterology at Pinellas Park, had determined in June 1998 that Mr. Benedetto was in danger of dying at any moment, but that he had an excellent chance of regaining his health with a transplant.
The H.M.O. insisted that the sole reason for its denial was that hepatitis B patients did not meet the state criteria for transplants. Costs for the procedure are high, the company acknowledged, with the average hospital bill for the operation in Florida at $117,000, plus the costs of finding a suitable organ and the subsequent costs of preventing rejection of the organ or recurrence of viral infection, said Nancy Gareau, Staywell's vice president for operations.
The company, under contract with Florida to manage Medicaid patient care, covers five or six transplants a month, Ms. Gareau said.
Once the H.M.O. refused to authorize a transplant, Mrs. Benedetto said, Mr. Benedetto was turned away by three hospitals. Jackson Memorial Medical Center, affiliated with the University of Miami School of Medicine, said it would not do the transplant unless Mr. Benedetto produced a $150,000 down payment, Mrs. Benedetto said. Shands Hospital required $136,000 down.
Both hospitals confirmed Mrs. Benedetto's account and said the total bills could run much higher. Mr. Benedetto, unemployed because of his disability, could not begin to pay that cost. Tampa General Hospital also turned him away, because it said its doctors were not convinced that Mr. Benedetto would survive a transplant.
Administrators at several American medical centers, health care experts and doctors do not fault hospitals that seek assurance they will be reimbursed for transplants, whose high cost, if uncompensated, would quickly drive them out of business. "And if it did one transplant free, wouldn't it be unjust to deny one to someone else who also needed one," said Dr. John M. Vierling, chairman of the American Liver Foundation.
And while some doctors characterized Mr. Benedetto's experience as yet another example of how tight-fisted H.M.O.'s harm patients, others said that in their experience most H.M.O.'s were fully cooperative in covering transplants where they were warranted.
In any event, Dr. Vierling said, the original decision in the 1980's to exclude patients with hepatitis B from transplant rosters was legitimate. The problem now, he said, is adapting the rules to changing medical conditions. Once a procedure is excluded, he said, it is often a long and tortuous process to get the rule changed. That is true in the case of hepatitis B, he said, even though new treatments have produced long-term success rates equal to overall rates for liver transplants.
Dr. Donald A. Young, a senior vice president for policy and clinical services of the American Association of Health Plans, the nation's largest trade and lobbying association for private managed care companies, said health care providers had an obligation to treat their patients.
"The first rule -- the principle of beneficence -- says you have the responsibility to provide the care needed to the individual without regard to your own interest," including financial interests, he said. But, he added, "Second, the principle of stewardship provides that justice must be done for all where you have to allocate resources." He said it would be unethical to spend so much time and money or resources in saving one patient that it became impossible to save a group of others. Although the two principles may be contradictory, Dr. Young said, the goal is to try not to violate either.
What does this mean for Ralph Benedetto? In the past, it might have meant that it would not be right to give him a liver in a transplant doomed to fail, if the organ might save someone else's life. But today, Dr. Young said, "It seems to me the doctors and hospitals and the State of Florida and the H.M.O.'s should all get together and find a way to work something out."
Later in the day on which the American Association of Health Plans discussed the ethical considerations in the Benedetto case, March 4, its spokesman said it had pondered the question further. "We found the question highly disturbing," the spokesman said. "We will do something."
In the end, on March 5, after probing questions had been raised about Mr. Benedetto's case, Kate C. Morgan, chief of the Florida Agency for Health-Care Administration's Bureau of Managed Health Care, said the case had prompted senior agency officials to make an immediate change in the agency's rule on hepatitis B. "We have relayed that information to the H.M.O.'s, and Staywell is going to move forward with the transplant" as long as Mr. Benedetto is still a candidate, Ms. Morgan said. Staywell confirmed that this was the case, she said.
But now Mr. Benedetto may no longer be a viable candidate.
When he was tested in June in an effort to appeal Staywell's denial, he was found to have responded well to various medications. But now, Dr. Enrique J. Martinez, his hepatologist, said, the virus is renewing its attack.
If events had been conspiring against Ralph Benedetto, now they seemed to be mobilized on his behalf. On the afternoon of March 5, Dr. Martinez's transplant center, Lifelink, a nonprofit institute affiliated with Tampa General, was notified that it had just received approval to use an experimental drug, adefovir, that was not yet approved for general use but could be prescribed by selected research centers on a compassionate-use basis. Preliminary trials have found it to be 90 percent successful in controlling the recurrence of hepatitis B viral attacks.
Dr. Martinez said he believed the chances were excellent now that the adefovir would enable Mr. Benedetto to be put on the list to await a transplant within weeks.
Several health care professionals said it was heartening to see senior state health officials act so quickly in this case, but also expressed concern. Dr. Vierling of the American Liver Foundation said: "Those recent developments are, of course, good news for the Benedettos. But it is still disturbing that it took the fight and persistence of a person like Theresa Benedetto and the action of a few key people in the system before it could be spurred into action. And it disturbs me that many dying patients with hepatitis B still cannot get transplants."

HEADLINE: World Briefing

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

ASIA
 
INDIA: NEW THREAT TO COALITION -- The conflict deepened between the Hindu-nationalist-led Government and its largest coalition partner, as Jayalitha Jayaram announced that two ministers from the party she leads would resign. Prime Minister Vajpayee won the backing of the other Government members in rejecting her demands that Defense Minister George Fernandes be dismissed, the ousted naval chief be reinstated and a parliamentary committee be set up to investigate charges of corruption against Mr. Fernandes. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: BALLOT REGISTRATION BEGINS -- Voter registration began for Indonesia's general election, which is scheduled to be held on June 7. A total of 48 parties will seek parliamentary seats, the first step toward electing a new President. The United Nations is coordinating the distribution of $80 million in foreign aid for the balloting, in which 125 million people are eligible to vote.
 Seth Mydans (NYT) 

MALAYSIA: ANWAR'S WIFE FORMS PARTY -- The wife of Anwar Ibrahim, the former Deputy Prime Minister who is on trial for corruption and illegal sex acts, has announced the formation of a new political party. Mr. Anwar's wife, Azizah Ismail, said she would challenge the leadership of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohammad.
 Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
VIETNAM: WORKING WITH PHILIPPINES -- Vietnamese and Philippine troops will stage joint exercises in order to east tensions over the two nations' competing claims to the Spratly Islands in the South China Sea. Disputes have grown in recent months over sovereignty of the islands, which are also claimed by Malaysia and China. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
NORTH KOREA: DENIAL OVER SHIPS -- North Korea denied any involvement in an incident in which two ships sneaked into Japanese waters and then fled toward North Korea, setting off Japan's first naval pursuit in more than 40 years. "The ultra-rightist reactionaries of Japan invented such a shocking incident," North Korea's official news agency said.
 Nicholas D. Kristof (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST -- IRAQ: OIL PIPELINE ATTACKED -- Western warplanes destroyed a control station on a pipeline used by Iraq to export oil through its southern terminal of Mina-al-Bakr, the Iraqi News Agency said, but a shipping official in London said loading of oil was uninterrupted at the terminal. The agency said the raid took place at the Bazrkan oilfields near the southern city of Al Amarah, 220 miles southeast of Baghdad. (Reuters)
 
IRAN: U.S. CONCERN OVER OIL DEAL -- The U.S. voiced concern and disappointment over a $300 million contract with Iran by two Western companies, one French and the other Canadian, to exploit an oil deposit in the Persian Gulf. "The United States remains strongly opposed to investment in Iran's petroleum sector," the State Department spokesman, James Rubin, said. "We've repeatedly urged the Governments of France and Canada at the most senior level to discourage this investment." (Agence France-Presse)
 
ISRAEL: STRIKE HITS NAZARETH -- The center of Nazareth was deserted as shopkeepers complied with a call by Muslim leaders for a commercial strike after clashes broke out with Christians over a planned millennium pilgrimage site at the Church of the Annunciation, where Muslims want to build a mosque. Muslims demanded the resignation of the town's Christian mayor. (AP)
 
THE PALESTINIANS: ARAFAT IN MOSCOW -- Foreign Minister Igor Ivanov urged the visiting Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to put off declaring Palestinian independence next month, and called for reviving the Mideast peace effort. HEADLINE: European Oil Companies Plan Expansions in Libya

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TRIPOLI, Libya, April 5

 BODY:
European oil companies are preparing for an investment boom in Libya after the nation turned over two suspects in the 1988 bombing of a Pan Am airliner, clearing the way for the United Nations to lift sanctions.
ENI S.p.A. of Italy, already Libya's biggest foreign oil producer, and Lasmo P.L.C. of Britain are among the companies planning to expand investments. Their activities will further strain sanctions that the United States imposed independently on Libya two years before the bombing in response to terrorist incidents that forced American oil companies to leave the nation. 
 Libya has lost $24 billion in potential revenue since the sanctions were imposed in 1992 and is desperate for investment. Oil income, accounting for 95 percent of the nation's hard-currency earnings, fell more than a third last year as prices for crude touched 12-year lows. That forced Libya to devalue its currency by 18 percent in December.
"Oil companies will now feel more comfortable in talking with the Libyan Government about potential projects," said Mohammed Abduljabbar, a consultant with the Petroleum Finance Company in Washington. "It will allow Libya to rehabilitate its oil production."
The lifting of United Nations sanctions means international flights to Tripoli could resume and the nation could buy supplies to refurbish oil-export equipment. The European Union has no ban on oil drilling in Libya, but the six-hour drive from Tunisia to Tripoli is a strain that wards off many investors.
Already, Libya has taken steps to welcome back oil companies that left through the 1980's, a result of the sanctions and threats against foreigners by the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.
Later this month at a conference in Geneva, the Libyan Oil Minister, Abdallah Salim al-Badri, is expected to conduct the first major round of bidding for oil exploration rights in four years.
The Oil Minister said last month in Vienna that he had already held talks with United States oil companies about returning.
"As far as Libya is concerned, they are welcome back," he said. "We already have been in contact with some of our previous partners. We have been contacted by the American oil companies, and we want them to come back to Libya."
With proven reserves of about 30 billion barrels -- almost as much as has been found in the North Sea -- Libya is a prize for the world's oil industry. Lasmo pumps Libyan oil for $5 or so a barrel, about half the cost in Britain.
The two-year drop in oil prices has made Libya's cheap oil even more attractive. Benchmark Brent crude oil prices, now $14.72 a barrel, are little more than half their 1997 peak price of almost $25. Libyan projects, however, are profitable even if prices slip to less than $10 a barrel.
"We're looking for more exploration acreage in Libya," said Roy Beadle, a spokesman for Lasmo, Britain's second-biggest oil exploration company. "Our guys have no problem working there, even with the sanctions."
ENI produces about 16 percent of Libya's oil and found the nation's biggest offshore field. The company is seeking clients to support a $3.5 billion investment in new gas production from the Wafa field on Libya's Mediterranean coast and a pipeline under the sea to Italy.
Others, such as Total S.A. of France, OMV A.G. of Austria, Repsol S.A. of Spain and Lundin Oil A.B. of Sweden, are also active in Libya.
"Doing business in Libya would be easier" without sanctions, said Terance Taylor, assistant director of the International Institute for Strategic Studies, a policy adviser in London. "Financing for new projects will be easier to obtain."
Still, the United States companies that withdrew in the early 1980's after sanctions tightened probably will not be back soon. In 1986, President Ronald Reagan told the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and a consortium including USX-Marathon Group, Conoco Inc. and the Amerada Hess Corporation to pull out after Libyans were linked to the bombing of an Egyptian airliner and a German nightclub.
The Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation withdrew even earlier, in 1982, a year after a United States trade embargo began. And in 1996, Congress tightened sanctions against Iran and Libya, accusing both of financing terrorism.
If United States sanctions are lifted, Conoco, Hess and Marathon could have a head start on their rivals because about $2 billion of assets -- including seven major oilfields -- has been held in trust by the Libyan Government until sanctions are removed. The group was part of the Oasis Oil Corporation.
Since 1986, Conoco's share of output from Oasis, about 300 million barrels of oil valued at about $5 billion, has gone to the Libyan Government, said Carlton Adams, a Conoco spokesman. "We hope to return and resume our operations there once all the sanctions are lifted," he said.
Hess and Marathon did not comment on the issue.

HEADLINE: William J. De Lancy, 82; Headed Republic Steel

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
William J. De Lancy, who ran the Republic Steel Corporation during some of its toughest times, died from complications of Parkinson's disease Friday at his home in Shaker Heights, Ohio, his family said.
He was 82. 
 Born in Chicago in 1916, Mr. De Lancy earned both bachelor's and law degrees from the University of Michigan. After graduation in 1940, he was hired by the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore. He served as a Naval intelligence officer on the aircraft carrier Bennington in World War II, and returned to the firm after the war.
In 1952, he joined Republic Steel in Cleveland as assistant counsel. He rose through several positions including general counsel, and became the company's president in 1973 and its chief executive in 1974. He added the title of chairman in 1979.
Republic, then the fifth-largest steelmaker, suffered, as did the entire steel industry, from heightened competition from more efficient producers abroad at a time of weak demand induced by the recession and high interest rates in the late 1970's and early 1980's.
By 1980, for example, the industry was operating at little more than half of capacity, and shipped only 84 million tons of steel, down from 100 million tons the year before. Steel industry employment was at its lowest level since 1933.
In 1980, Mr. De Lancy became president of the industry's trade group, the American Iron and Steel Institute, and he led a lobbying effort aimed at strengthening the existing government restrictions on imports of steel.
The industry contended that European and Asian steelmakers were "dumping" steel in the United States; that is they were selling the steel at artificially low prices, possibly for less than their cost of production.
In 1982, Mr. De Lancy turned 65, and he retired both from Republic and the steel institute.
The company and industry continued to suffer. Steel production hit a postwar low of 75 million tons in 1982, and production did not return to 1980 levels until 1994. In 1984, Republic merged with Jones & Laughlin Steel to form the LTV Corporation.
Mr. De Lancy is survived by his wife, the former Sally Roe, and his children, Ann of Seattle and Mark of Chicago.

HEADLINE: Russia's Role in Kosovo

 BODY:
The road to peace in Kosovo may yet run through Moscow. Despite Russia's rhetorical belligerence about the NATO air campaign and Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov's failed diplomatic mission to Belgrade last week, Russia has the credentials and motivation to play a constructive role in ending the conflict. Doing so will require some straight talking by the Russians to their Serbian cousins, and a degree of cooperation with Washington that may be awkward for the Kremlin, but Russia could greatly enhance its international stature by brokering a political settlement.
For now, Slobodan Milosevic may think he has little reason to consider a diplomatic solution, and he did not seriously entertain one in his talks with Mr. Primakov. The Serbian assault on Kosovo has driven a million ethnic Albanians from their homes, and NATO air attacks have so far done little to impede the Serbian brutality in Kosovo or diminish Mr. Milosevic's military forces. 
 But this conflict, as President Clinton declared yesterday, must not end with Kosovo permanently emptied of its citizens. With improving weather and additional aircraft, NATO air power will eventually begin to hobble the Serbian military and weaken Mr. Milosevic's stranglehold on Kosovo. If Mr. Milosevic concludes that the balance of power is shifting in NATO's favor, he will doubtless start looking for a deal that allows him to remain in power. If Mr. Clinton and NATO stick with their wise decision not to commit troops to a potentially costly ground war in Kosovo, they too will be looking for a negotiated resolution.
Because of Russia's longstanding friendship with Serbia, Mr. Primakov is among the few world leaders who has the standing in Belgrade to tell Mr. Milosevic he must end his subjugation of Kosovo, withdraw all his forces and permit the repatriation of the ethnic Albanians. Kosovo must also be granted at least the same degree of political autonomy it enjoyed until 1989. All this would be easier for Mr. Milosevic to accept if it were endorsed by the Russian Government, and came with a promise that Russian troops would participate in an international peacekeeping force that would assure the safe return of the refugees.
Moscow favored most of the elements of this plan before the NATO air offensive commenced, and ought to overcome its resistance to the peacekeeping force now that Serbia has demonstrated such savagery in Kosovo. The NATO air strikes have stirred anti-Western sentiment in Russia, limiting Mr. Primakov's latitude as he looks ahead to parliamentary elections in December and a possible presidential race next year. But both Mr. Primakov and his patron, President Boris Yeltsin, well understand that Russia's long-term economic and diplomatic interests are better served by working with the United States and Europe rather than by cultivating Slobodan Milosevic. The White House should be working behind the scenes to encourage a constructive Russian role.

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 4; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Scholar's Stormy Life With Morgan's Ghost

BYLINE: By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
THEY are not a perfect couple: J. Pierpont Morgan, the inarticulate, unreflective and unofficial central banker of the United States before there was a Federal Reserve, and Jean Strouse, a former Radcliffe English major whose analytic gifts were previously focused on a biography of Alice James, a powerless invalid.
But for the last 15 years, Ms. Strouse has lived nearly full time, on paper and in her head, with Morgan, the titan who gave birth to industrial America and many of New York's most important cultural institutions. She has pored over Morgan's ledger books, investigated his mistresses and found pressed violets in the diary of his first wife. Even now, she has yet to move the Morganalia out of her one-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side. "Morgan takes up more space than I do," she said. 
 In short, no one alive knows him as well. Evidence: her 796-page "Morgan: American Financier," published this month by Random House, in which Ms. Strouse is part detective, part novelist, part psychologist. Reviewers are in awe that Ms. Strouse has found a human being underneath the rapacious robber baron (the view of the left) or the financial Moses (the right). For her part, Ms. Strouse spent her first five years with Morgan eyeing him with a prosecutor's disgust. "It was as if I had my hands on my hips saying, 'Oh, sure,' " she said.
In the end, Ms. Strouse liked Morgan but didn't excuse him -- and felt she had forged an intimate connection. "But it took years to feel that," she said in an interview at the Morgan Library, the same place where Morgan famously locked up the nation's bankers during the financial panic of 1907 and ordered them to sign a bailout package, at 4 A.M. "Because he's such an alien character to me. He didn't want to know any of the things I wanted to know."
And what, if Morgan were alive and down the hall (he died in 1913), would she ask him?
Ms. Strouse hesitated. She is a journalist-turned-scholar, with a serious reputation. "I don't think I want to say," she said. Which makes it all the more interesting.
Well, she relented, there was the matter of his first wife, Amelia -- Memie -- his true love, who was already so sick with a serious cough when he married her in 1861 that Morgan had to hold her up at the altar. He then insisted on taking Memie to the Mediterranean for a cure, only to be told in Europe that Memie had tuberculosis. Morgan nursed her obsessively and carried her up and down seven flights of stairs in Paris. But Memie died four months after the wedding, when Morgan was 24.
"I don't know whether that marriage was ever consummated," Ms. Strouse said, a little embarrassed by her admission. It is not, she admitted, a historically important question, just the human curiosity of someone who knows Morgan, and cares. "Because he really loved her," Ms. Strouse said. "I don't know if he ever got over her death."
THESE days Ms. Strouse, 53, is enjoying that moment when the private life of a scholar becomes the public life, however fleeting, of just-published biographer. There will be a party for her at the Morgan Library next week, a book tour, plus her re-entry into the 20th century. (Ms. Strouse knew it was time to move on from Alice James, the sister of Henry and William, when she began writing "Dec. 12, 1878" on her own correspondence.)
"I don't think I want to do this again," she said of big biography. "It was too long and hard. A friend of mine says that biography is a little like marriage -- you only have room in your life for one or two. Well, I've had two."
Ms. Strouse has never married, was involved with a man until recently and travels in the gossipy intellectual world of what people sometimes call The New York Review of Each Other's Books. Ms. Strouse grew up in Los Angeles, where her father was an internist, came to New York after graduating from Radcliffe in 1967 to work as an assistant to Robert B. Silvers, the co-editor of The New York Review of Books, left in 1975 to write her 1980 Alice James book (which won the Bancroft Prize), spent four years as a book critic at Newsweek, then started working on Morgan in 1983. She plays squash and dresses well, but otherwise lives a very un-Morganesque life.
When her 1983 advance payment from Random House ran out -- she describes it as "in the low six figures" -- Ms. Strouse put together academic grants, teaching jobs, money from her mother and additional payments from Random House. "I've been living like a graduate student, and I've had it," she said. "Especially writing about somebody who lived the way Morgan did -- it was comical."
Halfway through, she nearly gave up when she began waking up at 4 A.M., convinced she would would never understand the 19th century financial data. "But I couldn't pay back the advance, and I also couldn't admit failure," she said. A friend who runs a hedge fund, Roger Alcaly, talked her through it, and today Ms. Strouse is a trustee, rather than her three younger brothers, of some family investments. "I've been educated," she said.
She has no idea what she'll do next, but well remembers when she finished the book -- Aug. 19, 1998. Two days later she took a break.
"I felt so light," she said. "It was the first vacation I'd taken without J.P. Morgan in 15 years."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Are Little Changed As Economy Shows Strength

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were little changed to slightly lower yesterday, as a rise in stocks removed some demand from the debt market. Trading was light.
There was minimal reaction to a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management that its index of nonmanufacturing business rose to 62.5 in March -- the highest since May -- from a reading of 57.0 in February. 
 Jack Ablin, president of Colonial Asset Management Inc. in Jacksonville, Fla., said, "Last week's N.A.P.M. report on manufacturing activity was so strong that it overshadowed today's report."
The yield on the 30-year bond slipped to 5.58 percent, from 5.59 percent on Friday, while its price, which moves in the opposite direction, increased 4/32 to 95 5/32 .
Mr. Ablin said he thought the Fed policy makers were not likely to be swayed by yesterday's report, "especially if they have yet to be prompted into action by the 30 percent rise in oil seen over the last few weeks." Yesterday, crude oil futures moved higher after the United Nations said that one of Iraq's main pipelines, which carries oil south to the Persian Gulf port of Mina al-Bakr, had slowed to about 45 percent of its normal rate after weekend bomb damage. Iraq blamed Britain and the United States, but the United States denied the charge.
As the American economy continued to show signs of strength and little deceleration, bond yields have climbed more than half a percentage point in the first quarter of this year, as investors, fearing inflation lies ahead, have demanded a greater discount in price.
Michael Englund, chief economist for Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis firm in San Francisco, said the market got the employment report it was looking for last week, although there was limited room on Friday for Treasuries to rally because of the holiday-shortened session. This week he expects a bullish bias to trading, based on the employment data, a flight to Treasury securities because of the events in Kosovo, the unwinding of effects from the end of the Japanese fiscal year and the attractive level of yields available.
Corporate debt sales in the coming weeks, however, could limit gains in Treasury securities, since corporations give investors a higher yield and firms arranging these debt sales often sell Treasuries first as hedges against losses in case rates rise before the sales are completed. Some of the well-known corporate names planning sales are Conoco Inc.; Korea Development Bank; the Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, which is a General Motors spinoff, and the Union Pacific Resources Group.
The regular weekly Treasury bill auction was somewhat mediocre. The three-month bills were awarded with a rate of 4.265 percent, a little better than expected, and the six-month maturity came in at 4.345 percent. The number of bids for the six-month issue was considered weak, with a ratio of 4.03 to 1.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Palestinians Planning to Offer Bonds on European Markets

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: RAMALLAH, West Bank, April 5

 BODY:
The Palestinian Authority hopes to cover part of a $150 million budget deficit this year by selling the first Palestinian bonds, the authority's financial affairs chief said here today.
Entering the so-called sovereign debt markets would represent a breakthrough for the Palestinian Authority, which has been unable to raise money on the markets with its ambiguous status as a semiautonomous territory controlled militarily by Israel. 
 The finance official, Mohammed al-Nashashibi, said the Palestinian Authority expected to pay most of its bills with tax revenue, including income from official import monopolies that had gone unreported in previous budgets. Mr. Nashashibi spoke as he submitted his 1999 budget to the legislative council here today. But a projected 10 percent increase in tax revenue is not keeping up with a 25 percent jump in the state payroll this year, and foreign donors are no longer willing to bridge the gap.
Mr. Nashashibi said in an interview that governments, which he would not name, were prepared to provide backing for Palestinian bonds to be sold in European financial markets. He said he was now negotiating the size and pricing of a bond issue with major investment banks that are prepared to serve as underwriters. The bonds, to be denominated in either dollars or euros, could be issued as soon as June, he said.
The Palestinian Authority's leader, Yasir Arafat, is expected to postpone a long-discussed declaration of independence from May 4, which falls in the closing weeks of an unanticipated Israeli election campaign.
Routine expenses in the Palestinian region are met largely from sales taxes and customs levies collected by Israel but passed on to the Palestinian treasury under an agreement. But the authority, with no uncontested claim on sovereign property or financial assets, cannot provide collateral for a commercially viable bond issue on its own.
There is some precedent for securities from poor nations to be backed by wealthier creditors, such as the Brady bonds from Brazil and Mexico, which carried repayment guarantees from the United States Treasury. But these were bonds issued by independent countries, with their own national assets and formal standing in the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
The Palestinians face several hurdles to sell bonds, including getting a credit rating and ironing out all the legal complications of a bond issue. An emerging markets analyst in London, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Palestinian Authority was moving into uncharted territory. But he also that if these problems were overcome, it was possible there might be a group of Middle Eastern investors interested in buying such an issue, despite the risks involved.
He noted that Lebanon has sold small Eurobond issues at more favorable interest rates than many Latin American countries because there is a large number of Lebanese and other Middle East expatriates willing to buy such debt securities.
In addition, the way to a bond issue would presumably be eased if the United States or other countries decided to offer guarantees.
Palestinian critics, echoed by overseers from Western aid donors, have demanded a public accounting of hitherto-undisclosed revenue from state agencies with exclusive rights to import and distribute fuel, cement, tobacco and other goods. "There is a serious problem with fiscal transparency, or rather the lack of it," said an expert with an international financial institution, who also spoke in exchange for anonymity.
Mr. Nashashibi did not mention plans for a foreign bond issue in his address to legislators, who have two weeks to review the budget plan. Mr. Arafat has already approved the spending plan, he said.
With Mr. Arafat's supporters holding a solid majority on the legislative council, approval is expected.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS;
A Relief Phone Line

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 5

 BODY:
The Agency for International Development has established a toll-free telephone number and Internet site to encourage charitable donations to private groups helping to feed and shelter the hundreds of thousands of refugees who have streamed out of Kosovo.
Callers to the telephone number (1-800-USAIDRELIEF, or 1-800-872-4373) and visitors to the site (www .info.usaid.gov) are provided with a list of charitable organizations working along Kosovo's borders. 
 The agency, the lead Government organization in the humanitarian aid effort for the refugees, is encouraging donors to offer money to the groups, rather than collecting clothing or food.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE EUROPEANS;
News Reports Bolster Support for Bombings

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: LONDON, April 5

 BODY:
The television images of refugees staggering out of Kosovo are having a powerful effect on public opinion across Europe, turning pacifists and anti-NATO activists of decades ago and NATO critics of just a week ago into supporters of sustained bombing.
In Madrid, Francisco Sanchez, a 25-year-old office worker, has watched the coverage and felt a national kinship with the suffering. "Spaniards also have emigrated when we were in need," he said, "and we should accept them here." 
 In Italy, the images of Kosovars packed onto exile trains have brought the war home with chilling reminders of moments from "Life Is Beautiful," the Holocaust tale by the Academy Award-winning actor Roberto Benigni.
In Britain, Prime Minister Tony Blair said that for him the refugee pictures were "scenes that belong to Europe's darkest hour."
Newscasts and front pages are filled daily with accounts of brutality and suffering and deeply affecting pictures of people stranded in border fields, streaming across frontiers in forced marches and crowding around relief workers for food.
Roy Hattersley, a former British Labor Party deputy leader and Government minister, wrote in today's Guardian: "My own doubts about the bombing -- expressed in this column last week -- have been completely removed by seven days of pictures. A NATO victory is the only real hope of permanent relief and decent resettlement for the refugees.
"A NATO defeat would convince political psychopaths all over the world that they, like Slobodan Milosevic, could tyrannize a whole people and get away with it. Whether or not we should have started the war, we clearly have to finish it. That must be obvious to everyone who owns a television set."
Earlier horror about seeing aerial combat return to Europe for the first time in 50 years is being overwhelmed by concern for the refugees and revulsion at the way they have been forced from their homeland.
Daily now across Europe there are announcements of government and private appeals to speed aid to the refugees, and even countries like Britain and France with reluctance to admit foreigners have had to respond to public pressure to shelter the refugees.
Germany has offered to take 40,000 Kosovars; the United States and Turkey, 20,000 each; Norway, 6,000, and Canada and Greece, 5,000 each. Britain and France said at first that they worried that airlifting refugees from the Balkans, even with the understanding that they would one day return to Kosovo, would risk abetting Mr. Milosevic's own desire to rid the province of its ethnic Albanians.
Mr. Blair conceded today that his Government would accept an unspecified number of refugees, adding that the "ultimate objective" must remain repatriating them to Kosovo. The French Defense Minister, Alain Richard, said Paris did not want to be seen taking a position apart from its allies.
But Mr. Blair and Mr. Richard twinned these moves with aggressive statements about the need for NATO to persevere in the bombing. Mr. Richard announced "even more intense attacks" by France's Mirage 2000-D fighter-bombers, and Mr. Blair said, "People have to be prepared to go on, have to be prepared for the longer haul in order to make sure that our objectives are secured and successful."
In his briefing today, the NATO spokesman, Jamie Shea, stressed the alliance's commitment to caring for the exiles, saying it was "fully mobilized" behind the refugee assistance effort, building campsites and ferrying aid into Albania and Macedonia.
Though there has been acknowledgment of the historic menace of Balkan instability to Europe, the coming together of a joint political will on the Continent has not been based on a perceived threat to national political and economic interests, the traditional threshold issue.
What is driving the growing support for NATO is the sense of responsibility for forestalling human rights abuses and punishing those who commit them. A Guardian editorial said approvingly that European policy was increasingly in the hands of "humanitarian hawks."
In Germany, Prime Minister Gerhard Schroder, Defense Minister Rudolf Scharping and Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer, who were stern critics of United States policy in Vietnam and the installation of nuclear weapons in their country in the 1980's, are now taking Germany into its first war in 50 years.
A recent German newspaper headline read, "Dictators Look Out -- the 1968'ers Are in Charge."
Not all members of Mr. Fischer's Green Party are content with the Government's unflinching backing of NATO's aerial strikes. Roland Appel, a party leader in Dusseldorf, called it the party's "most difficult test" and pleaded with members to avoid reflexive pacifism that could split the party and force it out of the country's ruling coalition.
Mr. Schroder said today that he saw no reason to change the strategy of relying primarily on military force rather than diplomacy. Gunter Verheugen, a top Social Democrat within the Foreign Ministry, was blunter. "We are dealing here with one of the most terrible criminals of this century," he said, "and he must be treated accordingly."
In Italy, where Prime Minister Massimo D'Alema has given only wavering support to the bombing and called for a return to negotiations, public opinion has been swayed toward NATO through the dramatic reports of Antonio Russo, a broadcaster for a left-wing radio station. He stayed in Pristina, Kosovo's capital, after other Western journalists had left and managed to spirit out dispatches from a hiding place that students had arranged for him.
He escaped on Friday and sent an impassioned report to the daily La Repubblica recounting his odyssey among Kosovars in a sealed train.
The detail that drew particular attention because it so closely recalled "Life Is Beautiful" was the harrowing moment when heavily armed Serbs forced women, children and the elderly, with Mr. Russo among them, onto the freight cars. As they herded them on board, the Serbs said, "Come on, you've won a free train ride -- in exchange for your homes."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Main Gauges Of Stocks Rise To Records

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
The stock market's torrid affair with technology and Internet companies continued yesterday, lifting the three main gauges of stock market performance to records.
Stocks rallied in their first day of trading since the release on Friday of mixed employment data for March. The news touched off a strong rally in the bond market on Friday in an abbreviated session. Stock exchanges were closed in observance of Good Friday. 
 The employment report makes it increasingly unlikely that the Federal Reserve will feel the need to raise short-term interest rates in the near future, a positive situation for stocks. Still, traders said they had not expected yesterday's surge.
"Things were kind of quiet at the end of last week, and the positive tone during the morning was quite surprising," said Andrew M. Brooks, a vice president at T. Rowe Price Associates.
For the most part, however, the biggest gains were concentrated among the largest and best-known leaders of a select group of industries, from I.B.M. and Microsoft to Intel, Lucent and America Online. Several financial-services stocks also soared.
"The strong are getting stronger, and cash is going into those stocks that have done well recently," Mr. Brooks said. "At some point, the music is going to stop, but no one knows when that is going to happen."
At the close, the Dow Jones industrial average, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq composite index had all set records. Trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange was light, with just fewer than 700 million shares changing hands. On the Nasdaq, 977.8 million shares were traded.
"Things are good, but there is no volume," said one stock trader, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "What trading there is is all in technology, Internet issues and some financial stocks."
The Dow, which closed above 10,000 for the first time last week, did so again yesterday. The gauge rose 174.82 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,007.33. The S.& P. 500 gained 27.40, or 2.1 percent, to 1,321.12.
The Nasdaq composite index rose to a record for the first time in two months. Bolstered by gains in stocks like Microsoft, 2 1/4, to 94 15/16 ; Intel, 6 5/8, to 127 1/2; Yahoo, 39 3/8, to 219 1/8, and Amazon.com, 15 1/2, to 186 1/2, the index soared 66.69, to 2,560.06.
For the most part, developments in the war in Yugoslavia were seen as inconsequential for stocks.
"Right now, people think the economy will continue to expand at a 4 percent rate and that inflation is dead," said Byron R. Wien, United States equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The market is resistant to bad news, and Kosovo is a good example of that."
The Dow was led higher by I.B.M. and American Express, which together accounted for nearly 40 percent of the rise in the gauge.
I.B.M. climbed 6 15/16 , to 183 15/16 . And American Express rose 4 7/16 , to 125 7/16 .
Other Dow components did nearly as well.
General Electric gained 3, to 114 5/8. And Hewlett-Packard, the other computer company in the Dow, rose 3 9/16 , to 71 7/16 .
America Online led the S.& P. 500 higher and was again the most actively traded stock on the Big Board. It jumped 16 15/16 , to 166 15/16 . The gain propelled the company to ninth in terms of its weighting in the S.& P. 500, ahead of companies like AT&T and Lucent Technologies.
Lucent, whose previously announced 2-for-1 stock split became effective yesterday, had a big day. It rose 3 1/16 , to 58 15/16 . Meanwhile, AT&T's stock fell 1 1/16 , to 77 7/16 .
On-line brokerage stocks soared after an analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston said on-line trading rose 30 to 35 percent in the first quarter.
Charles Schwab, the biggest on-line broker, gained 9 1/8, to 103 3/8. Ameritrade Holding, the sixth-biggest on-line broker, soared 29 1/16 , to 91 5/8. And Equitable's Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, which owns a widely used Internet brokerage service, gained 4 5/16 , to 71 3/4.
But the session also had some big losers.
The stock of Aspen Technology fell 3 5/16 , to 9 15/16 , after the software manufacturer said it expected to report a significant operating loss for the quarter ended March 31.
And shares of Aspect Development fell nearly two-thirds, losing 14 15/32 , to 7 15/16 , after the software maker said it expected first-quarter revenue and earnings to be well below analysts' estimates.
The breadth of the market's advance improved a bit yesterday, a development some analysts said was encouraging. On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,695 stocks rose, while 1,318 fell.
"In the last week, breadth has improved a bit, but this is a very selective market, and it has been for over a year," said Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards Inc. in St. Louis. "The bears just can't adjust to the kind of market we have right now."
