HEADLINE: Political Memo;
For Giuliani, Often Maverick, Party Support Isn't Assured

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
For all the differences between Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rudolph W. Giuliani, none may be more important than this: The Democratic First Lady is assured the support of her party if she runs for Senate next year. But the Republican Mayor faces the prospect of a complicated primary, fought in front of Republican voters who have long been wary of him.
The huge interest stirred by the prospect of a Clinton-Giuliani race has clouded Mr. Giuliani's sometimes difficult history with his party and its leaders, and the ways in which he might be vulnerable, for ideological and geographical reasons, in a Republican primary. 
 A reminder that his nomination would not be a foregone conclusion came yesterday as Representative Rick A. Lazio, a Long Island Republican, prepared for a week of appearances before Republican audiences upstate, where he will discuss his own interest in the Senate seat held by Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a Democrat retiring after four terms.
Mr. Giuliani, unlike Mrs. Clinton, remains an unsteady figure in his own party, notwithstanding his evident political success. An array of influential party leaders -- starting with Gov. George E. Pataki and including Alfonse M. D'Amato, the former Senator -- have battled Mr. Giuliani for years, and many Republicans say the Governor and the former Senator are tacitly backing Mr. Lazio's bid.
Mr. Giuliani's success in positioning himself for an election where Democrats have a million-vote edge -- moderate on some issues, and conservative on others -- could complicate any Republican primary. The Mayor, for example, was one of the few Republicans who defended President Clinton during impeachment proceedings, and he opposed a ban on some forms of late-term abortions.
Mr. Giuliani's position on both issues runs counter to the strong sentiments of the generally conservative Republicans who are likely to vote in a primary. By contrast, Mr. Lazio voted for Mr. Clinton's impeachment and has supported a ban on the late-term abortion procedure.
Party strategists said it was clear that voters in Mr. Giuliani's political power base of New York City would have nowhere near the dominance in a statewide Republican primary that they would in a Democratic primary or, to a lesser extent, in statewide elections. Mr. Giuliani's advisers are counting on his strong standing in the city to help him overcome a statewide Democratic edge. In a primary, however, he could find himself facing a candidate from the suburbs who could erase any geographic advantage Mr. Giuliani hoped to have.
By any measure, Mr. Giuliani has to be viewed as a dominant figure in any Republican primary. He is well known, has demonstrated an overwhelming ability to raise campaign funds and has run New York City at a time when crime has dropped while the economy has boomed.
Mr. Giuliani's advisers asserted yesterday that they were not concerned about the prospect of a tough primary race if he decides to run for the Senate, recalling that he had won two primaries for mayor. "I don't see a Republican issue against him," said Peter J. Powers, the Mayor's political adviser. "When you look at what the Republican Party stands for -- lower taxes, lower spending, fighting crime -- he has stood for all of those things."
But other supporters of Mr. Giuliani were a bit more concerned about how he might fare in a Republican primary. The main concern is that the candidacy of a rival like Mr. Lazio -- a poised and articulate 41-year-old, four-term Congressman -- could turn into a rallying point for upstate Republicans wary of some of Mr. Giuliani's more liberal positions, from supporting rent regulation to backing gay rights, as well as the Mayor's frequently gruff manner.
Further complicating the outlook is the prospect that Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato might support a subterranean campaign against Mr. Giuliani, encouraging supporters or contributors to back Mr. Lazio or saying things that could undercut Mr. Giuliani's standing.
Mr. Lazio said yesterday that both Mr. Pataki and Mr. D'Amato had offered him counsel as he considered his future career.
"They have been helpful and generous with their advice and in sharing their experiences," Mr. Lazio said. "And I am comfortable running on some of the same issues that Pataki has run on, including tax relief, protecting the environment and quality of life issues."
Zenia Mucha, the Governor's senior adviser, said that as a rule, Mr. Pataki stayed out of others' primary races. "It is imperative that New York elect a Republican Senator," she said. "We will work on behalf of the Republican nominee, who we are certain will be a candidate who embraces Republican principles and will be able to win."
In recent days, a number of state Republican leaders with ties to the Governor have spoken up for Mr. Pataki, while blaming Mr. Giuliani for the off-and-on political feud between the two leaders.
"The concern I get -- and I'm getting this from the other western New York county chairman that I work with -- is this feud doesn't make sense," said Robert E. Davis, the chairman of the Erie County Republican Party. "Everybody is concerned about what's going on. George Pataki helped rebuild the Republican Party."
Many Republican leaders are quick to recall Mr. Giuliani's support of Mario M. Cuomo, the Democratic incumbent, against Mr. Pataki in the 1994 race for governor. All of which could make it easy for Mr. Pataki to complicate Mr. Giuliani's attempt to line up the support of the party's apparatus.
Mrs. Clinton is not alone among potential candidates in the Democratic field -- Representative Nita D. Lowey of Westchester is also interested in the nomination. But Ms. Lowey has said she would step aside if the First Lady ran.

HEADLINE: 2 LIBYAN SUSPECTS HANDED TO COURT IN PAN AM BOMBING

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: UTRECHT, the Netherlands, April 5

 BODY:
More than a decade after Pan Am Flight 103 exploded over Scotland, killing 270 people, the two Libyans charged with planting the bomb arrived in the Netherlands today to face trial for the crime.
As a result, the United Nations immediately removed severe sanctions on the Government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya. 
 The end of those sanctions, in place since 1992, allows international air travel and the sale of vital industrial equipment to resume. The step will also release Libyan assets that had been frozen in a number of countries.
But separate sanctions imposed by the United States before the deaths over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988 will not end until other conditions are fulfilled, American officials said.
The delivery of the suspects in a highly unusual arrangement of trial in the Netherlands under Scottish law followed years of international pressure and months of diplomatic negotiations with Colonel Qaddafi.
Americans relatives of the dead expressed some bitterness at the turn of events, arguing that Libya had won more than it lost. But others expressed the hope that the extraditions would mark an important turn on the road to exacting punishment for the attack. Page A14.
 The two Libyans, Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fahima, both assumed to be government agents, were brought here under a complex arrangement that treats a former military base near here as Scottish territory so the suspects can be tried under Scottish law. It was this formula -- promoted by Britain -- of holding the trial in a third country that finally broke the deadlock and ended Libya's long refusal to cooperate with American and British prosecutors.
The Scottish judges will have to weigh the still secret evidence provided by the United States and Britain and decide whether the two Libyans are guilty of planting the suitcase bomb. The judges will then face the fundamental questions of who gave the orders to blow up the plane and why.
The British and Americans have outlined the main conclusions of their case, but have withheld the particulars.
Libya handed over the two suspects this morning in Tripoli, the Libyan capital, to Hans Corell, the United Nations Undersecretary General for Legal Affairs, in the presence of envoys from half a dozen Arab and other nations invited by Col. Qaddafi.
An Italian plane took the two Libyans, each accompanied by a relative and a lawyer, to the Dutch military air base, Valkenburg. Dutch authorities at first took the two Libyans into custody after they arrived this afternoon but hours later formally extradited them to Britain -- on paper, that is -- so the Scottish police could take over.
Dutch military helicopters then took the Libyans to Camp Zeist, a former military base a few miles outside Utrecht. Some of the camp's buildings are being converted to include a detention unit for the suspects and a room for the Scottish court that will be sitting here. More than 100 Scottish officials, including prosecutors, police and court employees have already arrived in recent days. The camp, once used by American military and then taken over by the Dutch, is kept under tight guard by Scottish police officers.
President Clinton issued a statement today saying he was "gratified" by the extraditions. "Now, at last, the road to justice has begun."
Administration officials said that Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright spoke with about 20 family members of the Lockerbie victims in a conference call today and reassured them that the sanctions on Libya could be reimposed if the Libyan Government backed away from any part of the agreement.
The British Foreign Secretary, Robin Cook, who was deeply involved in the diplomatic maneuvering leading up to the handover, said that today ended "a 10-year diplomatic stalemate."
"We had over a year of hard diplomatic effort and tough negotiations to get here," Mr. Cook said. "There will now be a criminal trial for that act of mass murder and the relatives of all those who died will have their first opportunity to hear all the evidence that we hold in open court."
He said one of the most difficult aspects of the case was that the Government had not been able to tell relatives of the victims of the explosion "what we know and suspect happened to their loved ones."
Eleven of those who died were on the ground in the village of Lockerbie, while most of the passengers who died were Americans.
British and American investigators concluded that a bomb was put aboard the Pan Am flight on its way from Frankfurt to New York during its stopover at Heathrow Airport. Less than an hour after takeoff, the Pan Am Boeing 747 exploded in flames, killing its passengers and crew members. In 1991, Britain and the United States indicted the two Libyan Government agents in connection with the bombing.
The two countries, which have gone to great lengths to amass the evidence for the crash, have insisted for years that the suspects must face trial in either Scotland or in the United States. When Libya refused, the two countries pressed the United Nations to impose sanctions in 1992. The sanctions were toughened in 1993.
These sanctions have barred air travel to and from Libya as well as the sale of arms and spare parts for aviation and for the oil industry, which is vital to Libya. Although the sanctions were suspended today, the Security Council is to vote to lift them completely. It can do so within 90 days if the Secretary General reports that Libya has met other conditions, like cooperating with France in its investigation of a UTA flight over Niger in 1989 in which 171 people died and committing itself to pay compensation to the families of the crash victims in case its two agents are convicted. The deadlock was broken last year when Washington and London took up an old Libyan offer to have the two suspects face trial in a third country. Libya had argued the two could not get a fair trial in Britain or the United States.
Libya's handover of the two follows months of mediation by South Africa and Saudi Arabia and threats by the United States and Britain that Libya could be subjected to even tougher sanctions. President Nelson Mandela of South Africa and United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan took part personally in the negotiations with Colonel Qaddafi.
Asked if the sanctions played a role in Libya's decision, Mr. Annan said today, "I prefer to think they played a role. No country likes to be treated as an outcast." He added, "Libya wanted to get on with its economic and society development."
No date has been set for the trial at Camp Zeist.
 
Lockerbie: Years of Anguish and Anger
LONDON, April 5 (Reuters) -- These are key dates in the efforts to bring two Libyans to trial in the bombing of the Pan Am flight near Lockerbie, Scotland:
 
DEC. 21, 1988 -- Pan Am flight 103 from London to New York is blown up over Lockerbie, Scotland.
 
NOV. 14, 1991 -- United States and Britain accuse Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fahima of Libya of involvement. Libya denies any involvement.
 
MARCH 23, 1992 -- Libya's United Nations delegate says the suspects will be handed over to the Arab League, but the West rejects Libya's conditions.
 
MARCH 31 -- Security Council Resolution 748 tells Libya to surrender the suspects by April 15 or face a worldwide ban on air travel and arms sales.
 
APRIL 30 -- The Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, says that Libya will not hand over the two suspects.
 
NOV. 11, 1993 -- The Security Council tightens sanctions.
 
MARCH 23, 1995 -- The F.B.I. offers a record $4 million reward for information leading to the arrest of the two Libyan suspects.
 
APRIL 19 -- Libya sends a flight of Muslim pilgrims to Saudi Arabia despite the air embargo.
 
JUNE 11, 1997 -- Libya says in a letter to the United Nations Secretary General that sanctions had caused losses to Libya of $23.5 billion.
 
MARCH 20, 1998 -- The Security Council debates the Lockerbie issue, with widespread support for a trial in a neutral country.
 
APRIL 22 -- After a visit to Libya, representatives of victims' families say the Government has agreed to a trial in the Netherlands under Scottish law.
 
AUG. 24 -- Britain and United States agree two suspects can be tried in The Hague under Scottish law.
 
AUG. 27 -- The Security Council unanimously endorses the plan.
 
FEB. 13, 1999 -- A South African envoy meets with Colonel Qadddafi and says there is an accord.
 
MARCH 19 -- President Nelson Mandela of South Africa goes to Libya and, with Colonel Qaddafi, announces that the two suspects will be handed over by April 6.
 
APRIL 5 -- The suspects are handed over to the United Nations, and the sanctions are suspended.

HEADLINE: Immigration Boosts Our Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
George J. Borjas's warning about the fiscal consequences of large-scale immigration of both unskilled labor and "high-tech braceros" (Op-Ed, April 2) runs contrary to the experience of the United States over the last two centuries, when the large influx of immigrants contributed to America's economic growth and made it the world's major economic power. 
 Restrictive immigration laws enacted during the 1920's, along with other factors, helped precipitate the Great Depression.
Despite the lack of high levels of education among most undocumented workers, they fill jobs like short-order cook, cleaner, gardener, farm worker and nanny at wage levels that do not trigger inflationary pressures.
 
VEDULA N. MURTI
Middletown, Pa., April 3, 1999
 
The writer is an assistant professor of economics, Pennsylvania State University.

HEADLINE: Immigration Boosts Our Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Illegal Immigrant Workers Being Fired in I.N.S. Tactic" (front page, April 2): The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 made it a felony for employers to hire an illegal immigrant. However, employers cannot refuse employment to a worker who presents a document that appears "genuine on its face." This Catch-22 forces farmers to hire workers they suspect may be illegal immigrants, which in turn makes farms easy targets for raids and audits by the Immigration and Naturalization Service. 
 Farmers do not want to hire illegal immigrants, but the Federal guest worker program -- the only way that immigrants can obtain temporary visas -- is complex, time-consuming and expensive for farmers.
That program must be reformed.
 
JULIE MURRAY
Olympia, Wash., April 2, 1999
 
The writer is director of farm labor, Washington State Farm Bureau.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: IN MACEDONIA;
Macedonian Delays Endanger Refugees, Relief Agencies Say

BYLINE: By CARLOTTA GALL 

DATELINE: BLACE, Macedonia, April 5

 BODY:
With tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians fleeing Kosovo backed up in dismal conditions at the Macedonian border, international relief officials accused Macedonia today of endangering lives by processing the refugees too slowly.
One official said that Macedonians were deliberately delaying the processing out of fear that a vast influx of Kosovo Albanians would upset the country's ethnic balance. Albanians account for about 20 percent of this country's population, while Macedonians, who generally sympathize with Serbia in the current conflict, make up about 45 percent. 
 Paula Ghedini, press officer for the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said that Macedonian authorities were clearing only 5,000 refugees a day, while 65,000 were stuck on a muddy hillside at the border, blocked by Macedonian forces from entering the country.
"That is not enough," Ms. Ghedini said. People are now dying at a rate of 10 a day, she said, and "this will increase if we do not get people out from the open."
"We have to get them out of the mud," she said. "It is extremely cold, it has been raining quite a lot, people are weakened, fatigued and in a state of shock."
Macedonia has been flooded with 136,000 refugees, most arriving in the last few days. In addition to the 65,000 believed to be stranded at Blace, the main crossing, another 30,000 people are thought to be on the far side of the border, in Kosovo.
And, at least one more train arrived this morning from Pristina, carrying some of the 5,000 people who arrived in the last 24 hours.
The latest arrivals have come on foot from Urosevac and even from Vucitrn, in northern Kosovo, fleeing Serbian forces and police officers who have forced a mass exodus of ethnic Albanians from their homes.
One official from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, who insisted on anonymity, said Macedonian officials were barely cooperating with relief operation, and said the Macedonians were intentionally halting the influx.
Foreign aid organizations, which are providing the food and supplies, and NATO and the United Nations Commissioner, which are setting up camps to take the refugees elsewhere in Macedonia, were clearly losing patience today.
"They do not want to move people into Macedonia, that is incredibly clear," the United Nations official said. "They do not like Albanians at all, and that feeling is incredibly widespread among the population in Macedonia."
Macedonia has declined to give the United Nations a full mandate to process, register and care for refugees, despite the agency's offer.
"We have the experience and ability to process 20,000 refugees in one day," the official said, "but they do not want us do it."
Government officials have said the influx of refugees threatens Macedonia's economic and political stability. They have also expressed anxiety about the security of the border, and have brought in extra forces to secure the area and guard the refugees.
The policy appeared to have widespread support among ordinary Macedonians, who did not conceal their antipathy for the Albanians.
"Why don't your countries take them," asked one young policeman, cradling an automatic weapon as he guarded the road at the camp. "We don't want them."
Residents of Skopje were even more outspoken against the refugees. "The Government should not let them in," said Niko, a 24-year-old dealer of spare car parts and an ethnic Macedonian. "As you see we have enough problems ourselves. They are closing the factories because there is no money and if the Albanians come in, things will be even worse. We will become a minority here."
The Macedonian Government's actions also seem aimed at forcing foreign countries to take a large number of the refugees. United Nations officials agreed that other countries should share the burden.
"We are one hour's flight from any European capital, and they could offer safe havens to people," Ms. Ghedini said. "They should let them in on a temporary basis because most of these people will want to go back to Kosovo when they can."
Several busloads of refugees were taken straight to the airport this evening in an apparently uncoordinated move by the local authorities, and five planes reportedly flew about 750 Kosovars to Turkey.
Other countries have pledged to take refugees, but in the meantime, Ms. Ghedini said, the refugees should be given immediate help inside Macedonia.
Only one foreign aid agency, Doctors of the World, has been allowed to set up a medical tent inside the sprawling camp at Blace. Only local aid workers are allowed into the camp, to distribute food and gather up the sick. The official reason given for preventing foreigners from working in the camp is that it is a restricted border zone.
Ms. Ghedini said she worked all day and night at a transit camp put up by NATO. "We were ready at 2 P.M. yesterday, but there were no registration officials, no buses to take the refugees," she said.
The authorities began transferring the refugees in the middle of the night. By 3 A.M. some 5,000 refugees had been moved to the transit camp. "But there was no official at the camp, and we have no information as to whether they will be processed," she said. "This is quite frustrating."

HEADLINE: Dispensing Of Drugs On Internet Stirs Debate

BYLINE: By LISA NAPOLI 

 BODY:
Dr. James De Yarman specializes in performing hair transplants at his clinic in San Diego. Last September, he took his expertise on line, setting up a site on the World Wide Web called DrPropecia.com. There, he offers information about the drug Propecia, which promotes hair growth in men. Prospective patients can fill out an on-line medical history form, which Dr. De Yarman reviews for a $50 fee. If he determines that the drug would be useful for a patient, he then prescribes it and sells it to him.
"I have to assume they're telling me the truth," he said. "I'm not a drug store. I look at this as providing a service, going on line to sell it. What would I do different if they were to come into the office?" 
 Dr. De Yarman and others, who essentially function as both physician and pharmacist on line, are just one example of the ways in which the World Wide Web is changing how prescription drugs are changing hands. In other cases, international pharmacies, which sell drugs without prescriptions that may not be regulated in this country, offer on-line signposts for their wares. And, in the freewheeling climate of the Internet, patients are exchanging information and selling leftover drugs to one another.
These activities are raising questions about how drug transactions should be regulated -- and how, with the borderless, seemingly infinite shape of the on-line medium, they can be.
The Internet has leaped ahead of the agencies that govern prescription drugs in the United States. Typically, drugs are approved for use by the Food and Drug Administration, prescribed by doctors who are licensed by state medical boards, and dispensed by pharmacies licensed by state pharmaceutical boards. But by using the Internet, people can often purchase drugs from sources not licensed by these agencies. These activities have long gone on off-line, but have been difficult to detect. Now these practices seem to be booming on-line.
One concern stems not from the well-advertised Internet drugstores like Drugstore.com or Soma.com, both of which require a patient to fax a prescription from a doctor to have it filled on line. The focus is on sites like MDpharmacy.com, Net-Dr.com and US-care.com, which, like Dr. De Yarman's site, circumvent the traditional medical relationships by allowing a patient without a prescription to fill out a consultation form on line, pay a fee for its review and, if approved, receive drugs through the mail.
While the American Medical Association said it was not a violation of its code of ethics for a doctor to sell prescription drugs, it is an ethical violation to sell drugs without a face-to-face consultation. State law in California, where Dr. De Yarman does business, prohibits the sale of drugs without an examination. But most laws and codes which govern medicine were written before the Internet, said Greg Abrams, legal counsel to the California Medical Society, and do not factor in the questions raised by the medium.
Keith Lamb, who lives in Columbus, Ohio, recently purchased oxycodone, a potentially addictive pain reliever classified as a controlled substance in the United States, from a Spanish pharmacy he found over the Internet, because no doctor he visited locally would prescribe the drug for his back pain. "Foreign pharmacies willing to ship without prescription are a growing source who has seized on this gap because their countries do not regulate drugs the way the U.S. does," he said.
Dr. Randy Wykoff, the associate commissioner for operations at the F.D.A., said the sale of illegal or unapproved products is, of all the violations made possible by the Internet, of particular concern to the agency. In recent years, he said, several staff members who would typically investigate medical fraud have been redeployed to look for fraudulent practices on line.
Besides buying from foreign-operated Web sites, some Internet users swap drugs, facilitated by bulletin boards and other Web areas that foster a flea market environment on line. One participant in an on-line infertility group, for example, offered to sell "leftover" drugs she had purchased from Israel.
Determining which actions to take and which policies to rewrite to acknowledge the vast impact of the Internet on the sale of pharmaceuticals will take time. The House Commerce Committee last month commissioned the General Accounting Office to conduct a study on the scope of the prescription drug trade on line. The National Association of Boards of Pharmacy, the trade group for pharmacies, announced last month that it is developing a seal of approval for on-line pharmacies to help customers determine which ones are legitimate. The first seals are expected to be issued by May.
"We are not concerned about the economics, but about patient safety," said Carmen Catizone, the executive director of the pharmacy association.
For his part, Dr. De Yarman sees more benefits than pitfalls in extending his medical practice on line. "This is the future of medicine," he said.

An article in Science Times last Tuesday about the dispensing of drugs on the Internet misidentified the one ordered on line from a Spanish pharmacy by Keith Lamb of Columbus, Ohio, who suffers from back pain. It was codeine, not oxycodone.

HEADLINE: At Tip Time, Restaurants Do the Math

BYLINE: By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
RESTAURANTS aren't sure that customers get the idea behind tips. Diners seem to have this notion that they're voluntary, a show of appreciation, something that's done only because they feel like doing it.
In fact, the tip is just part of the game -- and a growing number of restaurants are trying to lay down rules to make it easier for diners to do what they are expected to do. 
 Some restaurants -- like the new 16-32 Coach House in New York -- have tried calculating a 15 percent tip and adding it to the bill, just like an extra appetizer or entree.
Others, like Lula in Santa Monica, Calif., are printing "gratuity guidelines" on checks, and calculating what a 15 or 20 percent tip would be.
A few, like Restaurant Daniel, are setting mandatory tips of 20 percent on groups as small as six.
And many more places, including Union Square Cafe and the Palm Court in New York, are determinedly looking for ways to provoke diners into leaving a large enough tip, while not provoking them so much that they'll never come back.
It's been a bumpy experiment so far.
"Americans don't like to be told what to tip," said Barry Wine, a New York restaurant consultant. "We, the customer, want the power to reward good service and penalize bad service."
But restaurateurs aren't giving up.
The "gratuity guideline" or a "suggested gratuity" is the most common ploy. The restaurants list a variety of tips -- usually 15, 18 and 20 percent -- calculated from the bill. The tip is not added to the total, but the implication is clear: tip within the given range.
Offering tip calculations is "quicker for the customer," said Karen Kraushaar, a spokeswoman for the National Restaurant Association.
"It's easier," she said. "It's a convenience, there's no question."
But that is not quite the reaction most diners have. "It's kind of tacky," said Jay Goswick, an anesthesiologist in Los Angeles. When he recently had dinner at Lula and the bill came with a gratuity guideline, Mr. Goswick was taken aback. You can patronize the patron only so much.
"It was funny to see that this was the tip they thought you should leave," Mr. Goswick said. "It would make me more critical, make me question, 'Do they deserve that much?' "
Z-Tejas Grill in Austin, Tex., has been telling diners how much to tip for six months. "You kind of get mixed reviews," Doug Young, the general manager at the restaurant, said. Some diners have complained, he added, saying that the restaurant is trying to force them into leaving at least 15 percent.
The servers, however, like the system. "It has 20 percent on there," Mr. Young said, "and if you give good service then you usually get 20 percent."
Some restaurants are more bullying. At the "21" Club, the diner is advised: "Suggested 20 percent gratuity is not included."
Keeping servers happy is important during a time when they are in great demand -- and short supply. Tips generally make up at least 80 percent of a server's salary, so gratuities are built into the restaurant economy.
"Tipping does vary," Ms. Kraushaar said. And calculating tips for diners "is a way of trying to establish some consistency in tipping -- that's why it could be worth trying."
Companies that make the software used to calculate guest checks and to print credit card receipts say there is a growing interest in programs that calculate tips.
American Express developed a gratuity calculation feature on its terminals last year. "Merchants wanted it," Judy Tenzer, a company spokeswoman, said. Restaurants can request the feature, and can then choose the tip levels they want printed on the check.
Micros, a maker of sales terminals with more than 1,400 restaurant clients in New York and New Jersey, has received several requests for the program over the last nine months, said Lubodar Olesnycky, its president. One of them was from Union Square Cafe, which for years has been at the forefront of service in American dining.
An employee at the restaurant saw a gratuity guideline on a check at a small Chinese restaurant in northern New Jersey, and brought it to the attention of the management. They immediately took an interest in the idea.
"The problem it's trying to solve is universal," said Paul Bolles-Beaven, a managing partner at the restaurant. "Sometimes, people leave a low tip and it's not an indication of poor service. Maybe they're having a bad math experience or they've had a little more wine than is normal."
In the past, he and his partners had considered ways of incorporating tips into the price of the meal. They discussed this new idea for several months and asked Micros to develop a way to integrate it into their current system.
"On the positive side, we felt it could feel like a service to the guest," Mr. Bolles-Beaven said. "On the negative side, we felt it could take what is currently a discretionary thing and add some arm twisting to it."
When the management asked some of its regular guests whether they thought it should proceed with the program, though, the response was a unanimous "No." And the idea was promptly buried.
But restaurateurs and consultants say that New York is unique in respect to tipping. First of all, calculating tips is made easier by New York state tax, which, if doubled, equals 16 1/2 percent. But also, said Steve Hanson, the owner of Ruby Foo's Dim Sum and Sushi Palace and several other restaurants in the city, New Yorkers consider themselves more sophisticated.
"They can calculate what 2 percentage points can be," he said. And they don't want to be told.
The one exception used to be that parties of eight or more were charged a set tip, usually 15 percent. Now, in many Manhattan restaurants, like Le Bernardin, Bolo and Gotham Bar and Grill, parties of just six are charged an automatic gratuity, often as high as 20 percent.
When the 16-32 Coach House opened recently, the restaurant, which has a fixed-price menu, tried tagging on a 15 percent service charge to all checks. "It was a way of establishing that you come in and you know this is what you're going to pay for a meal," said Kirk Reed, the general manager of the restaurant. "It was trying to simplify things, but it ended up making things less simple."
Some diners failed to notice the service charge, which was listed on the bill, along with other food and beverage charges. So, they added a second tip. A blank line below the total, marked "gratuity," didn't help matters.
But the other drawback to this policy was that in New York, when service charges are added to a bill, they must be added before tax, which means that the tip is taxed.
The restaurant has since gone back to a traditional discretionary tipping system.
For many years, Michael's restaurant, in New York City and Santa Monica, added 15 percent service charges to all checks. Michael McCarty, the owner of the restaurants, converted back to an optional tipping system last year. To his surprise, the average tip in both locations is now closer to 20 percent.
"All these years, we gave our clients a bargain at 15 percent," he said.
He remains adamant that service charges are a more civilized way of doing business but is tired of trying to win over diners. "You're really wasting your time if you're trying to dictate to people what to leave," he said. "People are independent."
The United States is one of the few countries where voluntary tipping is customary. In Europe, a service charge of 10 to 15 percent is almost always included in the bill. Many travelers visiting the United States for the first time simply do not know to tip.
In New York City, some restaurants are not shy about cluing them in. There may be a large-type line on the menu, noting that a gratuity is not included. There may even be a second reminder printed on the check.
And in some cases, the server may simply take the matter into his own hands.
At the Palm Court at the Plaza Hotel, for instance, if the guest doesn't speak English, servers may automatically add a 15 percent gratuity. The management has found that almost 50 percent of their diners fail to leave adequate -- or 15 percent -- tips. A fact that they blame on uninformed tourists.
The American Festival Cafe in Rockefeller Center tried a softer approach. The check was brought to the table with a form asking diners -- in six different languages -- if they wanted to have a 15 percent tip added to their check. Diners could check "yes" or "no" boxes. The space, leased by Restaurant Associates, is currently being renovated. But when it reopens this summer, it will provide a similar form.
For Restaurant Associates, though, this form is where it draws the line. It would not consider adding gratuity calculations to checks, said John Harding, the director of marketing.
"It seems presumptuous to tell a person this is how much to tip," he said. "Tipping is a voluntary appreciation of service."
Or at least it is for the moment -- if your party is six or less, if you speak English and if you dare to ignore the guidelines.

HEADLINE: In the Balkans, No Wars Are 'Local'

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan is a correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly and the author of "Balkan Ghosts: A Journey Through History."

DATELINE: STOCKBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The humanitarian nightmare in Kosovo may be reason enough for NATO's involvement in the former Yugoslavia, but for the United States there are vital strategic stakes involved as well. These stakes justify the use of any NATO measures needed to defeat Serbia, including the use of ground troops, because nothing less than the future contours of Europe are now being decided.
When the East-West division of Europe was erased in 1989 with the collapse of the Berlin Wall, a new division immediately began forming: that between Central Europe and the Balkans. Even before the outbreak of fighting in Yugoslavia in 1991, the Central European states of Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia were pulling dramatically ahead of Balkan countries like Romania and Bulgaria in terms of progress toward stable, democratic rule. 
 These northerly states of the former Warsaw Pact had several advantages: they were heirs to the traditions of the Hapsburg Empire, and they had sizable middle classes prior to World War II and Communist rule. The Balkan states were burdened by centuries of Byzantine and Turkish absolutism, and even before the Communist takeovers their middle classes had been mere specks amid vast seas of peasantries.
The admission of Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has formalized this dangerous historical and religious redivision of Europe: between a Roman Catholic and Protestant West and an Orthodox Christian and Muslim East.
However, Slobodan Milosevic's campaign in Kosovo has now given the West a chance to reverse this process. A real NATO victory, one that not only gives the Kosovars protection but also knocks Serbia off its perch as the region's military threat, would go a long way toward stabilizing the continent.
This is because the immediate impact of the current fighting is being felt well beyond the states of the former Yugoslavia, which all told constitute only a third of the Balkan peninsula. Three major Balkan countries -- Romania, Bulgaria and Greece -- though not directly threatened by the flood of refugees roiling Albania and Macedonia, are nevertheless at a pivotal point of political destiny.
In Romania, the largest and most populous Balkan state, there is a tenuous peace between the Orthodox Christian majority and the ethnic Hungarian minority, which is mixed Catholic and Protestant and lives in the northwestern region of Transylvania. This relative calm is a significant achievement given that in the course of this century each group has occupied the other's territory.
Yet social peace is threatened by the lack of modernization in the countryside and Cabinet chaos in Bucharest, where economic reform is in slow motion and investor confidence is eroding. In Romania only the military is well run. Though Romanians are Eastern Orthodox, the horrible memory of dark Stalinist decades makes them desperate for NATO membership, which would keep the military out of politics, stifle ethnic nationalist politicians and energize the elite in the direction of good government.
The same goes for Bulgaria, where the democratically elected Cabinet is valiantly working toward economic reform but is besieged by criminal groups with links to Russian businesses and mafias. These groups operate as a state within a state and control large parts of the economy, including banks, car insurance and energy companies, tourist businesses and agricultural exporting. They put tremendous pressure on the Government and effectively push the country into Russia's fold.
The Bulgarian elite is fighting back but is legitimately afraid of being stranded at the far end of the Balkans, spurned by NATO and severed from Central Europe by instability in Kosovo and Macedonia. If the West cannot pacify the region, Bulgarian politicians will have to survive through deals with Russophile criminals.
Greece is the most misunderstood Balkan country. The West demands that Greece behave exactly like the other members of the alliance because it is middle class and a member of NATO. But it can't, because it is in the Balkans and must adjust its foreign policy relative to its geographical position. Greeks know that they are fated to live next door to the Serbs long after any NATO troops leave.
Moreover, throughout the long centuries of Turkish occupation, Greeks were supported by their Orthodox co-religionists in Serbia and Russia -- a fact of history with effects that run deep. And, having never experienced Soviet occupation or Communism, Greeks have a romantic attachment to Russia that doesn't exist in Romania or even Bulgaria.
The Greek Government is supporting the United States as best it can, given the pressures upon it from both the political left and right. But if the Serbs humiliate NATO, Greeks will act in self-interest: their NATO ties will be reduced to an official trapping, even as they deny this very fact and quietly intensify links with their fellow Orthodox in Moscow and Belgrade. After 47 years of NATO membership, Greece could be lost.
Appeals to conscience will not keep Greece a de facto as well as a de jure member of NATO, nor will they keep Romania and Bulgaria from slipping into the sway of Russia. What is required is nothing less than a complete NATO military victory. Indeed, while the Greeks and the Macedonian Slavs despise each other, as Orthodox Christians they equally despise the Muslim Kosovars. Few in the region can be expected to feel sympathy for the Islamic refugees, who disrupt the fragile religious and ethnic balance in neighboring countries, already burdened by weak governments and high unemployment.
Thus, if the bombing campaign fails and NATO gives up at the negotiating table, it would seal Europe off according to medieval lines, with the newly expanded NATO a mere variation of the old Holy Roman Empire -- the old Christian West, that is -- and with the Near East beginning where the old Ottoman Turkish Empire once did, roughly on the border between Croatia and Serbia and somewhere in Transylvania where ethnic Hungarians meet Romanians.
In 1834, entering the autonomous Ottoman principality of Serbia from the Hapsburg Empire, the English travel writer Alexander Kinglake wrote, "I had come, as it were, to the end of this wheel-going Europe, and now my eyes would see the Splendour and Havoc of the East." That same demarcation between East and West will re-emerge unless Mr. Milosevic is crushed with air and ground troops and a NATO protectorate is established in Kosovo and Macedonia. Only Western imperialism -- though few will like calling it that -- can now unite the European continent and save the Balkans from chaos.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Storyteller Tries to Lift Up a Ravaged Land

BYLINE: By JOYCE WADLER 

 BODY:
THE organizers of the People's Poetry Gathering, a three-day festival going on in a half-dozen downtown locales this weekend, were proud to announce, among their poets, a West African griot, or storyteller and history-keeper, one Kewulay Kamara, who was raised in Sierra Leone.
As that job sounded like a cousin to a reporter's, it seemed worth a trip to Queens, where Mr. Kamara lives with his wife and three children in Jackson Heights, to compare notes. His apartment was sun-filled and welcoming; there was coffee and a plate of brownies. 
 But one could see early on there were cultural gaps to bridge.
"Griot," for example, is considered a somewhat offensive term, associated with French colonialism. Mr. Kamara, who will be performing at Cooper Union on Sunday afternoon, prefers the word "finah" (pronounced FEE-nah). Finahs are not simply historians; they are orators, emcees, inspirational speakers.
Do finahs, as tellers of the village tales, have the same complaints from their community if their stories are too frank as did, say, the young Philip Roth?
A perplexed look from Mr. Kamara, 45, who, while he has a computer alongside his African drums and has lived in this country since he was 18, is not familiar with early Roth.
"It's not told in a literal way, the way history in the West is told," Mr. Kamara says. "Our history is very, very didactic and it's told in the company of music."
A smile. "Multimedia."
Another cross-cultural problem, this one belonging entirely to Mr. Kamara: He is a history keeper. His country has been torn apart by war. How to tell that story?
Do you believe in an African Eden? That is the picture that comes to mind when Mr. Kamara speaks of Danka Wali, his village in the mountains of Sierra Leone.
The town had grown up about a great tree, 20 feet in width. So welcoming were the people of Danka Wali, Mr. Kamara says, that when strangers arrived they would be met with a song. Mr. Kamara sings a little, then translates.
"Tabom bari moya dudee -- come to my home you will see the epitome of hospitality, there is abundance of food in my home" -- and suddenly, in his living room, one thinks (Aha!) of the brownies -- "there is abundance of laughter."
Mr. Kamara's father was a finah and a farmer. Mr. Kamara accompanied his father to all the important ceremonies of the town. He was also the first of his family to have a Western education.
HE attended a Roman Catholic boarding school, then came to the United States and spent a year in a public high school in Massachusetts. He received a political science degree from the State University at Oneonta, and a master's degree in economics from the New School. He works for the Census Bureau.
Last year, Mr. Kamara learned that his village had been attacked. Almost all 200 homes were destroyed, two of his uncles were murdered, two brothers were missing.
"The people came out to welcome them, singing," says Mr. Kamara, in his storytelling voice, "and what did they do? They herded the children into huts and lit them up. The old were hacked and thrown into huts and lit up. The people dispersed into the forests. Three days of killing and maiming."
Mr. Kamara raised $5,000 and returned to Sierra Leone with money, clothing and medicine. He brings out what he salvaged from his father's home: two clay medicine pots.
"I was going to write about it," Mr. Kamara says. "But I wanted to write an uplifting story where the people came back to the village and began rebuilding their houses. And shortly thereafter it was attacked again and again and there were more horror stories."
Doesn't Mr. Kamara feel obligated to bear witness to a story even if it doesn't have an optimistic ending?
"What is the meaning of telling a story if it doesn't help people transcend?" Mr. Kamara says.
Then Mr. Kamara recalled another story about his village, told to him by his father:
There once was a village that had many conflicts. Then a village elder told the people to make a sacrifice to the great tree that stood over them. After that, life was harmonious.
"Then there came a time when a great conqueror walked the land," Mr. Kamara says. "Wherever he went, the vultures were never hungry and smoke covered the sky. He was told not to go to Danka Wali, but he did. And when he stood under the great tree, there was thunder and lightning. And when it was clear, the great conqueror lay dead."
Was there in fact a conqueror who was killed in Mr. Kamara's village?
"Well, I'm telling you what I was told," Mr. Kamara says. "As you can see, there is a poetry in it. Maybe he did die. I believe it. But the way I am doing it now, telling this old story with the new, gives new meaning to it: Hey, this thing continues. The village was not destroyed before. People have come with their guns. But they will not destroy the village."
Mr. Kamara reflects.
"I grew up surrounded by sacred forests where you can't cut a living tree and when the village was attacked, where did the people hide? In the sacred groves they were forbidden to cut down."
Two writers considering:
Aha!
Aha!

LENGTH: 1616 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Banking System and the Sword;
A Regulator Sets His Agenda For Japan's Financial Giants

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 6

 BODY:
As a samurai, Hakuo Yanagisawa would have never bothered to sheathe his sword. He spends his time feinting and darting and backing his adversary -- Japan's banking system -- against the wall. The establishment seems ready to yield.
Not long after Mr. Yanagisawa took over as chief regulator of Japan's banking system last fall, word raced through town that two bank presidents had committed suicide. It wasn't true, but it captured the fear felt by bank executives that Mr. Yanagisawa's demands on them would be unbearably taxing and that their jobs might no longer be secure. 
 Mr. Yanagisawa has suggested that he wants fewer banks. He has bullied five banks into pulling out completely from international business. And others have caved in to his demand that they abolish the deeply ingrained practice of "sodanyaku," in which former top executives continue to draw large salaries and retain a company-paid car and driver until the day they die.
For his part, Mr. Yanagisawa, a 63-year-old member of Parliament, shrugs off the talk of suicides and undue pressure. He argues that his rule is harsh only in comparison with the Finance Ministry officials who, he says, governed the banks for years "tenderly, like a mother."
"We are absolutely not giving the Japanese financial institutions the cruel treatment or giving them an impossible or unsolvable agenda," he said. But, he added pointedly, "I am convinced that this is a time of change."
Like the Resolution Trust Corporation in the United States, which simultaneously shut down numerous savings institutions and bailed out many others, the Financial Reconstruction Commission that Mr. Yanagisawa heads will rely on a combination of carrots and sticks.
Mr. Yanagisawa and other Government officials say the banks wiped off all the bad debt from their books on March 31, the end of the fiscal year. They set aside $77 billion, enough to both cover the bad debt and provide a cushion for good debt that might go bad.
The day before, the banks buttressed their weak cushion of capital when the Government funneled in large chunks of cash in a bid to restart the recessionary economy. The Government hopes that the infusion of $64 billion will encourage banks to take more lending risks, thus easing a credit squeeze.
Mr. Yanagisawa is attaching some strings to the money. He demanded agendas for restructuring, which now include cutting one in three board directors on average.
Moreover, when banks distribute their preferred shares to the Government, in return for taxpayers' money, they will have to watch their stock prices closely. If a bank's stock slides, then the Government could increase its stake when it converts its preferred shares, which do not carry voting rights, into common stock. In some cases, such as Daiwa Bank, the Government could start stepping up its voting stake beginning as early as June.
"This is the first time in Japanese banking history that the share price is important to management," said Robert Zielinski, a banking analyst at Lehman Brothers in Tokyo. "If they let the share price drop, they might be owned by the Government."
To be sure, Mr. Yanagisawa is hardly a radical. A former Finance Ministry official, he rose in the bureaucracy as an elite graduate of Tokyo University. As a politician he has defended farmers, a key constituency. He rarely drinks more than one beer at a time and he does not play golf. His idea of a good time is a walk through a modern art museum with his wife, a woodblock artist.
And though his aides leap when Mr. Yanagisawa calls, especially to nightly meetings that often end at 10 P.M., they say he takes good care of them, sometimes ordering take-out for those who work late.
Mr. Yanagisawa contends that Japan is near the end of its eight-year battle with bad debt, and an increasing number of financial experts -- while still worried about Japan's enormous economic problems -- are encouraged by the growing sense that banks will not collapse and throw the system into shock.
As a result, Mr. Yanagisawa has been winning plaudits where it counts -- in the marketplace. The stock market is up some 20 percent from its low in October and bank shares have leapt 65 percent since then. Some overseas hedge funds and other investors are betting that the worst has passed and that the potential for gains now outweighs the risk of further losses.
The changes inside the banking system may seem to come slowly, but progress is being made. Bank executives are losing their bonuses, salaries are being cut, and more and more employees are afraid of being dismissed. Banks are re-evaluating their customers, writing off loans, calling in others or demanding partial repayment. They are unloading unwanted real estate, as well as selling some bad loans.
The Financial Supervisory Agency, which Mr. Yanagisawa's commission oversees, says it plans to set up an electronic monitoring system at the banks over the summer, and it is considering sending in full-time inspectors.
Still, there has been a lot more talk than action, and Mr. Yanagisawa has critics. For one thing, no one believes that the banks' books are clean just yet. The present estimate of $77 billion in bad debt is only a tiny fraction of the various estimates that previously made the rounds -- $650 billion and higher -- although it is unclear whether previous estimates were too high or the present one too low.
Some analysts say the banks need to anticipate at least another $85 billion in bad-debt disposal next year, and even more public money, especially if the economy retreats again.
"They've put some stability under the tottering structure, but they haven't repaired it," said Alicia Ogawa, managing director at Nikko Salomon Smith Barney. "They have a lot of good policy out there. The question is: Is the Government really going to enforce it? Judging from recent history, there's not a lot of good hope."
Others complain that key decisions about the banks were based on hasty inspections. Teams of 10 inspectors from the Financial Supervisory Agency spent more than two months poring over the books of each bank, but their work may be suspect because many had previously worked in the Finance Ministry, which has been seen as too gentle on the banks.
Mr. Yanagisawa has been trying to raise the credibility of his watchdogs, and he refused to move into the same office compound as the Finance Ministry.
Japanese bankers themselves are skeptical about rapid change. One Japanese executive said real change could only come when his generation retired. Another banker said that unless senior management set a good example, it would be hard to impose changes in pay scales, eradicate lifetime employment or curb pension and other benefits.
"My worry is that by the time the F.S.A. says they will fire management, I think it will be too late," the banker said. "The problem that many banks face is that they can't make the tough decisions to invest in new businesses when their mission now is to fire and get rid of the bad loans."
Japan's banking system faces a number of obstacles before it regains its balance, much less before it becomes internationally competitive. Banks need to catch up in technology -- they are not even fully linked to the Internet -- and transform the way they perceive and perform their business.
"The problem in the Japanese banking system now is that they are not making money," said a senior official at the Financial Supervisory Agency. "The challenge they face is to look for new businesses where they can expect higher profitability.
"This time in Japan, there are new young entrepreneurs," he added, speaking on the condition he not be identified. "I hope the banks would help people take over old traditional sectors and enterprises in Japan, so that each enterprise becomes more active in taking risks."
While some analysts are encouraged by the new direction, they say Mr. Yanagisawa's commission, which is supposed to oversee the supervisory agency for another two years before its mandate expires, must keep up the pressure. Otherwise, the banks will lapse into old habits.
One worry is that the financial supervisors are stretched too thin. With banking reform on track, the agency now wants to turn to the problems at smaller, local financial institutions, as well as the billions of dollars in bad debts burdening the insurance industry. But it cannot afford to ignore the banks.
The Government demanded detailed plans from the banks on how they would refocus their businesses, but Mr. Yanagisawa was disheartened to find that almost all of them chose the same path: to strengthen their retail business. The problem, he says, is that banks still aim to protect stakeholders -- employees in particular -- rather than the shareholders who nominally are the owners.
"You can call it the Japanese character if you want, but I can definitely say that all of corporate management, not just the management at banks, is stakeholder management, not shareholder management," Mr. Yanagisawa said. "And they are inclined to all look at what other banks are doing. They want to be in a stable condition together. And considering the future of the Japanese financial industry, that is a little bit of a headache."
Everyone acknowledges that any progress will be slow. Hideichiro Hamanaka, deputy commissioner at the supervisory agency, lit some incense -- perhaps for good luck -- and likened Japanese banks to aircraft carriers, which require time to adjust to a new heading.
"The new direction for the Japanese financial companies has been set," he said. "One or two years down the road the new direction will be evident."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow and S.& P. Retreat, but Nasdaq Edges a Bit Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell from record levels as Gillette led consumer companies lower after the world's largest maker of razors said its earnings would not meet expectations because of slow Latin American sales.
Gillette joined Coca-Cola and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing in warning that business abroad was hurting profits. With stocks near record highs, "there's no room for error," said James Weiss, head of stock investments at State Street Research and Management in Boston, which oversees $54 billion. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 43.84 points, or four-tenths of a percent, to 9,963.49. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 3.23, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,317.89. The Nasdaq composite index edged up 3.11, a tenth of a percent, to 2,563.17, a record.
Declining stocks outnumbered advancing issues on the New York Stock Exchange 1,797 to 1,192. Volume was 787.5 million shares on the Big Board, in line with the three-month daily average.
Gillette slumped 7 3/4, to 50, after it said first-quarter profit would be a penny less a share than analysts had forecast because of weak sales in Latin America and for its Braun appliances. The company said it expected profit of about 24 cents a share.
Coke, which gets two-thirds of its sales and three-quarters of its profit abroad, fell 11/16 , to 59 13/16 . 3M, which gets half of its sales abroad, fell 1 1/16 , to 71 15/16 .
Intel led semiconductor shares higher with a gain of 2 15/16 , to 130 7/16 , after an analyst at Lehman Brothers said the industry's recovery from its worst recession ever was picking up steam.
"A multiyear bull market is under way in semiconductor stocks," the analyst, James Barlage, said in a report to clients. Semiconductor companies shipped $10.9 billion in goods in February, up 3.5 percent compared with sales in the month a year earlier, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association.
Applied Materials rose 2 3/16 , to 67 15/16 ; LSI Logic gained 3 1/2, to 36, and Micron Technology climbed 2 1/4, to 53 3/4.
Other computer stocks also rallied. Dell Computer rose 2 3/4, to 46 13/16 . The third-largest personal computer maker is set to brief analysts tomorrow. Dell and other computer-related companies have lagged behind the gains in the broad market the last two months on concern that sales were slowing. With first-quarter earnings reports on the way, investors are encouraged that Intel and Dell have not issued warnings.
"People are waking to the fact that the fundamentals continue to be very strong for technology companies," Mr. Weiss said.
Sun Microsystems surged 10 5/8, to 140 5/8, after the maker of computers that run Internet sites introduced products that work with a rival operating system from Microsoft. Sun hopes to profit from the sales growth of Microsoft's Windows NT, analysts said.
General Motors, the world's largest auto maker, surged 3 1/2, to 91 1/16 , amid optimism about car sales. Ford Motor, the second-biggest car company, said that total car and truck sales rose 13 percent in March, beating expectations. Ford, however, slipped 1/16 , to 58 1/4.
Liberty Media Group rose 3 1/4, to 59 1/2. The cable-TV programming company will acquire an 8 percent stake in the News Corporation, the world's No. 5 media company, for about $2.1 billion, the companies said.
In the bond market, Treasury prices rose for the second time in three days after Yugoslavia declared a unilateral cease-fire in Kosovo, making investors more willing to take on risk.
James Tesone, who manages $500 million of bonds at Carret & Company, said "the proposed ending of hostilities would make people feel better" about buying long-term bonds over safer, short-term securities, even though the cease-fire was immediately dismissed by NATO.
Treasuries were already rising before the cease-fire was announced as investors took encouragement from expectations for tame inflation in the United States and lower European interest rates.
The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury rose 30/32 , to 96 3/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.52 percent, from 5.58 percent on Monday.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Dividing an Office Tower to Get the Most From It

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
It's a modern marketing variation of divide and conquer -- dividing a building to better conquer the downtown real estate market. That is what the owners have done as part of a $60 million renovation at 60 Broad Street, a 39-story, million-square-foot office building that features a series of setbacks leading to a tower.
The bottom 23 floors, with separate entrances and lobbies, are for various government agencies. And the smaller, higher floors -- 24 through 39, which have windows on all four exposures and superb views of the harbor and the cityscape -- have been renamed the Tower @ 60 Broad Street and are being marketed as 205,000 square feet of high-end office space, with their own lobby and appropriately higher rents. 
 "We felt those floors would command higher rents, and we wanted to create a building within a building for the high-rise," said Richard Mandel, president of the Commercial Group of Kennedy-Wilson International, a publicly traded real estate company based in Los Angeles, which with Pioneer Holdings, a Hong Kong investment company, bought the building 14 months ago. "The views are incredible. You can see the harbor, the Statue of Liberty and the Verrazano Bridge to the south, Brooklyn to the east and the World Trade Center to the north."
The bottom 11 floors, about 450,000 square feet, are occupied by a variety of New York State agencies, with a separate entrance at 25 Beaver Street and nine years left on the leases.
Two New York City agencies have just signed up for floors 12 to 23 -- and their own separate lobby, at 33 Beaver Street. "We're fortunate that the building has a big base -- about 50,000 square feet -- that allows for a lot of entrances," Mr. Mandel said. "We removed a 1,500-square-foot retail space -- an art gallery that used to be on Beaver Street -- to create the new lobby entrance."
The administrative and planning offices -- commissioners and staff -- of the city's Department of Homeless Services and Department of Probation will occupy about 299,000 square feet, he said, with an annual rent of about $23 a square foot. The agencies, as do the state offices, will have their own elevator banks.
The tower floors start at 18,000 square feet, with most of the floors from 27 through 39 about 12,000 square feet. And Mr. Mandel has signed his first two tenants for the space. Grant Thornton, a Chicago-based accounting firm, has leased the 24th and 25th floors, 36,000 square feet. The International Securities Exchange, a new computer-based options exchange, has taken the 26th and 27th floors, 30,000 square feet. Cushman & Wakefield is the building's leasing agent.
Starting annual rents for the two new leases, Mr. Mandel said, "are in the high $20's a square foot."
"We expect to average about $30 a foot for the upper floors," he said, "which is still quite inexpensive, compared to the higher rents in other parts of Manhattan." Mr. Mandel said leases for several other floors are in various stages of negotiation.
The tower will have a new $2 million lobby, designed by Mancini Duffy, and its own six new elevators as part of the $60 million buildingwide plan.
When Kennedy-Wilson and Pioneer bought the building early last year for $62 million from Li Ka-shing, a billionaire investor from Hong Kong, only about 450,000 square feet was occupied. Now, Mr. Mandel said, about 87 percent of the million-square-foot building is spoken for.
The building, built for RCA during a real estate boom in 1961 by the developers Percy and Harold Uris, has been a barometer for the downtown real estate market. The Reichmann family's Olympia & York company bought the Uris properties during a recession in 1977, the first step in establishing itself as the largest commercial landlord in New York. The Reichmanns had a $160 million mortgage on the building in 1990, when the principal tenant, Drexel Burnham Lambert, went bankrupt.
Mr. Li bought the mortgage and a 50 percent stake in the building for $57.5 million in 1991, when Olympia & York was unable to cover the monthly mortgage payments. Olympia & York defaulted on the mortgage, and Mr. Li ultimately took control of the building.
He considered selling the top half of the building for conversion to 400 condominium apartments but eventually sold the entire building to Kennedy-Wilson and Pioneer.
After the new owners took over, they began renovations, which included asbestos abatement over 500,000 square feet, redoing the fire, electrical and sprinkler systems and completely upgrading the elevator systems, "to bring the building up to par with today's buildings," Mr. Mandel said.
Joel Wechsler, a senior managing director at Grubb & Ellis New York, the brokerage company, who specializes in downtown commercial real estate, said he thought that the building-within-a-building concept was a "terrific idea" because "it will enable small to midsize companies to acquire office space in the prestigious tower of a building rather than in the low-rise portion, where most of that competitive inventory is currently available."
Mr. Mandel said he was optimistic about finding tenants. "I expect," he said, "that 95 percent of the building will be leased by summer."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Russia Starting Key Talks With I.M.F.

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Wednesday, April 7

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund and the Russian Government will begin a critical round of negotiations later today that is aimed at completing an economic program and loan package to avert a threatened default on Russia's foreign debt.
Its Treasury and central bank reserves vastly depleted by the financial crisis that began last August, Russia hopes to get the fund to refinance about $4.8 billion in loans coming due this year, most of that in the second and third quarters. 
 The country also needs an economic program approved by the I.M.F. to successfully restructure nearly $17 billion in debt payments it owes to a group of Western lenders.
If it fails to get the fund's approval, Russia is likely to default on all its foreign debt payments. "Time is running out for Russia," said Christopher Granville, a strategist for the Russian subsidiary of Robert Fleming, a British brokerage firm.
Russia has been wrangling with the fund for months to win new loans to refinance its debts. A breakthrough of sorts came last week when Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F's managing director, and Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov issued a joint statement after a meeting in Moscow that noted that both sides had agreed to a primary budget surplus of 2 percent of the gross domestic product in 1999 "and most of the measures needed to achieve it."
It is now up to the I.M.F. delegation of economists that arrived here on Tuesday and the Russian Cabinet to work out the details of those measures, which are of a sort that is consistently among the toughest obstacles to completing aid packages.
At the heart of the problem is a budget shortage around 30 billion rubles, or $1.2 billion, Moscow economists estimate. To reach an agreement with the monetary fund, Moscow must find ways to raise enough revenue to fill the gap, including taking such unpopular steps as imposing a tax on gasoline or export tariffs on metals and other raw material.
Changes in the tax code must be approved by the Communist-controlled lower house of Parliament, which vigorously opposes legislation linked to the I.M.F.
Russia's strained relations with the West, especially the United States, over NATO attacks in Yugoslavia will make things even harder. Indeed, the Russian legislators recently undermined I.M.F. talks by voting for a cut in the value-added tax, which accounts for nearly half of budget revenue, according to the Russian-European Center for Economic Policy, a research group here.
Skittish so far about entering into a long battle with Parliament, Mr. Primakov's Cabinet has taken "a salami-slicing approach to negotiations with the I.M.F.," said a Western diplomat, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "Instead of developing a few major efforts to discuss with the I.M.F.," the envoy said, "the Russians come up with 400 nickel-and-dime measures that grind down their opponents across the table. It shows a political weakness."
Despite the Government's waffling, most economists in Moscow believe that the I.M.F. and the Russians will announce an economic program in the coming days, and that the I.M.F.'s board will approve the new credits at its meeting at the end of this month. Clearly, neither side wants a default. Russia owes the I.M.F. $19 billion, making it one of the lending agency's largest debtors.
For Moscow, default could cause another round of possibly disastrous economic and political upheaval. For the I.M.F. and its major contributing nations, a Russian default would signal the failure of their efforts to nurture market capitalism here.
But after lending Russia money for years, often on the strength of just its promises, the I.M.F. is expected to be much tougher this time. It may insist, for example, on a trial period to see if Russia can make good on the conditions of the economic program before the first installment of aid is released.
"One of the differences from the past is that the I.M.F. is demanding that certain laws be passed before the money is released," said Rudiger Ahrend, director of the Russian-European Center for Economic Policy. "The I.M.F. doesn't want to be seen as giving money to countries heading for another failure."

HEADLINE: Leading Indicators Rise for a Fifth Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators posted its fifth consecutive monthly increase in February, suggesting that the economy will keep growing well into its ninth year of expansion.
The index, which was released yesterday by the Conference Board, is intended to predict economic growth for the following six months. It rose two-tenths of a percent in February -- as expected -- after an unrevised gain of five-tenths of a percent in January. 
 Declining jobless claims and rising consumer confidence led the increase. The number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits was below 300,000 for all of February and has stayed below that level for nine consecutive weeks, the longest such stretch since an 18-month run that ended in December 1973. The University of Michigan's index of consumer expectations -- the gauge used in calculating the leading economic indicators -- rose in February to 103.6, the highest level since April.
"The economy seems to be cruising along well, shrugging off international challenges," said Carl Tannenbaum, chief economist at LaSalle Bank in Chicago.
Of the 10 components of the index, 4 rose in February and 4 declined.
In addition to jobless claims and confidence, a rise in the money supply and a widening of the interest rate spread between the Federal funds rate and the 10-year Treasury note contributed to the index.
Declining new orders for consumer goods and nonmilitary capital goods, a drop in building permits and faster vendor deliveries had negative effects on the index.
Two components, an unchanged manufacturing workweek and a slight decline in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, had no effect on the February index.
The index "shows less breadth than usual, with only 4 of the 10 components rising in February," Michael Boldin, director of business cycle research at the Conference Board, said in the report. "Nonetheless, the overall trend continues to point to strong growth."
The index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current economic activity including industrial output, rose three-tenths of a percent in February after rising two-tenths of a percent in January. The index of lagging indicators rose two-tenths of a percent in February after rising five-tenths of a percent in January.
