HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
A China Trade Deal Is Now Up to Clinton

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
With 24 hours remaining before the arrival of China's Prime Minister, President Clinton struggled tonight to decide whether to strike the broadest trade agreement in Chinese-American history, in return for American agreement to usher China into the World Trade Organization. But his top advisers were deeply split about whether to take the deal.
In two days of furious negotiating here preceding Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's arrival on Wednesday night, American officials have been locked up with China's Trade Minister, Long Yongtu, in an effort to resolve a wide variety of outstanding differences. President Clinton had several conversations today about his bottom-line positions with his trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, but Administration officials said he might try to resolve the last issues directly with Mr. Zhu in their meetings on Thursday. 
 Officials said they had already concluded accords on a series of contentious issues involving agriculture, including a Chinese agreement to allow in American wheat that China previously insisted was tainted with disease. Rather than barring the wheat altogether, China agreed to a tolerance level that will permit most of the American-grown wheat into the country.
In Los Angeles, where Mr. Zhu started his visit today, he said his negotiator had reported "good news" on progress in the trade talks. Page A3.
But the two sides were still negotiating how large a stake American companies will be allowed to take in Chinese telecommunications companies. China has already said it is willing to sell 30 percent stakes in these companies to foreigners, but will not permit them to take controlling interests.
As of this afternoon, both sides were arguing over how much liberty American banks and brokerage firms would have to operate throughout China. At the same time, American officials have raised new issues, including a demand that the United States extend quotas limiting the import of Chinese-made textiles until 2010, an effort to win over some members of Congress whose constituencies are bound to be aroused by any deal. The Chinese have protested the effort, and -- perhaps in a last-minute negotiating ploy -- appeared to back off today on some offers to open the market in the financial sector and on tariff reductions for some American-made goods.
While negotiators argue over the details, though, President Clinton appears focused on the strategic significance of a deal -- helping to integrate China into both the global economy and a global set of legal regulations governing trade. Mr. Clinton is also intent on helping strengthen the authority of Mr. Zhu, whom he sees as an accomplished economic reformer and Washington's best hope of opening a true channel of communication with the Chinese leadership.
But Mr. Zhu, under pressure at home, cannot be seen to be giving in too much to American pressure, especially at the cost of Chinese jobs. And Mr. Clinton, as one of his advisers put it today, "is facing the likelihood of another Nafta fight in Congress" -- a reference to Mr. Clinton's defying his own party to push through the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1993.
Congress had a direct vote on the wisdom of Nafta, and most Democrats opposed it, saying that it would move jobs to Mexico. The China argument, though, is far more complex. Congress does not have a direct voice in whether the Administration casts its vote to get China into the World Trade Organization, which sets the rules of trade and arbitrates disputes. But China's entry would require Congressional action to amend the law that creates an annual Congressional review of China's trading rights, which inevitably becomes enmeshed in China's human rights record, its standoff with Taiwan and now its espionage efforts.
Officials who have sat in meetings on the negotiations say the President is leaning strongly toward striking a deal. But the head of the National Economic Council, Gene Sperling, has argued that anything short of a perfect deal -- and there is no such thing in trade negotiations -- would undercut the Administration's efforts to unify Democrats on Social Security, Medicare and other issues that Mr. Clinton views as central to his legacy. He has received some support from John Podesta, the White House chief of staff.
Tonight Mr. Sperling denied he was opposed to a deal, and added, "We're not raising the bar out of politics, but not lowering the bar to get a deal during the trip, either."
The strongest advocate of a deal, the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, has been almost entirely tied up managing the crisis in Kosovo, the officials say, and that has cast some doubt about how the final arguments will play out in the Oval Office. "From the start, Sandy has wanted this because he realizes it's the only thing that we can get done with the Chinese before the end of this Administration," one White House official said recently.
"But this is a case where the most important relationship we have is getting a lot less attention at a critical moment than it should because of the military action under way," the official continued, "and that raises the chances for miscalculation on our end or the Chinese end."
Still, some of the concessions that Chinese have made so far go beyond the road map that American officials gave Beijing three years ago, when negotiations over China's entry into the World Trade Organization seemed stalled. For example, China has agreed to limit its demand that American companies provide technology to China in return for a right to invest there. The demands for technology have been a major issue for American companies like Boeing, which at times have refused to provide the Chinese with proprietary technology at the cost of large deals.
Whether Mr. Clinton decides to sign a deal may depend on his calculation about how strongly American businesses will support it. Their willingness to lobby in Congress -- pointing out the benefits to individual companies in individual Congressional districts -- may well determine the strength of opposition.
But how willing they will be to press the issue depends on what they get from the deal, which will vary from industry to industry. "Any deal that doesn't have the seal of approval of the business community isn't a deal worth doing," Ms. Barshefsky said last week.

HEADLINE: Ruling Allows Tariffs by U.S. Over Bananas

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 6

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization handed the United States a significant but only partial victory in its long-running dispute over banana trade today, authorizing the Clinton Administration to impose roughly $191 million in sanctions against European-made goods.
The figure is the organization's estimate of the damage done to American companies because of Europe's elaborate quota system that favors the importing of bananas from its former colonies, instead of from Central American nations where Chiquita Brands and other American corporations are major growers. The United States had argued that the damage was far higher, amounting to $513 million, and it began collecting 100 percent tariffs on many European luxury goods early last month. 
 The trade organization's far lower estimate of damage is based on a different, more conservative formula than the one employed by the Clinton Administration. That was a victory for Europe, where officials have accused Washington of exaggerating the effects of Europe's rules. At the same time, the panel of judges determined that Europe's revised rules governing imports amounted to nothing more than a rewriting of the old rules and were an effort to avoid compliance with several past rulings.
"Time is running out" for the Europeans to comply with the organization's mandate, said Peter Scher, who directs agricultural negotiations for the United States trade representative's office.
The oddity of the United States declaring victory over Europe in a long-running economic dispute, while trying to hold the same European nations in alliance in the Kosovo crisis, was somewhat jarring today -- a dissonance that was rarely seen in the days of the cold war, when security always overrode nasty trade spats.
This argument, however, has already gone far beyond questions of banana trade, with Europe and the United States both having considerable political capital invested in their respective positions. President Clinton, who has argued about the issue for hours with European officials, has cast it as a test of the authority of the trade organization to mandate that nations change their trading practices. Unless he can show Americans that Europe is forced to drop trade barriers, he argued recently, it will be impossible to forge a consensus for Congress to comply with rulings that go against the United States.
Presumably, today's ruling paves the way for a negotiated settlement. But so far neither side has been willing to back down, and Mr. Scher said today that the United States would impose the sanctions retroactively, to March 3. Because only $191 million in imports are involved, however, the list of products subject to sanction -- everything from pecorino cheese to expensive European clothing accessories -- will have to be cut at least in half.
The European Union has accused the United States of acting arrogantly, pointing out that virtually no American jobs are at stake. The whole argument, they contend, has arisen only because the head of Chiquita, Carl H. Lindner, is a powerful contributor to both Democrats and Republicans, and has been pressing the Government to aid his company.
There is little doubt that Mr. Lindner's influence pushed the issue to the top of the American trade agenda. But the bottom line of today's decision is that the ruling favored the United States. This evening, Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said in a statement that the W.T.O. decision "sends a clear message" that Europe cannot use a lengthy legal process to buy time, keeping its restrictions on imports in place.
"This is the fifth time in six years that an international trade panel has found the E.U.'s banana policies to be in violation of international trade rules," she said.

HEADLINE: Luck and the B Train Win a Race for a Yankee Fan

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
It was not Mae-Ann Gilbert's worst subway ride. That, she said, would have been the morning rush hour in 1988 when the No. 3 train struck and killed a woman and other passengers cursed the victim for making them late. Nor was it her most unpleasant experience in a contest. That came in 1984, she said, when she was the first-ever black contestant in the Miss Staten Island pageant and her appearance on stage was greeted with stony silence.
But yesterday, as her No. 4 train, allegedly an express, slowed to a walk somewhere north of 14th Street and was passed by a No. 6 train on the local track, she could feel the Great Yankee Stadium Subway Race pulling away from her. "We may be the last ones coming in on this train," she said. "Very slow." 
 For years, the Yankees have entertained fans between innings by showing an animated race on the scoreboard between the B, D and 4 trains from Brooklyn to the Yankee Stadium stop at 161st Street in the Bronx. Yesterday, three subway riders took part in a real-life race to see which train provided the quickest ride.
The three contestants in the race, organized by New York City Transit and Modell's Sporting Goods to promote a new line of Metrocards commemorating the Yankees that go on sale today, were chosen by a drawing at Modell's. Each started at a station in Brooklyn judged to be a one-hour ride from the stadium.
At 10:15 A.M., Ms. Gilbert, 36, an unemployed marketing consultant from South Ozone Park, Queens, stepped through the turnstile at the New Lots Avenue station on the 3 line (she would transfer to the 4 at Utica Avenue). David Ladd, a Hofstra University law student and die-hard Yankee fan from Plainview, N.Y., got on the B train at 50th Street and New Utrecht Avenue in Borough Park. And Dennis Bell, 45, an unemployed maintenance man from Fort Greene, Brooklyn, started at the D station at Avenue U in Sheepshead Bay.
Al O'Leary, a spokesman for New York City Transit, said the inside money was on the No. 4, which runs express in Manhattan (unlike the B) and seems to take the most direct route. Ms. Gilbert, a numerology buff, tried to improve her odds further by sitting in the fourth seat in the fourth car on the 4 train, but the train's mysterious slowdown -- an announcement by the conductor was inaudible -- did her in.
Mr. Bell's D train spent the shortest time en route, about 61 minutes, but he had to wait 10 minutes to board because he entered the station just as a train was pulling out. Even so, he arrived at 161st Street on the same train as Mr. Ladd, who had to transfer to the D at 145th Street in Harlem, the last stop on the B line.
It was here that Mr. Ladd's experience and youth served him well. Confronted with the maze of hallways in the station, Mr. Bell, who had never been to Yankee Stadium, froze in confusion. He spotted Mr. Ladd, only to see him take off like a shot. "I got out and saw the McDonald's, and I knew where I was," Mr. Ladd said. "I headed out across the traffic, and I just started running."
Mr. Ladd, who had recently come off crutches for a sprained ankle, sprinted the half-lap around the stadium to the giant bat on the home-plate side to finish in about an hour and 15 minutes. Mr. Bell, who stopped running several times to catch his breath, wheezed home a few minutes later. Ms. Gilbert, who also got lost in the subway station, finished last.
For Mr. Ladd, who won a pair of box seat tickets to the Yankees' home opener on Friday against the Detroit Tigers, the trip was a learning experience. In dozens of trips to the ballpark, he had always driven. He was circumspect when asked if he would take the Long Island Rail Road and the subway from now on. "I might start," he said. "There's no reason why I wouldn't."

HEADLINE: Reforms Punish Poor, Veteran Socialist Says

SERIES: LIFE AFTER WELFARE: Ending a Tradition

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, April 6

 BODY:
Welfare's sudden death has stunned many residents of the central city here, but few have expressed more dismay than an elderly gentleman on a poverty-pocked block who has been monitoring the neighborhood's civic affairs since the Great Depression.
At 86, Frank P. Zeidler is the last of Milwaukee's three Socialist Mayors -- no other major American city has had even one -- and a living link to a time when Wisconsin politics was synonymous with safety-net expansions, like workers' compensation and unemployment insurance. 
 Now Wisconsin is known for a seemingly opposite passion, an anti-welfare campaign that has cut the state's cash assistance rolls by more than 90 percent. And Mr. Zeidler -- learned, courteous, still sharp as a tack -- is mulling the question that may keep political scientists busy for the next generation:
What happened to the state's famously progressive traditions?
"What you're seeing in Wisconsin is a deconstruction of the progress we made in the first decades of the 20th century," Mr. Zeidler said recently at his home in Milwaukee's poverty belt. "It's a kind of neo-anarchism that says, 'Nothing the Government can do is right,' and only the profit motive is justified. This is one manifestation of it: 'Get rid of the people on welfare.' "
Then again, the welfare restrictions have the support of some of the city's leading Democrats, who say they are building on a progressive past that celebrated toil and toilers. One of the most vocal welfare critics here is the current Mayor, John Norquist, a three-term Democrat who has run each time with Mr. Zeidler's support. As Mr. Norquist puts it, progressive reforms like unemployment insurance aimed "to help workers get through a tough time and get back to work -- the idea wasn't to keep people on welfare."
Ideological disputes aside, most people here agree on one thing: Mr. Zeidler is a civic treasure. A gold mine of local lore -- he interrupted his welfare talk to help a caller trace the origins of Milwaukee fish fries (they started in taverns in the Depression) -- Mr. Zeidler observes the attack on welfare through a unique set of lenses.
As an organizer, he has been working the north side wards since 1932, when German-American factory workers formed the core of the Socialist vote. As Mayor from 1948 to 1960, he fought battles for public housing that foreshadowed the welfare wars. And as a central-city homeowner for 53 years, he has endured white flight, black riots and a rash of break-ins that left him sleeping behind a saw-horse barricade, as devoted to the neighborhood as ever.
"Moving is a terrible hassle," he said. "And you don't want to get pushed out of your own house."
Mr. Zeidler, a Socialist Mayor when Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin was busy hunting Communists, knows that political heritages are complex. In his view, the city's progressive ways have been eroding for more than 40 years, partly for racial reasons. The postwar boom brought poor Southern blacks streaming into Milwaukee, and a white backlash followed. Indeed, as an advocate of public housing, Mr. Zeidler himself was a target. "There was a feeling that benefits were attracting the poor and that cutting benefits would stop it," he said.
The City Council blocked his drive to build more subsidized apartments. (Oprah Winfrey was reared here in one, he notes with pride.) His 1956 opponent called for time limits for public-housing residents -- presaging the time limits on cash assistance that followed 40 years later. And Mr. Zeidler won that race despite wildfire rumors that he was urging blacks to move to town by posting billboards across the South.
"They said I was bringing in all the blacks and secretly moving out," said Mr. Zeidler, who is white. "And here I am, 53 years in the same house."
Yes, he is here, but control of the state has shifted to conservatives in the Milwaukee suburbs and their rural allies, like Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. Mr. Thompson, a Republican from the small town of Elroy, has ridden an anti-welfare crusade to an unprecedented fourth term.
To Mr. Zeidler's chagrin, the drive to end welfare came with early support from Milwaukee Democrats, the closest thing he has to political heirs. As early as 1990, Mayor Norquist was denouncing welfare as harmful to the poor and calling for its replacement with public jobs.
Milwaukee has a long tradition of left-wing politics, noted for its conservative quirks. The city's Socialist pioneers were so pragmatic -- obsessed with services like sanitation, not revolution -- that radicals dismissed them as "sewer Socialists."
Consider the cry of the first Socialist Mayor, Emil Seidel, at his inauguration in 1910. "The eyes of thousands of stricken cities are today directed toward our Milwaukee," he began in soaring fashion -- before promising the masses such consolations as to "place the finances of our city on a sound and sane basis." (His assistants included a Socialist newsman, Carl Sandburg, who later turned to poetry.)
In holding City Hall for 38 of the next 50 years, Milwaukee's Socialists were known for clean water, more parks, strict zoning, low debt and honest and efficient rule -- a sensibility that elsewhere might have been known more simply as "good government." Working in the State Legislature with their off-and-on allies, the rural Progressives, they also passed the nation's first programs of workers' compensation (1911) and unemployment insurance (1932).
By 1993, the Socialists were gone and a war on welfare was under way. In the view of Democrats, Governor Thompson had been denouncing the program without offering a credible alternative. One of Mayor Norquist's proteges, State Representative Antonio Riley (a former welfare recipient himself), introduced a bill that dared the Governor to abolish cash aid and create public jobs.
By passing the bill (with no Republican votes), most Democrats hoped to goad the Governor into an embarrassing veto. But instead, Governor Thompson agreed to "end welfare" three years before Congress followed suit. (He vetoed the jobs provision and fudged the issue later by creating modest community service positions for those unable to find work.) Forced now to work for welfare, most recipients have simply left, to find private jobs or rely on friends.
Recently, another of Mayor Norquist's aides paid Mr. Zeidler a visit. A left-leaning critic of welfare, the aide, David Riemer, brings a near-religious faith in work programs like those created in the Depression. Indeed, it sometimes seems that Mr. Riemer knows every building, bridge, and trail left in Milwaukee by the public works crews of the 1930's.
Though he wants real jobs for the poor -- not community service, where those left on welfare simply work off their checks -- he considers the current system a good start. The state now offers low-income workers an impressive array of benefits: wage supplements, child care subsidies and subsidized health insurance. Even welfare recipients have gotten a raise, to $673 a month from an average of about $517.
"Once people are seen as workers, it's a lot harder to say no to them," Mr. Riemer said. "That was part of 'sewer Socialism': the idea that people who could work, should work -- and society then should help."
Politely, but firmly, Mr. Zeidler disputed the parallels with the past.
Socialism was a movement of the poor, he said, while the welfare reductions have mostly come "from people who want to punish the poor." Socialists stressed education, he said, while the reductions have forced many women to leave school. The Socialists protected minors through child labor laws. They would have been distressed, he said, by a program that puts infants in day care when they are 12 weeks old.
Speaking from nearly nine decades of experience, Milwaukee's last sewer Socialist warned against simple theories of the poor. "People are poor for lots of reasons -- you have to have a net to catch the ones that don't fit your system," Mr. Zeidler said. "And I don't see that anymore. That safety net is gone."
With the nation's welfare rolls down 43 percent, President Clinton, as well as his Republican critics, count the landmark 1996 welfare law as the cornerstone of their respective legacies. That law replaced a 60-year-old cash safety net with a program of time limits and work requirements.
No place has come closer than Wisconsin to the goal of "ending welfare." A decade ago, 100,000 Wisconsin families relied on public aid. Now 9,000 do.
The changes taking place in the state, particularly in its largest city, Milwaukee, continue to reverberate in broad and unpredictable ways. Throughout the year, The New York Times is returning to Milwaukee to plot the pattern of change.
The articles and related coverage of welfare issues are available on The New York Times on the Web, at: www.nytimes.com/ politics.

HEADLINE: First-Quarter Auto Sales Said to Be Fastest Start Ever

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 6

 BODY:
When the General Motors Corporation reports its sales of cars and trucks in March on Wednesday, the first quarter of 1999 will most likely go into the books as the best start ever to a sales year for the United States auto industry.
Virtually every auto maker closed March and the first quarter with sales higher than last year's healthy levels. Last week, DaimlerChrysler, Volvo, Honda and Infiniti reported record March sales. Kia had its best month ever, Volkswagen had its best March since 1981, and Subaru had its best March since 1988. Audi, BMW with Land Rover, Isuzu and Nissan also reported higher sales. 
 "Without even knowing G.M.'s numbers, the first quarter has closed with the fastest sales start in U.S. history," said George Pipas, manager of sales analysis for the Ford Motor Company, which reported higher-than-expected March sales today. Ford said it sold 399,908 cars and trucks through its Ford, Mercury, Lincoln and Jaguar dealers in March, up 13 percent from March and surpassing the March record set in 1978.
When G.M.'s sales are added in -- and they are predicted to be slightly higher than last year's -- the seasonally adjusted average selling rate will likely rise to more than 17 million cars and light trucks, an increase of about 12 percent compared with last year's strong March results, said David Healy, an analyst with Burnham Securities in New York.
Mr. Pipas noted that the first quarter of 1999 was not a single quarter phenomenon. The annual selling rate has been running at 16 million vehicles or more every month since last March, except for July and August, when G.M.'s North American assembly plants were shut because of a strike by workers at two parts plants in Michigan. He sees no end in sight to strong car sales.
What is significant is not only the sheer volume of vehicles auto makers are selling, but what vehicles they are selling, Mr. Healy said.
"The most profitable models are showing the strongest sales and the biggest year-to-year increases," he said, noting sales of Ford's Expedition and DaimlerChrysler's Dodge Durango as well as luxury-car sales are extremely strong. "It's the best of all possible worlds for the auto makers. For a change, Detroit is profit city."
In addition, auto makers have backed off from costly incentives, and the deflation of car prices that has occurred over the last two years appears to be ending. Prices will most likely rise and incentives will continue to slow as auto makers find themselves in short supply of some vehicles because of the stronger-than-expected winter sales. March typically marks the start of the best-selling six months of the year, and auto makers build inventories through the winter to prepare for the spring selling season.
In response to strong sales, auto makers have been raising their sales forecasts for the year and increasing vehicle production. Ford said today that it would increase second-quarter production by 20,000 trucks and 10,000 cars. In March Ford raised its sales forecast for the year to between 15.5 million and 16 million vehicles, from 15 million to 15.5 million.

HEADLINE: How Suspects Were Moved, Very Discreetly, to Court

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 6

 BODY:
The operation was intricate, complex and above all secret. No one except Hans Corell, the chief legal counsel for the United Nations -- not even Secretary General Kofi Annan -- knew the details surrounding the logistics for the surrender of the two Libyan suspects charged with planting the bomb that downed Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.
In interviews during the last two days, Mr. Annan, Mr. Corell and other senior diplomats described eight months of intense political and logistical maneuvering that produced the breakthrough, ending a decadelong diplomatic impasse and giving the increasingly marginalized United Nations a sorely needed victory. 
 Mr. Annan disclosed, for instance, that all the legal and logistical problems had been resolved by mid-November. He and Mr. Corell had even asked Italy to lend the United Nations a Boeing 707 jet on which United Nations markings were painted.
Mr. Corell had located and interviewed trustworthy pilots, personally approved the flight plan to the Netherlands and recruited doctors and nurses to accompany the two "passengers," as he called them. He had even ordered appropriate food -- no ham, shellfish or alcohol, in light of Muslim dietary prohibitions -- and taken steps to insure that the food would not be poisoned.
Then Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's eccentric leader, balked at the deal that he and the Arab League had originally proposed -- putting the two suspected intelligence agents on trial in a third country.
So Mr. Annan orchestrated a discreet but relentless political campaign to persuade Colonel Qaddafi, including a hitherto secret appeal by Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov of Russia. As part of this appeal, the United States assured Libya that the trial would not be used to undermine the colonel's rule.
Mr. Annan said he had realized early in his tenure as Secretary General that Libya was slowly persuading the Organization of African Unity, the Arab League and other countries that the two Libyan suspects, Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fahima, would never get a fair trial in Britain or the United States.
Chad, Niger and Gambia, among other African states, began flouting the United Nations sanctions by flying their leaders or senior officials into Tripoli airport. And last summer the 53 members of the Organization for African Unity voted to stop abiding by the sanctions.
"I realized that if we didn't find a way forward," Mr. Annan said, the economic sanctions would lose all legitimacy.
At the same time, he said, by rejecting "every Libyan proposal," the United States and Britain "had boxed themselves into a situation of being the stubborn negative ones."
What Mr. Annan called the "first crack" in the impasse occurred last August when first Britain then, more reluctantly, the United States agreed to the Libyan-endorsed Arab League proposal that the two men could stand trial in the Netherlands under Scottish law.
"We ultimately decided," one American official said, "that agreeing to the Libyan proposal of a trial in third country would box Libya in." If Colonel Qaddafi agreed, "the impasse would be over," the official said. "If he did not accept a version of his own proposal, he would be embarrassed and ultimately isolated."
Last October and November, United Nations lawyers led by Mr. Corell and a Libyan legal team led by Kamel Hassan Maghur, a former Foreign Minister, met quietly at the United Nations over several weeks to "clarify" the many thorny questions: Who would be authorized to defend the Libyans in a Scottish court of law in the Netherlands? Would the suspects would be considered "passengers" or "prisoners" on the flight from Libya?
Meanwhile Mr. Corell quietly began preparing for the surrender and transfer. All of the legal issues and arrangements were completed by Nov. 13, Mr. Corell said, but still there was no political decision from Colonel Qaddafi.
"It's one thing to work with the technicians and another to get a political decision," Mr. Annan said. "And we needed a political decision, which is why I went to work."
In early December, Mr. Annan flew to Libya to meet with Colonel Qaddafi. After several hours of one-on-one discussions in the leader's tent outside Sirte, his desert capital, Mr. Annan said, he left convinced that the colonel had realized that a deal "had to be done."
But the Libyan had repeatedly vowed publicly never to turn the suspects over to a foreign court. "So he had to manage his own reality," Mr. Annan said, "and reverse the dynamics he had created."
Taking no chances, Mr. Annan flew from Libya to an Arab summit meeting in the United Arab Emirates, where he enlisted promises of mediation and other support from President Nelson Mandela of South Africa and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia and their emissaries. In the ensuing weeks, he said, he recruited dozens of leaders, including President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Prime Minister Primakov, to urge Colonel Qaddafi to accept the deal.
An American official agreed that Russia, which has opposed American policy on Iraq and Kosovo, had been "very helpful" in resolving the Libyan impasse.
Most of the diplomats interviewed said they began to believe that Colonel Qaddafi would surrender the suspects as promised only after President Mandela announced it on March 19 in a speech at Colonel Qaddafi's side in Tripoli. Even then, Mr. Corell was so secretive that not even Mr. Annan knew exactly when, where and how the Libyans would be moved.
Mr. Corell, a meticulous lawyer with a passion for bird-watching and playing bagpipes, left nothing to chance. An experienced negotiator and appellate court judge in his native Sweden, he and a Russian lawyer on his staff checked off item after item on their list, from jet fuel to devising a seating plan for the flight.
Diplomats said Mr. Corell was obsessed with security, and rightly so, given Libya's insistence on it and warnings the United Nations had received about people who wanted to insure that the two men would never stand trial in the Netherlands.
Today United Nations and American officials called the surrender a vindication of the sanctions that many complained would never work.
"For the first time, we decided to use a multilateral-sanctions approach on a terrorism issue," an American official said. "Now there will be a trial, and justice will be done."

HEADLINE: Let Immigrants Organize for Better Wages

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Immigration Boosts Our Economy" (letters, April 6): 
 The Immigration and Naturalization Service raids in several Yakima Valley warehouses in Washington State where workers were organizing violated the practice of noninterference with union campaigns. The raids occurred as agribusiness was lobbying for new guest worker laws similar to the "bracero" program that created horrifying conditions for Mexican migrant workers from the 1940's to the 60's.
Enacting a new guest worker program that lifts the requirement to recruit locally would depress wages and make it harder for farm workers to organize. Instead, we should enforce the rights of the immigrants already here to organize for better pay and working conditions.
 
NIEVES NEGRETE
Granger, Wash., April 6, 1999
 
The writer is with the Washington Alliance for Immigrant and Refugee Justice.

LENGTH: 128 words

HEADLINE: Let Immigrants Organize for Better Wages

 BODY:

To the Editor:
George J. Borjas (Op-Ed, April 2) urges immigration reform during our relatively prosperous economy. 
 But curiously muted in the discussion of such changes is the low replacement fertility rates among native-born Americans, which has been the case in the United States for 24 consecutive years, and for several decades in most developed countries. Heavy immigration has delayed or diminished some of the negative effects of below-replacement fertility rates.
Responsible demographers consider continued immigration as an imperative in order for developed countries to survive should present native-born birth rates hold.
 
(Rev.) JOSEPH A. FAHY
Atlanta, April 6, 1999
 
The writer is Hispanic apostolate, Archdiocese of Atlanta.

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Worker Can File Suit Charging Age Bias

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
A laid-off worker is free to pursue an age discrimination lawsuit against his former employer even though he signed a document promising not to sue in return for an $8,900 payment, a judge in Bridgeport, Conn., has ruled.
Judge Alvin W. Thompson of United States District Court, in a ruling that became public Monday, said that the worker's written promise to AlliedSignal Corporation was not binding because the company's waiver failed to comply with a 1990 Federal law. 
 The Older Workers Benefit Protection Act requires companies to disclose the ages and job titles of employees retained and laid off when they ask workers to waive their rights to sue in return for severance pay.
When the worker, Fred Suhy, was laid off from AlliedSignal's engine plant in Stratford in December 1994, the company only disclosed the age ranges of workers who lost their jobs. Judge Thompson said that was insufficient. Mr. Suhy was 52 and senior lab technician at the time.
"It's basically a 'Don't play games' decision," said Ellen J. Vargyas, legal counsel with the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
AlliedSignal, which closed the Stratford plant in 1996, had asked Judge Thompson to dismiss Mr. Suhy's lawsuit, saying he waived all of his claims and rights.
But Mr. Suhy's lawyer, Gary Phelan, who is seeking to have the suit declared a class action, argued that the company did not provide enough information for Mr. Suhy to make an informed decision. If Mr. Suhy had not signed a waiver, he would have received a smaller severance package.

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Two Voices From the Past That Echo in Today's Bias

BYLINE: By Walter Goodman 

 BODY:
Among the treats of "Writing New York," the new Library of America anthology edited by Phillip Lopate, are generous excerpts from a pair of remarkable 19th-century diaries that speak to us from a charmed distance in a sometimes uncharmingly immediate way.
Philip Hone (1780-1851) and George Templeton Strong (1820-75) had much in common. As well as being inveterate and invaluable diarists, both were successful businessmen and civic personages. As certified members of the city's self-designated elite they were accustomed to running things until their set, with its Colonial credentials and nativist assumptions, gave way to a flood of immigrant insurgents. 
 As Strong was in the throes of chronicling the decades in four million words, the action was moving uptown from its center around Wall Street. ("How this city marches northward!" he exults.) The diarists' accounts of social, commercial and political doings are larded with New York names: Ogden and Tappan, Schermerhorn and Olmstead, Griswold and Astor, Fish and Field. From such descendants of Olde New York were drawn the masters of the Stock Exchange, who traded tips at the Union Club, the Episcopal elders who worshiped at Trinity Church, the lords of Fifth Avenue mansions, the guest lists for brilliant fetes, the benefactors of the needy and the names of many city landmarks.
But even as they were writing, the patricians were being swamped by families of no wealth or distinction. The young profession of urban demography found its subject as one group of newcomers gave way to others and to still others in an inimitably American saga.
For the 19th-century Establishment, it was an invasion of the unwashed; that at any rate was how the best and the brightest, like Hone and Strong, greeted the Irish who sought succor in America and whose muscle built the city both horizontally and vertically. They were lumped by many Anglo-Saxon Protestants as an ignorant and superstitious mass.
Hone, not a particularly mean-spirited man, saw the early immigrants as an alarming element that was susceptible to rabble-rousing incitement against "the aristocracy," a word the patricians took unironically for themselves despite their revolutionary pretensions.
Even before the devastating potato blight of the 1840's that gave the city a Celtic cast, Hone wrote: "These Irishmen, strangers among us, without a feeling of patriotism or affection in common with American citizens, decide the elections in the city of New York." He warned that "the same brogue" in which political demagogues instructed them to shout "Hurrah for Jackson!" would in time be turned to cries of "Down with the natives!" Everything about the Irish seemed to invite terror or mockery. Strong called the tale of St. Patrick's campaign against snakes "a Popish delusion." He preferred to believe that the snakes perished of biting Irish people.
By the financial crisis of 1857, in Strong's view, the subversive contingent included German socialists, many of whom were out of work and were even more dangerous than the Irish. True Americans, after all, did not gather in alehouses to listen to one another rant their foreign-bred opinions, sometimes in a foreign tongue.
While admiring the charitable efforts of women of his class, Strong had little compassion for the rowdy unemployed: "Certainly the destitute are a thankless set and deserve little sympathy in their complaints." To counter the corruption and violence associated with the underclass, he liked the idea of a vigilante group of well-born respectables who would take the law into their own hands.
Such sentiments have been expressed, though not always so candidly, down the decades. No immigrant group has been spared. Being deemed a threat by self-advertised patriots is a rite of passage in America. And hard times or political commotion, as Strong's compelling account of the ferocious 1863 draft riots attests, brought out truly murderous passions.
The one group for which Strong found sympathy, out of opposition to slavery and perhaps because the New York Irish were among their tormentors, were blacks. Although he is given to racial epithets, he wrote after reports of beatings and lynchings: "They are the most peaceable, sober and inoffensive of our poor, and the outrages they have suffered during this last week are less excusable -- are founded on worse pretext and less provocation -- than the St. Bartholomew's or the Jew-hunting of the Middle Ages." Thus did another widely despised minority, the Jews, benefit at that hour at least from not being Irish.
But of course neither blacks nor Jews, neither Italians nor Latinos have been spared the cruel attentions of those who came before. George Templeton Strong and Philip Hone were far from vicious; by most standards they seem to have been honest dealers. Yet like so many other Americans, they made life miserable for the strangers who arrived among them with their odd and threatening ways.
So "Writing New York" is not altogether a cheering excursion. But reassurance is available in the fate of the once denigrated groups who caused the descendants of the Founders such distress and in turn were distressed by the arrival of even more foreign-seeming folks than themselves. The likes of Ralph Ellison, Isaac Bashevis Singer, Mario Puzo, Mary McCarthy and Al Smith, among the many contributors to these rich pages, evidence the unstoppable American odyssey that has been both the country's dream and its nightmare.

HEADLINE: British Outrage Heads for Brooklyn

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Visitors to the Brooklyn Museum of Art this fall may be in for a shock. Rather than sun-dappled Impressionist landscapes or forthright Rodin bronzes, its classical galleries will be filled with work by young British artists who have made a worldwide reputation creating art that disturbs and outrages. Prominently featured will be Damien Hirst's infamous dead shark floating in a tank of formaldehyde, Marc Quinn's cast of a man's head made of his own frozen blood and Ron Mueck's sculpture of his naked, dead father, reduced to the length of three feet.
These works are part of "Sensation: Young British Artists from the Saatchi Collection," a show that drew record crowds and a hailstorm of praise and criticism when it opened in late 1997 at the staid Royal Academy of Arts in London. 
 The show drew extreme reactions from both viewers and critics. Those who liked it said it captured the excitement and innovative talents of British art today. Those who damned the show felt its content was offensive, intended to shock for shock's sake, or just plain bad. Some pointed out that the show also served to increase the value of Charles Saatchi's collection.
The most extreme reaction was to the artist Marcus Harvey's depiction of Myra Hindley, who was convicted in the macabre "moors murders" of children in western England in the 1960's. Protesters splattered ink and raw eggs on the painting, saying that it trivialized her victims' suffering and glorified her crimes.
After London, the show traveled to the Hamburger Bahnhof in Berlin where it was just as popular.
"This is truly a defining exhibition," said Arnold L. Lehman, director of the Brooklyn Museum. "Rarely can you get enough works to accurately capture the spirit of what's happening at a specific moment in time. Museums, especially New York museums, ought to bring to their audiences the art happening today from all parts of the world."
"Sensation" will be the largest exhibition in the museum's 102-year history, occupying more than 20,000 square feet of gallery space. Among the other artists whose works will be on view are Mona Hatoum, Sarah Lucas, Chris Ofili, Fiona Rae and Rachel Whiteread. All are well known figures in London, and most have been shown internationally, exploring themes like sexual identity, feminism and social criticism.
The collection belongs to Charles Saatchi, the advertising magnate who is London's most important contemporary art collector and one of the earliest and most passionate supporters of these artists, who are often referred to as Y.B.A's (Young British Artists). Most of the 90 works in "Sensation" were bought during the 1990's. They constitute little more than a sampling of his collection of 20th-century art, which totals about 1,500 works. He was among the first collectors to buy these artists' works and to show them publicly; he owns an exhibition space on Boundary Road in London's St. John's Wood. (Some art critics who saw the show in London said they felt it gave too much weight to the taste of one collector.)
"Sensation," which will run from Oct. 2 through Jan. 9, has been in the planning stages for well over a year. The size of some of the works and the complexity of their installation has made it a logistical and economic nightmare for the museum, with financing being the biggest problem, museum officials said. The provocative nature of the work is generally thought to be too daring for corporate sponsors and has made it difficult to raise the $1 million necessary to mount the show.
So far, Mr. Lehman said, a number of individuals have agreed to contribute to the show, as has Christie's, the auction house, which was a supporter of the Royal Academy's show. The museum is still looking for other sponsors but would not say how much had been raised so far.
The show's installation will be unusually tricky, not to mention expensive. In order to comply with New York City health and environmental ordinances, for instance, dead animals have to be hermetically sealed in cases of steel and glass with tubes connected to carbon filters eliminating the smell of decay. "Our conservation department has been in discussions with people who have been involved in installing these objects and are aware of every aspect that must be dealt with," Mr. Lehman said.
Asked if he thinks the show will cause as much of a stir as it did in London, he added, "I think New Yorkers are incredibly sophisticated and believe like I do that they should be exposed to works that are both emotionally engaging and ones that make us think."
The show is likely to bring a kind of audience to the museum that it wants to attract: young, hip people who tend to frequent its neighbor, the Brooklyn Academy of Music. "I think this show is important for people of every age," said Mr. Lehman. "Brooklyn is becoming a center for contemporary art. We have something like 4,000 artists living here. It's terrific for them to see what their colleagues have been doing across the Atlantic."

HEADLINE: Immigrants Wanted

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Immigration, the Issue-in-Waiting" (Op-Ed, April 2): 
 Suppose we wanted the economy to grow at 2.5 percent a year in real terms over the next two to three decades.
If productivity growth were to average 1.5 percent (about what it did over the last 30 years), we would have to increase our labor force by about 1 percent a year.
Estimates from the Census Bureau suggest that over the next 10 years our population growth, including current immigration, should achieve this rate. However, beginning in about 2006 we will start to fall short and the problem will grow from that point on.
Rather than worrying about the welfare costs of our current rate of immigration, we should be concerned about the lost opportunity owing to the worker shortage of the future.
 
MARTIN A. REGALIA
Vice President and Chief Economist
U.S. Chamber of Commerce
Washington, April 6, 1999

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Tea-leaf reader alert: Minutes of the Fed's policy-making sessions include some intriguing phrases.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
THE minutes of the Federal Open Market Committee, the policy-making arm of the Federal Reserve, can be more illuminating than the cryptic utterances of the central bank's chairman, Alan Greenspan.
The release of the minutes from each meeting, though, is delayed until after the next meeting is held, usually about six weeks later. And by then the group's members -- Fed governors and some presidents of the regional reserve banks -- have often conveyed their thoughts to the financial markets in speeches and other ways. 
 Yet the minutes from the November, December and February meetings describe an important shift that has gone largely unnoticed. Changes in just a few words indicate that Fed policy makers have all but discarded hope that the economy will slow down significantly this year.
If the economy does not slow, the Fed will be more likely to raise interest rates later this year. Higher rates are used to reduce the inflationary pressures that generally build in a rapidly expanding economy but that have been nonexistent of late.
Whether an economic slowdown materializes or not, the mere expectation of one has helped persuade the Fed's policy makers to hold off raising short-term interest rates in recent years. With such expectations dashed, they might have to adjust their thinking as well, especially if inflation starts to rise moderately.
"They are beginning to recognize -- this is the process that you are seeing in the minutes -- that their forecast for any type of slowdown this year is not going to happen," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
"If they are changing their mind," he added, "then it becomes a question of when will they raise interest rates, not if they will raise interest rates."
According to the minutes of the November meeting, with the world's financial markets still in turmoil following Russia's effective debt default, the central bank staff that prepares economic forecasts for the policy makers said that the economy would slow "to a pace appreciably below the estimated growth of the economy's potential," which officials have suggested is around 2.5 percent.
That would mean a slowdown from the 6 percent pace of the fourth quarter to a pace much closer to 1 percent.
By December, when American financial markets were rallying again, the hope for such a slowdown was fading. According to that meeting's minutes, the staff was then forecasting that growth in the year ahead would slow "to a pace somewhat below the estimated growth of the economy's potential."
And in February, according to minutes released last week, any suggestion of a significant slowdown seemed to vanish.
The staff now predicted a slowdown "to a rate commensurate with the growth of the economy's potential," or about 2.5 percent growth.
But the policy makers seemed to think the economy might be even stronger than the staff suggested. Committee members, according to the minutes, expected growth to slow "to a pace close to or somewhat above that of the economy's long-term potential." And many members agreed that the biggest risk was that the economy would grow at an even faster pace.
At last week's meeting, Fed policy makers left interest rates alone. And they apparently left their policy indicator on neutral -- which means that in their view the next move on interest rates, whenever that might be, is just as likely to be up as down.
But the rising expectations for economic growth, as reflected in their subtle word changes, may herald a change in attitude.
Stand by. The minutes of the March meeting are scheduled for release the third week of May.

HEADLINE: Autos Pace a Rise in Consumer Borrowing

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 7

 BODY:
Borrowing by consumers grew at a faster-than-expected pace in February as the auto industry posted record sales.
Borrowing through credit cards, auto loans and other personal loans rose by $8.7 billion, to $1.323 trillion, after rising a revised $15.3 billion during January -- the largest increase in more than three years, the Federal Reserve said today. 
 "Growth in all major categories slowed in February, though the rise in auto loans remained quite rapid," the Fed said in the report.
Analysts had expected an increase of $6.4 billion for February. Previously, the Fed said January borrowing increased $14.7 billion.
Auto loans rose $5.2 billion in February after increasing $7.1 billion in January. Auto sales in February rose 13 percent, to a record annual rate of 17 million.
Revolving loans, which include credit cards, increased $2.3 billion in February after rising $6.2 billion in January.
The pace of consumer credit was rising at a 7.9 percent annual rate during February. That's down from the 14.1 percent pace of borrowing in January. In January, consumer credit increased a revised $15.3 billion, previously reported as an increase of $14.7 billion, according to the Federal Reserve's statistics.
Economists watch the Fed's credit report to help them gauge consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic output.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
French Union Urges Appeal Of Trade Case

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 7

 BODY:
The powerful French farmers' union urged the European Union today to appeal a ruling by the World Trade Organization in a dispute with the United States over banana imports.
"Europe must not stand down," the union said in a statement. "It must appeal against this unfair decision to avoid economic sanctions whose only motivation is political and is mostly aimed at dividing Europeans." 
A World Trade Organization panel ruled on Tuesday that the European Union's system for importing and marketing bananas broke global trading rules and would have to be changed. The system favors imports of bananas from former European colonies over nations in Latin America where Chiquita Brands and other American companies are major growers.
Sir Leon Brittan, the European Trade Commissioner, said the European Union reserved the right to appeal the ruling. Peter Scher, who directs agricultural negotiations for the Office of the United States Trade Representative, said the ruling was final and could not be appealed.
The ruling, effective retroactively from March 3, clears the way for the United States to impose 100 percent tariffs on nearly $191 million worth of imports from the European Union. The United States originally sought $520 million.
The United States had said that new European Union rules, which took effect in January, did not comply with earlier World Trade Organization decisions against banana import regulations.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
With Economies Soft, European Bank Considers Rate Cut

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 7

 BODY:
Hans-Joachim Becker thought he had endured the worst, until a few months ago.
As a managing director at Barmag A.G., a manufacturer of textile machinery near Dusseldorf, Mr. Becker pushed his company through a brutal restructuring that eliminated 2,000 out of 5,000 jobs in 1995. 
 It seemed to work brilliantly. Sales bounced back to a nearly record level of 1.1 billion marks last year and profit soared 49 percent, to 75 million marks.
But now his market has collapsed because of financial crises in Asia and Latin America. Orders for new machines have plunged 44 percent, and Mr. Becker predicts that sales this year will drop to 630 million marks, currently $347 million, from 1.1 billion marks, or $606 million. Two hundred people were laid off last month and another 200 may have to go before the year is over.
"There is absolutely no investment in this business," Mr. Becker said today. "We have millions if not hundreds of millions of consumers who are not able to afford a new shirt."
Though Barmag's case is extreme, it is not unique and goes to the heart of the challenge that confronts the European Central Bank when it decides on Thursday whether or not to lower interest rates.
Many analysts believe that the new central bank, which has until recently dismissed a need for rate cuts, has become sufficiently alarmed about Europe's economic growth prospects and is about to reverse course. The same is true for the Bank of England, which has already cut interest rates several times in the last few months.
A lot is at stake. As guardian of a new single currency, the European Central Bank is worried about establishing its credibility with financial markets. It must also reckon with contradictory trends: growth is stagnant in Germany but still strong in Spain, Portugal and Ireland; business confidence is low in many countries, but consumers are more optimistic than they have been in years.
The bigger question is whether a moderate cut in interest rates will make all that much of an improvement. Europe's biggest problems stem from the decline in exports to Asia, Russia and Latin America, where many countries are still in deep recession, and those problems have very little to do with European interest rates. "We already have an expansionary monetary policy," said Petra Koehler, a senior economist at Dresdner Bank here. "Monetary policy is not what is burdening the economy."
Indeed, interest rates in the 11 euro zone countries have been at 3 percent since the individual central banks, acting in coordinated fashion, lowered rates from 3.3 percent last December. Though the Europeans have cut rates less than the Federal Reserve in the United States, the benchmark short-term rate is still well below the American Federal funds rate of 4.75 percent.
Economists widely expect the Bank of England to cut its benchmark rate by one-quarter of a percentage point, to 5.25 percent. Those who think that the European Central Bank will reduce rates do not expect more than a quarter-point cut, which would put the rate at 2.75 percent.
Germany's economic troubles have been aggravated because exports of machinery and equipment were its major source of growth. Like Barmag, which makes machines that produce and weave synthetic fibers, scores of German engineering companies put themselves through wrenching cost-reduction programs earlier this decade.
Between 1991 and 1997, German engineering companies cut their combined work forces by more than one-third, to 925,000 from 1.49 million. But they also became shrewder about marketing and design, and persuaded unions to be more flexible about overtime or weekend work.
Those strategies bore fruit over the last two years. Aided by a decline in the value of the German mark, which made products cheaper in other markets, German exports enjoyed double-digit growth until Asian financial crises deepened early in 1998.
The problems have now sunk into many of Germany's and Europe's biggest industries. The German chemical industry, led by companies like BASF and Hoechst, saw exports decline by 9.5 percent in the last quarter of 1998 and are only limping along, with selling prices under intense downward pressure.
For people like Mr. Becker, there is little the European Central Bank can do to help. "With overcapacity so high and prices so low, there is nothing you can really do to stimulate the market," he said. "The market will come back only when the buying power of consumers, mainly in Asia, comes back."
Economists note that manufacturing is only once facet of German business and that Germany does not represent all of Europe. Consumer confidence, even in Germany, is generally higher than it has been in a long time. Although retail sales remain flat, people are warming up to the use of credit cards, spending money on travel and entertainment.
While most economists predict that Germany will grow less than 2 percent this year, down from 2.8 percent in 1998, Spain is growing by 3.4 percent, Portugal 4 percent, and even France is expected to grow by at least 2 percent.
Those differences would make the European Central Bank's decision tricky enough. But the bank is also concerned about insuring the credibility of the euro, which has dropped nearly 8 percent in value against the dollar since it was introduced on Jan. 4.
Bank executives have repeatedly said that they are not concerned about the exchange rate, viewing it merely as a result of underlying economic trends. But they are worried about being perceived as too relaxed on monetary policy or too vulnerable to political pressure.
The political pressures on the bank have in fact eased since Germany's left-wing Finance Minister, Oskar Lafontaine, resigned last month. In recent weeks, bank officials have dropped numerous hints that they are more receptive to a rate reduction. They have emphasized concerns about slowing economic growth and said they see no signs of resurgent inflation.
Economists are about evenly divided between those who expect a rate cut on Thursday and those who do not. But investors have been betting on a reduction -- if not on Thursday, then at the next meeting on April 22 -- and they have expressed that view by pushing down the value of the euro, which settled in New York today at 1.0772 to the dollar, down from 1.0848 on Tuesday.
"It is not a clear decision, and there are several arguments against it," said Stephan Bergheim, an economist at Merrill Lynch, who is nonetheless betting on a rate reduction.
A cut, he noted, would provide a bit of insurance against a deeper economic slowdown. But it could also lower the euro's value further and rekindle price pressures -- particularly with recent oil price increases.
What a rate cut would not do, he said, is rescue German industry from its current doldrums.
"The main reason for the slowdown is export-related," he said, "and there is not much that the E.C.B. can do about that."

HEADLINE: In America;
The Other America

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

 BODY:
During the daylight hours the interior of Nellie Perez's home is nearly as dark as night. She lives with her disabled husband and five others in a dangerously rickety shack in Guadalupe, a tiny poverty-racked town tucked in the midst of one of the most affluent areas in America.
Guadalupe is part of Maricopa County, one of the fastest-growing counties in the country. Its neighbors, which include Phoenix, Tempe, Paradise Valley and Scottsdale, are feasting on the nation's unprecedented economic boom. Million-dollar homes and splendidly manicured golf courses abound. Some of the malls are glittering jewels. 
 But as Andrew Cuomo, the U.S. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, said during a visit on Tuesday, Guadalupe is different. It was not invited to the economic feast. "That wealth," said Mr. Cuomo, "is not their wealth."
When night falls, Guadalupe, populated mostly by Yaqui Indians and Mexican-Americans, goes to bed hungry.
Mrs. Perez's home was built from scraps -- old doors, tarpaper, chicken wire, rotted wooden planks. It is like something from the third world in the 19th century, not the United States on the verge of the 21st. There is no bathroom, no running water, no electricity and no heat. The air is so close it is difficult to breathe. When I asked where the bathroom was, Mrs. Perez, an affable woman in her 50's, pointed across the street to a reeking outhouse.
Mr. Cuomo stopped by the Perez dwelling during his daylong tour. Mrs. Perez led him through the four dark and cluttered rooms. There was no floor, only planks, or the bare ground. "I'm sorry it's a little bit dirty," Mrs. Perez said.
Mr. Cuomo has been trying to spread the word that even with the economy booming, and the Dow hurdling the 10,000 barrier, and millionaires being created at an astonishing rate, there are still many Americans struggling with the equivalent of an economic Depression.
"Real people are suffering," said Mr. Cuomo. "And now is the time to do something about that. Now is the time to invest in the things we know how to do that would make their lives better, that would bring housing and jobs to their communities -- now, when the economy is strong and we have the largest surplus in history. If not now, when?"
Guadalupe is not an aberration. There are many pockets of extreme poverty across the country. Mr. Cuomo mentioned the Indian reservations, citing specifically the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota, home of the Oglala Sioux. He spoke of the continuing poverty among African-Americans in the inner cities, and among whites in parts of Appalachia and other rural areas. He spoke of the struggles faced by poor Hispanic families in Arizona and in Texas, especially those near the Mexican border.
"The Dow at 10,000 almost makes the irony crueler," Mr. Cuomo said. "This phenomenon of terrific economic growth and yet so many people just left out. There is no reason why in 1999 Americans should be living in shacks, literally. This should be a nightmare from the past."
Mr. Cuomo said his department was attempting to bring affordable housing and economic opportunity to struggling Americans, but the need is immense and he acknowledged that the resources available from HUD were not nearly enough. He said he was trying to bring more public attention to the plight of the poor.
"This is not something you hear much about," he said. "By definition the people affected are voiceless, because they are poor. They are not on television. They are not in the newspapers. For most Americans a place like Guadalupe does not exist."
Mr. Cuomo seems to speak with more passion now than he did a few years ago, and he seems more comfortable as he travels the country, meeting with the powerful and listening to the powerless. His message is one that has not been particularly popular for many years now -- that the country as a whole has an obligation to do what it can to assist those who are in danger of being left behind economically.
Before saying goodbye to Mrs. Perez on Tuesday, Mr. Cuomo asked if she had ever heard of the Dow Jones.
"The Dow Jones?" she said. "What does that mean?"

HEADLINE: Sol Hoffman, 67, Labor Leader In Garment Industry in Northeast

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
Sol Hoffman, a longtime labor leader in the Northeast, died on March 27 at a friend's home in Jersey City after suffering a heart attack. He was 67.
Mr. Hoffman, who lived in Teaneck, N.J., was a vice president of Unite, the Union of Needle Trades, Industrial and Textile Employees, and a director of Unite's Pennsylvania, Ohio and South Jersey joint board. 
 He was born in Brooklyn on Jan. 8, 1932. After receiving a bachelor's degree in economics from Brooklyn College and a master's in economics from the University of Michigan, he began his union career in 1954 at the International Ladies Garment Workers Union Training Institute. He spent the rest of his career with the I.L.G.W.U., which later became part of Unite.
He held various positions with the union, organizing and representing workers in Pennsylvania, Ohio, New Jersey, Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia. He was elected a vice president of the I.L.G.W.U. in 1974.
He was a participant in the civil rights movement in the 1950's and the protests against the Vietnam War in the 1960's.
"He was very much against the war," said Mr. Hoffman's wife, Catherine Lewis. "He was one of the leading organizers in Harrisburg."
Mr. Hoffman was also chairman of the trade union council of the Jewish Labor Committee, a trustee of William Paterson College in Wayne, N.J., and chairman of the college's board of trustees in the early 1980's. He received an honorary doctorate of human letters from the university in 1995.
Dennis L. Santillo, director of external relations at what is now William Paterson University, said Mr. Hoffman served 15 years on the board, "longer than any trustee in the history of the university."
Besides his wife, Mr. Hoffman is survived by two daughters, Florice, of Pasadena, Calif., and Simone, of Roswell, Ga., and two stepdaughters.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene: Limits of Economic Diplomacy;
Modest Goals in Push to Bring China Into Trade Group

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
Trade officials from the United States and China are scrounging for a deal that would allow President Clinton and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji to announce today that the two countries have come to agreement on China's application to join the World Trade Organization. If the issue were narrowly about trade and economics, the two sides would probably have little trouble shaking hands.
China, one of the world's major trading powers, wants membership in the organization that sets and adjudicates the rules. The Clinton Administration thinks that is just fine -- as long as China agrees to open its borders widely to imports and foreign investors. There is plenty of economic room for a deal. 
 But Mr. Clinton and Mr. Zhu are hemmed in by politics. The President must look over his shoulders at the Republicans who want no accord at all and the Democrats who want the deal to satisfy every one of their constituencies. Mr. Zhu faces domestic problems from those within the Communist Party who are not enthusiastic about market reforms and from managers and workers in protected sectors who risk losing their jobs. The problem is that neither side appears to know exactly where the other side's bottom line lies.
What is known is that China wants to insure that its critical textile and apparel industries are not discriminated against as global quotas are relaxed. At the same time, it is looking for enough time to conform to international trading rules so that its authoritarian leaders can minimize internal disruption and resistance. The United States wants to quickly knock down dozens of barriers that keep American goods, services and investors out of China's potentially vast markets. But beyond the generalities are layers of confusing and contradictory forces.
Take the argument by some Republicans leaders, from Gary Bauer, a Presidential hopeful, to Senator Jesse Helms of North Carolina, that China should not be awarded entrance into the world's trading community in the wake of human rights violations, accusations of nuclear espionage, illegal campaign contributions to President Clinton and burgeoning trade surpluses. But to many economists, this argument makes little sense.
"The big winner is the United States -- or at least American corporations. The United States has few carrots to offer the Chinese to sign a deal," says Nicholas Lardy of the Brookings Institution in Washington. "The economic benefits of W.T.O. membership for China are relatively meager."
Mr. Lardy's point is that American markets are already essentially open to China. So are every other country's. China gains little by entering the World Trade Organization. But many of China's markets are closed. High tariffs, bans on agricultural imports, rules that shut out foreign firms and restrict foreign investors, loose enforcement of copyright protections and regulations that prevent foreign companies from selling goods directly to Chinese customers combine to keep American exports low. Last year, China ran a huge trade surplus with the United States of nearly $60 billion, only slightly behind Japan's.
Though bilateral trade deficits are economically benign, economists say, they are politically incendiary. One way for Mr. Clinton to chip away at the trade deficit with China is to make China friendlier to American exports.
It is important to keep the economic argument in perspective. Extra trade with China will not do much for the average American. Even trade worth more than $85 billion a year between the United States and China is simply too small -- little more than 1 percent -- to make much of a dent in an $8 trillion American economy one way or the other. But Mr. Clinton's chief trade official, Charlene Barshefsky, has spent years negotiating on behalf of excluded insurance, pharmaceutical, farm and telecommunications interests. Hard bargaining could do wonders for specific companies, even certain sectors, but not for the economy as a whole.
The other payoff for the United States is political. The trade organization, whose fair-trade rules disproportionately help American exporters, will suffer without the cooperation of China, already one of the largest trading countries. The United States would be better off if China were inside the World Trade Organization tent rather than disrupting it from the outside.
For the United States, the main drawback would be that it could no longer easily impose unilateral sanctions for China's sins. In most instances, the United States would be obligated to first bring its complaint before an international judicial panel. But that is not much of a burden: those panels have provided effective relief so far in every case where Washington has brought valid complaints.
Some Democrats will oppose China's formal entry into the global trading regime for the same protectionist reasons they opposed a free-trade agreement with Mexico. Yet the argument that trade with low-wage countries hurts American workers was weak when applied to Mexico -- the United States' second-largest export market after Canada -- and weaker still when applied to a distant, less pervasive trade partner. The data show, Mr. Lardy says, that imports from China come largely at the expense of other Asian exporters.
China's benefits from membership are more distant. The Chinese are among the world's lowest-cost producers of textiles. But their exports are limited by quotas imposed by the United States and many other countries. These quotas will, by international agreement, be phased out within the next few years under rules that will be set by the World Trade Organization. China knows it can best protect its interest if is part of the organization that will draw up the rules.
Beyond that, the big payoff of membership may well be to consolidate China's move to the market and thereby cement Mr. Zhu's position within the Chinese political establishment. Prof. Barry Naughton of the University of California at San Diego says that it is "absolutely clear that Mr. Zhu is driving toward markets." As proof, he cites Mr. Zhu's willingness to see one of seven workers in state-owned factories thrown off his job to close worthless state-owned enterprises. Moreover, nearly all goods in China are now traded in markets free of price controls.
No one knows what economic model Mr. Zhu has in mind. It might include a heavy government hand, as in South Korea. It might include large government-run sectors in transportation and health. "Yet Mr. Zhu's overall direction is clear," Professor Naughton said. " An international accord that locks China into market-opening reforms may make it easier for Mr. Zhu to fend off attempts to slide back into government planning."
Though economists are mostly enthusiastic about China's entry into the World Trade Organization, they flag possible pitfalls. "There is danger in demanding too much from China," said Dwight Perkins, a professor at Harvard. "A country with half of its population in agriculture cannot be expected to open up its food markets entirely. A banking system loaded down with bad loans to state-owned factories may not survive vigorous competition from foreign banks."
Professor Perkins is convinced that China's membership in the trade group makes sense for both sides. But he wants the deal to give Chinese banks and agriculture time to adjust. That means, he says, phasing in market reforms over five or more years, though there ought to be strict deadlines for every market-opening measure, so that China cannot dither.
Greg Mastel of the Economic Strategy Institute, while agreeing that Beijing should be joining the trade group, worries that the China lacks the discipline of markets or legally enforced rules. He points to Chinese violations of the trade accord it struck with the Bush Administration. China, he says, did not live up to promises to open up government contracts to foreigners or abandon import licenses and other trade restrictions.
"If China does not obey the rules once it is inside the tent," Mr. Mastel warns, "the credibility of the tent is at risk."
Mr. Mastel thinks that World Trade Organization panels might be largely ineffective in monitoring economic practices in China's closed society because they lack the power to compel the presentation of documents. He wants the deal to include a safeguard provision that would allow the United States to withdraw unilaterally if it deems China out of compliance. Mr. Lardy of Brookings calls for a more limited safeguard that would allow the United States to slap tariffs on its imports from China if they soar.
The idea of safeguards is to take the risk out of the political calculations on Capitol Hill that stand in the way of Chinese entry into the trade group. And that would be a small price to pay, Mr. Mastel says, to help "make the world's largest nonmarket economy into a market economy -- the most important economic task on the global agenda."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Issues Gain, With Yields Falling to 3-Week Lows

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, and yields fell to three-week lows as traders took heart from statements by two Federal Reserve officials that inflation is at bay.
Gary Stern, president of the Federal Reserve bank in Minneapolis, said he did not "see any signs of accelerating inflation." 
 Robert Parry, president of the San Francisco Fed, said the 40 percent increase in crude oil prices this year would not lift consumer prices.
In the absence of inflation, "Treasuries offer good value," said Zane Brown, who oversees $12 billion of bonds at Lord, Abbett & Company in New York. He said he expected 30-year bond yields to fall about one-half percentage point by the end of the year to 5 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 8/32, to 96 7/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.50 percent from 5.52 percent Tuesday.
Treasuries also got a lift yesterday after the Fed bought notes in two outright purchases, or "coupon passes," intended to add money permanently to the economy. At the same time the Treasury and other borrowers sold more than $10.5 billion of new debt.
Even with recent gains, bonds are within the narrow range where they have been trading in recent months.
"It doesn't look like we can burst out of this trading range," said William Sullivan, money market economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Federal Home Loan Bank System and the International Paper Company are among other borrowers that raised more than $3.5 billion.
Fannie Mae, Cargill Inc., Lyondell Chemical Company and others preparing sales of up to $15.5 billion.
Investors are eager to buy corporates and other securities yielding more than Treasuries because the economy is strong and inflation is tame.
With that backdrop, investors are less inclined to worry about bond defaults or credit rating cuts and are more willing to tolerate risk in exchange for higher yields.
