HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
European Interest Rate Cut Sends U.S. Gauges to Records

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Europeans cut interest rates yesterday, igniting stock markets in midsession here, and all three major market gauges climbed more than 1 percent to new records.
Financial stocks were again among the pacesetters, but they were joined by such recently lagging blue chips as Coca-Cola and Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which have suffered from sluggish European operations. Another standout was Wal-Mart Stores, which jumped 4 3/4, to 102 1/4, one of several retailers reporting very strong March sales. 
 "The strength of the market seems to be coming from the bond side," said Philip J. Orlando, the chief investment officer at Value Line Asset Management.
Lower interest rates not only tend to make stocks relatively more appealing but also reduce such business costs as carrying inventory or investing in new machinery.
Although there was little reaction to an early rate cut by the Bank of England, a larger-than-expected cut by the European Central Bank shortly after noon galvanized investors and lifted prices sharply.
By the close, the Dow Jones industrial average had gained 112.39 points, to 10,197.70, just over 11 percent higher than at the beginning of the year. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 17.09 points, to 1,343.98, and the technology-driven Nasdaq market rebounded from Wednesday's slump to gain 28.96 points, to 2,573.39.
Bond prices advanced along a broad front, with the bellwether 30-year Treasury issue rising 2 6/32 point, to 97 5/32, to push its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, down to a six-week low of 5.44 percent, from 5.50 percent on Wednesday. Rates on 5-year and 10-year Treasury securities -- the latter a benchmark for home mortgages -- eased even more.
With inflation in this country remarkably benign in the ninth year of an uninterrupted economic expansion, United States Treasury securities offer some of the best rates of return among global bond markets.
Initially in yesterday's session, rates were little changed as investors looked largely in vain for signs of cooling economic growth. Another factor was Fannie Mae, which was tapping the market for $3 billion. Dealers who had sold Treasuries as a hedge suddenly were forced to scramble for cover as the market rallied on the larger-than-expected half-point cuts by the European Central Bank. Fannie Mae's 10-year notes were sold at a price to yield 5.716 percent, or about 59 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
"The rate cuts caught those who had set short positions leaning the wrong way," said Daniel Antonellis, market analyst at Briefing.com, an analytical firm in Menlo Park, Calif. But he added that they "gave the market much needed direction, particularly with the Federal Reserve on hold."
Besides the financial sector, which included gains of 3 1/2, to 87 7/8, for Chase Manhattan and 3 11/16, to 52 1/4, for Republic New York, hefty gains were widespread among drug and oil companies. Lilly, Abbott and Pfizer all rose about 3 points, while Chevron jumped to a record before closing at 93 3/4, up 3 13/16 points for the day. Oil prices have rebounded smartly in recent weeks.
The Dow's biggest gainer was Union Carbide, which surged 5 1/2, to 51 3/8, on revived speculation that the chemical company may be acquired. General Electric eased 5/8, to 113 7/8, after an earnings report that matched, but did not surpass, profit expectations. Brokerage stocks rose again but generally less than on Wednesday. An exception was a 10-point gain, to 84, for Knight/Trimark Group, a market-maker in Nasdaq and other securities; it traded as low as 4 1/2 six months ago.
But the latest advance did little to remedy what Alan Ackerman, market strategist at Fahnestock, called a bifurcated market in which household names keep going up, while most others are ignored.
"The big-cap stocks are in a bull market, while the small-cap stocks appear to be in a bear market," he said. The S.& P. is now up more than 9 percent so far this year while the Russell 2000, composed of smaller companies, is down more than 5 percent. The Russell rose 53/100 of 1 percent yesterday, less than half the 1.29 percent gain for the S.& P.
On the New York Stock Exchange volume expanded to 850.6 million shares from 816.4 Wednesday.

HEADLINE: Mrs. Whitman Looks to the Senate

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey is planning to run for the Senate in 2000. Her announcement that she is setting up a fund-raising committee is as positive a declaration of candidacy as is seemly from a sitting Governor who must convince voters she intends to stay focused on the state's business for the next year and a half.
The idea of adding a Republican woman of Mrs. Whitman's stature to the Senate will excite many people, and to the rest of the nation she probably seems an odds-on favorite. She defeated the incumbent, Jim Florio, in 1993 and presided over a growing New Jersey economy. Like her neighbor, George Pataki of New York, she has identified herself with two popular issues -- tax cuts and environmental protection. Right now the leading Democratic candidate is Mr. Florio, who left office identified with tax hikes, a concept that elicits something less than universal enthusiasm. 
 But Mrs. Whitman's entry does not mean she is an automatic winner. New Jersey has not elected a Republican senator since 1972, and the state seems to have trended Democratic in recent years. Mrs. Whitman herself has never gotten more than 49 percent in any state election, including her surprisingly weak showing against State Senator James McGreevey in the last gubernatorial race.
A contest between Mrs. Whitman, one of a large crop of successful Republican governors, and Mr. Florio, who had to run the state in far less prosperous times, would make for interesting debates. But some Democratic leaders, still smarting from the fact that Mr. Florio's tax plan cost their party control of the state legislature, are hunting for another candidate. Others worry that a primary would leave any Democratic nominee in a weakened condition to run against Mrs. Whitman, but that is not necessarily true. The winner of a primary often simply comes out looking like a winner.
The real problem on everyone's mind is, as usual, campaign funds. A tough Senate race is expected to cost more than $10 million. Mrs. Whitman's fund-raising drive is going to be led by Lewis Eisenberg, who has already been rewarded for past money-raising efforts on her behalf with the post of chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The Port Authority is a troubled organization, and Mr. Eisenberg might do better to hand over his job to someone else who does not have to worry about the state of Mrs. Whitman's war chest. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: John Hartwell, 83, Retired Head Of Financial Management Concern

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
John M. Hartwell, an investment counselor and mutual fund manager, died April 2 in New York City, his wife, Sheila, said. He was 83.
Until his retirement in 1996, Mr. Hartwell was the president of his own firm, J. M. Hartwell & Company, which managed private accounts and university endowment funds. 
 Admired for his candor, geniality and acumen, Mr. Hartwell was widely quoted in business publications. "He was one of the early pioneers in identifying the inherent value in growth stocks and growth industries," said Alexander Lazer, a principal with J. M. Hartwell & Company. "Using his research methods, several of his former partners went on to start well-known money management firms."
Born in Everett, Mass., Mr. Hartwell graduated from Harvard College in 1936 and from the Harvard Business School two years later. He taught economics and accounting at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and at Rutgers University before joining the Navy as an officer in World War II. He was awarded the Purple Heart for wounds received during the invasion of the Marshall Islands.
Before founding his own company, Mr. Hartwell worked as an economist for Mutual of New York and an economic analyst for the Ford Motor Company. He was also the treasurer of the Piedmont Life Insurance Company and special assistant to the chairman of the finance committee of the Vick Chemical Company.
In addition to his wife, the former Sheila Walker, of Manhattan, Mr. Hartwell is survived by three children, Robert, of Dorset, Vt., John 3d, of Greenwich, Conn., and Kathryn Hartwell of Manhattan; a brother, Richard, of Bellevue, Wash.; a sister, Tina Hartwell of Loma Linda, Calif.; two stepchildren, Jonathan Walker and Jason Walker, both of Manhattan, and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Iraq Rejects Panels' Efforts to End Impasse on Security Council

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 8

 BODY:
Iraq has angrily rejected the recommendations of three special panels that have tried to find a solution to the diplomatic impasse over Iraq on the Security Council.
Western diplomats said Iraq's blistering response made it clear that Baghdad would not accept any further arms inspections unless economic sanctions imposed after its defeat in the 1991 Persian Gulf war were lifted. 
 "The net result of the recommendations is disappointing" because they "fall short of the goal, which should have been putting an end to the prolonged regime of sanctions," Iraq wrote in response to three reports issued last week by Celso Amorim, Brazil's representative to the United Nations, who was the chairman of all three panels.
The panels' conclusions not only provide "the enemies of Iraq with the pretext for future aggression," Baghdad said; they would infringe Iraq's territorial sovereignty and dignity.
"Such a position," the statement declared, "will never be accepted by the Government of Iraq."
The three inquiries were set up in January to seek compromises that would permit arms inspections to resume, improve the health and welfare of Iraqis and resolve the fate of more than 600 people who disappeared after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
Western diplomats said Iraq's defiant rejection of the findings puts Russia, China and France, the permanent members who have argued most forcefully for an end to the sanctions, in a politically difficult position. "Iraq's most vocal advocates now have a big problem," said a senior American official. "Iraq clearly doesn't want to cooperate, and we intend to make that noncompliance and noncooperation the major issue."
For that reason, Western diplomats said, Richard Butler, the executive chairman of the special commission charged with disarming Iraq, decided once again not to provoke a fight within the Council by trying to attend Security Council deliberations on Friday on the future of his agency.
Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia's representative, vowed today to bar Mr. Butler from the Council's discussions on Friday, as he did on Wednesday. Mr. Butler agreed on Wednesday to send in his place his American deputy, Charles Duelfer, after Mr. Lavrov warned that unless Mr. Butler were barred, he would not enter the room.
According to associates and friends, Mr. Butler decided that provoking a fight over his presence would only distract the Council from the real issue: Iraq's unwillingness to disarm and to comply with the Council's resolutions.
The United States and Britain have argued that Council resolutions require Iraq to disarm itself of unconventional weapons and meet its other commitments before sanctions are lifted. Russia and China have argued, by contrast, that sanctions are no longer warranted because most questions surrounding Iraq's past weapons programs have been answered.
Mr. Amorim tried to strike a balance, arguing that a reinforced long-term monitoring system could both answer questions about Iraq's past programs and monitor future ones. While recommending that steps be taken to get more food and medicine to Iraq, he did not urge that sanctions be lifted.
Iraq also repeated reports that the United States has used inspection missions and the monitors' field office in Bahrain to spy on President Saddam Hussein and select targets for American air strikes.
Clearly unnerved by such allegations, Bahrain, another Security Council member, has asked Secretary General Kofi Annan for public assurances that the monitors are not using their base there to spy or for any purposes other than disarming Iraq.
"We want to be assured publicly, as we have been in private, that things have been done according to the United Nation's resolutions," said Jassim M. Buallay, Bahrain's representative. "We don't want our facilities to be used for anything else."
In another development today, American officials and diplomats confirmed that the United States had asked Mr. Annan to help set up meetings with Libya to clarify what Tripoli must do to persuade the Council to lift sanctions imposed in 1992 and 1993.
This week Libya surrendered two men charged with downing Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, enabling Washington to abandon its longstanding prohibition on direct contacts with Tripoli, officials said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Europeans Cut Key Rate More Than Foreseen

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, April 8

 BODY:
Confronted with an economic slowdown over much of the Continent, the European Central Bank surprised almost everyone today by reducing interest rates to one of the lowest levels European nations have ever seen.
The cut in the central bank's benchmark rate, to 2.5 percent from 3 percent until now, came hours after a smaller cut by the Bank of England. It reflected growing alarm that economies are stalling and need a boost from lowering the cost of borrowing. 
 There had been some expectations that rates would be lowered today. But the European Central Bank's cut was twice as deep as had been anticipated. The announcement -- which came after European financial markets had closed but with nearly four hours of trading remaining on Wall Street -- ignited a broad rally in American stocks, and major market indexes all closed at record highs. Page C6.
The European rate reduction also seemed aimed at quieting complaints by officials of European Governments, many of whom have pressed the bank for months to stimulate economic growth as a way to reduce joblessness averaging more than 10 percent across the Continent.
Yet the central bankers, even as they reduced borrowing costs to such low levels, warned again that in their view the only real solution to high unemployment was through lightening European nations' costly regulation and social welfare programs.
"Monetary policy is not the cause of structural unemployment, nor is it the solution," said Wim Duisenberg, the president of the European Central Bank. "Now it will become demonstrably clear that monetary policy is not the solution to those problems."
Today's move marks the first major policy decision by the new central bank, which assumed its powers with the introduction of a single currency, the euro, on Jan. 4.
It came after months of pressure from political leaders, particularly in Germany and France, for lower rates. Until recently, bank officials had only stiffened their resistance at each new call for cheaper money.
But a stream of bleak economic data made it increasingly clear that growth has slowed much more sharply than in the United States. At the same time, inflation has all but evaporated and many experts have begun to worry about a deflationary spiral in prices.
"Inflation is not a danger," Mr. Duisenberg said, and this "enabled us to pay more attention to the second objective of the European Central Bank, which is to support the economy."
He added that the bank -- which is governed by a board that includes the central bank presidents of all 11 countries in the euro zone -- decided to act more boldly than expected in order to put an end to second-guessing about future rate cuts.
"We were afraid that only a smaller move would have led to expectations in the future of more small moves," Mr. Duisenberg said. "Now you can be sure: this is it."
The Bank of England's decision to reduce its key short-term rate to 5.25 percent from 5.50 percent was done independently of the European central bankers and was the latest in a series of reductions over the last half year. There is some expectation that the Bank of England might cut rates further.
Thomas Mayer, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs in Frankfurt, said that Mr. Duisenberg clearly intended to put new pressure on European political leaders to push ahead with legislation promoting economic growth. "They threw the ball back into the politicians' court," he said. "From now on, they won't be able to put the blame on monetary policy."
At least initially, the decision seemed to have no real impact on the euro. The euro has fallen more or less steadily against the dollar, from $1.17 at the time of its introduction to $1.0740 in New York today.
Though an interest-rate reduction can lower the value of a currency, traders had already anticipated a cut of some sort. Indeed, in a display of buying on the rumor and selling on the news, the euro climbed slightly before the central bank made its announcement and then eased back again later.
European political leaders quickly expressed pleasure at the decision.
"This signal can only boost confidence among economic actors and international partners in the European Union's ability to return to strong growth," said a statement released in Brussels tonight by the union's caretaker executive body, the European Commission.
In France, a spokesman for Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn praised the rate cut as "part of a rebalanced European policy mix more supportive of growth and employment."
Mr. Duisenberg insisted that the bank had not capitulated to political pressure or changed its basic approach, which places top priority on price stability.
"I want to deny that in any way we switched our monetary policy," he said. With inflation stable at less than 1 percent a year, he said, the bank now had the leeway to stimulate the economy by lowering rates.
Mr. Duisenberg also said he was not concerned by the euro's slide against the dollar. Indeed, he said, based on the value of a "synthetic euro" -- a hypothetical currency made up of the 11 national currencies in the months before the euro's introduction -- its value is about the same as it was a year ago.
But most economists were skeptical that today's rate cut would do much to strengthen growth, because the problems derive more from structural issues within Europe, such as high taxes and rigid regulations, and from declining exports to Asia, Russia and Latin America.
"Growth here was not weak because of high rates," Mr. Mayer of Goldman, Sachs said.

HEADLINE: Denver's Hispanic Residents Point to Ills of the Uninsured

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Erica Aguilar, a Mexican-American born in Denver, is 21 years old and has three children, ages 4, 2 and 8 months. The children have Medicaid, and for them she uses the city's La Casa Family Health Center.
But Ms. Aguilar herself has no health insurance. She works 26 hours a week as a sales clerk at Montgomery Ward for $6.50 an hour, and as a part timer, she is ineligible for insurance even if she could pay her share of the premium. Yet she earns too much to get Medicaid. 
 So for herself and sometimes her children, Ms. Aguilar uses home remedies. "I go by what my grandmother tells me," she said. She douses her eyes with sugar and water to cure eye irritations. To cure colic, she rubs the baby's stomach with warm oils.
Ms. Aguilar's story is emblematic of a striking disparity in the nation's health care. For reasons that are largely economic, but also cultural, 34 percent of the nation's 31 million Hispanic people have no health insurance, compared with 22 percent of blacks and 12 percent of non-Hispanic whites. Over all, 43 million people in the nation lack insurance, up from 31 million a decade ago.
While Hispanic people appear to be gaining in economic and political strength, they disproportionately lack insurance coverage and ready access to professional care. That is particularly true for the three-quarters who are from Mexico and Central America. Cuban-Americans tend to be older and wealthier and to have insurance.
The social costs of the uninsured come with the dangers of untreated contagious diseases and an eventual reliance on emergency room care, according to the Centers For Disease Control and Prevention.
Denver has a vast Hispanic population, making up a quarter of the city's half-million residents compared with 11 percent nationwide.
Hispanic residents here are mostly young and mostly from Mexico and Central America, and as in many cities their lack of professional health care sustains a thriving system of alternative care built on religion, tradition and home remedies. Often it works. But just as often, it delays and impedes crucial care.
Health system officials and community leaders here say the menial jobs for relatively young and uneducated Hispanic workers make health insurance unlikely for them. But the disparity in coverage is worsened, the officials say, by cultural and bureaucratic barriers and a political climate that has darkened for immigrants, both legal and illegal.
"They tend to be poor," said Ann Zuvekas of the George Washington University Center for Health Policy Research in Washington and author of several studies of minority health. "They tend to work for small employers, in low-wage jobs, cleaning buildings and gardening, in car washes."
Ms. Zuvekas added: "There are cultural differences and language barriers. And a number are immigrants. Public policy has been to make sure that many immigrants don't get insurance."
Under the welfare overhaul of three years ago, for example, legal immigrants must wait five years to apply for Medicaid, the health insurance program for the poor.
Little has been done to treat the gap in the Hispanic population's coverage, beyond a $48 billion, 10-year program enacted two years ago to expand Government insurance to allpoor children.
"We are being lobbied to improve our children's care," said Richard C. Allen, director of Colorado's Medicaid program. "But regarding Hispanics? No."
Some who do qualify for programs like Medicaid still will not enroll because they do not like being counted.
"They're frightened," said Dr. Richard Wright, chief executive of Community Health Services of Denver Health, the city's health care system, which was once public and is now independent. "They think, 'If I enroll, that will work against me as an immigrant."'
For most uninsured Hispanic people the disparity in coverage arises from a decline in jobs that offer benefits. Only half of all Hispanic people are covered through employment, compared with two-thirds of African-Americans and three-quarters of white workers.
When employers do offer insurance, usually asking workers to share the cost, Hispanic workers are the most likely to refuse, because they feel they cannot afford it.
While economic reasons dominate, issues of culture also emerge.
"People rely on faith a lot," said Luz Collins, who was born in Mexico and is the administrator of the Westside Family Health Center, one of 11 Denver Health clinics. "They wheel and deal with God. You call it home medicine. It's our actual medicine. A lot of it's hidden because we realize it's not accepted by the majority."
Some home medicine tends to be harmless, like the ceremony performed for the 2-year-old granddaughter of Irene Chavez. Recently, in the waiting room at La Casa, Ms. Chavez lovingly displayed a framed photograph of the toddler with her deep, happy dimples and wavy black hair.
"She's a beautiful granddaughter," Ms. Chavez says, "so beautiful that people just can't believe she's real."
Whether in spite, envy or admiration, she said, someone gazed too long at her granddaughter and marked her with the evil eye, or mal de ojo. A day or two later the child fell ill, with vomiting, diarrhea and a high fever. Doctors said she had a virus. "They said, 'Stop being paranoid,' " Ms. Chavez said. ' "There's nothing wrong with her.' "
Unconvinced, the family called in Louise, their 77-year-old neighborhood curandera, or healer. Chanting prayers, the woman rubbed an unbroken egg over the child, tracing signs of the cross. Then she broke the egg, put it in a cup, placed a cross made of twigs in the yolk, and put the cup under the child's bed. By morning the child was well. The egg, Ms. Chavez said, had exorcised the curse.
But when such efforts fail and patients belatedly show up at doctors' offices, says Dr. Alicia Vazquez, the primary care physician at La Casa, they have been drinking cocktails of exotic herbs or using cheap, under-the-counter prescription medicines that bodegas smuggle in from Mexico.
"A 32-year-old female comes in with a five-day history of sore throat, runny nose and a cough and reports that she's been taking an antibiotic from Mexico because that's all she could get," Dr. Vazquez says.
Dr. Vazquez takes a culture of the patient's mouth to see if she has strep throat. It proves negative. "But is that because she does not have strep throat, or is she partially treated?" she said. Not knowing which, she said, leaves the doctor with the choice of treating a condition the patient may not have or waiting to see if the conditions worsens.
Even the act of going to a clinic is novel to some. "In Mexico, there are so many things around for curing yourself that you don't go to the doctor," said Juvenica Acevedo Flores, a hearty widow who is 4 feet 4 inches tall and 87 years old.
She has Medicare but rarely used it until a few years ago when she was found to have diabetes. Now her daughter takes her to the Westside clinic for checkups. "It's necessary," Ms. Acevedo said with a shrug.
Lucille Brodsky, a clinic manager whose grandmother was a curandera, said the whole notion of insurance could be foreign. "The culture isn't one to ask for help outside the family," she said. "Then when something really bad happens, you turn to the family for money" to pay for professional care.
Language is also a barrier, both in efforts to get patients to enroll in health care programs and in communicating with them once they sign up.
At Denver Health's Community Health Services, which oversees the clinics and serves a predominantly poor and Hispanic clientele, 83 percent of the 80 physicians are non-Hispanic whites. So are all eight senior social workers and 84 percent of the 97 registered and advanced-practice nurses.
As a result, said Ms. Collins of the Westside clinic, "a Hispanic is given heart medicine and it's not well-explained."
"They end up taking it when they have a chest pain," she said, "not every day."
Barbara Sanchez-Martin, director of the Center for Community and Behavioral Health at the Denver branch of the Latin American Research and Service Agency, says the problem is one of "cultural competence," not just language.
At the private, largely church-funded Tepeyac Clinic, husbands sometimes stop their wives from having pap smears. "If the doctor's a man," said Jim Garcia, chairman of the clinic's board, "the husband says no. The idea of another man touching his wife is beyond comprehension."
"So we try to relieve that," said Susan M. Gallo, a psychologist and the clinic's executive director, "by having a female attendant in the examining room -- a chaperone."
Barriers like these help drive Hispanic people into the unofficial health care safety net. One strand is the neighborhood curandera, and another the bodegas and specialized stores that dispense herbs, teas, incense, charms, sprays and oils, some with proven medicinal value and often prescribed by curanderas.
Dr. Rick Padilla, a family physician at Westside, estimates that 100 to 200 curanderas serve Denver, nearly all working from their homes and known only by word of mouth. In a random survey of 405 adult Hispanic patients, he found that 29 percent had sought a curandera's intervention at least once in their lives.
Some charge nothing, Dr. Padilla said. Others accept a meal, or a donation ranging from $5 to $100. "They're not very well regulated," he said, "and there's a lot of potential for abuse." But when he feels that Hispanic patients' fears and suspicions obstruct their care, he refers them to a trustworthy curandera.
"Many Latin people think their diseases are related to someone having put a hex on them," said Toni Palma, a counselor to the elderly at Westside. A woman might say she has been cursed and made sick by another who wants her husband.
On the face of it, the disparities in insurance coverage do not translate into conclusive evidence of a sicker population. Nationwide, the average Hispanic resident is a first-generation immigrant and 26 years old, or 10 years younger than the rest of the population, and less likely to have contracted the diseases that develop later in life.
Still, among the three largest population groups -- non-Hispanic white, black and Hispanic -- statistics from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention show that they have the highest rates of such diseases as mumps, tetanus, whooping cough and German measles. They have lower levels of H.I.V. infection, diabetes and tuberculosis than blacks but about twice the levels of whites.
Twenty-eight percent of Hispanic children are uninsured, the journal Health Affairs reports, compared with 18 percent of black children and 12 percent of white children.
Once Hispanic immigrants have lived in the United States for a decade or two, physicians here say, their diets begin to shift from beans, grains, fruit and vegetables to fast and processed foods.
 So once they are settled, said Robin Weinick, social scientist at the Federal Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, "Hispanics tend to be in poorer health." And, she said, "They have the poorest access to care of any population we measure."
Dr. Wright of Denver Health said: "We've got to learn. We've got to talk to people in the community. We've got to have a dialogue so our system and their beliefs can be more in sync."

HEADLINE: 9 Men Plead Guilty to Slaughtering Cormorants to Protect Sport Fishing

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Nine men from sport-fishing communities along the eastern shore of Lake Ontario pleaded guilty yesterday to charges stemming from the shotgun slayings of more than 1,000 federally protected birds last summer, prosecutors said.
The shootings, which killed hundreds of double-crested cormorants -- both adults and nestlings -- and left dozens of nestlings to starve to death, are considered by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to be one of the largest mass killings ever of a species protected by Federal laws. 
 A 10th man pleaded guilty to being an accessory to the crime by hiding shotguns used to kill the birds. The plea agreements, negotiated over the last few weeks, were entered in Federal District Court in Syracuse, said Thomas J. Maroney, the United States Attorney for the Northern District of New York.
The five men who pleaded guilty to the most serious charges agreed to serve six months of home confinement, monitored with electronic ankle bracelets. They each agreed to pay a $2,500 fine and to contribute $5,000 to the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, a private group, which will use the money to restore wetlands around Lake Ontario.
But several of the men, who are professional fishing guides, have said all along that they believed they were justified in shooting the fish-eating birds to save their livelihood. And they feel vindicated, they say, by the state's recent decision to cull the cormorant flock to protect sport fish.
James R. McGraw, a defense lawyer in the case, said the state plans proved that the killing of the birds was appropriate. "They've done nothing other than what the State of New York is going to do itself," he said. Several of the defendants were reached by telephone, but declined to be interviewed until their final sentences are handed down in August.
The cormorants are not endangered, but are protected by the 81-year-old Migratory Bird Treaty Act, which prohibits hundreds of species that migrate across international borders from being killed or harassed.
Their numbers have risen sharply in recent decades, and the birds, which can each gulp several pounds of fish a day, are considered pests by anglers in the Great Lakes and catfish farmers in their winter range along the Gulf Coast.
Before the shootings last year, several of the defendants in the case had publicly threatened to cull a fast-growing colony of the birds on Little Galloo Island, which is about five miles from Henderson, a lakeside town where dozens of charter boats dock and 8 of the 10 defendants live.
Many people in the community blamed the cormorants for a recent sharp decline in stocks of smallmouth bass, a popular game fish. The economy of Henderson, which is largely built on bass fishing by tourists, has seen a simultaneous downturn, as anglers seeking a sure catch have headed elsewhere.
A study released in December by New York environmental scientists confirmed a link between the growth in the cormorant colony and falling fish stocks.
But prosecutors and Federal and state wildlife officials said yesterday that there was no excuse for the outburst of violence against the birds.
"Vigilantism, and especially this kind of cruel killing by individuals, has no place in resolving a complex population issue," said Craig A. Benedict, an assistant United States attorney who helped prosecute the case.
The pleas filed in court described the systematic nature of the shootings: On July 27, the five men facing the most serious punishments, David McCrea, Ronald Ditch, Mitchell Franz, Louis Cook and John Kabot, took Mr. McCrea's boat to the island, where they split into groups and began shooting birds from the boat and the shore.
Mr. Ditch and Mr. McCrea are guides whose families have made a living from sport fishing for several generations. Mr. Cook owns a marina.
After the July 27 shooting, according to the plea agreements, the men handed their shotguns to Rex Allen, who was in another boat and who did not shoot any birds. Several of the guns were later hidden by another man, Angelo Aversa.
The mass shooting was discovered when state biologists visited the island two days later as part of a continuing study of the birds' diet. They found dozens of fledglings starving to death, sitting among piles of carcasses.
In the same plea agreement, Mr. Aversa and Mr. Ditch's three sons -- Andrew, David and Thomas -- admitted to shooting cormorants in separate incidents last year along with the other five men. They have agreed to serve three months of home confinement and pay smaller fines. Mr. Allen, who never shot at the birds, will pay a fine and be placed on probation.
Mr. McGraw, a lawyer for Mr. Ditch and his sons, said they stood by their actions, but were willing to accept punishment.
"When they got involved, they knew there was going to be a consequence," Mr. McGraw said. "They weighed the good and the bad and decided it was appropriate to do. When the bureaucracy sits back and lets a community die and an industry die, I don't think that's vigilantism."
The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation is planning to go ahead with its own culling of the Little Galloo Island colony, under a permit that is expected to be issued by Federal wildlife officials in the next few weeks.
State biologists plan to trap and kill 300 adult birds and dip the cormorants' eggs in mineral oil and return them to nests. This practice suffocates the embryos, but the parent birds continue to roost and thus are not prompted to breed a second time. The goal is to reduce the colony from 6,000 nesting pairs to about 1,500 in five years, according to the state proposal.
The men are to be sentenced Aug. 11 by Magistrate Judge Gary L. Sharpe, and will not be confined to their homes until September. They are not prohibited from fishing on the lake this summer, said Mr. Benedict, the assistant United States attorney.

HEADLINE: U.S.-CHINA TALKS FAIL TO PRODUCE MAJOR TRADE DEAL

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 8

 BODY:
President Clinton and China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, fell short today of reaching a major trade deal that China has long sought, even though the two leaders said they made significant progress in negotiations to usher China into the organization that sets the rules for global commerce.
Although the announcement by Mr. Clinton that "we are not quite there yet" came well short of the hopes both leaders had harbored for China's entrance into the World Trade Organization, it had the virtue of giving Mr. Clinton and Mr. Zhu more time to prepare their constituencies at home for an agreement that faces fierce opposition in both capitals. 
 At a 90-minute news conference today, the blunt-talking Chinese Prime Minister blamed what he termed an "anti-Chinese" mood in Washington, saying, "If you want to hear some honest words, then I should say that now the problem does not lie with this big difference, or big gap" in negotiating positions, "but lies with the political atmosphere." If it were not for that, he said, China and the United States would be ready to sign "a full-package agreement."
Business executives and China experts expressed surprise at the scope of some of Beijing's concessions -- some of which may have as much political resonance as economic impact. For the first time, for example, China agreed to permit American telecommunications companies to control Chinese cellular telephone firms and Internet companies, and operate throughout the vast country of 1.2 billion people. How China would square that with its efforts to quash political opposition and limit Internet access was unclear.
Among the issues left outstanding, though, were some that directly affect two of President Clinton's most high-profile constituencies: Wall Street and Hollywood. China has refused to let American brokerages into its free-for-all stock markets, and it wants to restrict the number of American movies that can be released in its theaters, arguing that it must limit what one Chinese official recently called "cultural pollution."
The days of furious negotiations were overshadowed this afternoon, however, as Mr. Zhu used the news conference to take on China's critics with a vehemence and a directness that no Chinese leader has ever shown on American soil.
He invoked Abraham Lincoln's use of force to keep the Union together as an example China should keep in mind as it deals with Taiwan, which Beijing considers a breakaway province -- a comparison Mr. Clinton stepped in to reject. He derided reports that China stole nuclear weapons secrets, and mocked assertions that China sought to influence the 1996 Presidential election.
"I have $146 billion of foreign exchange reserves," said the man who has overseen China's profound economic transition in recent years, "so I should have put out at least $10 billion for that purpose."
"Why just $300,000?" he said, referring to the amount of campaign contributions investigators say originated from Chinese military intelligence. "That would be too foolish!" he said, as the audience laughed and Mr. Clinton cracked a smile.
And even in human rights, the perpetual area of dispute, Mr. Zhu first attacked the American decision to win an international condemnation of its political crackdown, and then tried disarming his critics by partially agreeing with them.
"I am more impatient than you are" to change China's human rights environment, he said, suggesting that his country was still struggling under the hangover of thousands of years of a feudal system.
Today's meetings came amid a clear effort by Mr. Clinton to embrace Mr. Zhu as the kind of Chinese reformer he can deal with -- an embrace similar to the one Washington extended a decade ago to the Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Although he is a clear No. 2 to President Jiang Zemin, who came here a year ago, the 70-year-old Mr. Zhu received most of the trappings of a state visit.
On Washington's first cloudless and warm spring day, the economic reformer who talks openly about dismantling Mao's system of state-owned industries was given a 19-gun salute, full military honors and a welcome from President Clinton that included thanks for China's willingness 200 years ago to give "our newly independent nation equal standing with the powers of Europe." He was clearly suggesting that the United States, by guiding China into the trade organization, intended to return the favor.
Tonight, Mr. Clinton was host at a glittering official dinner and invited business executives and academics with ties to China, for a performance by Yo-Yo Ma, the world's premier cellist.
Mr. Zhu seemed relieved by the welcome. Asked today why he came to the United States at this difficult moment in the two countries' relations, he said: "Are you asking me to tell you the truth? To tell you the truth, I was really reluctant to come," adding that he had asked a delegation of American Congressmen and Senators in Beijing last week, "Will my 'new face' be turned into a bloody face?"
But he came to Washington as Congress was out of session, meaning that he did not have to confront China's critics on the Democratic left and the Republican right, who appear to be joining forces in opposing China's entry to the world trade group. In fact, Mr. Clinton's aides acknowledged today that any trade deal with China would become enmeshed in the debates about nuclear spying, stepped-up political repression and a soaring trade deficit.
"Getting this through the Hill is going to be a killer," a senior Administration official said today.
Before the news conference, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Zhu met in two separate sessions that, participants said, were far more sober and businesslike than their public performance later in the day. They discussed -- and disagreed on -- Kosovo this morning in a small session attended by the national security adviser Samuel R. Berger, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, the Cabinet member who has most frequently encountered the Chinese Prime Minister. Chinese leaders fear that the precedent of international intervention over a rebellious province could easily be applied to Taiwan.
At a larger meeting with other aides present, Mr. Zhu repeated his vow not to devalue the Chinese currency, the yuan. Mr. Rubin and others fear that a devaluation could re-ignite the Asian financial crisis. They argued briefly over Mr. Clinton's plans to develop a missile defense system in Asia, one ostensibly intended to protect American troops from North Korean missiles, but a system the Chinese believe could ultimately be used to defend Taiwan against Chinese missiles.
At one point, veering into a discussion of Tibet, Mr. Zhu and Mr. Clinton discussed the possibility of using the Vatican as a conduit for discussions between Chinese leaders and the Dalai Lama, the exiled religious leader of the Himalayan territory. In public, the Dalai Lama is denounced as a religious fraud by Chinese diplomats; the private conversation about opening a secret channel to him, which White House officials refused to confirm tonight, was calm and businesslike, according to several people familiar with it.
In an interview this evening, the main American negotiator on the trade issues, United States Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, described China's willingness to open its markets in agriculture, telecommunications, banking, insurance and other areas as "very sweeping." She suggested that final agreement was near -- but that negotiators had simply run out of time.
"I do not believe that any of the remaining issues are show-stoppers," she said. "I would expect fairly rapid resolution" that would pave the way for China to join the trade organization by the time it holds a ministerial meeting in Seattle in November. In fact, executives of several companies said they were surprised by the last-minute concessions that China made, some of which are bound to open Mr. Zhu up to criticism that he is leaving Chinese enterprises too vulnerable too soon to foreign competition.
The telecommunications agreement -- allowing foreign control of cell phone networks, Internet providers and other "value-added services" -- came as a surprise. But while the business opportunities for the likes of Motorola Corporation or AT&T -- along with their Japanese and European competitors -- are obvious, such accords usually run into myriad obstacles on the ground. And over the years, the Chinese have shown that they understand that Internet connections and a vast cell phone network are a price of joining the global economy -- even if they dilute Beijing's ability to control dissent and outside information.
Other aspects of the accord hint at a broadening of economic freedom. China agreed to allow 100 percent foreign ownership of commercial banks within five years -- almost all are now joint ventures between Chinese and foreign partners -- and they will be permitted for the first time to handle individual Chinese accounts. That creates the possibility that a worker in Xian would be able to deposit his savings at Citibank -- even if he would still face restrictions on moving his money abroad.
"These are things that five years ago the Chinese wouldn't even talk about," Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said this morning, as Mr. Zhu and President Clinton reviewed the military guard on the South Lawn.
But the Chinese were unwilling to let foreign brokerages compete for Chinese customers. They argue that an uncontrolled flow of foreign capital worsened the Asian crisis, and they have no desire to repeat the experience. But Administration officials said they believed China's reluctance had more to do with protectionism, noting that they could keep in place strict rules on capital flows in and out of the country.

HEADLINE: British Airways Will Close Base in Queens

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
British Airways, one of the largest employers in Queens, plans to shut its American headquarters at the former Bulova watch building near La Guardia Airport -- a move that union officials fear will result in the loss of hundreds of jobs.
Airline officials said yesterday that they planned to close their offices at the Bulova Corporate Center in Jackson Heights when the company's lease runs out in 2002 and shut down their telephone sales operations, which employ more than 600 people. About 200 other corporate employees in Queens will be moved to a smaller headquarters at a location that has not yet been chosen. A British Airways spokesman would not say whether the new headquarters would be in the New York area. 
 The airline has been an anchor tenant at the sprawling 23-acre Bulova property since it was converted to an office complex from a watch factory 12 years ago.
"The company has made the decision to close the facility in three years," said John W. Lampl, a spokesman for British Airways. "But we have guaranteed jobs and no loss in pay to everyone who will be affected."
Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, whose district includes the Bulova center, said that he learned of the airline's plans a few days ago. "For British Airways to be so cavalier about its relationship with New York is rather striking to me," he said.
Mr. Vallone said he informed Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of the airline's plans yesterday. "The Mayor didn't know anything about it," he said. "We're naturally very concerned about this and we're going to try to convene a meeting with the airline to talk some sense into them and get them to stay in the city."
Randy L. Levine, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, said that he spoke with company officials yesterday, who assured him that after union contract negotiations were completed and a planned terminal expansion at Kennedy was finished next year, "they expect that in the future, there will be a net increase of British Airways jobs in New York."
Mr. Lampl said that although the airline planned to turn its telephone sales operations over to outside sources, it would offer its displaced workers other customer service jobs at four airports in the United States: Kennedy International Airport and airports in Seattle, San Francisco and Charlotte, N.C.
Union officials said, however, that many of the workers had been with the company and had lived in the area for a long time and that relocation would be difficult at best for them. They also said they believed the company's plan to hire an outside company to handle telephone sales was an attempt to break the union.
"If you're working 25 years there, you can't pick up your family and just go," said Joseph Adinolfi, general chairman of District 142 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, which represents British Airways workers in New York and Houston. "We don't believe that can happen."
The airline's plans to phase out its telephone sales operation have been a major point of contention in recent contract negotiations with the union, which represents the airline's telephone sales representatives, airport customer service agents and airport mechanics. In addition to the changes in New York, the airline plans to close its telephone sales division in Houston in 2001, where 160 people are employed.
Union leaders said they believed that the airline planned to shift its telephone sales network to a nonunion call center in Florida and possibly to a site in India, where the airline has a major reservations center. Mr. Lampl said that the airline had not yet chosen a vendor to handle its telephone reservations but that the move to an outside vendor was intended to help save the company money.
"We have a corporate business efficiency program that requires us to save one billion British pounds a year," he said, or roughly $1.5 billion. Among other changes throughout the corporation, he said, its United States operations "decided to outsource telephone sales to lower costs."
Contract negotiations stalled earlier this year and the National Mediation Board, the Washington agency that moderates labor disputes in the airline industry, mandated a 30-day "cooling-off period" that runs out on April 17. Union officials have said that if negotiations are not successful next week, the workers might go on strike, but they said there also are indications that the airline might lock out its employees.
"We're hopeful that we will be able to reach an agreement," Mr. Lampl said. "But if there is an industrial action, we have contingency plans, and service will not be disrupted." He said that the company had already trained replacement workers.
Wendy Szerencses, who has worked in reservations for British Airways for the last 14 years, was one of 200 employees who protested against the airline's plans in front of the British Consulate in Manhattan yesterday.
"I planned to retire from this company," she said. "It was a great airline until the last few years when they began angering employees by asking for cutbacks despite huge profits." She said that she and her husband had just bought a house in Queens and that they were uncertain what they would do if she were forced to relocate.
British Airways last year recorded $14.49 billion in revenues and $77 million in profits, according to Mr. Lampl. The telephone sales representatives are paid an average of $12 an hour.
Local officials from the City Council, the State Assembly and Congress said they would introduce resolutions denouncing the British Airways plan to close its Queens headquarters.
"This would be a very significant loss for the city because we're talking about a large number of good-paying jobs that are going to be difficult to replace," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, a Democrat from Woodside, Queens.

HEADLINE: A New Strain On the Cost Of Health Care;
Latest Medical Devices Bring Bigger Bills

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Managed health care plans and the Medicare program have had some success slowing growth in spending for doctors, hospitals and home care agencies. But managed care has been much less successful reining in spending on new life-enhancing medical devices and procedures.
Advances in technology -- from laser treatments to the latest surgical procedures with miniature instruments -- are one of the main reasons for the reacceleration in the overall costs of health insurance, after several years of slow or zero growth. Sales of new medical devices in the United States rose 30 percent over the last five years, outpacing the 22 percent rise over all in health care spending and all other categories except prescription drug sales, which were up 50 percent. 
 "About half the growth in real per-capita health costs is associated with medical technology" including advances in procedures and drugs, said Mark Freeland, deputy director of the National Health Statistics Group in the Health Care Financing Administration.
Increased medical costs were cited yesterday by Humana Inc., a managed care company with 6.2 million members, as it announced that its first-quarter earnings would fall below Wall Street's expectations.
Paradoxically, many of the new procedures are promoted as reducing costs: a $3 million laser device that provides an alternative to brain surgery can pay for itself by reducing the costs that surgical procedures and lengthy hospital recoveries would have previously required. But health plans are finding that over all, technology costs are surging, in large part because the new procedures are more available or more attractive to more people -- fostering a demand that insurers cannot stem.
Patients who are hesitant about traditional open surgery, for example, will eagerly agree to minimally invasive procedures with miniature instruments to repair heart valves or remove defective gallbladders.
The pattern was clear at Health Partners, a big, nonprofit Minnesota health maintenance organization. In only two years, from 1996 to 1998, the H.M.O. counted double-digit growth in the number of procedures for every thousand members in eight categories, including some of the most expensive: brain and nervous system procedures, heart and artery surgery, orthopedics like hip and knee replacements and organ transplants. Premature infants were another big-ticket item.
At Children's Hospital in Minneapolis, where many patients are tiny premature babies, "there has been a technological explosion and a tremendous increase in survival rates and the good news is, we did not have an increase in extremely damaged children," Dr. Ronald Hoekstra said. But with the advances, he added, costs are bound to go up.
One of Dr. Hoekstra's patients, Simon Hagman, a strapping 30-pounder who celebrated his third birthday late last month, has already made a personal contribution to the economics of high-technology health care. Health Partners, his family's plan, spent $1.2 million on lifesaving care for Simon, whose birth only 22.5 weeks after conception was dangerously premature.
Simon, born weighing 1 pound, 4 ounces and only 12 inches in height, lived for 14 months in the neonatal unit at Children's Hospital. With the help of sophisticated procedures and technology, he overcame three heart attacks, several bouts of pneumonia and a threat of blindness. He went home, with 24-hour nursing, still dependent for a time on an oxygen system that augmented his miniature lung power.
"Miraculously, Simon survived without brain damage," said his mother, Tracey Hagman.
A dozen years ago, there would have been small hope for an infant with Simon's precarious medical profile. For premature babies with severe problems who did qualify for the less-advanced treatments available then, the medical charges were about $250,000.
The new drugs and procedures were welcomed as essential to excellent care. "It's the right thing to do, but it's very expensive," said George Halvorson, chief executive of Health Partners.
"As a result, our premiums are going to go up, and people are going to have to pay more for care," he added. There were 345 cases in 1998 on which Health Partners spent $50,000 or more. That was more than double the number in 1996.
While some experts say the spread of managed care will slow the introduction of advanced devices, that is clearly not the case at many H.M.O.'s.
"It is extraordinarily difficult for H.M.O.'s to put up barriers for care that is valuable," said Michael Chernew, a health economist at the University of Michigan.
Most big managed care plans rely on advice from panels of medical experts to recommend acceptance or rejection of new technology. For example, a Blue Cross advisory panel endorsed a number of new developments last year, but the group determined that a heavily marketed new electron beam CT scanner was not as effective in diagnosing heart disease as the older methods, said Dr. Alan Garber, a professor of medicine at Stanford University who is a member of the panel. Such panels appraise the scientific value of products and procedures; insurers typically weigh the recommendations as well as cost-effectiveness in deciding whether to approve the innovations.
Not all the advanced devices are big and complicated. Among the most popular are stents, the tiny metal tubes that prop open clogged blood vessels. In part because of new competition that cut the price, sales of stents exploded last year to $1.4 billion, up 40 percent from 1997, said Vivian R. Wohl, a health care securities analyst with Merrill Lynch. Sales of implantable defibrillators, which shock faltering hearts, rose 20 percent, to $1.2 billion.
Other new products are in demand: a robot-assisted gamma knife to attack tumors deep in the brain, lasers to improve vision by sculpturing corneas, ultrasensitive blood oxygenators to keep premature infants alive and inch-long metal spinal implants to relieve back pain.
And there is much more to come. Medical devices still being tested include one to position a functioning heart in what is called beating heart surgery; minimally invasive devices to thwart blood clots and prevent strokes, advanced insulin pumps that continuously adjust to changes in a diabetic's blood sugar; devices that use microwaves, lasers or ultrasound to treat enlarged male prostate glands.
"We are going to see a flood of these things," Dr. Garber said. "Most of these new technologies do contribute something to improve health, but the cost pressures are enormous."
Health care costs, to be sure, are rising for a number of reasons, including an aging population. While the cost pressures of many factors can be estimated with reasonable accuracy, technology is a moving target, with some prices falling and the number of sophisticated procedures rising.
"Some of the biggest impacts are not clear until years after a procedure is introduced, as it gets better and physicians find more uses for it," said Paul B. Ginsburg, president of the nonprofit Center for Studying Health System Change in Washington.
And a new procedure can often be used by a larger pool of patients than before, raising overall costs.
"When you get better at doing a procedure, through experience, you are willing to do it on older people and frailer people, as happened with coronary bypass grafts," said Joseph Newhouse, a health economist at Harvard.
Bypasses were also improved in ways that made them more expensive. "The product in 1999 is not what it was in 1990," Dr. Garber said. Defying expectations, the number of open heart bypass surgeries kept on growing, even after a wildly popular alternative, the angioplasty balloon-and-stent procedure to repair arteries, took off, he said.
"Looking far out, there are some possibilities that new kinds of technologies might be so powerful as to reduce the cost of health care," said Stuart Altman, a Brandeis University professor who is chairman of the Council on the Economic Impact of Health System Changes, a nonprofit group supported by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation. "But for the next 5 to 10 years, if not longer, the general consensus is that technology will continue to increase health care spending."
Even today, however, studies have shown that some of the latest drugs and devices can save money. Last month, scientists at the New York University Medical Center said that patients who required surgery for defective heart valves spent four fewer days in the hospital after a minimally invasive procedure, compared with traditional open chest surgery.
And in brain surgery, 45 American hospitals and surgery centers have purchased $3 million gamma knife systems, which use radiation instead of a risky cutting procedure to zap tumors.
One patient, Joseph Keenan, had put off surgery for years on a tumor that was interfering with his hearing and balance. Dr. Keenan, 55, a professor of family medicine at the University of Minnesota, finally had the procedure done about a year ago with a gamma knife.
He checked into the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., at 5 A.M., had the procedure and was sent home by 10 the same morning. Two days later, he flew to China for a long-scheduled lecture tour and a round of golf.
"It was great," Dr. Keenan said.
At Health Partners, new devices are screened by expert committees in each area, said Dr. George Isham, chief health officer of the Minnesota H.M.O. The gamma knife reviewers, for example, included a brain cancer specialist from Mayo, a radiation oncologist and a brain surgeon from the University of Minnesota, a brain surgeon from the Park Nicollet Clinic, a big Twin Cities medical group, and a neurologist from Health Partners' own medical group.
After reviewing scientific reports, the experts concluded that the knife was effective. The H.M.O. then decided to pay for the procedures, Dr. Isham said.
At the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, which pioneered gamma knife surgery in the United States, Dr. L. Dade Lunsford said that studies had shown an "enormous return on the initial technological investment."
Dr. Lunsford, who is chairman of neurosurgery, said the gamma knife was increasingly used to destroy hearing-nerve tumors like Dr. Keenan's. Typically not cancerous, they are a problem for 2,000 Americans each year.
Patients return to work in days instead of months, he said. Complications are rare and the need for additional surgery has been eliminated, he said.
"The total cost of traditional surgery was $30,000," he said. The charge for Dr. Keenan at Mayo was $18,000, paid by Health Partners.
As for Simon Hagman, the premature baby, he is "very well nourished and improving with time," Dr. Hoekstra said.
"I don't think you can put a price on a life," Simon's mother said. "It was worth every dollar spent."

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Edge Up as Oil Costs Jump

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
Producer prices rose less than expected last month as the biggest increase in oil prices since the Persian Gulf crisis in 1990-91 was offset by falling prices for computers and a variety of other products.
The Labor Department said today that producer prices, which are paid to factories, farmers and other producers, rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March. Although that was a reversal from February, when prices fell four-tenths of 1 percent, the March increase was below the forecasts of analysts, who had expected a gain of three-tenths of 1 percent. 
 The core rate of price growth, which excludes food and energy costs, was unchanged in March for the second consecutive month. Analysts had expected a rise of one-tenth of 1 percent.
"Those who are looking for inflation are being frustrated by every piece of data we get," said Brian Wesbury, chief economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, a Chicago investment firm. "We expected oil to rise, but the rest of inflation is behaving very, very well."
Crude oil prices rose 27.1 percent in March, the biggest gain since October 1990, when they jumped 29.7 percent, shortly after Iraqi forces occupied oil-rich Kuwait.
Producer energy prices over all rose 1.2 percent in March, led by the largest increase in the cost of home heating oil since February 1994. The increase reflected late-winter storms in some parts of the country. Gasoline prices also increased.
The price of crude oil has risen as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has moved to reduce production.

HEADLINE: Venezuela's New Leader: Democrat or Dictator?

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
To the adoring, impoverished masses who catapulted him to power, Hugo Chavez Frias is El Comandante, their protector and benefactor, the bold leader who will wipe out 40 years of inequality and corruption and redirect this country's enormous oil wealth to better their lives.
To his opponents, the 44-year-old former army paratrooper who is Venezuela's new President represents something unsettling, even dangerous. With his talk of "revolution," his contempt for institutions he calls "worm-eaten and decadent" and his violent coup attempt seven years ago, he strikes many of them as an autocrat in the making. 
 The jury is still out on Mr. Chavez, who took office on Feb. 2 while riding a wave of popular disgust with a political system seen as venal and unresponsive. But whether he turns out to be democrat or dictator, his charisma and his vows to overturn the prevailing order have already transformed politics in this country of 23 million people.
Trying to divine Mr. Chavez's ultimate intentions from a flood of contradictory public pronouncements has become a popular pastime here, leading to the publication of several new books with titles like "Chavez the Wizard of Emotions: Psycho social Analysis of a Political Phenomenon."
But ask Mr. Chavez, and he classifies himself as a post-modernist politician, bound by none of the "Cartesian" limitations of established ideologies.
"If you try to assess me by traditional canons of analysis, you'll never emerge from confusion," he said in an interview in his office at the same presidential palace he attacked in 1992. "If you are attempting to determine whether Chavez is of the left, right or center, if he is a socialist, Communist or capitalist, well, I am none of those, but I have a bit of all of those."
Mr. Chavez's Minister of Finance, Maritza Izaguirre, describes the President, who had never held public office before, as a pragmatist going through "a process of apprenticeship." Dealing with the budget, for instance, he was eager to learn even the most arcane details of state spending, she said.
But the President's critics argue that Venezuela, the largest supplier of crude oil to the United States in recent years, is mired in a crisis so severe that it cannot afford the luxury of giving him on-the-job training. Inflation and unemployment are near all-time highs, oil prices slumped to their lowest level in years just as Mr. Chavez was taking office, and the Venezuelan economy is expected to contract this year for the second year in a row.
To deal with the situation, Mr. Chavez demanded from Congress, and received late in March, the power to rule by decree for the next six months. But the main, and most controversial, plank of his campaign platform was a pledge to convene a constituent assembly to do away with the country's "moribund" Constitution and draw up a new one. A referendum on that proposal is scheduled for April 25.
 On April 8, Mr. Chavez rejected the "enabling law" that Congress had approved, saying it did not go far enough. He threatened to impose a state of national emergency, which would allow him to suspend constitutional guarantees and to rule by decree.
As envisioned by Mr. Chavez and his Fifth Republic Movement, the new Constitution would grant him expanded powers and allow him to run for a second consecutive term, instead of waiting 10 years as currently required. That has led his critics to charge that he plans to make himself a caudillo, or classic Latin American military strongman in the mold of Juan Peron, Fidel Castro or Omar Torrijos, an accusation that Mr. Chavez ridicules.
"If I were going to be a tyrant, I would already have carried out a coup d'etat," he said dismissively. "How am I going to be a caudillo when I am subject to the rules of a system?"
Yet fears that Mr. Chavez plans to ignore the restraints of traditional politics were fanned in mid-March, after he said that he and his supporters would "take to the streets" if the Supreme Court did not allow him to organize the constituent assembly as he wanted. But when the court ruled against him, Mr. Chavez accepted the decision and has tried to make his decree conform to the court ruling.
"The danger is that Chavez could come to believe himself that his relation with the people is like that of a strongman with the masses, like that of Il Duce, Der Fuhrer, El Comandante or the Secretary General of the Party," said Teodoro Petkoff, a former guerrilla leader and a former Minister of Planning. "This kind of primitive conception, which disdains and demonizes political parties or any other intermediary between the population and those in power, could develop from this singular relationship he has created with a good part of the poor population of the country."
Thus far, though, "Chavez has acted as a restraining wall to those around him who have authoritarian impulses, whether they are military men or from the old left," Mr. Petkoff continued. "I think he is finding he has the temperament and a taste for the political game and that he is learning it quickly."
Mr. Chavez's hand has clearly been strengthened by the disrepute that clings to the political parties that have governed Venezuela since the collapse of a military dictatorship in 1958. As ordinary Venezuelans see it, poll after poll has indicated, the country's political elite has either squandered or pocketed billions of dollars of oil revenues that should have been used to make the country and its people rich.
"Chavez's origins are those of the avenger, the instrument the Venezuelan people use to debit the account of the political class that has dominated this country for 40 years," said Alcibiades Castro, leader of the congressional delegation of Copei, the more conservative of the country's two traditional parties. "Notwithstanding the election, not everyone in the parties are fully aware of this, and so our very identities and viability are at stake here."
Traditional politicians may wince at the frankness of some of Mr. Chavez's more colorful or incendiary observations, but most people appear to like what they hear. He was elected with 57 percent of the vote, but recent polls indicate that his support has soared since taking office.
Several gestures intended to demonstrate that the country is in crisis have been particularly well received: Mr. Chavez has refused to accept his $1,200 a month official salary, donating it to a scholarship fund and saying he can live well enough on his military pension, and he has also dispensed with use of a limousine and other traditional perquisites of power.
"Chavez is of the people, with humble origins," said Eduardo Beltran, 29, a security guard at a downtown building. "When have you ever seen a President of this country stop his limousine to get out and talk to the poor? He is a second Bolivar, just the President Venezuela needs."
Indeed, Mr. Chavez's humble start as the child of two schoolteachers is one of his strongest selling points. Eustoquio Duque Castro, a retired military officer, was stationed in Mr. Chavez's hometown, Sabaneta, when the President was a boy, and remembered him selling fruit and ices outside the barracks after school every afternoon before running off to baseball practice.
A left-handed pitcher, Mr. Chavez "could do it all, hit, field, run and pitch, but couldn't afford the equipment he needed," Mr. Duque remembered. As a teen-ager, Mr. Chavez was such a standout that the army recruited him for its team. But an arm injury sidelined him and ended his dreams of a big league career.
"I never thought he could be President, but I voted for him, and I don't regret it," Mr. Duque, 66, said. "I have faith in him. With a young President who wants to work hard, the country is already more animated and disciplined."
After a rocky start caused by his populist declarations and flirtation with Fidel Castro, his relations with Washington also have improved. Mr. Chavez was for many years denied a visa to the United States because of the 1992 coup attempt, but that ban was lifted after his resounding election victory. He has already visited Washington twice.
"We are behind him so long as he remains within constitutional parameters for reforming the country," Peter Romero, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said on a recent visit.
Mr. Chavez said he was acutely aware that all of his words and actions were being dissected here and in the rest of Latin America, where he is seen as an alarming throwback to the age of the strongman. But he said he welcomed the scrutiny, and invited skeptics to "analyze with objectivity the truth of what is taking place here."
"If they want to know where we are going, then let them watch us, with satellites or lenses, from near or from far, and observe our tracks," he said. "We are heading toward the light, toward the open horizon, gradually building a true democracy, and not towards the darkness of the jungle."

LENGTH: 900 words

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Long Mandibles, Sleek Carapace. A Steal at $300.

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 9

 BODY:
Yumiko Tanuma held the 3 1/4-inch-long beetle in her hand, tried not to think of it as an overgrown cockroach and stroked it gently.
"It's kind of cute," she pronounced, smiling tenderly as it waved its pincers. 
 And it should be cute, considering its price. The beetle sells for about $300 at the Tobu Department Store where Miss Tanuma works.
The sad thing for Japan's many beetle owners, though, is that 5 or 10 years ago it might have sold for $6,000 or more. The plunge in beetle prices has been catastrophic, wiping out the value of used bugs that were once worth more than used cars.
Everybody knows about the tumble in value of Japanese real estate and financial assets like stocks. But it is not just office towers and bank shares that have lost value over the last decade. Almost every Japanese investment seems to have dropped in price, from antique porcelain to racehorses -- and especially ohkuwagata, the giant stag beetles that generations of Japanese have hunted and raised as pets.
For many Americans, it may be hard to understand the attraction of buying large black bugs that try to pinch their owners. The typical impulse on seeing an ohkuwagata would be to shriek and run.
"People who don't know bugs might say they look like cockroaches," conceded Katsutoshi Misaki, the insect salesman at Tobu Department Store. "But they have different personalities -- this one is shy, that one is more aggressive and so on."
"When I raise it and hold it in my hand," Mr. Misaki added, "I feel real affection for it."
Japanese have had a passion for insects for more than 1,000 years, collecting crickets and various kinds of beetles and going out at night to spend hours admiring fireflies and collecting them. Foreigners visiting rural areas are sometimes startled to be dragged out through the fields at night for firefly-watching and disquisitions on the merits of various species of fireflies and crickets.
Young Japanese have a special fondness for collecting beetles. The rarest kind are ohkuwagata (Japanese is a far richer language for beetles than English), a variety of stag beetle that hides in rotten logs in remote mountains and is extremely difficult to find. Thus in the "bubble economy" of the 1980's they became a valuable commodity, and department stores began to sell them at prices that until the early 1990's reached $7,000 for a single insect.
One breeder says that six years ago a huge and superb ohkuwagata sold for $30,000.
The collapse of the stock and property markets made people poorer and hurt prices, but market forces were also at work to increase supply and pop Japan's bug bubble. Most important, insect specialists figured out how to breed ohkuwagata.
Supply soared, and prices slumped catastrophically. Many department stores stopped selling insects, and beetles lost some of their cachet. These days almost all ohkuwagata come from breeders, and most specimens sell for less than $100 apiece.
"The increase in supply will continue, because of the breeding," said Kikuo Iwaguchi, an entomologist at Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology. "I think prices will go down, down, down."
In 10 years, he said, small ohkuwagata might sell for less than $5.
Another factor has been the gray market in imported beetles. Ohkuwagata also live elsewhere in Asia, and when Japanese ohkuwagata were selling at outlandish prices, travelers began to smuggle foreign ones in. One advantage of the foreign ohkuwagata is that they stay active year-round, while Japanese ohkuwagata hibernate several months -- a practice that seems a bit self-indulgent for a pet that costs thousands.
Importing foreign beetles is illegal, but selling those that are already in Japan is of uncertain legality. In any case, the imports began to trade hands and depressed the market just as it was collapsing anyway.
"Smugglers would put threads on their ohkuwagata and tie them up, and then put them in with their souvenirs," said Daiichiro Koseki, a breeder. "Or they put them inside their clothes."
One might suspect that Japan is using the ban on beetle imports to protect its own bug market, just as it curtails rice imports to protect its rice industry. The Japanese insect industry denies this.
"It's not protectionism," said Hiroshi Fujita, editor of Gekkan Mushi, which translates roughly as Bugs Monthly. "It's to protect ecology, because the fear is that the foreign beetles would disrupt Japan's environment."
Mr. Fujita also said that the ohkuwagata market was too small for Japanese bureaucrats to worry about. The whole market in Japan for insects and accessories, he said, has annual sales in the tens of millions of dollars, although some estimates run into the billions.
While the bug market is now severely depressed, Tobu Department Store still has one pair of ohkuwagata priced at $12,500. They have white eyes, a rarity, but so far there have been no takers.
While some other kinds of beetles live a year or less, ohkuwagata live for four or five years, so owners have some time to enjoy their pets. And the bugs do not fly much, so an investment is unlikely to disappear out the window. But of course owners have to look where they step.
"You've got to watch them when you take them out for a walk," said Mr. Misaki, the insect salesman, with a nod to his $12,500 beetle duo. "Otherwise, they could run away and disappear."
