HEADLINE: Don't Let Libya Off the Hook

BYLINE: By Paul Hudson; Paul Hudson is a lawyer. He lost his daughter Melina in the Pan Am 103 bombing.

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
Although Libya has finally handed over two suspects charged with planting the bomb that brought down Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland more than a decade ago, the United States should not assume that full justice is being done.
President Clinton, like Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush before him, has said that there can be no safe haven for terrorists -- not even for government officials engaged in state-sponsored terrorism. But some American officials are now arguing that we should be satisfied with prosecuting two low-level operatives in a conspiracy that probably involved other officials in Libya and perhaps even Iran. 
 Now that the United Nations has removed sanctions against Libya because the two suspects have been delivered to the Netherlands for trial, some American companies are lobbying for the removal of United States sanctions -- the very sanctions that helped persuade Libya to turn over the suspects. Moreover, United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan has reportedly pledged that the trial will not be used to "destabilize" Libya. Whether that means that higher-level officials in the Government will not be prosecuted is open to interpretation.
So many concessions have been given to Libya to bring these suspects to justice, I can only wonder what kind of justice it will really be.
International law says that when agents of a government murder citizens of another country, the agents' government is liable for their actions -- even if they abused their authority. Countries are sometimes required to pay compensation to the families of the murdered people, and even reparations to the government of the victims' nation.
The two Libyan suspects in the Pan Am 103 case were chief of security for the Libyan national airline and an employee of the airline in Malta. They are also suspected of being representatives of the Libyan agency for state-sponsored terrorism known as the External Security Organization.
According to a white paper by the American State Department, the Libyan Government also financed, planned or committed dozens of other acts of terrorism against citizens of the United States and other Western nations in the 1980's.
Representatives of the Libyan Government, including the brother-in-law of Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, have been charged by French courts with blowing up a French UTA jet over Niger in 1989, killing all 171 on board, including six Americans and the wife of the United States Ambassador to Chad.
The investigation of Pan Am 103, the sanctions by the United Nations and United States, and the implicit threat of American military retribution have no doubt prevented and deterred many other terrorist attacks over the past decade. However, the United States must do more to really end the threat of state-sponsored terrorism. It must continue its criminal investigations of Pan Am 103 and other cases of terrorism to obtain the evidence needed to indict any higher-level Libyan officials responsible. Should any new evidence against other suspects come out in the trial in the Netherlands, we should pursue these leads to their fullest.
America has the world's best intelligence agencies, along with witness protection programs and many new Federal Bureau of Investigation field offices in foreign countries. All of these resources can be used to shed more light on the Pan Am 103 case as well as other major terrorist cases.
In addition, the families of Pan Am victims have 150 civil cases now pending in the American court system against Libya, its airline and its agents. If these cases succeed in getting punitive damages, it would not only punish those responsible for the bombing, but may help deter other such acts in the future. Mr. Qaddafi and his henchmen would like immunity from American criminal and civil courts, as well as from international tribunals. They must not get it.
The courts must go wherever the evidence leads. No person or government should be able to get away with mass murder merely by giving up the lowest-level players, paying minimal compensation and allowing the passage of time and economic pressure to absolve them of responsibility.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Council Plan on Arts Alters Routine Budget Battle

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
It is one of the most predictable sequences in the annual budget theatrics at City Hall: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani slashes funding for museums and other cultural institutions, and the City Council rushes to restore the lost money.
But the Council wants to change the routine, and it has proposed a plan this year that has sent cultural groups into conniptions. For the first time in recent memory, its members have vowed not to restore the $17.9 million in cuts to the Department of Cultural Affairs that Mr. Giuliani tucked into his preliminary budget. Council members said they are tired of using a precious bargaining chip to win back funds for groups they describe as unappreciative. 
 Not only that, but Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone wants to overhaul the way that the city funds cultural institutions, using revenues from the hotel tax to create a pool of money that would be split between arts programs and -- here is the rub -- stadium construction. Mr. Vallone would replace the Department of Cultural Affairs with a commission appointed by the Mayor and the Council, whose members would divide the annual hotel tax revenues between arts and sports.
Mr. Vallone insists the plan would benefit cultural institutions by providing them with a reliable source of funding that would be protected from the Mayor's budget knife. But at a time when Mr. Giuliani has proposed building a sports complex on the West Side of Manhattan and several smaller stadiums around the city, arts groups fear they would get only a tiny portion of the revenues.
"With all the stadium fever that is going on right now, I am very afraid the arts will get shortchanged," said Kathy Giaimo, administrative director of the Thalia Spanish Theater in Queens, which gets about 10 percent of its $429,000 annual budget from the city. "We shouldn't be lumped together with sports, because we are two very different things."
But Council leaders said such fears were unwarranted, because the arts would receive at least half of the annual hotel tax revenues. Their proposal, which Mr. Giuliani will consider before presenting his final budget plan later this month, would devote $150 million in hotel tax revenues to stadium construction and the arts in the 2001 fiscal year. The amount would increase to $200 million in 2002, and by 2003, all hotel tax revenues -- about $230 million a year -- would be divided between sports and the arts.
Even if the city built a stadium on the West Side for $1 billion, Council leaders said, the debt service would cost only about $90 million a year, leaving the bulk of hotel tax revenues for the arts.
"We would structure it to insure that it's an enhancement for cultural affairs and never a cutback," Mr. Vallone said. "It will no longer be discretionary on the part of any mayor whether we pay for our cultural institutions."
While Council leaders are couching the proposal as a means of protecting dozens of museums, theaters and dance groups, its other purpose -- giving the Council more control over future stadium construction -- is more politically significant. Mr. Giuliani's proposal last year to build the Yankees a new stadium in Manhattan using tax dollars infuriated Mr. Vallone, who tried to stop the plan with a referendum.
Although the Giuliani administration ultimately blocked the referendum in court, it won widespread praise for Mr. Vallone, who vowed that the Council would have a voice in any future stadium planning.
With his proposal, Mr. Vallone is trying to thwart Mr. Giuliani's own plan for stadium construction, which would use $900 million in revenues from the commercial rent tax over the next four years. Mr. Vallone has called for eliminating that tax.
"The Council recognizes the need to support professional sports teams," said Thomas L. McMahon, the Council's finance director. "But we believe the amount of dedicated revenue should be more modest and should also address the needs of the arts community, one of our largest economic engines."
Arts advocates said the plan seemed well-intentioned, but predicted that the Mayor and the Council would still use cultural institutions as political pawns in budget battles -- this time, over how much to spend on stadium construction. While they praised the Speaker for trying to find a steady source of funds for the arts, they bristled at the thought of being linked with sports.
"We have entirely different missions," said Andrew Ackerman, executive director of the Children's Museum of Manhattan, whose $3 million annual budget includes about $200,000 in city funds. "Getting rid of the Department of Cultural Affairs and tying us with sports would dilute the uniqueness of what cultural organizations bring to the city."
Others said they were even more vexed by the Council's plan to not restore the funds that Mr. Giuliani intends to cut from the $102.4 million cultural affairs budget this year. The Mayor has proposed a 13 percent reduction in city funds for large cultural institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and a 65 percent reduction for smaller arts groups, like the Thalia Spanish Theater. Those groups, many of which are outside Manhattan, tend to rely more heavily on private donations than city funds, so most would not be devastated by the cuts.
But neighborhood theater groups might have to reduce the number of plays they produce, small galleries could be forced to reduce their staffs and dance groups might have to cut back the performances they do in public schools, arts advocates said.
"I can understand the Council's frustration with the Mayor about funding us, but I don't think this is the way to go," said Ms. Giaimo of the Thalia Spanish Theater. "It's putting a lot at stake."

HEADLINE: Niger Leader Assassinated, Apparently By His Guards

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: NIAMEY, Niger, April 9

 BODY:
President Ibrahim Bare Mainassara was killed today, the Government announced. Police officials and witnesses said Mr. Mainassara had been ambushed at Niamey airport by dissident soldiers.
In Washington, the State Department said Mr. Mainassara had been assassinated by members of the presidential guard but did not disclose the source of the information. 
 In a broadcast on state radio, Prime Minister Ibrahim Assane Mayaki said only that Mr. Mainassara had been killed in an "unfortunate accident." He went on to announce the dissolution of Parliament and the suspension of political activity.
Although Mr. Mayaki said the present administration would continue in office until a national unity government took over, it was unclear who was really in charge. Troops were guarding the presidential palace, the airport and top ministries.
Witnesses and police officials at the airport said the ambush took place as Mr. Mainassara was preparing to travel to the interior. Some members of the President's security staff were critically wounded in the attack, they said.
Earlier today, troops with tanks moved into the streets, blocking access to the presidential palace and other important locations.
It was unclear if the assassination was part of an attempted coup, and, if so, what had happened to the perpetrators.
Mr. Mainassara, 49, a former army chief, ended Niger's first attempt at multiparty democracy with a coup in January 1996 that toppled an elected Government. Since winning a disputed presidential election in July of that year, he had faced relentless pressure from an opposition spearheaded largely by leaders of the civilian Government he overthrew.
Friday's events came after a week of mounting political tension over local elections in February. On Thursday, the opposition called for President Mainassara's resignation following a Supreme Court order for a recount in most districts.
Niger, a poor, largely arid nation in West Africa that gained independence from France in 1960, experienced decades of single-party civilian or military rule, before moving toward true multiparty politics in 1990.
In 1993, Mahamane Ousmane became Niger's first democratically elected President in elections that were hailed then as a rare example of a peaceful transition to democracy in Africa.
The country enjoyed a minor economic boom based on uranium production in the 1970's but drought and a slump in world uranium prices in the 1980's took their toll.

HEADLINE: Shipyard Strikers Demand 'Justice'

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., April 9

 BODY:
As Marvin Lowrie, a 52-year-old machinist, walked the picket line outside the giant shipyard here, there was pride laced with bitterness when he talked, pride that his shipyard produces the world's most sophisticated nuclear aircraft carriers.
But Mr. Lowrie, who constructs intricate piping systems for the carriers, voiced unmistakable bitterness that after 27 years on the job making ships essential to the nation's defense, he was still earning less than $30,000 a year. 
 Seething about what they called stingy wages and pensions, Mr. Lowrie and more than 8,000 other workers at Newport News Shipbuilding went on strike after their contract expired on Monday in one of the largest walkouts this decade.
"The people here are world-class shipbuilders, yet they get paid peanuts," Mr. Lowrie said.
To Mr. Lowrie, the dispute is not about whether workers get a 14 percent raise or a 22 percent raise, but about economic justice, about whether workers share in the fruits of economic prosperity. The strikers, members of the United Steelworkers of America, demand that the shipyard reward them after they helped nurse it back to financial health by agreeing to a 50-month wage freeze in their last contract. After losing money in 1997, the company earned $66 million in 1998 -- not enough, company officials say, to award the large raises sought by the union.
"Now that the company has had a big turnaround and has a tremendous backlog of work, we want to get our fair share of the pie," Mr. Lowrie said, adding that his annual pay was proving to be a particular hardship now that it cost $9,800 a year to send his 21-year-old son to college.
Unlike many other strikes in their early days, this one does not appear to be shadowboxing. Both sides are digging in, with neither asking the other to return to the bargaining table for fear that it would look as if it blinked first. The shipyard insists it has made its final offer, while the union, steel workers Local 8888, has begun determining who among its strikers will need the most financial assistance to endure a long walkout.
"We realize there is every chance that this could be a lengthy strike," said Alfred Little Jr., the shipyard's vice president of human resources. "I think it could be months, but I hope not."
For now, the workers are in a festive mood, excited by a sense of solidarity while not yet feeling squeezed by weeks without paychecks.
"We're in the honeymoon phase," said Jan Hooks, a crane operator for 23 years whose big complaint is that when she retires in five years her pension will be about $400 a month, not enough to cover her rent.
Today, in groups of 5, 20 and 50, the workers picketed in front of 10 gates at a shipyard that stretches for two-and-a-half miles along the water. Beyond the gates were gigantic, 1,100-foot-long, 90,000-ton aircraft carriers under construction or undergoing nuclear refueling.
In front of company headquarters, an austere brick building, 20 strikers, watched by nine police officers, sang variations of a labor anthem with verses that included, "We build first-class ships. We shall not be moved," and "We want a contract. We shall not be moved."
Shipyard officials insist they have made a generous offer that will increase pensions by at least 10 percent and raise wages by 18 percent over 47 months for most workers.
"This new offer essentially makes our top-rated mechanics the highest paid in the industry when you take into account regional differences in the cost of living," said Jerri Fuller Dickseski, the shipyard's spokeswoman.
The two sides in strikes often see differing realities, and that is certainly the case here.
"Their offer is insulting," said Randolph Deloatch, a stocky 46-year-old who installs and removes nuclear fuel from the carriers.
While company officials hail their proposed 18-percent increase as generous for four years, union members called it ridiculous, saying it would translate into 18 percent over 10 years -- or less than 2 percent a year -- since the workers have not received an across-the-board raise since December 1993.
Dave Meredith, 37, another nuclear fueling worker, noted that one full-time colleague in his highly skilled department earned so little that he qualified for a welfare program to help feed his children. Mr. Meredith also criticized the shipyard for paying him only $12.59 an hour, even though his job is dangerous and demanding, while workers at a nearby Anheuser-Busch brewery earn more than $20 an hour.
"I'm glad for them, but I'm not sure what they do is as important for the national interest," he said. "There's real suffering going on here. It's tearing families apart. A lot of this is being precipitated by a lack of money."
As for the proposed pension increase of more than 10 percent, Arnold Outlaw, Local 8888's president, termed it paltry, saying it would be an increase from a small base -- most recent retirees receive less than $500 each month.
"The way things are, retirees can't even afford to bury themselves after they die," Mr. Outlaw said.
Mr. Little, the vice president, said management's overall pay proposal was the most generous made by any shipyard in years. He also said that the improvements in wages and pensions would make the shipyard the second-best-paying in the nation, behind only Electric Boat in Groton, Conn., where the cost of living is significantly higher.
Mr. Little warned that it would be unwise for the union to push for too steep a raise. The union's proposals amounted to a 35 percent increase, he said, and might push the shipyard into the red and persuade the Pentagon to turn to lower-cost suppliers. He also said the union was wrong to think the shipyard was highly profitable.
"We're on our way to doing better," Mr. Little said, "but there's certainly room to do better than this.
"We're always under a tremendous amount of pressure from the Navy to reduce costs. If we're to continue to get more work in the years, we have to make sure our cost structure doesn't get out of whack. If that happens, we all suffer."
Mr. Outlaw, the union president, said one reason for the strike was that far more shipyard workers belonged to the union than was the case two years ago -- more than 80 percent of the 9,200 hourly workers have joined, up from about 50 percent in 1997.
Workers at unionized companies in Virginia are not required to join the union or pay dues. In theory, the more workers belonging to the union, the fewer will cross the picket line, enabling the union to put more pressure on the company. Pointing out that the colossal cranes at the shipyard were dead still, Mr. Outlaw said the company had largely been shut down, helped by the teamsters' decision to honor the picket line.
Mr. Little voiced optimism that the shipyard could endure a long strike.
"The work is going to continue," he said, "but at a much lower level. It will grow as time goes on."
But William Rollins, a striking mechanic, said, "They're looking to break us and have us run back into the yard. But there's so much unity this year. We have the heart of the shipyard out in the streets. Without the heart, they have nothing to run the yard with."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: IN RUSSIA;
'Don't Push Us,' Yeltsin Warns West On Balkans

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, April 9

 BODY:
No, President Boris N. Yeltsin did not order Russian nuclear missiles to be targeted at NATO countries taking part in the bombing of Yugoslavia. Nor did he formally endorse the joining together of Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia in a geographically awkward Slavic union.
But at a meeting today with Gennadi Seleznyov, the Communist who is the Speaker of the Russian Parliament's lower house, he unmistakably warned the West not to push Russia into another war in the Balkans. 
 "I told NATO, the Americans, the Germans, don't push us toward military action," he said, speaking before television cameras. "Otherwise there will be a European war for sure, and possibly a world war. We are against this."
It took the Kremlin the better part of the day today to clarify exactly what Mr. Yeltsin said and did not say in his Seleznyov meeting. As he emerged from the session with Mr. Yeltsin this morning, the Speaker sent out the alarming report that Russia would be targeting NATO states with nuclear warheads, touching off an intense flurry of diplomatic activity in Western capitals.
By midafternoon top Russian officials were issuing denials. "As far as we know in the Foreign Ministry, no orders concerning missiles have been issued." said Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov.
Mr. Seleznyov also appears to have overstated the President's support for a union among Russia, Belarus and Yugoslavia, an idea pushed by the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, as a way of shoring up Moscow's support for Belgrade. According to remarks televised tonight, Mr. Yeltsin told Mr. Seleznyov that the proposal should be studied.
A union between Russian and Belarus is already under negotiation, but as the proposal now stands, its main purpose is to standardize economic relations between the two countries, without any provision for military or security agreements.
As the Kremlin spokesman, Dmitri Yakushkin, noted, including Yugoslavia in such a union would involve several "extremely complicated and delicate" questions that would take months to resolve.
Mr. Yeltsin has repeatedly pledged to keep Russia out of any military involvement in Yugoslavia, a promise that the United States and its allies said today had been reaffirmed through diplomatic contacts. But Russia's harsh denunciations of the NATO campaign against Yugoslavia, and vague threats to adjust its military doctrine, have raised enough concern to prompt a meeting next week in Oslo between Mr. Ivanov and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright.
In other remarks today, Mr. Yeltsin set down further markers on future NATO policy in the Balkans. "They want to use ground troops, take over Yugoslavia, make it their protectorate," he said. "We cannot allow this. Russia and the access to the Mediterranean Sea are nearby, so we can by no means give Yugoslavia away."
Russia last week sent a reconnaissance ship from its Black Sea fleet towards the Adriatic Sea to monitor NATO's activities off the coast of Yugoslavia. The Turkish Foreign Ministry said Russia had notified Turkey that as many as eight more ships might pass through the Bosporus, with sailing dates staggered between April 12 and 16. But so far, Moscow has not announced a decision to send any of those vessels.
The Yeltsin administration, with its tough cold-war-style oratory, has so far managed to stay abreast of the wave of anti-American feeling that has swept Russia. But as the NATO bombing continues, limiting Russia's opposition to just words may prove increasingly difficult.
By a vote of 279 to 30, the Communist-led lower house of Parliament demanded last Wednesday that the Government send military aid and advisers to Yugoslavia, in violation of United Nations sanctions against Belgrade.
The war in Yugoslavia has added new tensions to Russia's already overheated domestic political struggle. Mr. Yeltsin's Communist opponents, emboldened by the anti-Western mood, have been pressing an impeachment vote against the President, now scheduled for debate on Thursday.
The political atmosphere has been further sullied by an unresolved clash over the future of Russia's chief prosecutor, Yuri I. Skuratov. His dismissal by Mr. Yeltsin, for a second time, has opened up a Pandora's box of charges and countercharges of corruption and misconduct that have threatened to taint members of the President's inner circle.
In a week marked by alarmist reports that the Kremlin is setting the stage for a dramatic showdown with Parliament, Mr. Yeltsin today said publicly that he had no plans to dismiss Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov or to ban the Communist Party.
Nor, he told a meeting of governors, will he support any plans -- like one proposed recently by Mr. Primakov -- to eliminate the direct elections of Russia's regional leaders.
But Mr. Yeltsin gave only lukewarm support to Mr. Primakov and dropped strong hints that a Cabinet shuffle might be in the works. "At this stage, Yevgeny Primakov is useful to us," he told the governors. "Later we will see. On the other hand, the Cabinet does need reinforcement."
Several prominent members of the Communist Party are ministers in the Primakov Government, and in a recent interview, the Prime Minister confirmed reports that he had given his Communist allies a pledge that he would resign before agreeing to dismiss any of their top ministers.
The former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who met this week with Mr. Yeltsin, said in an interview published in Izvestia that he would support changes in the Cabinet. "I wonder why reaction to all this has become so painful," he said. "I changed three Cabinets, and no one reacted so painfully to that."

HEADLINE: U.S. Tells Albany to Aid Failing Hospitals

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
In a strongly worded letter, a Federal agency has warned the Pataki administration that many of the state's most financially troubled hospitals will go bankrupt or default on their loans unless the state does more to help them.
The letter from the Department of Housing and Urban Development calls on the Pataki administration to expand the use of a state-controlled fund that can be tapped to aid struggling hospitals. The letter was sent on Wednesday to Gail H. Gordon, chairwoman of the State Dormitory Authority, which administers the hospital fund. 
 The letter also accused state officials of generally dragging their feet in assisting troubled hospitals, and cautioned that more hospitals will be in danger of failing if the state does not act faster and more forcefully.
"By dragging things out, it is making the situation worse," William C. Apgar, Assistant Secretary for Housing and author of the letter, said in an interview today. The Housing Department issued the letter because it insures state bonds that finance hospital construction and repairs.
Claudia Hutton, a spokeswoman for the State Dormitory Authority, said Mr. Apgar's letter was "riddled with errors" and accused him of playing politics. She said the state had been monitoring its financially troubled hospitals and did not expect that any of them would default on their loans.
Gov. George E. Pataki is a Republican, while the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, Andrew Cuomo, is a Democrat. In 1994, Mr. Pataki unseated Mr. Cuomo's father, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
Housing Department officials denied that there was any political motive behind their letter, which comes during a fierce dispute between the Pataki administration and hospital executives over the economic well-being of the industry.
Hospital officials contend that cuts in government aid, an increase in the number of uninsured patients and the expansion of managed care have hurt many hospitals. Some have cut budgets and laid off workers while others are in danger of closing, the officials have warned.
Both Governor Pataki and the Clinton Administration have recently proposed additional reductions in government-financed health care programs.
The Pataki administration contends that the hospitals are generally in sound financial shape and should be able to handle new reductions. In January, the state's Health Department released a report, based on 1997 data, showing that hospitals had a 42 percent increase in net profits over the previous year.
Part of that increase appears to result from a change in accounting rules that made hospital revenues look larger than they were.
The head of a major hospital trade association asserted today that the Housing Department's letter showed that the Federal Government agrees with industry officials that many hospitals are in dire financial condition.
"There's a ton of cash that needs to be pumped into these places, and nobody has it," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association. "The Pataki administration is not recognizing that they are sitting on a time bomb."
The hospital industry has joined forces with unions representing health care workers to lobby legislators in Albany to oppose Mr. Pataki's proposed cuts in Medicaid, the government health care program for the poor.
The industry is also pushing in Washington for greater Federal spending on Medicare, the government health care program for the elderly and the disabled.
Mr. Apgar said that the state had fallen $325,000 short of a pledge to provide $800,000 to help struggling Lockport Hospital, near Buffalo, repay federally backed loans.
Ms. Hutton said the state planned to send the final installment of money to the hospital once it developed a plan for getting out of debt.
Mr. Apgar also said that the state had lagged in assisting two other struggling hospitals, Flushing Hospital Medical Center in Queens and Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He said the state should be using a special pool of money more aggressively to help those hospitals pay their debt service. The restructuring pool, as it is known, is financed through hospital taxes and is intended to help hospitals become more competitive.
Mr. Apgar also asserted that several other hospitals, including Union Hospital of the Bronx and Victory Memorial Hospital in Brooklyn were financially ailing and may need state assistance to avoid bankruptcy.
"If the Lockport experience is a portent of the future, there's trouble brewing," Mr. Apgar said in the interview.
But Ms. Hutton said there was too little money in the fund to start helping every ailing hospital pay back its debt service. She said it was up to the Legislature to provide more money to do that.
"HUD is trying to insert itself into New York policy making," she said. "It's just plain wrong."

HEADLINE: Rally to Promote Port Leases Widens Gap Between States

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In a sign of the escalating tensions between the governors of New York and New Jersey, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman plans to go to the World Trade Center on Monday for a union rally intended to push the two states to stop squabbling and sign leases with two of the largest shipping lines in New York Harbor.
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York plans to be in Albany, his spokesman said. 
 The battling between the governors has brought to a standstill the protracted negotiations between the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the two companies, Sea-Land Service and Maersk Line, which together account for billions of dollars of cargo business in New York Harbor, 1,000 jobs and a payroll of $100 million. The matter has taken on increasing urgency because Sea-Land and Maersk have given the Port Authority until 5 P.M. Tuesday to deliver its long-promised final lease offer.
If the deadline is not met, many officials in New Jersey and New York, maritime executives and the longshoremen's union fear that Sea-Land and Maersk will make good on their threat to move to Baltimore, which continues to sweeten its offer to build a new hub terminal for the two companies. Sea-Land's lease at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal in New Jersey expired in February, and Maersk's leases expire over the next 14 months.
"My people are very frightened by what's going on," said John Bowers, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, which called for the rally. "I invited Governors Whitman and Pataki to meet my membership and explain to them why their jobs and livelihoods are being used as a bargaining chip in the negotiations between the states."
The terms of the leases with the shipping companies have become ensnared in a heated debate over the distribution of projects and revenues by the Port Authority. The Whitman administration has been eager to finish negotiations with the shipping lines, but Governor Pataki and his chief negotiator, Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority, see the lease negotiations as their best opportunity to gain what they contend would be a more equitable distribution of agency resources.
Assemblywoman Joan L. Millman, whose district includes parts of Brooklyn and Staten Island, said that although she shares some of the Pataki administration's concerns about the Port Authority, she felt the departure of Sea-Land and Maersk could prompt other maritime businesses to leave New York Harbor.
"This could be a really big blow to us," Ms. Millman said. "If these two giants leave, is anyone else going to stay?"
Not only is Governor Pataki not planning to attend the rally, his administration had also tried to persuade the union to abandon its plans, one state official said.
"The Governor's in Albany on Monday," said Mr. Pataki's spokesman, Michael McKeon. "We're ready to negotiate, but we also want to protect our interests. The place to get that done is at the table."
New Jersey officials have said that the Pataki administration has failed to recognize the importance of the port, a $20-billion-a-year maritime industry. The 166,500 jobs in the port are about evenly split between New York and New Jersey.
"It's unfortunate if he chooses not to go to the rally," said Joan Verplanck, president of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce. "It's the mark of a coward. It's pretty easy to hide in Albany."
It does not appear that either side is willing to give in. Mr. Gargano met briefly yesterday with Louis Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority, who is Governor Whitman's principal negotiator. According to officials from both states, New York has demanded that New Jersey agree to restructure the Port Authority, separating New York airports and other sites from those in New Jersey, while leaving the Interstate bridges and tunnels under the agency's control.
Mr. Gargano has also demanded that the agency set up a $400 million "balancing bank" for New York projects, to offset investments in the Elizabeth Marine Terminal. The Whitman administration has agreed to $250 million.
"There are still fairly significant differences," said one official from New Jersey who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Whitman said she won't agree to their ultimatum on restructuring as a way to getting the Sea-Land-Maersk deal done."
Although no meetings were scheduled, officials in both states expected negotiations to continue this weekend.
According to the Port Authority, the agency has invested $5.05 billion in capital projects in New York over the last 15 years, compared with $4.8 billion in New Jersey. New York, however, contends that revenues from projects are used to offset nearly $250 million in operating subsidies for the PATH trains and the Port Authority Bus Terminal, both of which the Pataki administration contends should be New Jersey's responsibility.
It is far from certain that these wide-ranging issues can be resolved in time to provide Sea-Land and Maersk with the terms for new leases. The dispute has come to a head as the Port Authority is predicting that port business could triple over the next 20 years.
It is further complicated by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's disputes with both Governor Pataki and the Port Authority.
"You've got three different poles on this, which is making everything worse," said Elliott Sclar, professor of urban planning and economics at Columbia University. "The political wrangling between these three ambitious Republican politicians obscures the facts. The container port is in New Jersey. On the other hand, the entire port is vital to New York and the region's status as a distribution center for the global economy."

HEADLINE: Police Officers Get 250 More Reasons to Live in the City

BYLINE: By JODI WILGOREN 

 BODY:
Hoping to persuade more New York police officers to live in the city, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development plans to offer about 250 houses at half price to law enforcement personnel who agree to live in them for at least three years, Federal officials announced yesterday.
The houses, which the Government acquires through foreclosure on HUD-financed mortgages, are scattered in 54 so-called distressed neighborhoods in all five boroughs, from University Heights in the Bronx to Stapleton on Staten Island. Police officers will also be eligible for a 20 percent discount -- up to $2,000 -- on a HUD-insured mortgage or home improvement loan on the properties. 
 "This is not an abstract concept, this is not a theoretical or rhetorical plan, this is a real initiative that will make an impact on the ground," the Housing and Urban Development Secretary, Andrew M. Cuomo, said at a news conference in lower Manhattan yesterday morning. "This is a win-win, a real incentive package to bring police officers into the communities that really need them."
The initiative comes amid renewed focus on the question of whether police officers should be required to live in the city where they work in the aftermath of the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo two months ago. Two of the four officers who were indicted on charges of second-degree murder for killing Mr. Diallo in a hail of 41 bullets live in the city, and two live on Long Island. A residency requirement, or an incentive program like HUD's, has been a central demand of those outraged over the shooting.
Overall, 54 percent of New York Police Department officers live in the five boroughs, down from 60 percent a decade ago. A residency requirement would require a change in state law, which is considered a political impossibility, but Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir announced recently that they would try to persuade officers to live in the city with offers of financial and other bonuses.
The Federal plan announced yesterday is an expansion of the two-year-old Officer Next Door program, in which police officers nationwide can buy HUD properties for half their market value. So far, New York has been just a bit player in the Federal program, with about 70 houses bought by city officers. Nationwide, 2,700 police officers have bought HUD houses under the program, which the department promotes as a way to stabilize troubled neighborhoods. In New York, the program is available to members of all law enforcement agencies except for corrections officers.
Officer Nefer Simon, who has been on the New York force for nearly seven years, paid $60,000 for a HUD house in South Ozone Park, Queens, on Feb. 4 and plans to move in by month's end. Officer Simon, who does background investigations on recruits, grew up in Brooklyn and will be leaving her co-op in the Clinton Hill section of that borough. She said it was the price that lured her.
"My rent was up so high, I was like, 'Oh, my goodness.' When this came up, I was like, 'Wow, I'll be paying cheaper in mortgage than I am in rent,' so I jumped on this idea," said Officer Simon, 28, who is married with two children. "It was a good deal, basically to get a house practically with no money down."
Organizers of the program, and community groups that support it, say police officers can help stabilize troubled neighborhoods by living in them, because the officers serve as role models for children and add security. City residency also helps officers understand the communities they work in, experts say.
With her kitchen and bathroom being remodeled, Officer Simon and her aunt have already begun to plant a flower garden in the small front yard of the three-bedroom Colonial. She said she had met her neighbors but had not yet mentioned that she was a police officer.
"They were just pleased to have someone move onto the block instead of an abandoned building," Officer Simon explained. "It doesn't seem like a bad neighborhood."
She remains unsure, however, about what her role as an "Officer Next Door" will be. "When you get into a lot of off-duty incidents, the job might not indemnify you, so you're taking a chance," she said. "But if I see something happening in front of me, I don't think I could just stand there and watch."
It has been difficult to lure officers into the program in New York in part because the available houses have so far been in high-crime neighborhoods, officials said. A similar program that gives New York officers free apartments in public housing projects has attracted just 46 people.
But the expansion of the program means that officers will be able to buy houses in the Clinton Hill, Crown Heights and Red Hook sections of Brooklyn; in St. Albans and Jamaica, Queens, and in Harlem, Washington Heights and the Lower East Side in Manhattan.
Marilyn Mode, Mr. Safir's spokeswoman, called the expansion a "great idea" that "certainly parallels what we've been talking about."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: WARY TRAVELERS;
More Americans Canceling Or Delaying European Trips

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
The Balkans conflict and refugee crisis have started to hurt leisure and business travel well beyond the combat zone, with increasing numbers of Americans scrapping or delaying plans to visit Europe during what ordinarily would be one of the best times to go.
Travel agents and tour operators say they have received cancellations not only to Central and Eastern Europe, which is much closer to the conflict, but also to popular destinations like Italy and Greece and as far as Russia and Turkey. 
 Sobered by television coverage of the nightly NATO bombings in Serbia, the misery of Kosovo refugee families and anti-American demonstrations in countries that support President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, would-be American visitors to Europe are deciding to make other plans.
"I have a sister in Bologna, Italy, and we were thinking of visiting her this summer," said Juan Sabalones, the director of animal husbandry at the Newport Aquarium in Newport, Ky. "But as long as there's a war going on, I've decided to keep an eye on things, and it's possible we may not go at all."
Tour operators say they have already noticed a small but unexpected increase in bookings to the Canadian Rockies, South America, Asia and America's national parks, which they attribute to customers' deciding against traveling to Europe.
Peter Tauck, president of Tauck Tours, a big tour operator with headquarters in Westport, Conn., said that while people were still traveling to popular Italian and Greek vacation spots, "we've had cancellations this week, and the pace of bookings is suddenly relatively flat."
As of yesterday, Mr. Tauck said, there were 42 bookings this week for the company's three tours to Italy this year, compared with about 100 bookings for Italy in a normal week this time of year.
Steve Kang, the president of Maupintour, another big tour company, in Lawrence, Kan., said that he had seen little effect on tours to Turkey and Greece, but that "bookings to Italy are unexpectedly slow."
"The only reason I can think of for that is that people see Aviano on CNN, and they know it's a staging area in Italy," he said. Aviano is the site of a NATO air base used in the bombing campaign.
Many tour operators quickly postponed tours through Yugoslavia when the crisis began building last month and detoured trips when NATO began bombing on March 24. But now they are canceling tours months into the future on the assumption that the conflict will last a long time.
Maupintour canceled two 16-day cruises that were scheduled to go from Bucharest to Vienna, through Belgrade and other points in Yugoslavia, departing May 25 and June 2. Regina Tours, which specializes in Roman Catholic pilgrimages,
canceled its monthly 10-day tours to Medjugorje, Bosnia, through the rest of the year.
Even National Geographic, which specializes in relatively adventurous tours, decided to postpone until this fall a tour to Turkey that had been scheduled from April 26 to May 12, and to cancel its Treasures of Russian Waterway, scheduled from May 28 to June 10. While the Russian tour was canceled because of concern over turmoil in the Balkans, the Turkish tour was postponed over concern with recent bombings in the country attributed to Kurdish militants, National Geographic said.
Yesterday, the Association of Corporate Travel Executives issued a "cautionary travel advisory" warning members about traveling not only to danger zones but also to other European cities. "The P.R. campaign waged by Serbian nationalists," said Earl Foster, president of the 2,500-member association, "has led to some violent street protests in cities far from the battle. We're advising our members to alert their travelers to these related situations, specifically with an eye to avoiding them."
While the recent travel disruptions are not at all as widespread as those surrounding the Persian Gulf war in 1991, the travel industry's big concern is that the Balkans conflict could drag on toward summer.
The concern comes at a time when both the American economy and the warming weather make it a particularly good time to visit Europe. The dollar is strong, American incomes are rising, and many people are spending money.
To be sure, the evidence of a potentially serious slowdown in travel to Europe is largely anecdotal. There are still signs that travel to Europe remains little affected by the Balkans conflict.
United States airlines said yesterday that while there had been some cancellations to central and Eastern Europe, on routes flown by their European partners, there had been few cancellations to Western European cities. "April and May bookings are good," said Tim Smith, a spokesman for American Airlines, "and bookings for the summer indicate those months will be strong."
On Monday, Joseph Buhler, the United States chairman of the European Travel Commission, said its member tourist offices in several countries in the immediate region of the hostilities had reported a slowdown in bookings, with scattered cancellations. But overall, he said, members reported "relatively little adverse impact on travel to Europe as a whole due to the fighting in Yugoslavia."
To forestall cancellations, the cruise industry moved quickly to keep out of harm's way. Three Cunard Line ships and two belonging to Seabourn Cruise Lines -- both companies are owned by Carnival Corporation -- substituted stops at Italian ports on the west coast of the Adriatic for the previously scheduled stops at Dubrovnik and other Croatian ports along the eastern Adriatic. Windstar Cruises has substituted stops in Italy for scheduled stops in Dubrovnik and Rab. Holland America's Maasdam replaced Dubrovnik on three European itineraries with stops in Italy and Greece.
"We've only had 15 or 20 cancellations," said Erik Elvejord, a Holland America spokesman, "but we've had a couple of hundred calls from people concerned about those itineraries." He added that bookings were lagging for the 12-day Venice-to-Venice round-trip cruise, scheduled to depart April 19.
Industry officials say the reason the current fighting has not depressed travel as much as during the gulf war, when bookings on United States airlines decreased 44 percent on trans-Atlantic routes in 1991, is that there is little fear of terrorism in connection with the Balkans conflict.
But most travel officials believe that a Balkans-inspired terrorist incident in the West would set off a wave of airline cancellations.
"If this turmoil and the demonstrations continue for a long time, Americans are going to be afraid to go anywhere in Europe," said Predrag Krivokapic, whose Kompas Holiday International agency in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., specializes in travel to Central and Eastern Europe.
Other travel officials agree. "Especially if it's on TV on a daily basis," said Tom Souza, executive vice president of Collette Tours in Pawtucket, R.I.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 2; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1457 words

HEADLINE: How U.S. and China Failed to Close Trade Deal

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9

 BODY:
On a bitterly cold day in Beijing in early January, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, was given a startling message by Zhu Rongji, the Chinese Prime Minister who was remaking the country's economy.
Despite China's economic slowdown, Mr. Zhu said, he decided that China was finally ready to offer huge openings of its markets -- in telecommunications, banking, insurance and agriculture -- in return for getting the country into the World Trade Organization. 
 He offered some tantalizing details, apparently hoping that Mr. Greenspan -- whose domain has nothing to do with trade -- would make sure that the right people in Washington got the message.
They did, and in the next three months the two sides made enormous progress, resolving 95 percent of the issues that had divided them for years.
But in the end President Clinton, the man who has repeatedly made commercial diplomacy the centerpiece of his foreign policy, backed away. Distracted by Kosovo, he did not give clear instructions to his trade negotiators until very late in the talks about how much he wanted an agreement now, officials familiar with the negotiations said.
Nor did he make a strong public case until the morning of Mr. Zhu's arrival for what would have been the biggest economic deal in Chinese-American relations.
Some of his top foreign policy aides, led by the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, hoped for an agreement that would bolster Mr. Zhu, whom they see as China's leading force for openness and reform. At a meeting last Saturday, some State Department and trade officials argued that China had moved as far as it could and the President should take the deal on the table.
But one official said there had been "a sense it won't quite do it" with a Congress that is increasingly suspicious of China's intentions. Others expressed fears that any deal involving China would further divide Democrats, enrage labor unions and end up in a huge battle on Capitol Hill that the President would most likely lose.
Moreover, some argued that the Congressional battle would create a rallying cry for Republicans seeking an outlet to debate charges that China has stolen nuclear secrets and surreptitiously donated to Democratic coffers.
In a major speech about China delivered the morning before his meeting with Mr. Zhu, the President declared that "if China is willing to play by the global rules of trade, it would be an inexplicable mistake for the United States to say no."
Many of Mr. Clinton's closest aides took that as a sign that the debate was over, that the deal was done. They proved wrong.
It is too early to tell what the long-term impact of the failure to reach a deal on Thursday may be. Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who appeared in no particular hurry about striking an agreement of this scope, insisted today that in the coming months a deal "is certainly doable." The United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, insists that "we still want a deal, Zhu wants a deal and I'm sure it will happen."
But without question, momentum has been lost. A fear now is that once Mr. Zhu gets back to Beijing, the deal could unravel. Trade negotiations are like a carefully staged opera, one that can come to a rousing conclusion only after the most careful stagecraft. In this case the singers were playing to very different audiences, and the last act never came off.
Mr. Clinton did not press Mr. Zhu for additional concessions at their meeting on Wednesday night, aides said. And some American officials say they believe that Mr. Zhu was worried that he already had given too much.
If he agreed to strict provisions that would give the United States unilateral rights to retaliate against import surges and would offer more protection to the American textile workers by extending for years strict quotas on the volume of textiles that China can send to the United States, he would be subject to enormous criticism from other Chinese officials.
"I've never seen the President back away like this," one veteran of trade negotiations said today. "We're all still scratching our heads."
By some measures this could be a prime example of how one of America's most critical diplomatic initiatives fell victim to the distractions of a war in the Balkans.
Mr. Clinton has long argued that Chinese membership in the trade organization is not about economics, it is about global integration. It would get China into a legal framework, forcing it to work under Western-style trade laws. It would create huge market openings that, in time, could expose more Chinese to foreign ideas.
And by spreading cell phones and Internet nodes in China, the West would help create more outlets for political expression -- outlets the Chinese Government finds it increasingly difficult to control.
So when Mr. Greenspan returned to Washington in January with his message, Ms. Barshefsky leaped at the opening. She sent her top China negotiator, Robert Cassidy, to Beijing for what turned into weeks of negotiations. In the first week of March she went to Beijing herself, and spent two and half hours with Mr. Zhu.
"For the first hour I talked nonstop," she said. "And it was clear that great progress was being made."
For the first time the Chinese were talking about sweeping away many of the barriers that had long stymied American farmers: limits on agricultural imports, and requirements that goods be distributed only through state-owned companies. There was talk about letting American companies invest in the telecommunications industry for the first time.
"It came in dribs and drabs," said a person involved in the negotiations. "We would push, and we were often surprised that the Chinese came back and said, 'We can do it.' "
Clearly the Zhu visit here was the deadline, and everyone knew it. But in the interim a lot had changed in Washington.
Suspicions that China had obtained the design of the W-88 warhead, the most miniaturized in the American nuclear arsenal, created a new atmosphere on Capitol Hill, and the White House found itself under attack.
Meanwhile, at the negotiating table, the Chinese kept giving. "My overall sense is that the Chinese conceded more than I thought would be politically possible," said Nicholas Lardy, an expert on the Chinese economy at the Brookings Institution. "You have to remember that unemployment is at a 30-year high in China, corporate profits are falling off a cliff, and here is Zhu arguing that this is a moment to actually allow the foreigners to offer more domestic competition."
Mr. Berger argued that this was a moment to support Mr. Zhu, making him the man who brought China the prestige of entering the global trading system. Mr. Clinton seemed to agree, and his speech on Wednesday was filled with a discussion of America's interests in both an economically stronger and more secure China.
But inside the White House there was less talk about the dangers of a weak China than the dangers of an agreement that labor unions, liberal Democrats or powerful senators from textile-producing states -- like Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, and Ernest Hollings, South Carolina Democrat -- could use to rally opposition.
And there were other unhappy interest groups with a strong connection to the White House. China insisted on limits on the import of Western films, meaning that Hollywood might seek to kill the deal.
And the Chinese would not allow American brokerages much access to the rough and ready Chinese markets. That underwhelmed Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, the Administration's most important voice on any economic matter.
The arguments played out in regular meetings in the office of John Podesta, the White House chief of staff, who worried about the damage that would be wrought trying to push the deal through Congress.
"John had visions of Nafta dancing in his head," one participant in the discussions said, referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement, which passed in 1993 only because Mr. Clinton was able to rally Republicans to the cause. This year, few of them were expected to come to the President's rescue.
As the White House debate rolled on, Mr. Clinton was busy with other things. He spoke with Ms. Barshefsky only sporadically; she made a last-minute trip to Beijing last week without a clear sense of what the President wanted. There were few meetings to prepare the President for a major meeting with Mr. Zhu.
"He could barely focus on the summit," said a foreign policy aide.
So by the time Mr. Clinton was deeply involved in the details, it was clear that negotiators had run out of time to complete a deal that might have been acceptable to both China and Congress.

HEADLINE: An American Paradox

 BODY:

To the Editor:
 Bob Herbert's April 8 column on the paradox of dire poverty in America during an unprecedented economic expansion points to a second paradox. In the United States, to talk about "the American economy" and its successes is to perpetuate the assumption that this wealth is a public wealth, a wealth to be shared. It is not. We would like to believe that America is the richest nation on earth, but we are not. We are the nation with the richest individuals on earth.
 
JOHN E. ISOM
Madison, Wis., April 8, 1999

HEADLINE: An American Paradox

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re Bob Herbert's April 8 column: I was intrigued by the concern for the poor, homeless members of society expressed by Andrew M. Cuomo, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. However, one of the reasons that people end up like that is that there is no living wage in this country. 
 Just one minor catastrophe, like a health crisis or unexpected bill, can make someone homeless. A large number of people are paid a wage that does not permit them to save money after paying their bills.
 
ABIGAIL MOUAT
Gainesville, Fla., April 9, 1999

LENGTH: 144 words

HEADLINE: On China, A Failed Strategy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "U.S.-China Talks Fail to Produce Major Trade Deal" (front page, April 9): There is no evidence that trade pressure or the threat of sanctions has ever produced a sustainable improvement in Chinese human rights practices. In fact, the greatest recent period of political openness, in the late 1980's, was marked by highly favorable Chinese-American relations. 
 Senator Paul Wellstone's statement (Op-Ed, April 5) that the United States must insist that China "establish an independent judiciary, a free press and respect for the rule of law" would be more credible if Congress financed the rule-of-law programs President Clinton and President Jiang Zemin of China agreed to pursue last summer.
 
ELIZABETH ECONOMY
New York, April 9, 1999
 
The writer is deputy director of Asia studies at the Council on Foreign Relations.
